webTitle: Bolton 1 - 0 Norwich

fields.headline: Bolton find home comfort
fields.trailText: Dean Holdsworth proved that there is no substitute for experience with a goal that takes Bolton to within one point of second-placed Blackburn in the First Division promotion race.
fields.byline: Mark Ogden at the Reebok stadium
fields.body:
Dean Holdsworth proved that there is no substitute for experience with a goal that takes Bolton to within one point of second-placed Blackburn in the First Division promotion race.

The 32-year-old former Wimbledon forward scored his third in four games to secure Bolton's first league win at home since a 2-0 victory against Tranmere on January 13. A run of six draws and one defeat since that long-forgotten success explains why they are now chasing Blackburn for the remaining automatic promotion spot.

Dropped points against the likes of Gillingham, Crewe, Stockport and Grimsby have left Bolton requiring a slip or two from Blackburn in order to regain second place. One duly came at the weekend when Graeme Souness's team failed to overcome Wolves and another failure at Grimsby tomorrow night will throw Bolton an unlikely lifeline.

For much of this game, though, Wanderers seemed destined to send their supporters home unhappy yet again. Whenever a goalscoring opportunity was created, Bolton were let down by finishing that sent the ball flying inches over the crossbar or narrowly wide of the upright.

Norwich did little to fray the nerves of the home supporters, however. Nigel Worthington's team hardly threatened but for one chance created by Darren Kenton after the Bolton defender Anthony Barness had been caught in possession.

Kenton had a clear run on goal, but instead of forcing a save from Matt Clarke he could only pull his shot wide of of the far post. It was one of those days.

The one flash of inspiration came from Holdsworth and it was enough to win the game for Bolton. The referee Paul Rejer had penalised Norwich's defender Matt Jackson for a foul on Gareth Farrelly and Holdsworth used his nous to take the free-kick while Norwich's 21-year-old goalkeeper Robert Green was busy organising his wall.

There were no complaints from Norwich. "Holdsworth used all of his experience, moved the ball slightly and spotted that the goalkeeper had left a gap at the far post," Worthington said. "My goalkeeper is still on a learning curve, but I could do without him learning his lessons while we are in a relegation fight."

While Norwich must continue to look anxiously at the relegation battle below them, Holdsworth is hopeful of a Grimsby victory tomorrow. "If we win all of our games and Blackburn slip up, who knows, there might be one last shock," he said. "I won't be sat watching Teletext, though."

With Blackburn having to play three of their last four games away from Ewood Park, Bolton's wishes may yet come true.

webTitle: Leicester 0 - 3 Middlesbrough

fields.headline: Boksic brilliance lights Boro's escape route
fields.trailText: Terry Venables will receive the lion's share of the congratulations should Middlesbrough avoid relegation, but his task has been helped by Alen Boksic. On Saturday the Coatian striker produced a moment of sublime genius that has given his side every chance of staying up.
fields.body:
Terry Venables will receive the lion's share of the congratulations should Middlesbrough avoid relegation, but his task has been helped by not having to devote too much time to Alen Boksic.

The Croatian striker is blessed with the sort of talent that cannot be learned through instruction, and on Saturday he produced a moment of sublime genius that has given his side every chance of staying up. He may earn £63,000 a week but if he ensures Boro remain in the Premiership it will be considered well spent.

With Boro clinging to a 1-0 lead, Boksic prised Gerry Taggart off the ball and strode majestically forward. While alert to the possibilities either side of him, he decided to go it alone and in the twinkling of an eye struck a shot from 30 yards which, while essentially a chip, carried enough venom to leave Leicester's goalkeeper Simon Royce grasping at the vapour trails.

The goal knocked the stuffing out of Leicester, who were desperately trying to avoid an eighth successive defeat. Within two minutes Paul Ince had added a third. Game over.

That a side which can utilise Boksic's brilliance could go down seems ridiculous, although Boro did manage relegation with both Juninho and Fabrizio Ravanelli on board - if not on the same wavelength - four years ago. One more win, however, should suffice this time.

Dean Windass, who has added some grit and determination to Boro's efforts since his move from Bradford in March, admitted afterwards that with the squad that has been assembled at the Riverside, the possibility of going down should be the last thing on their minds.

"We've got some quality players in our team and that was typified by Boksic's goal," the midfielder said. "When you've got players like that in your team you've got a great chance."

There is also a depth to Boro's squad that belies their perilous position. Once the game had been put out of Leicester's reach, Venables decided it was time to swap sweat for style. Off came Boksic, Christian Karembeu and Hamilton Ricard to be replaced by Noel Whelan, Robbie Mustoe and Phil Stamp.

While these three hardly amount to an embarrassment of riches, they were more effective than the substitutes Peter Taylor, Leicester's manager, could rustle up.

Since Taylor replaced Martin O'Neill last summer he has spent £16.35m on 14 players, all but four of them from the lower leagues. With injuries to key players, the likes of Lee Marshall, Trevor Benjamin and Junior Lewis have been pressed into service earlier than Taylor would have liked. None have yet indicated they are stars in the making.

Taylor, it seems, is suffering from the curse of being touted as a future England manager, a billing that Bryan Robson, Venables' co-pilot, has been unable to live with. This seventh straight league defeat since they were knocked out of the FA Cup by Wycombe equalled Leicester's worst-ever run.

Taylor was encouraged by a first-half performance in which Damien Delaney hit the bar, and Ade Akinbiyi and Gerry Taggart both put free headers off target. But, as has characterised Leicester's collapse in recent weeks, they were chasing the game from an early stage after a quickly taken corner was finished by Ricard after 12 minutes.

After Boksic's piece of magic doubled Boro's advantage, Ince smashed home a drive from the edge of the area to confirm the win.

Venables stressed afterwards that his side must "keep straight thinking" until safety is guaranteed. Boksic should ensure this is sooner rather than later.

webTitle: Burnley 0 - 0 Birmingham

fields.headline: Blues await the cavalry
fields.trailText: Birmingham's form has dipped since their loss in the Worthington Cup Final. Now a return to the Millennium Stadium for the First Division play-offs is looking increasingly uncertain.
fields.body:
Having reached the Worthington Cup final this season and held their own against Liverpool, a return trip to Cardiff's Millennium stadium for the First Division play-offs next month should hold no fears for Birmingham City. Trevor Francis's biggest problem, however, is coaxing his players back there after 10 games without a win.

Birmingham were challenging Fulham and Blackburn for automatic promotion when they visited the Principality in February. Two months of struggling for points since mean they are now far from certain of claiming even a play-off place.

A win over Grimsby at St Andrews next Saturday, which would be their first since March 10, ought to be enough to do it, but if the Burnley striker Gareth Taylor had put away an injury-time header here to give the play-off possibles victory over the probables, even Francis's faith might now be wavering.

Birmingham were somewhere between six and 12 inches away from defeat, the distance by which Taylor steered the afternoon's best chance wide, and Francis admitted that it was the piece of luck they needed.

"We defended very well until injury-time," said the Birmingham manager. "A draw was far more satisfactory for us because Burnley knew they had to win.

"I think we've steadied the ship now and we've still got players to come back from injury who are going to have a big influence."

Paul Weller's volley brought the best out of Birmingham's goalkeeper Ian Bennett, and the referee Roger Furnandiz did his bit for the Blues by refusing a penalty after Michael Johnson blocked Kevin Ball's second-half header with his hands.

Burnley last played in the top flight 25 years ago and though Stan Ternent has got them close to a return, they will almost certainly have to wait at least another 12 months.

"We won't give up," the manager said. "We could still get 75 points, but this has made it difficult for us."

webTitle: Davids done for drugs

fields.headline: Davids done for drugs
fields.trailText: The Italian League returned to normal this weekend, with the leaders Roma back to winning ways, Serie A leading scorers Andriy Shevchenko and Hernan Crespo getting a goal each, concerns about racist abuse at Lazio and, oh yes, a drugs scandal overshadowing everything.
fields.body:
The Italian League returned to normal this weekend, with the leaders Roma back to winning ways, Serie A leading scorers Andriy Shevchenko and Hernan Crespo getting a goal each, concerns about racist abuse at Lazio and, oh yes, a drugs scandal overshadowing everything.

Edgar Davids has tested positive for nandrolone. Juventus's Dutch international midfielder, who has recently been linked with Manchester United, faces a suspension of up to two years. He denies taking steroids.

Davids is the eighth Serie A player to fail a drugs test this season and the seventh to test positive for nandrolone, the anabolic steroid that has recently been making a number of unwelcome appearances in dope tests, including those of the British athletes Mark Richardson, Dougie Walker and Linford Christie. Some have contended that the positive tests have been the result of taking legitimate dietary supplements.

Earlier this month Fernando Couto, the Lazio defender and captain of Portugal, also tested positive for nandrolone.

Davids was tested after Juve's game against Udinese on March 4. Gazzetta dello Sport reported in its Sunday edition that he had come up "non-negative".

Davids nevertheless played for Juventus on Sunday afternoon - and played well. The Parma fans greeted him with whistles, but he ended the game as man of the match.

"Edgar did not have a great match but a superb one," the Juventus coach Carlo Ancelotti said. "If he needed to he gave a great answer with such a game."

It did Juve little good. The Old Lady huffed and puffed but failed to crack the Parma defence. The French international striker David Trezeguet had two good chances to win the game inside the final 10 minutes but he first shot weakly at Gianluigi Buffon and then opted to pass in the final seconds with a clear sight of goal.

"We showed we are still alive," Ancelotti said. But the gap between his team and Roma is back up to six points with seven games to go after the leaders won 3-1 at Udinese.

Damiano Tommasi helped to scale down the doubts after two disappointing results by helping Roma into a 2-0 half-time lead. His 39th-minute shot was too hot for Luigi Turci to handle and Vincenzo Montella knocked in the rebound for his 15th goal in 19 appearances. Then Tommasi got one himself in injury-time.

Hidetoshi Nakata put Roma three up in the 66th minute, when he clipped a running volley from a Cafu cross into the top corner.

"We were resolute and focused and relaxed a little only in the last 15 minutes," said the Roma coach Fabio Capello. "Results have gone against us, but we have always played great football."

Roma's next two games are against their only remaining rivals for the scudetto, with the Rome derby against Lazio next Sunday and Juventus at the Stadio delle Alpi the following week.

Lazio may find themselves with an even trickier run-in if fears that they may be temporarily exiled from the Stadio Olimpico are realised. They picked up their fifth fine of the season after their fans abused Parma's black players recently. "If it happens again," said the Lazio president Sergio Cragnotti, "they will pull us out of the Stadio Olimpico."

Lazio remain seven points off the pace after their 2-1 win in Vicenza on Sunday. Diego Simeone gave them the lead 10 minutes before half-time before Crespo scored his 19th league goal of the season.

Their three closest pursuers, Parma, Atalanta and Milan, all drew on Sunday. Milan needed a last-minute goal from their Georgian international Khaka Kaladze at Lecce to gain a 3-3 draw. And Atalanta conceded a last-minute equaliser at Perugia when the Korean international Ahn Jung-Hwan struck from 20 yards.

At the bottom of Serie A, Bari lie five points adrift after going down 4-2 at Bologna, for whom Giuseppe Signori scored twice. And Reggina won 3-0 at Verona in a game in which they were reduced to 10 men at the end of the first half. Francesco Cozza received a red card almost immediately after putting Reggina 2-0 up, but the visitors kept their nerve and their clean sheet while Verona had two players sent off in the second half.

Napoli missed a chance to climb out of the relegation zone when they conceded an equaliser to a Roberto Baggio free-kick deep into injury-time of their game against Brescia at the Stadio San Paolo on Saturday.

webTitle: Anne Robinson and her Weakest Link have catered for an anti-British US viewing public

fields.headline: Special relationship? Goodbye
fields.standfirst:
Anne Robinson and her Weakest Link have catered for an anti-British US viewing public

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Anne Robinson and her Weakest Link have catered for an anti-British US viewing public.
fields.body:
We live in an era when TV shows are as significant as battles once were. That is why the launch of The Weakest Link in America is a British defeat that has cost us the equivalent of several regiments lost at the Battle of Yorktown. This is no heroic setback, no Dunkirk. Those who watch The Weakest Link cannot paraphrase General Bosquet at the Charge of the Light Brigade: "C'est magnifique mais c'est seulement la television." No, this is much graver stuff. Robinson's name will join those of Cornwallis and Burgoyne who oversaw defeats without glory.

A harsh propaganda blow has been struck. Historians of the 21st century will point to one of the cruellest cuts against our national prestige since the debacle of Saratoga and the humiliation of Suez. This phenomenon is the special relationship in reverse, the pop-cultural manifestation of George Bush's withdrawal from the British embrace. Anne Robinson and her Weakest Link confirms all the bad things Americans want to believe about the British: Florence Nightingale borrowing Jack the Ripper's medical-bag.

Personally, I admire Robinson. I admire her as I would probably have admired General Raglan - until he went abroad in command of British interests. When NBC invited Robinson to America to present her show, the British press were pathetically grateful that the Lone Superpower actually wanted one of us, a severe, middle-aged Englishwoman, to appear on its television. So when the show appeared, even the BBC News covered Miss Robinson's arrival, as if her landing at NBC Studios-LA was as striking a victory as our first Falklands bridgehead. Weren't we all proud?

But then we were slightly bewildered by the torrent of vicious reviews, as if her nastiness was real, not just a clever pantomime. Much worse was the revelation that the American guests did not take her seriously. This is not very surprising: how could a few insults from an English nanny shame a nation inured to the trailertrash shamelessness of Springer? None the less, she was a metaphor for Britain: the bulldog with no teeth. Like the Boston tea party, the Weakest Link makes Britain laughable.

No wonder the Americans lured our heroine over there, receiving her with such glee! Those in the Bush White House, who wish to distance America from the old Rooseveltian chains of the sec ond world war, need only look at this TV harridan to see Britain's insolent weakness. Where Margaret Thatcher represented iron strength, Robinson's bravado reveals weakness. Her rudeness is reminiscent of the British imperialists of the War of Independence - a stand-in for George the Tyrant, whom Tom Paine called the "royal brute", the substitute for the cruelty of Banastre "Butcher" Tarleton and "Swagger" Burgoyne.

Her reviews read strangely like the letters of American rebels who wrote about "haughty, crabbed" British with their "arrogant bearing ... who treat everyone else with contempt". One American friend who watched her in her leather greatcoat told me she reminded him precisely of the Brits in The Patriot, a recent movie that completely invented a British massacre.

Anyone who has lived in America knows that the English, especially women, are seen as pale, lumpy, jagged-fanged and malodorous. In the same week that the flagship of American physical triumphalism, the Sport Illustrated Swimsuit Issue, came out, Americans were delighted Robinson remained handsome in her English way.

Her stentorian accent (upper class to them) confirms what they are sure they know about the British class system: it's a rigid aristocracy, impenetrable by merit. They instantly recognised Robinson as a Victorian task-mistress, if not humourless Queen Victoria herself. Robinson represents the shallow, US-psychobabble analysis of our royals - she is the queen of dysfunction, personifying emotionally crippled Britain. In dramatic terms, she is the stock Hollywood villainess. America's celluloid baddies are usually played by Brits (the cruel Romans in Spartacus, the Gestapo-esque monsters of The Patriot, the cold snobs of Last of the Mohicans, the drear imperialists of Star Wars).

And finally there is sex. How Americans love to hate the dominatrix, that pornographic fantasy of British toughness. Those documen taries on the tedious rigmarole of American domin- atrixes, who spank and stamp on plump businessmen with their heels, reveal their hilarious "ersatz Britishness" - the accents, knickers and bodices, titles (Lady Strong-lance, Lady Veronica Pain). But dominatrixes are all lash and no whip.

So if there ever was an argument for America First it is Anne Robinson in America. She is the best weapon of anti-British, republican, anti-imperialist isolationism in the US since Charles Lindbergh and Father Coughlin, since FDR secretly plotted with Stalin to dismantle the British Empire. The White House need only to look at her and say: "The special relationship is The Weakest Link. Goodbye!"

Her reviews read strangely like the letters of American rebels who wrote about "haughty, crabbed" British with their "arrogant bearing ... who treat everyone else with contempt". One American friend who watched her in her leather greatcoat told me she reminded him precisely of the Brits in The Patriot, a recent movie that completely invented a British massacre. Anyone who has lived in America knows that the English, especially women, are seen as pale, lumpy, jagged-fanged and malodorous. In the same week that the flagship of American physical triumphalism, the Sport Illustrated Swimsuit Issue, came out, Americans were delighted Robinson remained handsome in her English way. Her stentorian accent (upper class to them) confirms what they are sure they know about the British class system: it's a rigid aristocracy, impenetrable by merit. They instantly recognised Robinson as a Victorian task-mistress, if not humourless Queen Victoria herself. Robinson represents the shallow, US-psychobabble analysis of our royals - she is the queen of dysfunction, personifying emotionally crippled Britain. In dramatic terms, she is the stock Hollywood villainess. America's celluloid baddies are usually played by Brits (the cruel Romans in Spartacus, the Gestapo-esque monsters of The Patriot, the cold snobs of Last of the Mohicans, the drear imperialists of Star Wars). And finally there is sex. How Americans love to hate the dominatrix, that pornographic fantasy of British toughness. Those documen taries on the tedious rigmarole of American domin- atrixes, who spank and stamp on plump businessmen with their heels, reveal their hilarious "ersatz Britishness" - the accents, knickers and bodices, titles (Lady Strong-lance, Lady Veronica Pain). But dominatrixes are all lash and no whip. So if there ever was an argument for America First it is Anne Robinson in America. She is the best weapon of anti-British, republican, anti-imperialist isolationism in the US since Charles Lindbergh and Father Coughlin, since FDR secretly plotted with Stalin to dismantle the British Empire. The White House need only to look at her and say: "The special relationship is The Weakest Link. Goodbye!" mailto:SimonSebagMontefiore @compuserve.com

webTitle: Axe hovers over Serra Ferrer as Barcelona lose again

fields.headline: Axe hovers over Serra Ferrer as Barcelona lose again
fields.standfirst: Latest: Barcelona sack coach Ferrer
fields.trailText: Cheer up Roy. United might be shite but it could be worse - you could play for Barcelona.
fields.body:
Cheer up Roy. United might be shite but it could be worse - you could play for Barcelona.

Barça are already out of the Uefa Cup and nowhere near Real Madrid, and even their chances of making the Champions League are crumbling - this weekend they were on the receiving end of a 3-1 kicking from relegation candidates Osasuna. And just to make things even worse, Barça had three men sent off - Simão, Sergi and Ivan de la Peña.

Barcelona, said Catalan daily El Mundo Deportivo, were a "disgrace", while Marca couldn't resist a little dig of its own. "Patético," it chuckled.

That defeat, alongside Mallorca's 2-2 draw with Villarreal, leaves Barça two points off the fourth Champions League place. All is not well - wherever you turn players insist they're leaving and with fans staying away in droves, Serra Ferrer looks set to pay the inevitable price.

Even his supposed mates are turning against him. In midweek assistant sports director Carles Rexach offered to take over team affairs following the Anfield disaster. Poor old Lorenzo. "I consider myself one of Charly's friends," he whined, "but looking at what's happened to some of his friends I'm going to have to be careful" - a not-so-thinly veiled reference to the fate of Johan Cruyff, who called Rexach a traitor after he was sacked from Barça.

Tongues were wagging even more furiously after president Joan Gaspart was seen going into the Barça dressing room after the Osasuna game. But he wasn't there to bollock his side, of course. Or the boss. No, not at all - Gaspart was there to "gee them up".

But it seems that Serra Ferrer has only been given a temporary reprieve. Reports in the Catalan daily Sport this morning suggest that he'll be sacked at a meeting this evening. And his replacement until the end of the season will be his loyal friend, Carles Rexach.

Bizarrely, even if Serra Ferrer is forced to step down as team manager he'll still take up his post as sporting director. In other words, he'll have a say in what happens to the manager's job and its potential incumbent Rexach. No prizes for guessing what he'll chose to do with Charly boy. After all, there's a post available in the club shop.

Meanwhile Barça's eternal rivals Real Madrid are flying after opening up an 11-point lead at the top, thanks to their win over Zaragoza and Depor's 2-1 defeat in the Galician derbi.

Valerón headed Javier Irureta's side in front early in the second half, but Djorovic - back in the side after four months out injured - hit a fine equaliser for Celta four minutes later. Then Alexander Mostovoi really turned on the style. He signalled his intent with a sublime touch to play in Catanha and minutes later scored the winner with a superb curler from the edge of the box.

Depor seem to have things the wrong way round - the manager reckons that he hasn't (yet) done a good enough job to continue, but the president insists that he has. Irureta says he won't commit himself to another year at Depor until he has fulfilled his "duties" (i.e. secured a Champions League place). President Augusto Lendoiro is starting to suspect that the míster is simply employing delaying tactics and this week presented him with an ultimatum. If Irureta doesn't stay, Mallorca coach Luis Aragonés, the Mad Man of Hortaleza, is in pole position to take over at the Riazor.

Irureta might not think he's done his duty, but nor has he given up on the title. "I'm not saying adiós to the league," he insisted on Saturday night, "because I'm hoping Madrid lose."

No such luck, Jabo - Madrid beat an unlucky Zaragoza 3-2. Twice Real broke away to score, Savio supplying the cross for Raúl to head the first and the new-look Steve McManaman (gone are the shaggy locks) set up the second.

Jamelli bundled his way through for a second-half equaliser and then did something truly miraculous: running towards the fans in delight, the Brazilian reached into his shorts and somehow whipped out his pants.

Perhaps not the pair he was actually wearing (unless he really is talented), but why a professional footballer should keep a spare pair of pants stuffed down his shorts is a mystery. Protection perhaps - after all, he had been forewarned, having just witnessed referee Carmona Mendez get one in the nads.

Luis Costa claimed afterwards that his side had "had a great match". True enough, but Zaragoza were caught out for a third time - Luis Figo's corner found Savio who smashed in at the near post to make it 3-2.

Zaragoza deserved more but the Man in the Moustache's side should have run away with it after Savio's strike. Guti hasn't been able to stop scoring recently. On Sunday, he couldn't start. Perhaps he should take lessons from third division Yeclano's goalie, Galiesto - he scored a 100-yard cracker after just 40 seconds to give his side a 1-0 lead against Aguilas. If the goal was funny enough, Marca's comedy cartoon "reproduction" was better yet. click here and then on 'espectacular gol' .

Madrid may have sewn up the title, but things are far from sorted at the bottom. Osasuna are still in the relegation zone, but their win over Barça has lifted them above Numancia (who drew 1-1 with Las Palmas) and Racing Santander. Racing were convincingly beaten 3-0 by Espanyol, but it wasn't all good news for the Budgies: this column's favourite Espanyol player - driving-test dodger Raúl Tamudo - pulled a muscle and will miss Spain's midweek friendly with Japan.

There's a financial crisis at Valladolid, where players haven't been paid for a month. On Sunday's showing against Real Sociedad they hardly deserve to be paid - John Benjamin saw his side run out easy 3-1 winners, with youngster Gabilondo promoted to the first team and scoring twice.

Sent off last week, Toshack asked the club to fine him in midweek and had to watch this one from the director's box. "It was all right," he said afterwards. "The only problem is that there's so many cigars up there and the smoke's really annoying."

JB's happy, though - that win sees Sociedad climb above Real Oviedo whose first full house of the season saw a turgid 0-0 draw with Valencia.

Finally, there were 2-1 away wins for Bilbao against Rayo Vallecano and Málaga against Uefa Cup superstars Alavés.

Derbis weren't confined to Galicia this weekend. Sevilla and Betis, the top two in the second division, met on Sunday with Betis's new manager Luis del Sol insisting that "Sevilla-Betis is bigger than any derbi involving Real or Juventus". The match finished 1-1, but that was overshadowed by what happened off the pitch. More than 50 fans were hurt when a barrier at the Sánchez Pizjuán collapsed at one end. Five fans are still in hospital, all being treated for fractures.

webTitle: Mean Keane leaves United to go through the motions

fields.headline: Mean Keane leaves United to go through the motions
fields.standfirst: Manchester derby ends 1-1 with the champions looking flat and City seeking a miracle
fields.trailText: Far from celebrating the club's first championship hat-trick after a seventh title in nine seasons, Manchester United appear to have embarked on a month-long wake.
fields.body:
The domestic season quickly gathers dust once the championship has been decided and by the time Manchester United receive the Premier League trophy on Saturday week they may need reminding of what it is for.

But for their removal from the Champions League by Bayern Munich last Wednesday Sir Alex Ferguson's players would now be savouring the prospect of renewing acquaintance with Real Madrid in the semi-finals. Instead, and far from celebrating the club's first championship hat-trick after a seventh title in nine seasons, United appear to have embarked on a month-long wake.

In the aftermath of Munich Ferguson has declared his need for three more top-class players - PSV's Ruud van Nistelrooy is one and the outstanding young Auxerre striker Djibril Cisse may be another - while the United captain Roy Keane has put himself forward for the Foul of the Year award.

The vicious, knee-high lunge at Alf-Inge Haaland which saw Keane sent off by David Elleray towards the end of Saturday's 1-1 draw with Manchester City may well have stemmed from an incident at Elland Road in September 1997, when Haaland was playing for Leeds, but that was hardly a mitigating factor.

On Saturday Ferguson was as touchy as ever on the subject of his captain's disciplinary lapses and it is true that Keane has curbed some of his recklessness, so much so that some were starting to wonder if the devil had departed from his game altogether.

But no, Mephistopheles is alive and still kicking. Keane has now been sent off eight times in eight years at Old Trafford, including two red cards this season, the first for a gratuitous hack at Chelsea's Gustavo Poyet in the FA Charity Shield last August. As result he will be banned for a total of four games and will miss the start of next season.

Keane may be an outstanding footballer but, unlike another of United's Irish captains, Johnny Carey, he is not an outstanding football man. As Joe Royle, the City manager, said: "Alfie said he was lucky his leg was in the air. If it had been on the floor we would still be looking for it."

In terms of surviving relegation City are looking for a miracle that is not going to happen. Their gutsy recovery at Old Trafford to snatch a point with six minutes left typified a number of their away performances since winning promotion, including victories at Leeds and Newcastle, but few teams can suffer 11 home defeats and hope to stay up.

"We need two wins and a draw to have at least a chance," said Royle, but if his team were capable of closing a seven-point gap in the space of three matches they would not be where they are now.

Rightly, Royle holds consistently bad defending primarily responsible for City's failure to make it in the elite. Yet on Saturday the excellence of his centre-backs, Steve Howey and Richard Dunne, had much to do with United's failure to bid farewell to the briefly revived Manchester derby with a resounding victory.

This and the goalkeeping of Carlo Nash, who thwarted the opposition's best attempts to score and was beaten only by United's second penalty, taken by Teddy Sheringham, after Paul Scholes had dragged an earlier kick wide.

In the wake of their European exit United looked a little hung over, but it would be wrong to say they were not interested. Long before Keane's disgrace enough fouls were exchanged for the match to justify its derby status.

However, it would be true to say that Ferguson's players were not that bothered and this feeling manifested itself in the uncharacteristic long balls which were aimed vaguely towards Sheringham and Ole Gunnar Solskjaer, making the strikers' task more difficult and Howey and Dunne more confident. The attitude was, why run when the race is won?

Had a shot from Gerard Wiekens not been deflected on to the United crossbar by Wes Brown after four minutes and had Paulo Wanchope, running clear after catching Phil Neville in possession four minutes later, not delayed shooting until Jaap Stam could get back to clear off the line, an upset might have been on.

Instead City, their best chance of victory gone, spent most of the time defending with eight or nine men while United contrived a variety of ways not to score. But after Dunne tripped Solskjaer, Sheringham seemed to have settled it.

Then David Beckham inadvertently nodded on Paul Dickov's corner for Howey to force it in at the far post. Keane departed two minutes later but City had little thought of going for victory against 10 men, and at least they can claim to have denied United a goal in open play this season - Beckham having won the Maine Road game with a free-kick.

Man of the match Steve Howey (Man City).

webTitle: Economics: The hairdressers can yet save us

fields.headline: The hairdressers can yet save us
fields.standfirst: The lion's share of the UK economy is not really affected by what is happening overseas
fields.trailText: Larry Elliott: The lion's share of the UK economy is not really affected by what is happening overseas.
fields.body:
And with one bound he was free. A conference call with a handful of governors of the Federal Reserve, a half-point cut in interest rates, an instant response from Wall Street, and that's that. Fears of recession have been banished and the good times are just around the corner. The maestro is back in charge of events.

Well, that's one way of looking at it. For twitchy investors in the United States, it is probably the only way. For the alternative to believing that Alan Greenspan really can chart a course between a savage downturn and reinflating the bubble economy is that he has become the King Lear of the world's financial markets, raging impotently against forces he can no longer control.

The idea that Greenspan is now a senile old man is as daft as the notion a year ago that he was infallible. He is doing the best he can with a fiendishly difficult situation, and last week's bold action has bought him some time. Yet the fact that US interest rates have been cut twice as quickly as they were in the recession of 1991 tells its own story - there is widespread distress in the American corporate sector caused by a combination of over-investment and weak demand. For the rest of the world watching over the past nine months as the talk has turned from soft to hard landing, it is time to estimate just how badly they would be affected by a worst-case US scenario.

A fear that Britain may be sucked down by an American recession is one reason why the government is keen to have an election as soon as possible. The strong pound, the collapse of the technology bubble, the wettest weather on record and the foot and mouth epidemic are already affecting UK growth, and Britain's exposure to the US is considerable. Annual growth of 3%, claimant count unemployment at just under 1m and underlying inflation of 1.9% is as good as it gets at the moment.

Concern that the US will suffer a painful period of adjustment after the excesses of the past few years is well-founded. The almost religious belief in the power of Greenspan means that the markets are pricing in a speedy recovery, consumers are continuing to spend and foreign investors are keeping faith with the dollar. Lower interest rates will cut the cost of borrowing, easing the pressure on balance sheets, but as the announcement of the past few weeks have shown, not by enough to prevent some pretty savage job cuts.

As Roger Bootle, economic adviser to Deloitte and Touche, says: "Large sections of the market still expect this to be a shallow slowdown, or if a recession, then merely one of the V-shaped variety. We think they have lost the plot. This is not a short-term slowdown resulting from an inventory correction but rather the beginning of a long-overdue adjustment which has its origins in an asset price bubble and over-spending. The current account deficit last year was 4.4% of GDP. In the absence of other changes, the US has to go on drawing in this amount of capital from the rest of the world, year after year. This is an unsustainable position."

Eventually, Bootle will be proved right. Notwithstanding the well-documented and deserved success of a new breed of companies in the 1990s, the really rapid growth in the second half of the decade was the result of an economy living beyond its means. As with Britain in the late 1980s, underlying problems were masked by an over-valued currency, with the balance of payments the safety valve for inflationary pressure. What happened from the autumn of 2000 onwards was the start of a period of adjustment, once it became clear that stock market valuations were unrealistic in the light of what was happening to earnings. Having engineered that process through a tighter monetary policy last year, Greenspan has become concerned that the smooth descent to a more moderate period of growth could turn into a crash landing and executed an emergency u-turn.

With the stock market still over-valued by 50% on some estimates, Bootle believes that even a cut in interest rates to 3% coupled with George Bush's planned tax cut will do no more than "mitigate the scale and extent of the loss of output". He argues that the "need for adjustment is so large that there is no plausible package of rate reductions and tax cuts large enough to obviate a long period of below trend growth".

Charles Dumas, at Lombard Street Research, takes a slightly different view. While agreeing that the US is heading for trouble, he thinks there is the prospect of one last hurrah as the Fed pumps up demand by expanding the money supply. The excess liquidity will leak out into higher inflation, accompanied by a collapse in the dollar, which will result in a second leg of the recessionary process which will be far more serious than the current stage.

As ever, the normal health warnings apply. Greenspan's financial Dunkirk may succeed against all the odds, but it would not be wise to bank on it. The conventional wisdom is that if the mighty US hits trouble there is precious little hope for plucky Britain. And, up to a point, the conventional wisdom is right. Britain relies heavily on trade, and the US is a key trading partner and is also responsible for large chunks of Britain's inward investment. Some companies have already begun to mothball expansion plans and cut their UK workforces as part of global retrenchment.

Cloud to the silver lining

However, there are some causes for modest optimism. The first is that despite all the talk of globalisation, the lion's share of the economy is not really affected by what is happening beyond these shores. As Adair Turner says in his new book, Just Capital, in some ways economies are becoming more local, with an increasing share of national income spent on services such as hair-dressing or eating out rather than on goods that are internationally traded. However, the cloud to this silver lining is that the brunt of any US-induced slowdown would fall on the UK's manufacturing sector, thereby exacerbating the imbalance in the economy.

The second reason to be cheerful is that there is scope for macro-economic policy to be eased. Last week's minutes from the Bank of England showed that three members of the monetary policy committee supported a more aggressive cut in interest rates last month, and further reductions look certain. Even without the deflationary impact of slower growth, underlying inflation is set to fall to around 1.5% over the next few months, giving the Bank plenty of scope to act. Peter Spencer, economic adviser to the Ernst & Young Item club, believes that base rates could go as low as 3.5% - a full two percentage points below their current rate - should the circumstances require it. For that to happen, though, it seems likely that growth would have to weaken appreciably and inflation sink to 1%. Fiscal policy should also be supportive of growth over the coming months. The increases in public spending announced last year are only now coming on stream, and the size of the budget surplus means that there is potential for either tax cuts or further increases in spending.

Finally, the economy may be stronger than Britain's army of pessimists imagine. This, of course, is a moot point. Like the US, the UK has been living beyond its means (although not by so much) and many of the old weakness - low productivity, poor skills, pockets of industrial underperformance - are still all too evident. But, as Spencer argues, the economy has had a lot chucked at it in recent months and has remained surprisingly robust. That could either mean that there has been an underlying improvement or that we are in denial. If it is the former, we could yet escape with an easing of growth to 2% this year and next, even if things turn really nasty in the US. Keep your fingers crossed.

A conference call with a handful of governors of the Federal Reserve, a half-point cut in interest rates, an instant response from Wall Street, and that's that. Fears of recession have been banished and the good times are just around the corner. The maestro is back in charge of events. Well, that's one way of looking at it. For twitchy investors in the United States, it is probably the only way. For the alternative to believing that Alan Greenspan really can chart a course between a savage downturn and reinflating the bubble economy is that he has become the King Lear of the world's financial markets, raging impotently against forces he can no longer control. The idea that Greenspan is now a senile old man is as daft as the notion a year ago that he was infallible. He is doing the best he can with a fiendishly difficult situation, and last week's bold action has bought him some time. Yet the fact that US interest rates have been cut twice as quickly as they were in the recession of 1991 tells its own story - there is widespread distress in the American corporate sector caused by a combination of over-investment and weak demand. For the rest of the world watching over the past nine months as the talk has turned from soft to hard landing, it is time to estimate just how badly they would be affected by a worst-case US scenario. A fear that Britain may be sucked down by an American recession is one reason why the government is keen to have an election as soon as possible. The strong pound, the collapse of the technology bubble, the wettest weather on record and the foot and mouth epidemic are already affecting UK growth, and Britain's exposure to the US is considerable. Annual growth of 3%, claimant count unemployment at just under 1m and underlying inflation of 1.9% is as good as it gets at the moment. Concern that the US will suffer a painful period of adjustment after the excesses of the past few years is well-founded. The almost religious belief in the power of Greenspan means that the markets are pricing in a speedy recovery, consumers are continuing to spend and foreign investors are keeping faith with the dollar. Lower interest rates will cut the cost of borrowing, easing the pressure on balance sheets, but as the announcement of the past few weeks have shown, not by enough to prevent some pretty savage job cuts. As Roger Bootle, economic adviser to Deloitte and Touche, says: "Large sections of the market still expect this to be a shallow slowdown, or if a recession, then merely one of the V-shaped variety. We think they have lost the plot. This is not a short-term slowdown resulting from an inventory correction but rather the beginning of a long-overdue adjustment which has its origins in an asset price bubble and over-spending. The current account deficit last year was 4.4% of GDP. In the absence of other changes, the US has to go on drawing in this amount of capital from the rest of the world, year after year. This is an unsustainable position." Eventually, Bootle will be proved right. Notwithstanding the well-documented and deserved success of a new breed of companies in the 1990s, the really rapid growth in the second half of the decade was the result of an economy living beyond its means. As with Britain in the late 1980s, underlying problems were masked by an over-valued currency, with the balance of payments the safety valve for inflationary pressure. What happened from the autumn of 2000 onwards was the start of a period of adjustment, once it became clear that stock market valuations were unrealistic in the light of what was happening to earnings. Having engineered that process through a tighter monetary policy last year, Greenspan has become concerned that the smooth descent to a more moderate period of growth could turn into a crash landing and executed an emergency u-turn. With the stock market still over-valued by 50% on some estimates, Bootle believes that even a cut in interest rates to 3% coupled with George Bush's planned tax cut will do no more than "mitigate the scale and extent of the loss of output". He argues that the "need for adjustment is so large that there is no plausible package of rate reductions and tax cuts large enough to obviate a long period of below trend growth". Charles Dumas, at Lombard Street Research, takes a slightly different view. While agreeing that the US is heading for trouble, he thinks there is the prospect of one last hurrah as the Fed pumps up demand by expanding the money supply. The excess liquidity will leak out into higher inflation, accompanied by a collapse in the dollar, which will result in a second leg of the recessionary process which will be far more serious than the current stage. As ever, the normal health warnings apply. Greenspan's financial Dunkirk may succeed against all the odds, but it would not be wise to bank on it. The conventional wisdom is that if the mighty US hits trouble there is precious little hope for plucky Britain. And, up to a point, the conventional wisdom is right. Britain relies heavily on trade, and the US is a key trading partner and is also responsible for large chunks of Britain's inward investment. Some companies have already begun to mothball expansion plans and cut their UK workforces as part of global retrenchment. Cloud to the silver lining However, there are some causes for modest optimism. The first is that despite all the talk of globalisation, the lion's share of the economy is not really affected by what is happening beyond these shores. As Adair Turner says in his new book, Just Capital, in some ways economies are becoming more local, with an increasing share of national income spent on services such as hair-dressing or eating out rather than on goods that are internationally traded. However, the cloud to this silver lining is that the brunt of any US-induced slowdown would fall on the UK's manufacturing sector, thereby exacerbating the imbalance in the economy. The second reason to be cheerful is that there is scope for macro-economic policy to be eased. Last week's minutes from the Bank of England showed that three members of the monetary policy committee supported a more aggressive cut in interest rates last month, and further reductions look certain. Even without the deflationary impact of slower growth, underlying inflation is set to fall to around 1.5% over the next few months, giving the Bank plenty of scope to act. Peter Spencer, economic adviser to the Ernst & Young Item club, believes that base rates could go as low as 3.5% - a full two percentage points below their current rate - should the circumstances require it. For that to happen, though, it seems likely that growth would have to weaken appreciably and inflation sink to 1%. Fiscal policy should also be supportive of growth over the coming months. The increases in public spending announced last year are only now coming on stream, and the size of the budget surplus means that there is potential for either tax cuts or further increases in spending. Finally, the economy may be stronger than Britain's army of pessimists imagine. This, of course, is a moot point. Like the US, the UK has been living beyond its means (although not by so much) and many of the old weakness - low productivity, poor skills, pockets of industrial underperformance - are still all too evident. But, as Spencer argues, the economy has had a lot chucked at it in recent months and has remained surprisingly robust. That could either mean that there has been an underlying improvement or that we are in denial. If it is the former, we could yet escape with an easing of growth to 2% this year and next, even if things turn really nasty in the US. Keep your fingers crossed.

webTitle: Business: Britain tipped to avoid US contagion

fields.headline: Britain tipped to avoid US contagion
fields.trailText: Britain will escape the worst impact if the US economy goes to the wall, two leading forecasters predict today.
fields.body:
Britain will escape the worst impact if the US economy goes to the wall, two leading forecasters predict today.

Growth will slow from last year's 3% to closer to 2%, according to Roger Bootle - a former adviser to the chancellor - and the Ernst&Young Item club, which uses the Treasury's economic model to crunch its numbers.

But both forecasters agree that, provided the Bank of England cuts rate to 5% by the end of the year, it should be able to insulate Britain from the threat of recession.

Mr Bootle believes the fortunes of the Britsih economy are not as closely tied to the US economy as has been true in the past. "A good deal of the apparent closeness of UK and US economic growth rates derives from a connection between the UK economy and the world, rather than from any particularly strong link with America," he said.

The British economy is also more robust than it used to be, according to Professor Peter Spencer, the Item club's economic adviser.

"Any of the huge shocks that been thrown at the economy over the last three months - the US slowdown, the stock market crash, our own technology, media and telecommunications bubble bursting, extreme weather conditions, transport problems, and foot and mouth disease - would have sent business and consumer confidence into a tailspin in the past."

But the Item club warns that the huge number of profit warnings in the technology and manufacturing sectors both here and in the US suggest that the economic outlook is becoming increasingly dark.

In the worst-case scenario, where Alan Greenspan, the head of the US Federal Reserve, does not manage to save the stock market from plummeting, the Item club believes growth will dip below 2% and interest rates might have to be cut to as low as 3.5%.

Unlike Mr Greenspan, the Bank still has some room for manoeuvre because there are few signs of price pressures in the British economy. Mr Bootle believes Britain's trade and investment balance with the rest of the world will be the main casualty of the Bank's attempts to ward off recession. The current account deficit could widen to 2.2% of GDP, from 1.5% in 2000.

"This, though, is a small price to pay for escaping recession," Mr Bootle said. "Britain will have come through the crisis remarkably well - and the MPC will be the hero of the hour."

webTitle: National Secretary Day

fields.headline: It's your day
fields.standfirst:
Wednesday is National Secretary Day. Sadly, though, all the cards we found look suitable for the sort of people who still knit their own clothes

Guardian Unlimited Work
fields.trailText: Wednesday is National Secretary Day. Sadly, though, all the cards we found look suitable for the sort of people who still knit their own clothes.
fields.body:
This Wednesday is Renee Zellweger's birthday. It's also Al Pacino's, Ella Fitzgerald's and my Auntie Linda's. But far, far more importantly, it is National Secretary Day - aka Administrative Professionals' Day. National Secretary Day is just 24 little hours, slap-bang in the middle of Professional Secretaries Week. Like most things - potatoes, Cadillacs, Baywatch, the concept cruised on in from America, where next week they will be celebrating National Fork-Lift Truck Drivers Week with a parade and lots of candyfloss and streamers.

It's easy to be sceptical about such events. Lord knows, I'd be the first in the queue to purchase shares in the Hallmark greetings cards empire - were it not for the fact that I have little spare change left to fritter away on stocks and shares, after shelling out £2.20 for one of its cards. But perhaps we shouldn't knock a day that will allow secretarial and administrative staff to receive a little bit of credit for performing a string of thankless, lacklustre tasks day after day.

We purchased four cards from the impressively large Clinton Cards selection, at a total of £7.74. "You must know a lot of secretaries," said the helpful gentleman behind the till. "Four" hardly constitutes a puddle of secretaries, let alone a whole typing pool, but we didn't like to quibble.

Office Hours trapped Guardian style guru Caroline Roux, in the lift, to ask her what she thought of our National Secretary Day card selection. "They're very downmarket," she said. "They imply that all secretaries are not very sophisticated. They're not very metropolitan, they're very suburban." Caroline particularly objected to the card "For A Special Secretary". "It looks like it's for a 60-year-old woman. It's very old-fashioned. In the same way that the word 'secretary' is very old-fashioned," she said, stylishly. "And they're lacking in humour, which implies that secretaries are lacking in humour."

Caroline commented that our selection veered between cards aimed at "teens" and those suited to "old ladies". "There is nothing to suggest that these people are attractive, dynamic, fashion-conscious or design-conscious individuals. These are cards for people who still knit their own clothes," she concluded, with a hint of disgust, before flouncing off to somewhere so terribly hip and fashionable that you haven't even heard of it yet.

It's all very well for the stylishly clad to dismiss such cards as "suburban". Frankly that's their job. But what would a genuine, bona fide secretary think if she - or he - received one of these attractive cards on Wednesday? Office Hours quizzed our Secs in the City columnist for her esteemed opinion. "Erm, well, I don't reckon I'll be getting cards on Wednesday," she said, mournfully. No indeed, mademoiselle, especially not if they've twigged that it's you writing that column, poking fun at your workmates' every whim and whimper. "I don't think I'd want any of them either. They're horrible." Why? "Well they're like the sort of cards you get from your local corner shop because you forgot it was someone's birthday." I beg your pardon? "Or the sort of cards your Uncle Geoff still sends you, even though you haven't seen him for 16 years." Right. "I'd feel patronised if my boss gave me one of those. They're the greeting card equivalent of a box of Quality Street."

True, but they don't even have the benefit of those hazelnut-caramel, purple-wrapped chocolates do they? But sadly, so very few things in life actually do.

Our columnist particularly disliked two of the cards. "I'm not a bloody cheerleader," she grumbled, of one, with its syrupy, Americanised list of the supposed roles of the secretary - "postmasters, psychiatrists, supply clerks, schedulers, troubleshooters, messengers, consultants, psychics, coordinators, cheerleaders, errand runners, attentive listeners ...". "And what the hell is a supply clerk?"

With the other card, our columnist objected to the suggestion that secretaries "invent really great filing systems". "Is that sarcasm?" she asked. "And I really hate that last one, the "Smile the warmest smiles (even when they want to scream)". Believe me, I bypass the smiling bit, and just go for the screaming option. Every time."

So what would a secretary or PA actually like to receive on Wednesday? Last Friday, at online recruitment company fish4jobs.co.uk, five secretaries and executive support staff were allowed to job-swap with their bosses for a whole day. One of the swappers, Phylia Phoon, who is the executive assistant to the CEO Jonathan Turpin, decided to give all the PAs a day off. Good choice, Phoony. Turpin was left with the responsibility of booking the chauffeur-driven car. The PAs swanked off to lunch on the Strand, followed by a trip to the theatre. Back at the office, they had a change from the usual chores of filing, to be given a manicure. Thankfully not by Turpin.

Our Secs in the City columnist reckons a manicure is a nice idea. "You want something pampering. Something luxurious. Or even just to be taken out for a nice lunch or something. Although then you'd have to talk to your boss for at least an hour on your own, so maybe that's not such a great idea."

Caroline Roux suggests "a gift voucher for a pampering thing, or a very nice bunch of flowers". But we're not talking chrysanths or carnations here. "Fashion flowers," insists Caroline. Office Hours shudders to think what's fashionable in the flower world these days - probably radishes or something.

Still, if all you get on Wednesday is a measly "suburban" card thanking you for the fact that you "Always know the answers or where to find them", well it's better than, erm, not getting a measly "suburban" card. And if you don't find anything at all, - no chocolates, no cards, no balloons or flowers, sitting on your desk on Wednesday morning, you know you've only got yourself to blame - after all, it's you who's in charge of the boss's diary, isn't it?

(And PS, just so you're prepared, April 30 is Hairstylist Appreciation Day - no kidding).

webTitle: Forget the piggy bank ...

fields.headline: Forget the piggy bank ...
fields.standfirst:
One agency now provides free financial help and advice to its temps, reports Susannah Osborne

Guardian Unlimited Work
fields.trailText: One agency now provides free financial help and advice to its temps, reports Susannah Osborne.
fields.body:
Financial benefits and temping don't usually mix - it is a rare cocktail. But under an exclusive scheme launched by Office Angels, temps may soon be calling their agency for more than the next job. Angels is launching a scheme that will offer its employees free independent financial advice and an easy and efficient way to save those hard-earned pennies.

Temping is hardly the most secure profession - that nomadic lifestyle of office-to-office traipsing may bring in the money, but what do you do with it? The ebb and flow of monetary transactions is irregular at the best of times. Money goes in, money goes out, and while the pay can be good, it isn't always consistent - let's face it, the temp is hardly the bank manager's favourite customer.

For most temps, saving is not top of the list. Temping is often a stopgap, or a means to an end, and not a way of saving. "When you haven't worked for a few weeks and you see large amounts of money coming in you think 'fantastic', but it's more likely to go on a new outfit than in the bank - even if at the back of your mind is the thought that you may never work again," says Claire, who temped for six months.

But temporary staff would like to save. In a survey by Office Angels, one of the most requested services from their temporary staff was the need for financial advice. Temps, it seems, are lost at financial sea. More than a third (38%) of the staff interviewed by Office Angels temp for the money, but many of them don't have any formal savings scheme.

"Temps are often left in the dark, with no guidance as to what to do with their money," says Sarah El-Doori, head of marketing at Office Angels. Many of us are financially illiterate, but large companies often play big brother, they guide you and encourage you to save with dedicated schemes. Company pensions and free financial advice can take a great weight off your shoulders. "Why shouldn't temps get the same treatment," asks El Doori. "One person came to me asking whether temps could get mortgages. If people are asking these kind of questions, somebody needs to answer them."

The Office Angels scheme is a move to help temporary staff plan for their future. Through an exclusive partnership with Abbey National, temps will be able to save directly from their wages. Angels will deduct the amount they want deposited into their savings accounts directly from their wage packets - no banks, no paying-in slips, no fuss. A record of the contributions will be on the wage slip. The minimum payment is £10 a month, and the amount can be altered and additional payments made.

Office Angels' repertoire of services will also include mortgage and financial advice. A free telephone helpline staffed by Abbey National financial advisers will answer mortgage concerns and tailor suitable packages. Help will be available for choosing Isas, Peps and even making wills. "We are hoping that we will help to eliminate the first stumbling block - essentially, knowing where to start, and feeling secure in the knowledge that their money is being put to good use," says El Doori.

Office Angels' interest in the finances of its temps is part of the changing face of agencies. In an effort to look after its staff, companies are realising that the holistic approach is key. Temps may easily feel anonymous at work, so many agencies are adopting a more caring role. Temping is becoming less of the ephemeral career path it was. The average time spent temping is now around eight months - enough time to accrue a significant amount of capital, but also long enough for a company to show loyalty to its staff.

Sarah Alexander, relationship manager at Abbey National, is aware of this as a rising trend. "We are seeing companies taking an interest in the concerns of the everyday lives of their employees," she says.

The Office Angels and Abbey National scheme means that temps will now start to benefit from some of the perks of full-time work. Now, perhaps, temping will begin to be seen as a career choice in itself - rather than just a stop-off on the route to full-time employment.

webTitle: Classical: RSNO/ Lazarev

fields.headline: RSNO/ Lazarev
fields.standfirst:
RSNO/ Lazarev
Usher Hall
Edinburgh
****
fields.trailText:
RSNO/ Lazarev
Usher Hall
Edinburgh
****
fields.body:
The Royal Scottish National Orchestra is now over halfway through its Shostakovich cycle with conductor Alexander Lazarev: the last five symphonies will be performed next season. Alongside them, John Lill has been working his way through Beethoven's five piano concertos. This is solid, if predictable programming, combining two box office favourites in nearly every concert without compromising on seriousness of purpose. The results have been reliably first class: this is an orchestra with an acclaimed history of Shostakovich performance, and Lill's Beethoven recordings are classics.

For all Shostakovich's popularity, few of his symphonies give the listener an easy ride. The wartime Eighth is one of the bleakest of all. Where the other symphonies are more circumspect, the Eighth stares straight into the void. But, like all great tragedians, Shostakovich knows when to let up, even if those moments are always ambivalent. Deciding how to respond to these passages is a key performance issue - whether to read them as heavily ironic, or to allow them briefly to illuminate their dark surroundings.

Although there is a respectable tradition of Shostakovich performance that favours an exaggerated, sarcastic approach, Lazarev demonstrated that a gentler touch can not only benefit dramatic pacing but convey the humanitarian ethos at the heart of this music. Shostakovich's summary of his most tragic symphony as "life is beautiful" is characteristically double-edged. For if, in the C major finale, you find yourself clutching at the shreds of light that never quite come together, you are probably not far from experiencing the kind of fragile hope that Shostakovich had in mind. Lazarev's sensitivity to Shostakovich's frail vision made this performance incredibly moving. The RSNO played superbly, with some especially distinguished moments, notably in Stephen West's hauntingly bittersweet cor anglais solo.

If John Lill's initially rather workmanlike approach to Beethoven's Fourth Piano Concerto took a bit of getting used to, its purpose gradually became apparent - all Lill's reserves of spirituality and and dynamism were being stored up for the second and third movements. This made for a slightly mundane first movement; but the rest proved well worth waiting for. His performance of the slow movement confirmed Lill's place in the pantheon of great Beethoven interpreters.

webTitle: Dance: Duo:Logue

fields.headline: Duo:Logue
fields.standfirst:
Linbury Studio
London
***
fields.trailText:
Duo:Logue
Linbury Studio
London
***
fields.body:
Wayne McGregor wasn't a complete ballet novice when he was invited to collaborate with Deborah Bull, Edward Watson and five other Royal Ballet dancers last year. But, for a choreographer so closely associated with modern dance and with digital technology his resulting work, Symbiont(s), demonstrated a startling sympathy with the classical vocabulary.

It would be hard to make these dancers look anything other than glamorous. But McGregor didn't just treat them like expensive new toys, bending their legs as far as they'd go and putting them into extravagant poses. He got right inside the peculiar qualities of ballet, yoking its fleet footwork to his own fierce speed, realigning classical symmetries so that the dancers looked edgy but never abused.

Symbiont(s) has been revived this year for a joint programme danced by the Royal and McGregor's own company Random - and it looks superb. Once you've got over individual performances - the rapacious dancing of Watson and the radiant speediness of Jenny Tattersall - you start to admire how sophisticated McGregor has become in handling dancers in formation, expertly weaving threads of differently paced and coloured movement and making patterns appear from nowhere.

Aeon, the piece created last year for Random, looks less good than usual, however. Some of the choreography seems bitty and over long. Yet the bareness of the Linbury stage highlights the artfulness of the work's overall dance design and also the baroque detail of its movement.

The programme's final work, brainstate, is for both sets of dancers. It is a measure of how sympathetically McGregor has fused their styles that it's sometimes hard to distinguish between the two groups. The detail of the choreography is less intense but McGregor's handling of the 18 dancers is impressive, sustaining the momentum so tightly that he can move from solo to ensemble and back again without losing a beat.

McGregor will continue to work his most passionate experiments on his own company. But his collaborations with the Royal suggest he's ripe to handle a big Opera House commission.

 At Snape Maltings Concert Hall, Snape (01728 687110), on April 29.

webTitle: Theatre: Twisted family life at Hampstead Theatre

fields.headline: Twisted family life at Hampstead Theatre
fields.standfirst:
Buried Alive
Hampstead Theatre
London
**
fields.trailText:
Buried Alive
Hampstead Theatre
London
**
fields.body:
"Only connect", wrote EM Forster. And in Buried Alive Philip Osment seeks to forge connections between past and present, domestic tragedy and professional ethics. But while Osment, as evinced by his earlier plays such The Dearly Beloved and Flesh and Blood, writes excellently about family life, I here found myself doubting the assumed links between private and public worlds.

Osment's play takes the form of a detective story. The black, ambitious Ammy is writing a newspaper profile of Stewart, a reclusive, award-winning photo-journalist hiding away in Suffolk with his teenage Brazilian son. Sensing something murky in Stewart's past, Ammy pursues her investigations to his native Edinburgh, where she just happens to be giving a talk on the portrayal in the media of developing countries. Through flashbacks to the late 1970s and Stewart's home life with his two sisters, ferociously religious mother and supposedly mad dad we gradually discover the nature of the private tragedy that has determined Stewart's career.

And there's the rub. Osment provides a chillingly plausible account of a puritanical Scottish matriarchy where all pleasure is punished and where daughter Kate is locked in a cellar once it is discovered she is pregnant; Veronica Roberts is particularly good as the vindictive mother who brandishes a semen-stained towel in front of her teenage son.

What I find facile is Osment's assumption that Stewart's obsession with third-world victims is shaped by the disaster that has overtaken his family. I suspect people become photo-journalists for many reasons: curiosity, ambition, altruism, an appetite for danger. There is something reductive about the idea that they are simply working out their problems by identifying with their subjects. And even the extract we hear from Ammy's Edinburgh lecture, arguing that images of suffering are absorbed by a consumerist culture, never asks the obvious question: isn't all information a source of light and hasn't tyranny, in Europe as well as in developing countries, been exposed by the probing lens of the camera?

I wouldn't deny that Osment writes well about family cruelties or that Mike Alfreds's production is acted with scrupulous truth. Paul Higgins as the haunted photographer, Jane Arnfield and Louise Bush as his sisters, John Ramm as their abusive uncle and Michelle Joseph as the journalist are all first-rate. But to suggest, as Osment does, that public postures are the result of private derangements is to fall for the oldest of reactionary canards.

 Until May 19. Box office: 020-7722 9301.

webTitle: Pop: Steve Marriott lives again

fields.headline: Steve Marriott lives again
fields.standfirst:
Steve Marriott Memorial
Astoria
London
***
fields.trailText:
Steve Marriott Memorial
Astoria
London
***
fields.body:
Steve Marriott's virtual beatification following his death 10 years ago this month obscured the sad fact that the former child actor had spent the last 20 years of his life playing clodhopping pub rock to uninterested London drinkers and fronting such barely roadworthy vehicles as Packet of Three.

Now, thanks to the ministrations of Small Faces aficionados Paul Weller and Noel Gallagher, Marriott is once more capable of selling out the Astoria - this time, from beyond the grave - to an audience of elderly mods and skinheads.

Like Marriott's career itself, his memorial event - various worthies covering songs he had written or performed - was a curate's egg. Phase one involved a house band featuring Foreigner's Rick Wills (a Small Face during their mid-1970s reunion), a flop-haired Zak Starkey and a succession of vocalists of varying quality, as if it were a pub-rock open mic night in 1972.

Simon Hickling was lively on Big Train; Debbie Bonham screechy on I Can't Stand the Rain; Nine Below Zero's Dennis Greaves feisty on Whatcha Gonna Do About It and Love Affair's Steve Ellis excellent on My Way of Giving.

Phase two meant the re-formation of Humble Pie, Marriott and Peter Frampton's early-1970s band. Their plodding boogie was ignored in Britain then and, as if to revisit the past authentically, the crowd ignored it now, although the band seemed to enjoy themselves, jamming to eternity on I Don't Need No Doctor. Midge Ure emerged to jeers, bravely strummed My Mind's Eye solo and left to cheers.

Finally, a reminder of just how vital Marriott could be: Weller, Gallagher, plus original Small Faces Ian McLagan and Kenney Jones. While hardly the most vital live performers of their respective generations, Weller and Gallagher injected star quality into Become Like You, I'm Only Dreaming, Here Come the Nice, and Tin Soldier. They resolutely refused to jam and gave more than they took before the entire cast joined in on All or Nothing, Marriott's only British chart topper.

"If Steve had been here tonight, he'd have been very proud," one of the early singers had declared. If Steve had been here tonight, he'd have been bored, appalled and, at the end, thrilled.

webTitle: Debt taskforce targets credit cards

fields.headline: Debt taskforce targets credit cards
fields.standfirst:
Interest rate clarity and marketing curbs sought

Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: Clearer notification of credit card rates and a clampdown on certain types of marketing are understood to be among the recommendations of a taskforce set up by consumer affairs minister Kim Howells.
fields.body:
Clearer notification of credit card rates and a clampdown on certain types of marketing are understood to be among the recommendations of a taskforce set up by consumer affairs minister Kim Howells.

A full-scale review of the Consumer Credit Act is expected to be implemented by the Department of Trade and Industry following recommendations by the taskforce, which was set up last year to consider "indebtedness" and any steps the financial industry might take to help prevent consumer debt spiralling out of control.

The so-called debt taskforce, which recently held its last meeting, is understood to have recommended that financial firms make the interest rates on their credit cards easier to understand and compare with other card providers. When offers of market-beating rates expire, companies should contact the cardholder and inform them of the new rates.

The taskforce, set up last October and including representatives of a wide range of industries, is thought to have suggested that further research needs to be carried out to analyse the nature of debt and how much it affects people.

Among the concerns expressed in the report is the way companies use advertis ing and mailshots to offer deals such as immediate £10,000 credit limits. This type of marketing could entice some customers to get into debt, the taskforce believes.

The report also highlights store cards, and says financial firms might find it difficult to gauge the level of potential customers' debt because they could hold an array of different store cards.

The taskforce is thought to have concluded that a review of the Consumer Credit Act may be necessary. This is the act which lays out the rules for any loans under £25,000.

When Dr Howells set up the taskforce last year three parameters were set: improving transparency of information provided to consumers, adopting principles of lending, and giving clearer notification to consumers on low-interest agreements.

The taskforce is thought to have suggested that banks and other financial firms providing credit should not just rely on traditional scoring techniques such as scrutinising postcodes or previous addresses. However, this may cause some concerns for financial firms. The DTI refused to comment on the taskforce's report, which had been scheduled for publication this week but is now thought to have been knocked off course by the election.

The National Consumer Council, which did not sit on the taskforce, said: "One of the reasons behind indebtedness is that people are not sure what they are letting themselves in for. If they get more useful information they won't fall foul of the small print."
