webTitle: Flexitime

fields.headline: Your flexible friends
fields.standfirst:
Don't you long to work the hours that suit you? The problem, says Elizabeth Cripps, is selling the idea to your boss

Guardian Unlimited Work
fields.trailText: Don't you long to work the hours that suit you? The problem, says Elizabeth Cripps, is selling the idea to your boss.
fields.body:
You get up at 6am to iron clothes, feed the dog, dress the children, do the school run and make yourself at least vaguely presentable before leaving for work. But you know you are never going to be all that presentable when you are breakfasting on Danish pastries and coffee from Victoria Station, and have permanent bags under your eyes from getting up at such an ungodly hour every morning.

You then fight your way into work on the bus/tube/train/roads, just as everyone else in the UK is trying to get there, work your allotted eight, nine or however many hours, and battle your way home, exhausted.

Or, scenario two: you rock into the office at 10.30am, allowing yourself plenty of time to sleep off a hangover, and sampling blissfully empty public transport en route. OK, so you work late that night, but miss the rush hour. Plus you can have the next afternoon off to compensate, providing a welcome chance catch up on sleep, hit the shops, have a haircut, or just get a bit of extra time to yourself.

So far, so appealing. It is hardly surprising that research by public relations house Edelman has found that four-fifths of senior and middle managers and administrators regard flexible working as important to them.

The survey, based on interviews with PR and dot.com company staff, also found that a hefty 66% of people enjoy a flexible working arrangement with their employer.

Unfortunately, this does not carry across the board. For men, the figure is 81%; for women, only 52%. Similarly, men are more confident that their company has reacted well to the concept. And, while 25% of senior management believe that their employers have a specific working policy, only 8% of admin staff agree.

Paradoxically, it is women - and mothers in particular - who are generally agreed to benefit most when flexible working hours are successfully introduced. Almost half the respondents also said that fathers could profit.

That's not to say that flexible working, or flexitime, doesn't have its advantages for the young and single. Anyone who has had to leave the house at 7.30am after a heavy night out can testify to its advantages. Edelman is adamant that workers and companies alike need to stop seeing it as "a stereotypical benefit for women and people with children".

Ellie Perris, who works for a large financial company, is long accustomed to the plus side of adjusting her hours to suit other commitments. "I think it is good because it makes the working day less restrictive," she says. "There is time to fit in things such as doctors appointments. And if you have a high workload one day, you can sometimes take days off to make up for it."

From a company point of view, it might be a little harder to sell. Less than half the workers interviewed by Edelman think that flexible working would improve business processes, and only 3% think it benefits the company or employer. Inadequate staffing at some hours, abuse by staff of the new environment and decline in employee communications were raised as potential problems.

Even Perris, whose employer's flexitime policy is very much in her interest, is awake to its disadvantages. "I'm always sitting there trying to make up the hours to get another day off," she admits. "It can be more time-oriented than job oriented."

There are advantages. Flexitime can extend a company's operating hours, improve staff morale and staff retention and reduce tardiness. (If you can turn up whenever, you can never be late.) It is a low-cost way of keeping employees happy and, in the long run, that might have to be the deciding factor. Like massages at the desk, bumper bonuses and gym-membership, the top companies will have to offer flexitime to attract the best employees. Next stop the two-day week?

webTitle: Commentary: Global business too important to be left to business people

fields.headline: Global business too important to be left to business people
fields.trailText: Global business needs to be regulated to work in the interests of people, especially poor people. The British government, together with officials in the World Trade Organisation and business itself, fail to understand this.
fields.body:
Just as war is too important to be left to generals, business is too important to be left to chief executives. Global business needs to be regulated to work in the interests of people, especially poor people. The British government, together with officials in the World Trade Organisation and business itself, fail to understand this.

Underlying three current, headline-making stories - the price of Aids drugs in developing countries, child slavery in West Africa and foreign oil companies' investments in Tibet and Sudan - is the same question: how to make business work for rather than against the poor.

This is the question that the WTO has been set up to avoid. Regulation of business is not on the agenda of its next major meeting, in November. Neither is it on the British government's agenda. Instead, the government puts its faith in companies adopting voluntary codes of conduct. But, left to their own devices, companies are simply profit-generating machines. Often, only government action or intense public pressure make big business change behaviour. Indeed, it is only the international campaign against the pharmaceutical companies that has forced them to offer drugs to developing countries at lower prices.

But the governments of wealthy countries, while prescribing an economic medicine for the world, often called "liberalisation", are, in fact, more interested in promoting protectionism for their own companies. The patenting laws surrounding the scandal of Aids treatments - enabling companies to secure monopoly rights over life-saving drugs - are a case of massive corporate protectionism at the expense of the poor.

Those governments, including Britain's, also seek to reshape WTO rules to enable their companies to break into developing world markets previously denied to them. The developing countries themselves are pressed to eliminate trade barriers, which can lead to local producers being undermined by cheaper imports.

Developing countries are also being pressed to accord the same treatment - in trade, investment and procurement - to multinational companies as to domestic firms. Such "equal treatment" in WTO parlance really means favoured treatment for multinationals. A recent report by Unctad, the UN's trade body, showed that foreign investment can have a positive impact on the poor only if it is regulated. If it is not, foreign investment tends to drive out local investors.

Many successful development policies pursued in the past are now illegal under WTO rules. Global rules need to be flexible enough to allow the governments of poorer countries, in dire need of development, powers to regulate the activities of foreign companies. But, as the UN's Development Programme has said, business "needs to be brought within the frame of global governance, not just the patchwork of national laws, rules and regulations". Christian Aid would like to see the introduction of a global regulation authority to monitor and report on global business activities, give voice to communities affected by those activities, and to provide an enforcement mechanism. This would ensure that business is no longer beyond the law and complies with international human rights standards.

 Mark Curtis is head of policy at Christian Aid
fields.bodyText: Just as war is too important to be left to generals, business is too important to be left to chief executives. Global business needs to be regulated to work in the interests of people, especially poor people. The British government, together with officials in the World Trade Organisation and business itself, fail to understand this. Underlying three current, headline-making stories - the price of Aids drugs in developing countries, child slavery in West Africa and foreign oil companies' investments in Tibet and Sudan - is the same question: how to make business work for rather than against the poor. This is the question that the WTO has been set up to avoid. Regulation of business is not on the agenda of its next major meeting, in November. Neither is it on the British government's agenda. Instead, the government puts its faith in companies adopting voluntary codes of conduct. But, left to their own devices, companies are simply profit-generating machines. Often, only government action or intense public pressure make big business change behaviour. Indeed, it is only the international campaign against the pharmaceutical companies that has forced them to offer drugs to developing countries at lower prices. But the governments of wealthy countries, while prescribing an economic medicine for the world, often called "liberalisation", are, in fact, more interested in promoting protectionism for their own companies. The patenting laws surrounding the scandal of Aids treatments - enabling companies to secure monopoly rights over life-saving drugs - are a case of massive corporate protectionism at the expense of the poor. Those governments, including Britain's, also seek to reshape WTO rules to enable their companies to break into developing world markets previously denied to them. The developing countries themselves are pressed to eliminate trade barriers, which can lead to local producers being undermined by cheaper imports. Developing countries are also being pressed to accord the same treatment - in trade, investment and procurement - to multinational companies as to domestic firms. Such "equal treatment" in WTO parlance really means favoured treatment for multinationals. A recent report by Unctad, the UN's trade body, showed that foreign investment can have a positive impact on the poor only if it is regulated. If it is not, foreign investment tends to drive out local investors. Many successful development policies pursued in the past are now illegal under WTO rules. Global rules need to be flexible enough to allow the governments of poorer countries, in dire need of development, powers to regulate the activities of foreign companies. But, as the UN's Development Programme has said, business "needs to be brought within the frame of global governance, not just the patchwork of national laws, rules and regulations". Christian Aid would like to see the introduction of a global regulation authority to monitor and report on global business activities, give voice to communities affected by those activities, and to provide an enforcement mechanism. This would ensure that business is no longer beyond the law and complies with international human rights standards.  Mark Curtis is head of policy at Christian Aid

webTitle: Steer clear of the milkman

fields.headline: Steer clear of the milkman
fields.trailText: Summer is almost here and the sun may be shining most mornings. But I find myself waking up with a big, black cloud hanging over me - the threat of relegation. It is a problem I try to rectify during most of my working hours - and a lot of the rest of my time, too. I read with great interest Gordon Strachan's column last week about the stress of being the manager of a struggling team, and what it can do to you.
fields.body:
Summer is almost here and the sun may be shining most mornings. But I find myself waking up with a big, black cloud hanging over me - the threat of relegation. It is a problem I try to rectify during most of my working hours - and a lot of the rest of my time, too. I read with great interest Gordon Strachan's column last week about the stress of being the manager of a struggling team, and what it can do to you.

My milkman is a big Palace fan, and I regularly bump into him when I am taking our dogs for a walk in the morn ing. We can have a good chat about things at the club most of the time, but now we are struggling against relegation my instinct is to try to avoid him. It is the same on a wider social level. You are disinclined to go out so much in the local area because you are bound to come across supporters who want to know what is going on at the club.

If you are seen to be enjoying yourself, they say you don't really care about the situation, and if you look too worried, the word gets around that you are terminally depressed. It is very difficult for your family and friends. My wife and sons come to all our games, and it is not nice for them to hear some of the abuse I get. I can understand the fans expressing their displeasure at the manager, with whom the buck always stops. They are paying to watch what they hope will be an entertaining and successful side, and at the moment we are neither. And there are always 15,000 people who think they can do your job better than you can. What many don't realise is that every defeat hurts me as much if not more than anyone else. The amount of time and effort you invest in the club as manager is enormous.

As a coach you really only have to deal with the football side of things. But as manager, there are so many administrative aspects that make impossible demands on your time. I never envisaged, when I took over last summer, that I would spend whole days at the FA's offices arguing about disciplinary matters, as I have done. The four hours I spent there this week could have been better used on the training ground, which is where I am happiest and most useful. Another inherent problem for managers is that clubs need to make long-term plans but managers are rarely able to do that. With the average 'lifespan' of two-and-half years at any club, it is extremely difficult for a manager to work to a five-year plan as most good businesses do.

This season, after a dreadful start, we started to play well, reached the semi-final of the Worthington Cup beating good Premiership opposition and got into the top half of the table. But now we are in the rele gation zone, and we all know how critical the situation is. When you are under the threat of relegation, people react differently. Some players think there are plenty of other clubs waiting to snap them up if we go down, others who have just arrived might be in the process of moving house, while the younger players might think they will get more of a chance if we were to go down. We have had a lot of meetings, both collectively and individually, between players and staff. It is my job to make sure their thoughts are channelled towards the good of the team.

Without a stable home life and strong support from my wife, I would find it very hard to cope. Being a manager is essentially a lonely job, an insecure position and is getting harder and harder. It does make you wonder why we do it. Answers on a postcard please.

webTitle: Hoddle sets five-year goal

fields.headline: Hoddle sets five-year goal
fields.trailText: Glenn Hoddle has admitted he will have failed in his task at Tottenham if he has not got the club into the Champions League within five years.
fields.body:
Glenn Hoddle has admitted he will have failed in his task at Tottenham if he has not got the club into the Champions League within five years.

But he also believes he has inherited a better group of players than he did at Chelsea eight years ago, when he started the west London club's transformation from underachievers to Champions League contenders

As Tottenham take on Liverpool at Anfield today, Hoddle says that his target is to get the north London side back among English football's elite. 'Things aren't easy for us at the moment because of injuries, but they will improve,' he said. 'The major thing for me is that this is my club. It's close to my heart because I've been a fan since I was eight. I played here for so many years and had some tremendous times so there's an added feeling that's going to drive me on more than in any of my other jobs

'We've a new manager and new owners and things are changing. There's a plan here and it will be achieved. That's an important point to get across to players who are here and want to be involved - and to players who can see that vision from the outside and want to be part of it as well. This is a massive challenge, and one that's going to be really worthwhile trying to overcome.

'I'm confident it can happen and if we haven't qualified for the Champions League by the end of five years then I'd say that I would have failed.' And Hoddle feels the potential at White Hart Lane is greater than it was at Stamford Bridge when he moved there from Swindon in 1993.

'I feel I'm higher up the ladder already than I was when I took over at Chelsea considering the players I had available to me then. If we get everyone fit and bring in some players over the summer then we can take it on. At Chelsea we reached the FA Cup final in my first season and the European Cup Winners Cup semi-final the following year, and that was with a very limited squad. This squad is better - no doubt about it - and it gives me a lot of encouragement.

'The vision is there for the longer term rather than straight away. But there is a long-term plan and we will achieve it.'

Hoddle hopes that his own memories of a rare Tottenham victory at Anfield in 1985 will help his patched-up side overcome their nerves.

'That was a very significant game in my career,' he said. 'We hadn't won at Anfield since the year the Titanic sunk, but that game proved to me that the game is played mentally. We cracked it. Garth Crooks scored and we played really well and won 1-0 with a terrific side.

'After waiting so long for that, we went there the year after and won again. Suddenly we had two wins at Anfield. It shows the psychological part of the game is so powerful. Hopefully these young players can learn from it as well.'

webTitle: Said & Done

fields.headline: Said & Done
fields.trailText: Saints: London calling
fields.body:
Saints: London calling

Which London gaffer is set to give up his dream of European football and take up a job closer to his South Coast home? According to the football grapevine, West Ham boss Harry Redknapp believes he can't take the club any further, is fed up with losing big-name players, and is ready to throw it all in for a new life with Southampton - just 30 miles from his home in Bournemouth. If it happens, you read it here first. If not, you read it in The Sun .

'Content' Nic sets it straight

Nicolas Anelka - PSG's £22m disaster whose lack of goals has sent them crashing down the French league - has told the club, desperately trying to offload him to Chelsea, that he is 'content to stay'. The striker, scorer of eight goals this season (one for every £2.75m), told the club his plans last week. 'I am in Paris because it is my choice. When I returned to PSG, I thought that people would see me as a good footballer who has returned to the Parisian suburbs after three years away. If they had thought, as they should, that I have come back to my home, that would have been cool. But the reception has been different and I am whistled at. I cannot shake this reputation off.' So now Nic's come up with a way of countering his desolate, isolated, journalist-slapping, fan-slagging adolescent image: 'Every time we lose, I am the only one to take the responsibility,' Nic reasons. 'So I stay at home instead.'

Ecuador: pick fattie or sleep with fishes

Ecuador's successful U-20 coach has fled the country after claiming he was beaten up for refusing to pick the 'lunatic' former president's overweight son. The attack happened after the coach, Hugo Gallego, got out of a taxi in Guayaquil, and followed weeks of pressure to pick hefty utility player Dalo Bucaram. 'I'm convinced that this was a warning and that tomorrow or the day after tomorrow there will be another,' Gallego said from his bolthole in Medellin, Colombia - where Andres Escobar was shot dead in 1994. 'They were always insisting that I put this guy in the team. He is intelligent but has an excess of fat.' Bucaram's sinister dad Abadala - nicknamed 'the crazy one' - was sacked by Congress in 1997 on grounds of 'mental incapacity', then released a rock CD and burst into tears live on national television. Now, though, he says he wants a second crack at the presidency, and to see his son make a first-team breakthrough. Gallego plans to stay holed up in Medellin. 'I'm not afraid of death but I'm not going to go looking for it either,' he said. 'My family asked me not to go back because they want a live man, not a dead leader.'

When the seagulls...

Eric Cantona, Tuesday

'Since they [United] are going to score, they are going to win. Once they score, they will win. They will go through, I know it.'

Mombassa: Players mug ref

The Kenyan Football Federation's Mombasa branch has launched an urgent investigation after a referee was beaten up and robbed by players during a match last week. The ref, Aggrey Obwaka, was attacked by Nyali players and officials after failing to award a penalty: they stole his wristwatch, 3,000 shillings and tried to tear off his shirt and shorts. Players' cards and the team lists also disappeared after the game making it impossible for Obwaka to file an accurate report. 'I have never been beaten like this before,' said a wide-eyed Obwaka when it was all over, 'especially when I have done completely nothing to deserve it.'

Quote of the week

Clive Tyldesley, ITV commentator in Munich, with 93 minutes, 28 seconds on the clock:

'They're not going to do it, are they Ron?'

Said & Done: david.hills@observer.co.uk

And the rest...

webTitle: Tales from the Tabs

fields.headline: Tales from the Tabs
fields.trailText: £30m VIEIRA WILL GO
fields.body:
£30m VIEIRA WILL GO

Patrick Vieira will join Inter Milan in the summer in a massive cash plus player deal: they'll offer Clarence Seedorf, Hakan Suker or Francisco Farinos. 'I have a contract at Arsenal until 2004' says Vieira. 'But anything is possible in football'.

£40,000-A-WEEK TEDDY

Glenn Hoddle is ready to tempt Teddy Sheringham to London with a stunning £40,000-a-week three-year deal: the contract would keep him at Spurs until he's 38: 'There are a lot of things to consider', says Teddy. 'I want to sort it out as soon as possible'.

Arsène Wenger has drawn up a secret Arsenal summer shopping list: 'We have players in mind but it would be wrong to speak of them now.' Wenger wants defenders - which could mean exits for Matthew Upson and Igor Stepanovs, and will re-sign Emmanuel Petit. Bradford have offered £500,000 for Mechelen striker Joris van Hout: 'I need some more time to think it through,' says the forward.  Charlton are ready to open contract talks with Shaun Newton.  Dennis Wise says Chelsea should show some ambition and sign Rivaldo: 'I dream of seeing him playing alongside Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink and Gianfranco Zola'.  Coventry chairman Bryan Richardson has denied leading the race for Brighton striker Bobby Zamora: 'We already have John Hartson, Jay Bothroyd, John Aloisi and so on, so it would not be something that we are looking at'.  Derby's Horacio Carbonari will open contract talks this week.  West Ham are still planning to sign Everton flop Stephen Hughes on a free.  Chelsea's Eidur Gudjohnsen is a £4m target for Ipswich : Gudjohnsen wants regular first team football.  Leeds have played down reports of an imminent move for Sol Campbell: 'We have made no transfer plans for the close season apart from the Robbie Keane deal with Inter Milan' says Peter Ridsdale. 'David and I will sit down and discuss what we want to do'.  Peter Taylor has slammed reports that Leicester will lose Robbie Savage and Matt Elliott this summer: 'It's all rubbish. There is no way I would sell Robbie to Real Betis - there is no chance I would let him go'.  Liverpool are leading Newcastle, Rangers, Chelsea and Arsenal in the race to land Barca star Josep Guardiola.  Man City's streakers have been banned from Maine Road for life.  Manchester United have made Newcastle's Kieron Dyer and Argentinian ace Riquelme top summer targets: Riquelme would cost £17m. A fee for Ruud van Nistelrooy should be agreed this week.  Middlesbrough in ageing-foreign-millionaire shocker: they've targetted Rangers defender Lorenzo Amoruso.  Newcastle are considering a double raid on PSV: Bobby Robson wants defender Yuri Nikiforov and midfielder Mark Van Bommel.  Southampton are ready to step up interest in Egyptian star Ahmed Hossam.  Sunderland plan to wrap up a deal for Argentinian wonderteen Nicolas Medina this week.  Spurs are chasing Man United's £8m-rated Nicky Butt.  West Ham striker Frédéric Kanouté is an £11m target for Juventus and Arsenal.

webTitle: Susannah Clapp: Time to shake up the National Theatre

fields.headline: It's time for the National Theatre to be shaken up - and stirred
fields.standfirst: More Observer Theatre coverage
fields.trailText: Susannah Clapp: Anyone who wants the National to seize this chance for overdue change must want Stephen Daldry to succeed Trevor Nunn.
fields.body:
It's a long time since anyone felt the shock of the new at the National Theatre. With this week's announcement that Trevor Nunn won't be seeking reappointment as director, there's a chance for change. And anyone who wants the theatre to be shaken up and stirring must want Stephen Daldry to succeed Nunn.

It's Daldry's across-the-board talents as director, producer and entrepreneur which make him the most inspiring choice. At the Royal Court he brought in a wave of young writers and pushed through the reinvention of the old Sloane Square building. His expressionist An Inspector Calls made a National and West End triumph out of a fusty old war-horse. Even the obstacles in his path can look like assets. Last time round, the story goes, Daldry blew his chances of running the National when he confronted Tony Blair at a dinner party with the question of socialism.

Guts and diversity have been missing from the National over the last three years. There have been glorious evenings, almost all provided by Nunn's brilliance as a director of plays. But the lack of fresh directors and writers has been lamentable. And there's an even more fundamental problem: a failure to acknowledge the different kinds of theatre which are making waves.

At a time when the stage is being swept by other disciplines, the National has remained rigidly text-based. Where are the dance dramas? Where's the devised work? Where's the mixing of video and theatre craft? Where are the weird, imaginative puppets which are stalking other stages? Where are the promenade performances which bring actors and audiences into a different relationship?

Why was it left to the Tricycle to initiate important debate about the Stephen Lawrence inquiry? Why, when the National was once his plaything, did David Hare go to the Royal Court with his illuminating first-hand descriptions of the Middle East? Why was it left to the tiny Bridewell to show, in Floyd Collins, that the words 'blue-grass' and 'musical' could beautifully cohabit?

No one wants the National to stop doing what it does really well. No one wants to surrender the chance of seeing Simon Russell Beale as Hamlet. But the theatre can include circus arts as well as Bulwer-Lytton. And the National is the place where its range should be proved. There's little point in having three auditoria if they're used to stage the same kind of drama.

The composition of the National's Board - three knights (including the chairman, Christopher Hogg); one CBE (Joan Bakewell); one OBE (Sue MacGregor); and two writers (Ben Okri and Tom Stoppard) may be a symptom rather than a cause of staidness, but any incoming director should consider giving it a shake. That's all fine, but where are the younger writers or directors who might supply intelligence about other young talents? Perhaps Zadie Smith would gag at the idea of being on the board: if so, the National should ask itself why. Where are the links with bright organisations, such as BAC, that could be feeding administrative as well as artistic talent?

They might be forged by Jonathan Kent and Ian McDiarmid, who have created what amounts to an alternative national theatre at the Almeida, or by the gifted Michael Grandage at Sheffield. fields.bodyText: It's a long time since anyone felt the shock of the new at the National Theatre. With this week's announcement that Trevor Nunn won't be seeking reappointment as director, there's a chance for change. And anyone who wants the theatre to be shaken up and stirring must want Stephen Daldry to succeed Nunn. It's Daldry's across-the-board talents as director, producer and entrepreneur which make him the most inspiring choice. At the Royal Court he brought in a wave of young writers and pushed through the reinvention of the old Sloane Square building. His expressionist An Inspector Calls made a National and West End triumph out of a fusty old war-horse. Even the obstacles in his path can look like assets. Last time round, the story goes, Daldry blew his chances of running the National when he confronted Tony Blair at a dinner party with the question of socialism. Guts and diversity have been missing from the National over the last three years. There have been glorious evenings, almost all provided by Nunn's brilliance as a director of plays. But the lack of fresh directors and writers has been lamentable. And there's an even more fundamental problem: a failure to acknowledge the different kinds of theatre which are making waves. At a time when the stage is being swept by other disciplines, the National has remained rigidly text-based. Where are the dance dramas? Where's the devised work? Where's the mixing of video and theatre craft? Where are the weird, imaginative puppets which are stalking other stages? Where are the promenade performances which bring actors and audiences into a different relationship? Why was it left to the Tricycle to initiate important debate about the Stephen Lawrence inquiry? Why, when the National was once his plaything, did David Hare go to the Royal Court with his illuminating first-hand descriptions of the Middle East? webTitle: Yugoslav court martial reveals Serb war crime

fields.headline: Yugoslav court martial reveals Serb war crime
fields.standfirst: Comment: France's role in a Bosnian massacre
fields.trailText: Evidence has emerged that the Yugoslav army deployed a unit for burning bodies of Albanians murdered during the Kosovo war
fields.body:
Evidence that the Yugoslav army deployed a unit for burning bodies and erasing any trace of Albanians murdered during the war in Kosovo has emerged from the unlikeliest of places - a Yugoslav court martial trying three of its own soldiers.

The existence of the 'trace-erasing' unit, testified by five soldier witnesses, is proof the army covered up war crimes.

The disclosure comes three years after The Observer first reported evidence from refugees that bodies of massacred Albanians were burnt in furnaces in the Trepca mining complex. Forensic scientists working for the war crimes tribunal at The Hague have identified grave sites containing around 4,000 corpses, but 3,000 bodies have never been found - their traces have been erased.

One Yugoslav Special Forces paramilitary who had been at a massacre site in South-western Kosovo said: 'I saw some terrible things, but I am not going to tell you because I do not want to betray my fellow Serbs.'

The court martial in Nis found two soldiers and an officer guilty of murdering an elderly Albanian couple, the critical evidence coming from four soldiers and the war diary of army reservist Nebojsa Dimitrijevic, which said 'two people were cleansed'.

During the trial, chaired by military judge Radenko Miladinovic - a Milosevic-era appointee, who was on Europe's list of banned Yugoslavs for jailing a journalist - it emerged that Dimitrijevic and other witnesses were members of the 'trace-erasing unit'. In Dimitrijevic's pre-trial statement, he said the unit in Gornja Susica, near Pristina, included 'a subdivision tasked with body removal and burning up the remains'.

The murders took place in the aftermath of the Nato attack on Yugoslavia. Reservists in War Unit 5778, based in the Serb town of Gracanica, south-east of Pristina, fled Nato bombs on 27 March 1999, after two soldiers died and seven were injured. They were ordered to occupy two Albanian villages, Saskovac and Gornja Susica, and to 'cleanse' the inhabitants.

Feriz Krasniqi stood in his front garden and told the advancing soldiers that his wife, Rukija, was paralysed and unable to leave her bed.

Captain Dragisa Petrovic, angered by the old Albanian's refusal to budge, ordered soldiers Nenad Stamenkovic, Tomica Jovic and Dimitrijevic to kill them. Dimitrijevic aimed his gun at Krasniqi but couldn't pull the trigger. At that moment, Jovic fired a burst and killed Krasniqi. Sta menkovic went into the house and shot the wife.

The trace-erasing unit was part of the battalion stationed in Gornja Susica, commanded by a Lt Stojiljkovic. He told the court that when he came to the village, he found Krasniqi's body and ordered two soldiers to bury it. Another three bodies were found later.

Dimitrijevic was in a group of soldiers charged with burning remains. Svemir Mladenovic and Bratislav Zdravkovic said Petrovic had ordered them to dig up a carbonised body and rebury it.

Jovic and Stamenkovic were sentenced to four and a half years each for the murders, and Petrovic four and a half years for abetting them. The judge said the sentences had been light so the men could 'be with their families'.

 John Sweeney is a special correspondent for BBC Five Live.

webTitle: Quick escapes

fields.headline: Quick escapes
fields.standfirst: This week's top recommendations from Travel Editor Jeannette Hyde
fields.trailText: This week's top recommendations from Travel Editor Jeannette Hyde.
fields.body:
Under £200

Canada: Fly to Toronto with Canadian Affair (020 7616 9999) on 28 April from Gatwick for £169 - with return travel by 11 May.

Britain: Take a break in the country at the Waterhead Hotel in Coniston (01539 441244) or the Friars Carse Country House Hotel (01387 740388) for £22.50 per person per night, B&B, until the end of May. The hotels will donate £1 for every night booked to the National Farmers' Union.

Holland: See springtime in Holland before 24 May on a two-night break in Delft with Motours (01892 686666) for £116, including return ferry crossing with car and breakfast. In addition to the flowers at Keukenhof Gardens, visitors can explore historic Delft, famous for its blue and white pottery.

Greece: Stay in a traditional Greek stone cottage (with modern conveniences) in the woods on Paxos, the smallest of the Ionian islands. Seven nights' self-catering from 4 May costs £150 for two with www.villadeals.com. Flights are not included.

Under £300

Ibiza: Go clubbing for two weeks in Ibiza from 27 May with Cosmos (0870 908 4299), staying in self-catering accommodation and departing from Gatwick for £219.

Croatia: Online Travel Company is offering seven nights B&B at the four-star Albatross Hotel in the resort of Cavtat, south Croatia, for £279, departing between 29 April and 12 May, including flights and taxes. Hotel facilities include a fitness centre and tennis courts.

Leipzig Spend a weekend break in Bach's home town with Moswin's Germany (0116 271 9922) for £209 per person including flights, rail transfers and three-star accommodation with breakfast. The breaks take advantage of scheduled departures from Stansted to Berlin's third airport of Schonefeld - 90 minutes by train from Leipzig.

Under £400

France Go to France for spring walks before the end of May along the River Seine, from Caudbec to La Bouille with Belle France (01797 223777), which charges £369 for five night's half-board, on a self-drive basis. Guests follow an easy route, covering between 11 and 14 miles each day, and luggage is transferred to the next hotel stop.

Florida DIY USA with seven nights' accommodation in self-catering apartments for a party of four departing before 30 June at £315 through direct sell specialist Bon Voyage (0800 316 0194). The 'Palm at Shorewalk' apartments are close to Sarasota and the beaches of Longboat Key and Anna Maria Island. Flights are not included.

Singapore Shop until you drop at Singapore's annual shopping festival from 25 May to 8 July. Trailfinders (020 7938 3939) has flight-only fares including taxes for £376 for bookings made by 31 May.

Under £500

Antigua: Head to the Caribbean for five nights (accommodation only) in Antigua for £495 with www.ebookers.com, for travel 16 May-3 July. Must be booked by 12 May.

Cannes: Go celebrity spotting at the end of the Cannes Film Festival, sailing in on a five-night fly-cruise with Orient Lines (020 7959 5900) for £499 per person sharing an inside cabin. The cruise sails from Civitavecchia 17 May and calls at Livorno, Portofino, Cannes, Palma and Barcelona.

Los Angeles: Visit America's home of the stars with Distant Dreams (0870 241 2400) for seven nights' room-only accommodation in downtown LA, with departures on United Airlines from Heathrow on 10 May for £499.

Egypt: Go diving in Dahab with Longwood Holidays (020 8551 4494) for seven nights B&B departing 10 May from Gatwick. The price includes a five-day dive package of 10 dives with tanks, weights and air.

Under £600

Mediterranean: Take a cruise from Genoa to Naples, Malta, Bizerta (Tunis), Mahon (Menorca), Barcelona and Marseille for £545 for seven nights from 6 May with Festival Cruises (020 7734 0005). Prices are based on two sharing an inside cabin, with return flights from London - the airport depends on availability at the time of booking.

Australia: Austravel (020 7734 7755) has flights to Sydney from Heathrow for £531 with Korean Air, including taxes, before 15 June. Travel must be booked by 30 April.

Under £700

Bali: Bask in Bali for 12 nights at the four-star Aston Bali Hotel for £699 per person from 1 May to 30 June. The price, available through Worldwide Journeys (020 7388 6000), includes return flights with Garuda from Gatwick, transfers and B&B accommodation.

webTitle: Majorca is the very latest thing

fields.headline: Majorca is the very latest thing
fields.standfirst: Charters delayed to Balearics more than any other destination
fields.trailText: Charters delayed to Balearics more than any other destination.
fields.body:
If you're planning on flying to Majorca this summer then be prepared for a long wait. Holidaymakers are more likely to face flight delays when travelling to the Balearic island than to any other destination.

Figures released by the Civil Aviation Authority showed more than half of all charter flights to Majorca, the most popular holiday destination for UK tourists, were delayed between October and December compared with 43 per cent the previous year. The average length of delay also increased from 28 minutes to 50 minutes.

It's the same story in the peak holiday period, with 55 per cent of Majorca-bound charter flights delayed last summer, up from 48 per cent the previous year. And Simon Evans, spokesman for the industry watchdog Air Transport Users' Council (AUC), predicts it's going to get worse. 'There is little airlines can do to alleviate the problem. All the charter aircraft fly in on the same day so even big airports like Palma (Majorca) struggle to cope with the influx,' he said.

Other troublespots pointed out by the CAA included winter sun destinations such as Malaga (average delay of 35 minutes) and the Canary Islands of Las Palmas (38 minutes) and Tenerife (34 minutes).

Evans said the figures also hid some very severe delays on certain flights. 'A good proportion of those flights were on time so there must have been some really horrible delays,' he said.

Overall, the average delay for charter passengers increased from eight to 37 minutes between October and December last year. The increase was particularly high at Luton (12 minutes), Manchester (11 minutes), Gatwick and Newcastle (nine minutes). An aircraft is classified as late if it reaches the terminal more than 15 minutes after it's due.

Passengers on scheduled flights did not fare well either - the average delay rose by four minutes to 16 minutes. The deterioration was widespread, with scheduled services at all airports experiencing an increase in the length of the average delay. Travellers heading for Paris Charles De Gaulle were delayed for an average of 21 minutes while Dublin-bound passengers were forced to wait an average of 18 minutes.

webTitle: Ask the experts

fields.headline: Ask the experts
fields.trailText: Sailing by cargo ship | The pilgrim trail | Lowdown on Libya
fields.body:
Sailing by cargo ship

Do cargo boats take passengers as used to be the case? Where can I find out more?
J. Tomlinson, Lancs

Freighters still visit almost every destination you could imagine, and many of these vessels take a limited number of passengers. These services are good value, but only in comparison to taking a cruise. Typically you'll pay about £85-£100 for each day of your voyage.

Transatlantic voyages take about seven days without stops, while going all the way to Australia takes about 45 days, depending on route and ports of call.

Facilities are functional, but seeing life on a commercial ship can be lots of fun and an unusual travel experience.

Contact Strand Voyages (020 7836 6363) for more information or The Cruise People, a travel agency which specialises in booking passengers onto cargo ships, (020 7723 2450). Other useful websites: www.atwtraveler.com and www.geocities.com/freighterman.geo

The pilgrim trail

I'd like to walk part of the Camino de Santiago this summer. Is it going to be too hot and crowded? Also, can you suggest some good accommodation options in Santiago.
Jim Wiseman, by email

The popular pilgrim trail runs 1,180 miles west from St Jean Pied de Port in France to Santiago de Compostela in Galicia where the remains of St James were discovered in the ninth century.

The walk is almost unbearably hot and crowded in July and August. The best time to do it is May to June, when you can walk through stunning fields of wildflowers.

The Confraternity of Saint James (020 7403 4500) produces a series of guides for pilgrims as well as general information.

Once you've finished being awestruck by Santiago's stunning cathedral and impressive architecture, you may wish to reward your weary legs with a splurge on a hotel. The Hotel Real (00 34 981 56 92 90, fax 00 34 981 56 92 91) has everything you need for a good night's sleep, for around £39 a double. Alternatively you can splash out on the Hotel de los Reyes Catolicos (00 34 981 58 22 00, fax 00 34 981 59 02 87), situated in a Renaissance building built during the reign of Fernando and Isabella. Doubles fit for a king cost £105.

Lowdown on Libya

Is it possible to take a ferry to Libya from the south of Italy. Also do you know the entry requirements for a British national for Libya?
Richard Weetman, by email

The only direct sea route to Libya runs from Valletta in Malta. It currently isn't running, but Sea Malta (00 356 2322 30) will be the booking agent if and when it starts again. From Genoa (summer only) and Trapani in Sicily weekly services run to Tunis - you can travel overland to Libya from there.

Visas for British nationals cost £22 and are valid for 90 days. Independent travellers will find it hard to get a visa, as you need to travel in a group and require an invitation from an individual or business in Libya. The Visa Section of the Libyan People's Bureau in London (020 7589 6120) will have details. Most UK travellers visit with companies such as the Imaginative Traveller (020 8742 8612) and Cox & Kings (020 7873 5000).

Opera in Budapest

We will be visiting Budapest this autumn and would like to obtain tickets in advance for the State Opera House. Can we book direct or are there UK agencies that handle bookings?
Margaret Mowatt by email

A visit to the State Opera House is a must. Buy tickets in advance through the Interticket Agency in Budapest. A reputable agency, they accept credit-card bookings for a variety of events including theatre, classical music and Grand Prix. The office is open from 9am until 8pm and can be called on 00361 266 0000. Email: interticket@interticket.hu. You should get excellent seats for under £10.

 Our experts Tom Hall and Rachel Suddart will try to reply to as many of your questions as possible. Email us at travel.tips@observer.co.uk or write to Escape, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER.

webTitle: Get your kit on

fields.headline: Get your kit on
fields.standfirst: Pocket Gym
fields.trailText: Pocket Gym.
fields.body:
If you are looking for something more strenuous than a stroll up the airplane aisle or quick toe wiggle to keep the circulation going on long-haul flights, then look no further than the new Pocket Gym Lite, which at just 5 kg will slip into your travel bag and only take a fraction of your carry-on allowance.This versatile little exercise bar can be put to good use to encourage blood circulation in the legs and discourage the formation of potentially deadly blood clots.

Mind you don't elbow your neighbour when you're doing the pectoral press. And be prepared for the stewardesses to raise their plucked eyebrows if you move into the aisle to try the rest of the 30 exercises listed with the gym. For a tougher workout,there's also a sturdier Pocket Gym original, at 11 kg, offering a choice of resistance levels.

Available by calling 0800 072 0898 (www.pocket-gym.com) the Pocket Gym Lite costs £17.95 and the original Pocket Gym costs £39.95.

webTitle: Gunners nark Nyarko

fields.headline: Gunners nark Nyarko
fields.trailText: Normal service resumed at Highbury as Arsenal confirmed their ambition to finish as Premiership runners-up against an Everton side so uncompetitive they can have no complaints about finding themselves back in relegation trouble.
fields.body:
Normal service resumed at Highbury as Arsenal confirmed their ambition to finish as Premiership runners-up against an Everton side so uncompetitive they can have no complaints about finding themselves back in relegation trouble.

Walter Smith's side, like Middlesbrough before them, came to Highbury as rank outsiders. But they showed none of the ambition that helped Boro to a shock victory last week as they often lined up with 10 men behind the ball and only Kevin Campbell as an attacking outlet.

Arsenal, still subdued by the Boro blow and an even mightier Champions League thwack from Valencia in midweek, gratefully accepted the long spells of possession handed them by Everton's tactics and were good value for a 21st-minute lead.

Thierry Henry, Robert Pires and Ashley Cole had all enjoyed success of a sort attacking the right side of Everton's defence, and that is the route they took again to score. Henry slipped a low pass into the area and Freddie Ljungberg struck a first-time left-foot shot squirting into the net off the underside of keeper Paul Gerrard, caught out by the swiftness of the Swede's decision to shoot.

There had been something unconvincing about Arsenal, though. They seemed battle-weary and their concentration slipped when they allowed Everton to equalise swiftly.

Thomas Gravesen, who had earlier gone close from 20 yards, skilfully scooped the ball over both Tony Adams and Ashley Cole, taking the Arsenal defenders out of the game, to where Campbell stood unmarked 10 yards out. His shot was superbly beaten down by David Seaman, but Everton's leading goalscorer raised his season's tally to a modest total of eight by driving in the rebound.

Everton noticeably took confidence from their goal and looked more competitive. Arsenal, however, still had all the attacking ambition and - unlike their opponents - were never going to settle for a point. They deservedly regained the lead, 10 minutes into the second half, when Gilles Grimandi marked his return to the side by heading in a Robert Pires corner from the edge of the six-yard box.

No comeback, but abject capitulation was Everton's response this time and Sylvain Wiltord finished them off with Arsenal's third goal, in the 67th minute, with a 20-yard shot off the underside of the crossbar. It was all too much for an Everton fan who ran on to the pitch and tried to hand Alex Nyarko his shirt. The Ghanaian international responded by appearing to demand to be substituted. His wish was granted a few minutes later. Worse was to come. Half an hour after the game Nyarko emerged from the dressing room to announce his 'retirement' at 27 - explaining his tormentor from the terraces had troubled him before.

Abel Xavier was no more impressive when he clattered into Ashley Cole to earn a second yellow card and an 80th-minute sending-off - and the Everton defence seemed to suffer a collective fit of narcolepsy as they dozed while Henry danced past Gerrad to score Arsenal's fourth with three minutes to go.

webTitle: Belgian car train to the rescue

fields.headline: Belgian car train to the rescue
fields.trailText: British travellers dismayed at Rail Europe's decision to axe Motorail services into Italy can find another route this summer via Belgian Railways.
fields.body:
British travellers dismayed at Rail Europe's decision to axe Motorail services into Italy can find another route this summer via Belgian Railways.

Car-carrying services to Milan, Venice, Bologna, Rimini, Livorno and Rome will run from June to September from Denderleeuw in Belgium, which is about 90 minutes' drive from the French ports and the Channel Tunnel and about an hour from Ostend. Belgian Railways offers a variety of sleeping accommodation for parties of up to six people, without the need to share a compartment with others. A dining car is available on most services and an attendant will turn your compartment seats into beds.

A mid-season return for two with car including a two-berth sleeper costs £557 to Milan and £794 to Livorno. Similar prices are available for four people sharing a couchette.

Belgian Railways also runs extensive services into France, Switzerland and Austria and has cut some of its fares by as much as 40 per cent this year. A car and six adults in a couchette one-way to St Maurice, Switzerland, is from £230, or a car and two adults in a sleeper one-way to Frejus, near Cannes, from £228.

Contact Belgian National Railways, 200 Blackfriars Foundry, 156 Blackfriars Road, London SE1 8EN. Tel: 0207 593 2332.

webTitle: How to get a job abroad

fields.headline: How to get a job abroad
fields.trailText: Tips on how to find yourself work abroad while you're on your year out
fields.body:
1 Start early. Prince William's work in Chile has highlighted to parents the benefits of packing their children off for a gap year or the summer. So if you want to get beyond Ramsgate, you should be making those job applications, visa requests and agency enrolments now.

2 Consider voluntary work if you have not been abroad before or are feeling nervous about the experience. 'It's a bit of a cocooned environment,' says David Woodworth, editor of Summer Jobs Abroad 2001 (£9.99, Vacation Work Publications, www.vacationwork.co.uk). You will probably get a lot of help with the paperwork, have your accommodation arranged for you, be met at the airport and be working with other English speakers. Contact details of Willing Workers on Organic Farms and other organisations are available in books such as Summer Jobs Abroad 2001.

3 Recognise that tourism and agriculture are the biggest recruiters of seasonal summer jobs. Tour guides, catering staff and chambermaids are recruited in large numbers - and then there are the more demanding roles such as karaoke night organisers in Greece and disc jockeys on cruise ships.

4 Understand that France is probably the easiest EU country to find work in. Used to Britons coming over for camping holidays, for instance, it needs English-speaking staff to cater for these tourists. It is also a good place for novice travellers to spend their first summer - since it will not take you long to return home for a weekend if you are homesick.

5 Think of gaining a job on the spot if you leave it too late and can cope with the possibility that you will not find something. Building sites are an obvious source of work for men.

6 Remember that, if you are applying in advance, you probably make yourself more attractive if you can work the whole season. The internet is making it far easier to send CVs to businesses abroad.

7 Appreciate the advantages of a summer on a turtle conservation project in Greece. 'It stands out on your CV and is far better than being captain of the school hockey team,' says Woodworth. 'It shows that you have stamina and can organise yourself.' Living abroad changes most people - making them more confident, less dependent on families and more broad-minded. Most people who want a post abroad should be able to get one if they try hard enough.

webTitle: Island living casts its spell

fields.headline: Island living casts its spell
fields.standfirst: Barbara Gunnell  enjoys a diet of wine, swimming and song on a new 'restoration' holiday to the island of Zakynthos
fields.trailText: Barbara Gunnell enjoys a diet of wine, swimming and song on a new 'restoration' holiday to the island of Zakynthos
fields.body:
Greek islands always reward you with unexpected enchantment. I first went to Zakynthos on a cheap last-minute deal. After I'd booked, friends told me that the island was notorious for its all-night discos, but the rugged beauty of Zakynthos was not hard to find. It is around every corner, minutes from the tourist apartments and lodgings. Accept that the island's beaches and small seaside towns belong to the clubbers and walk just a kilometre along the coast or inland and you find lush green olive groves, mountain villages and wooded hillsides, isolated rocky shores and sparkling seascapes.

The second time I went to Zakynthos - for a rest and relaxation holiday at a private club - all these delights were there in abundance and not a hotel or disco in sight. The Peligoni Club nestles into a rocky hillside in the north-east of the island and is as far as you can get geographically and spiritually from the over-development of the south. The stone clubhouse and vine-shaded terraces barely impact on the natural uninhabited surroundings. There are a cluster of buildings and patios, a couple of diving platforms and a stepladder to take you straight from rocks to sea plus a concrete apron for windsurfers and sailors. Within a short drive, and similarly secluded and peaceful, are the apartments, villas and stone cottages where Peligoni guests sleep, have breakfast and can, if they feel particularly antisocial, laze about all day. Some of the villas have pools.

Vanessa and Johnny, who run the Peligoni Club, discovered the bay some 20 years ago. They liked it so much they bought a small house - and then another, and another. Friends came and sailed and painted and told more friends. Now they can accommodate 60 or more people and still maintain a personal welcome for each guest.

If you went and did nothing but eat wonderfully prepared fresh food, swim and drink the local wine, after a week you would probably come back fully restored from almost every modern anxiety. But for those who prefer to take their relaxation in more structured form, Peligoni has started offering 'restoration holidays', relieving you even of the worry of how to relax.

This year, they will be held in June and September, when the weather is at its most benign and the hillsides are carpeted with wild flowers. These are the island's natural relaxants but they will be supplemented with stress management, meditation and yoga. Optional extras include massage, lymph drainage and reflexology.

The days fell into an easy routine with the group (around a dozen) meeting for joint activities in the cooler mornings followed by a trip and lunch. One memorable lunch was taken at a taverna inland where owner Costas invited us after the meal into a tiny living room and sang a song of such haunting beauty that I would go back again just to hear him. Vanessa and Johnny are well known and loved around the island and their presence opens doors into worlds that most tourists never see. Afternoons were generally free for sailing or windsurfing (at no extra cost), dozing or reading followed by a rest and a shower and then a long dinner at the club. This was always outdoors, and could be peaceful or raucous depending on the mood of different groups and the amount of wine being drunk.

I was not too sure about some of the organised relaxation activities. What, I thought, was the point of closing my eyes and imagining a Disney landscape of mountains and waterfalls when my open eyes could engage with the most beautiful natural landscape in the Ionian Sea? None the less, being with the group was tremendous fun and our childish lack of reverence for some elements of the programme - some of us found pagan sun worship outside a Greek Orthodox monastery a little absurd - surely did us as much good as meditating. Laughter is very restorative.

Homer mentions Zakynthos, calling it the 'woody island' and notes in the Iliad that its men were among the crew of Odysseus's twelve crimson-prowed ships. The tourist board claims Homer also said that all who come to the island fall under its spell. The lack of building on the shore line in the north makes it easy to indulge in Odyssey fantasies if you take a boat or kayak out into the bay. Odysseus's tomb is said to be on neighbouring Cephalonia, of which we will soon be hearing much when Captain Corelli's Mandolin is released early next month.

Holidays offering, yoga, meditation and promising to change lives have become increasingly popular in recent years but they are a hit and miss affair depending on the set-up and the attitudes of your fellow-seekers after enlightenment. If you want an intensive yoga holiday or to entrust your psyche to a guru, then Peligoni is probably not for you.

But if you want an informal mix of swimming, good food, good company and a bit of meditating mixed with sailing, massage and the odd evening of raucous singing, it could be just the place to unwind. And whether or not Homer said it, the island will surely cast a spell over you.

Fact file

Dates: Peligoni holidays run from Thursday to Thursday. Restoration weeks begin 7 and 14 Jun, 13 and 20 Sept.

Painting holidays begin 10 and 17 May; 7 and 14 June; 6, 13, 20 and 27 Sept.

Price: £455 pp per week excluding flights and drinks but including all meals, guided day trip, transport on island including use of shared cars, single accommodation (£25 reduction for sharing) and use of all club facilities including sailing and windsurfing instruction.

Contact: Tarific Holidays, PO Box 88, Chichester, Sussex PO 20 7DP. Tel 01243 511499, fax 01243 513132

webTitle: Been there, run that... got the blisters

fields.headline: Been there, run that... got the blisters
fields.standfirst: Missed out on the London Marathon? There are plenty more races around the world to join in.  Martin Love  saw the sights of Paris the hard way when he entered its 'grand course'
fields.trailText: Missed out on the London Marathon? There are plenty more races around the world to join in. Martin Love saw the sights of Paris the hard way when he entered its 'grand course'
fields.body:
Whether it's historic churches, out of the way bistros or good, old-fashioned sun, sea and sand, most holidays are all about the pursuit of pleasure. Pain, discomfort and exhaustion don't normally feature high on our happy-holiday must-have list. Unless you choose to spend your vacation running a marathon, which is what my friend Alan, his brother Robert and I chose to do with our early Easter break.

A fortnight ago, the twenty-fifth Paris marathon got under way on a cold and drizzly Sunday morning. Miserable weather for most holidaymakers, but we and our 27,000 fellow runners couldn't have hoped for better conditions for our tortuous tour of Paris. Unlike the London marathon, which shamefacedly unwinds itself around mean little suburban roads, the Paris race is a celebration of the French capital. Starting down the Champs Elysées towards the Place de la Concorde, the Obelisk and the millennium wheel, the route follows the city's broad boulevards to the Bois de Vincennes, meanders back along the Seine, through the shadows of Notre Dame and past the Eiffel Tower before finishing in a glorious burst up Avenue Foch to the Arc de Triomphe.

We arrived the day before the race - having narrowly avoided missing our connection from Waterloo when the train flouted rolling-stock convention and left early, not late. Needless to say, it still managed to arrive behind schedule. We bookedin to a hotel near the Gare du Nord, where the manager was very excited about our participation in ' la grande course'. In French that even we could understand, he urged us to ' Courez vite'.

Having unpacked (our luggage seemed to be made up almost entirely of breathable undergarments, elastic knee supports, plasters and various lubricants), we headed off to find an Italian restaurant where we could load up on pasta - all marathon runners 'carb up' before a big race as the event consumes carbohydrates quicker than seven-year-olds eat Smarties. It was a 'dry' meal as runners have to avoid the dehydrating effects of alcohol and caffeine. This put us in the possibly unique position of being three lads on holiday in a foreign capital, strolling around the streets looking for entertainment... completely sober. I told you marathon running was fun.

We soon headed back to our room to do what all runners do before a race: compare treads on trainers, discuss whether we should run in vests or T-shirts (hilariously, I had written 'Keep up, Alan' on the back of mine) and make puerile jokes about Vaseline. Robert then showed off the talking photobox his wife and kids had given him which shouted 'Go Robert Go!' when you pushed a button, and Alan put the good-luck card his family had made for him on the mantelpiece. I saw my wife's handwriting on a folded note in the bottom of my bag. Discovering it was just an old shopping list, I had to make do with the hotel cleaner's cry of ' Bonne chance' as we left.

Standing beneath the Arc de Triomphe waiting for the starter's pistol, we anxiously ate as many bananas and Jelly Babies as we could stomach. (Alan assured us the glycogen content of the sweets makes them the ideal athletic snack, though none of us could recall seeing Linford Christie downing any before his races.) We soaked up the glorious multicultural camaraderie that every marathon conjures up and tried to ignore the smell of several thousand digestive systems nervously working overtime. Robert told us that we should try to imagine we were fully loaded Jumbos sitting on the runway and that as we flew round the course we'd get lighter and lighter. Alan and I weren't quite sure what he was getting at, and decided to try and mentally visualise ourselves successfully finishing the race instead. We soon stopped when we realised that even imagining a marathon was gruelling.

The first Paris marathon took place in 1896 and was won by an Englishman, Len Hurst, who stopped a few miles before the finish to down a glass of champagne and then crossed the line six minutes ahead of his nearest rival. Who knows, maybe this would be our year. Either way, we felt confident we'd do better than the seven runners who from some misplaced sense of history had chosen to run barefoot.

At 9am, we get under way and all along the route crowds gather to cheer us on. Our ears ring with cries of ' Allez, allez, allez'. We have our names written on our T-shirts and people step out to shout ' Bon courage, Martin ' and ' Bonne chance, Alan'. We feel both heroic and glamorous, something none of us has ever felt before. Bands play, an all-male cheerleading troupe lifts our spirits and a lone piper almost makes me burst into tears. At one point I discard an empty water bottle into the path of a fellow runner. ' Pardon, monsieur,' trips off my tongue. 'That's all right mate,' comes the reply. With six miles to go, we pass a feeding station where they are handing out glasses of red wine. Not sharing the same joie de vivre as our Gallic competitors, we wimp out and go for sickly energy boosters instead.

With only a couple of miles to go, I feel I can't take another step, but a comradely hand on the shoulder and grip on my elbow from a nameless fellow runner keeps me plodding on and somehow seems to sum up the genuine bonhomie that binds all the competitors.

The race's winner is the Kenyan Simon Biwott, who pipped me at the line by a mere 83 minutes. I'd finished in a personal best of 3 hours 32 minutes. Having collected our medals and rewarded ourselves with the first beer in a week, we make our way back to the Gare du Nord and the train home. The race may have lasted only a few hours, but the memories of our marathon weekend will stay with me for a lifetime.

Leaders of the pack... 10 of the most unusual big races on the planet

The oldest: In its 106th year, the Boston Marathon is the father of city races. You must be able to run a 3hr 10 min race to enter.

The most dangerous: You could bump into rhinos, cheetahs and leopards on the Safari Marathon in Kenya. Runners are protected by game wardens patrolling the route.

The easiest: You don't get much flatter than the Dutch city of Rotterdam, but it's not a complete walk-over. Last year running times were marred by a force four wind.

The biggest: About 30,000 runners are taking part in today's 21st London Marathon.

The most scenic: Some 3,700 steps have to be climbed during the The Great Wall Marathon. Part of the run is on the wall itself.

The hardest: Participants in the Marathon des Sables have to cross 150 miles of the Sahara in Morocco, carrying all their food and gear. It takes a week.

The highest: Four of the world's five highest mountains can be seen during the five-day 100-mile Himalayan Stage Race.

The most northerly: The Midnight Sun Marathon is run at night in Tromso, Norway, where the sun doesn't set from May to July.

Chicago Marathon (7 Oct) package includes three nights' accommodation in four-star hotel, flights with Virgin Atlantic, airport transfers and guaranteed race entries, from £884 twin-share

fields.bodyText: Whether it's historic churches, out of the way bistros or good, old-fashioned sun, sea and sand, most holidays are all about the pursuit of pleasure. Pain, discomfort and exhaustion don't normally feature high on our happy-holiday must-have list. Unless you choose to spend your vacation running a marathon, which is what my friend Alan, his brother Robert and I chose to do with our early Easter break. A fortnight ago, the twenty-fifth Paris marathon got under way on a cold and drizzly Sunday morning. Miserable weather for most holidaymakers, but we and our 27,000 fellow runners couldn't have hoped for better conditions for our tortuous tour of Paris. Unlike the London marathon, which shamefacedly unwinds itself around mean little suburban roads, the Paris race is a celebration of the French capital. Starting down the Champs Elysées towards the Place de la Concorde, the Obelisk and the millennium wheel, the route follows the city's broad boulevards to the Bois de Vincennes, meanders back along the Seine, through the shadows of Notre Dame and past the Eiffel Tower before finishing in a glorious burst up Avenue Foch to the Arc de Triomphe. We arrived the day before the race - having narrowly avoided missing our connection from Waterloo when the train flouted rolling-stock convention and left early, not late. Needless to say, it still managed to arrive behind schedule. We bookedin to a hotel near the Gare du Nord, where the manager was very excited about our participation in ' la grande course'. In French that even we could understand, he urged us to ' Courez vite'. Having unpacked (our luggage seemed to be made up almost entirely of breathable undergarments, elastic knee supports, plasters and various lubricants), we headed off to find an Italian restaurant where we could load up on pasta - all marathon runners 'carb up' before a big race as the event consumes carbohydrates quicker than seven-year-olds eat Smarties. It was a 'dry' meal as runners have to avoid the dehydrating effects of alcohol and caffeine. This put us in the possibly unique position of being three lads on holiday in a foreign capital, strolling around the streets looking for entertainment... completely sober. I told you marathon running was fun. We soon headed back to our room to do what all runners do before a race: compare treads on trainers, discuss whether we should run in vests or T-shirts (hilariously, I had written 'Keep up, Alan' on the back of mine) and make puerile jokes about Vaseline. Robert then showed off the talking photobox his wife and kids had given him which shouted 'Go Robert Go!' when you pushed a button, and Alan put the good-luck card his family had made for him on the mantelpiece. I saw my wife's handwriting on a folded note in the bottom of my bag. Discovering it was just an old shopping list, I had to make do with the hotel cleaner's cry of ' Bonne chance' as we left. Standing beneath the Arc de Triomphe waiting for the starter's pistol, we anxiously ate as many bananas and Jelly Babies as we could stomach. (Alan assured us the glycogen content of the sweets makes them the ideal athletic snack, though none of us could recall seeing Linford Christie downing any before his races.) We soaked up the glorious multicultural camaraderie that every marathon conjures up and tried to ignore the smell of several thousand digestive systems nervously working overtime. Robert told us that we should try to imagine we were fully loaded Jumbos sitting on the runway and that as we flew round the course we'd get lighter and lighter. Alan and I weren't quite sure what he was getting at, and decided to try and mentally visualise ourselves successfully finishing the race instead. We soon stopped when we realised that even imagining a marathon was gruelling. The first Paris marathon took place in 1896 and was won by an Englishman, Len Hurst, who stopped a few miles before the finish to down a glass of champagne and then crossed the line six minutes ahead of his nearest rival. Who knows, maybe this would be our year. Either way, we felt confident we'd do better than the seven runners who from some misplaced sense of history had chosen to run barefoot. At 9am, we get under way and all along the route crowds gather to cheer us on. Our ears ring with cries of ' Allez, allez, allez'. We have our names written on our T-shirts and people step out to shout ' Bon courage, Martin ' and ' Bonne chance, Alan'. We feel both heroic and glamorous, something none of us has ever felt before. Bands play, an all-male cheerleading troupe lifts our spirits and a lone piper almost makes me burst into tears. At one point I discard an empty water bottle into the path of a fellow runner. ' Pardon, monsieur,' trips off my tongue. 'That's all right mate,' comes the reply. With six miles to go, we pass a feeding station where they are handing out glasses of red wine. Not sharing the same joie de vivre as our Gallic competitors, we wimp out and go for sickly energy boosters instead. With only a couple of miles to go, I feel I can't take another step, but a comradely hand on the shoulder and grip on my elbow from a nameless fellow runner keeps me plodding on and somehow seems to sum up the genuine bonhomie that binds all the competitors. The race's winner is the Kenyan Simon Biwott, who pipped me at the line by a mere 83 minutes. I'd finished in a personal best of 3 hours 32 minutes. Having collected our medals and rewarded ourselves with the first beer in a week, we make our way back to the Gare du Nord and the train home. The race may have lasted only a few hours, but the memories of our marathon weekend will stay with me for a lifetime. Leaders of the pack... 10 of the most unusual big races on the planet The oldest: In its 106th year, the Boston Marathon is the father of city races. You must be able to run a 3hr 10 min race to enter. The most dangerous: You could bump into rhinos, cheetahs and leopards on the Safari Marathon in Kenya. Runners are protected by game wardens patrolling the route. The easiest: You don't get much flatter than the Dutch city of Rotterdam, but it's not a complete walk-over. Last year running times were marred by a force four wind. The biggest: About 30,000 runners are taking part in today's 21st London Marathon. The most scenic: Some 3,700 steps have to be climbed during the The Great Wall Marathon. Part of the run is on the wall itself. The hardest: Participants in the Marathon des Sables have to cross 150 miles of the Sahara in Morocco, carrying all their food and gear. It takes a week.
