It is in a far-from-affluent housing estate but does not have a high percentage of children with special needs which might affect its scores. If there are children particularly difficult to teach will that mean my relatively bright son will be ignored? The report is dated from 1999; are things better or worse now? A visit does not help - what head is going to say: 'Yes, this is a terrible school, I just can't get the staff, we have no parental input, the governors are just ambitious councillors who want to have an extra string to their bow on paper and frankly I'm just hanging on till retirement.' Appeal to a popular, oversubscribed school and immediately there is the brick wall of the Government's statutory class sizes - no more than 30. Parental choice? This is a parental con. LEAs across the country are in the process of being inundated with appeals. The number of appeals are expected to be more than double the 1998 total of 53,400 which was in turn 4 per cent up on 1997 with 38 per cent proving successful. Our first choice was a school where some of my son's friends from nursery school have places and in which other friends already attend. The school is within walking distance, a boon for his health, for the health of other children who will have one less car at the school gates encouraging the rising asthma rates, and for the council which actively backs the Government's policy of trying to end the environmental problems of the school car run. The closest school is a few minutes' walk but it is a Church of England school and as an atheist they don't want me, nor am I keen on school time being taken up by spiritual indoctrination. Conditioned to believe that education, education, education, is what it is all about, now we have expectation, expectation, expectation. We have agreed to pay the taxes, are happy to see the money being ploughed in to schools but we are also deeply selfish when it comes to our own. No parent wants their child to go in at the sharp end in an improving school rather than at the comfortable end in an already achieving school. Secretary of State for Education David Blunkett may dismiss such concerns as middle-class angst but everything is in place to encourage parents from all walks of life to believe that a good school equals success, fulfilment and achieving true potential. A bad school equals failure, unhappiness, bullying, poor teaching and, no doubt, glue-sniffing. Guilt, worry and trepidation is already a parental lot and the muddle that is schools admissions does little to alleviate that. I have been rejected for jobs, rejected by men and failed my driving test three times, and none of it compares to feeling my child has been rejected from the education I want for him.

webTitle: 'I lived with pain for no reason'

fields.headline: 'I lost my job. I lived with pain. And it was all for no reason'
fields.standfirst:
Jean Brett underwent eye surgery for a disease she didn't have. Her fight for justice has cost £30,000 and exposed failings in the way the NHS handles complaints.
The NHS debate - Observer special
fields.trailText: Jean Brett underwent eye surgery for a disease she didn't have. Her fight for justice has cost £30,000 and exposed failings in the way the NHS handles complaints.
fields.body:
Jean Brett was a buoyant, confident woman with a career in teaching when she was diagnosed with glaucoma by her ophthalmologist in 1985. Stunned, she was told it was an incurable condition leading to weakening or a complete loss of sight.

Mrs Brett was prescribed eye drops which, she says, caused such a severe and persistent reaction that she was forced to take early retirement three years later at the age of 52. She subsequently underwent an operation on her right eye at Watford General Hospital, performed by her consultant.

The eye haemorrhaged. It now has a pronounced droop and continues to cause pain. 'I had become a shadow of my former self,' Brett recalled last week.

In 1992, she was told an operation would also be required on her left eye. Mrs Brett insisted upon a second opinion. At Moorfields Eye Hospital in London, she learnt that not only was the operation unnecessary, she had never had glaucoma.

'I didn't know whether to hug the consultants or scream,' she said.' 'I'd given up a job I loved and lived for years with pain only to learn I had done so for no good reason.'

Mrs Brett attended a follow-up appointment at Watford General Hospital. What she sought, she says, was an explanation. 'I had been diagnosed and treated for seven years for something I'd never had. I also wanted an apology and a way of establishing whether anybody else might also have been similarly misdiagnosed.'

But nine years later, after spending £30,000 of her own money in legal fees and in spite of the intervention of the Ombudsman, two MPs, one Minister, Hillingdon Community Health Council and an independent conciliator, her case is unresolved.

Roxanne Glick, the conciliator appointed by what is now, after several mergers, the West Herts Hospital Trust, published her investigation into the Brett case in 1999. She described the Trust's politicking and prevarication as 'astounding' and 'wholly unprofessional'. Two years on, none of her recommendations have been properly implemented.

Glick said last week: 'Mrs Brett is entitled to a large amount of money but won't receive it. The Trust gave me access on what had become a very complicated case. It knew exactly what to expect in my final report. Mrs Brett had been wrongly diagnosed. She was forced to go down a route which has caused her and her family a huge amount of stress. Sadly, her case is not an isolated one.'

The NHS complaints procedure has become notorious for its inability to deliver adequate redress. A recent report into children's heart services at the Royal Brompton and Harefield Hospitals in London found what it called a 'serious breakdown in com munication and trust' between parents and some doctors.

Last year, Professor Liam Donaldson, the Chief Medical Officer, criticised a 'blame culture' within the NHS and a reluctance to learn from failure. Inquiries into recent scandals have failed to end the system of professional self- regulation. Nevertheless, transparency, accountability and respect for the rights and views of the patient are supposed to be the markers of a new era in the NHS.

On Tuesday, the Health and Social Care Bill reaches its report stage in the Lords. It aims to give patients better access to justice. Critics, among them David Hinchliffe, the Labour MP for Wakefield and chair of the Commons Health Committee, have called it unnecessarily complex, confusing and a 'dog's breakfast'.

In 1999, the then Health Secretary Frank Dobson described the system as 'a shambles'. In the same year, a legal charity, the Public Law Project published its own damning evaluation, referring to 'serious failings'.

Linda Mulcahy, who co-wrote the report, said: 'Complaints are constantly referred back so individuals find themselves in a Kafkaesque loop where nothing is ever resolved and complaints disappear into a black hole.'

Last year, the Government commissioned its own evaluation of the complaints procedure. The report has been repeatedly delayed. Critics, such as Arnold Simanowitz of Action for Victims of Medical Accidents, are concerned its proposals will continue to leave too much power in the hands of medical and managerial professionals. 'The cost to individuals and to public confidence in the NHS will be huge,' said Simanowitz.

Jean Brett's case is a reminder that the solitary patient continues to face enormous difficulties in achieving justice.

In 1985, Mrs Brett, from Rickmansworth in Hertfordshire, visited an optician, Anthony Gasson, for new glasses. He advised her to see an opthalmologist and suggested Roger Pearce. Unusually, Gasson referred her directly without going through her GP. She visited Pearce privately to avoid NHS delays.

In November 1988, when Pearce suggested her right eye required an operation, Mrs Brett said she would prefer to become an NHS patient and seek a second opinion. She was admitted to Watford General but did not see another consultant. Pearce performed the operation in March 1989. Before surgery, a registrar conducted a single set of tests, diagnosing glaucoma. Mrs Brett should have received three sets of tests.

Three years later, in 1992, she decided to stop using Pilocarpine, eye drops prescribed by Pearce. She had suffered from debilitating headaches and conjunctivitis. Pearce told staff that she would go blind without medication. He also advised a second operation on her left eye. Eight months later, Jean Brett learnt from a consultant at Moorfields that she had never had glaucoma. She demanded answers.

Dominic Wright, the Trust's surgical care manager asked her to complain formally so the hospital could investigate. She was told the procedure would take two months. In June 1993, the Trust instructed her to seek legal advice.

Reluctantly, she consulted solicitors. They told her the legal route would be costly, difficult and there was a strong chance she would be 'timed out' - failing to reach a conclusion within three years. She said: 'I decided it was the principle that mattered so I cashed in some policies. I was anxious that others, who also might have been misdiagnosed with glaucoma, would never learn the truth unless there was a review of Pearce's cases.'

The Glick Report shows how the months disappeared in a way common to many complaints. In a taped interview, Pearce admitted that his report on the case, dated 29 November 1992, had not in fact been given to the Trust until 1995, when Mrs Brett- now £30,000 poorer - was duly timed out. 'Had I not kept meticulous records, I would have been made out to be a stranger to the truth by Stephen Ramsden [the Trust's then chief executive of the Trust] who already had a tremendous psychological and practical advantage over me because of his position and the fact that he did not have to pay his own solicitor's bills. If it has been difficult for me, what it must it be like for those who are old or poorer or less able to cope?' said Mrs Brett.

In April 1996, the present NHS complaints procedure was introduced. It established three steps - local resolution; an independent review panel (IRP) and, finally, referral to the Ombudsman. Mrs Brett applied for an IRP in which the panel would receive evidence; ask questions and issue a report containing facts and recommendations.

A panel was eventually set up in July 1996 to examine the case. Its convener, Lady Mary Auld, was also a non-executive director of West Herts Trust. After it reported, Mrs Brett rejected the findings on the grounds that it had evaded the main grievance of mistreatment.

The Health Service Ombudsman upheld the charge and asked the panel to make clear its findings. He also declared much of the case out of time, since he is only able to consider clinical cases after 1996. Undaunted, Jean Brett continued her quest for the truth.

Finally, in 1998, five years after her original complaint, the Trust's chief executive admitted in a letter that it was 'a matter of regret' that she had been both misdiagnosed and mistreated. There was no explanation, no apology, no compensation and no review of her consultant's past cases. After pressure from Mrs Brett's MP, Richard Page, the Trust's new chief executive Stephen Eames appointed Glick as a conciliator. Her report was scathing. She said she found it 'beyond comprehension' that the panel had failed to record that Pearce had operated on a healthy eye. Glick declared it 'astounding' that the panel 'did not feel Watford General Hospital had been ineffective'.

Glick recommended the Trust enter into discussions with Mrs Brett, offer compensation, make an unconditional apology and undertake an audit of its ophthalmic department including a review of Pearce's past cases.

Six weeks later, Eames wrote to Mrs Brett offering £3,500 compensation and an apology which was 'conditional on drawing the matter to a complete close'. It also emerged that an 'independent' audit of practice within the Ophthalmology Department would be managed by the Trust's medical director.

Contrary to the directions of Glick's report, the audit only examined the case notes of patients over a period of six months from July 1999. It did not review their original diagnoses. Mrs Brett replied to Eames a week later rejecting the terms and, two years on, is still waiting to hear back. The Trust says it has endeavoured to resolve her complaint and that the audit, which revealed no major irregularities, was conducted according to NHS guidelines. Roger Pearce declined to comment.

Last month, the scale of mistakes within the NHS was indicated by a pilot study in two London hospitals. Extrapolated nationally, 850,000 patients may be victims of error - 70,000 fatal - at a cost to the NHS of £2 billion a year. Some Trusts have become highly proactive, investing in risk management and abandoning strategies based on defensiveness.

Research indicates that only a fraction of medical errors work their way effectively through the present complaints procedure. It also indicates that most patients who have a grievance want a 'soft' resolution - an apology and an assurance that other patients will be better protected.

The Health and Social Care Bill proposes that complaints first be dealt with at a local level by a Patient Advocacy and Liaison Service (Pals), employed by Trusts and far from independent. Autonomous Community Health Councils, which frequently offer advice and support to patients, will be abolished in England; Independent Patient Advocates, vague in detail, will take their place.

David Hinchliffe is far from satisfied. 'It is putting the cart before the horse to alter the existing complaints mechanism before the publication of the Government's evaluation of the system. It also makes a nonsense of the period of consultation which it has promised will follow its own recommendations.'

Susan Polywka of the Clinical Disputes Forum - lawyers, doctors and academics involved in medical negligence issues - which has produced its own suggestions for reforms - said: 'What's required is a simple one-stop shop - an accountable, independent, speedy process in the form of a tribunal, which can bring together investigation and compensation matters.'

For Jean Brett, the options are exhausted. 'Decent people within the NHS have risked their jobs to give me information. It is to maintain that ethos and for the sake of other patients that, even after nine years, I have no choice but to fight on.'

webTitle: The way we are

fields.headline: The way we are
fields.standfirst:
Special report: race in the UK

The way we are
fields.trailText: Statistics: Face of a changing nation.
fields.body:
 According to the last Census in 1991, 5.5 per cent of the British population was from an ethnic minority: 1.5 per cent was Indian, 0.9 per cent Black-Caribbean, 0.9 per cent Pakistani and 0.4 per cent Black African.

 A 1996 Labour Force survey revealed that Black African and Caribbean men had an unemployment rate of 28 per cent, Pakistanis 22 per cent and Indians 12 per cent, while the figure for whites was 10 per cent. Indians on average earned 6 per cent less than whites while the figures for blacks and Pakistanis were 12 per cent and 29 per cent.

 71,000 asylum applications were made in 1999 in the United Kingdom: 9,000 people were allowed to stay in the country and a further 5,000 granted asylum on appeal. In 1998, 19,000 applicants went missing in the UK. Ministers accept that this could rise to 115,000 by 2002.

 The largest proportion of asylum seekers in 1999 were from the former Yugoslavia.

 The UK Indian food industry (supermarket products and restaurants) has an annual turnover of £1.8 billion and employs 60,000 people. There are 9,800 'Indian' restaurants in the UK, 85 per cent of which are run by those of Bangladeshi origin. The British Tourist Authority first refered to curry as the 'national dish' in 1997.

 Half the UK's ethnic minority population lives in the Greater London area, almost 30 per cent of the capital's population.

webTitle: Bloody riots waiting to happen in the ghettos that divide a city

fields.headline: Bloody riots waiting to happen in the ghettos that divide a city
fields.standfirst:
Drugs, gangs and mean streets ... Paul Harris visits the Bradford suburb where Asians rose up in revolt
Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: Drugs, gangs and mean streets ...  Paul Harris visits the Bradford suburb where Asians rose up in revolt.
fields.body:
When he left school at 16, 'Doc' faced a choice his hard-working, Pakistan-born parents never did. He could join the long dole lines, take a poorly paid job - or start dealing drugs.

Doc, who would not give his real name, started selling cocaine and heroin. The easy money and tough image were attractive compared to the jobs his friends had on this poor Bradford estate. Together with three young friends, Doc was soon making up to £2,000 a day. Within months he owned a flashy Subaru car.

After two years, exhausted by the lifestyle and afraid of arrest, he tried to go straight. Now, six months later, Doc is being tempted back to his life of crime. Living on the right side of the law was not easy after he discovered that nothing had changed for a Bradford-born Asian. He still could not get a well-paid job.

'I have tried applying to call centres, everything, but there's not much going and I don't have much of a CV. I'm tempted to go back to selling, but I want to avoid it.'

The riots last week in Bradford's Asian suburb of Lidget Green, where Doc used to deal drugs, have cast a spotlight on British Asian communities in the North of England. Isolated in downtrodden towns where work is scarce, they are finding life increasingly difficult.

Drugs have entered their communities, violent gangs have followed and racism is never far away. They are becoming ghettos. Fears that estates in Bradford and Oldham may become virtual no-go areas for other races, especially whites, could yet become a reality.

Race in Bradford has dramatically shifted from what once was literally a black-and-white issue. Tensions between and within all the communities can run high. One of the shops destroyed during recent riots belonged to prominent Hindu businessman Hasmukh Shah, believed to have been targeted by Muslim youths for his views on Kashmir.

The city is divided by stark borders that mean a few yards can make the dif ference between an area that is 100 per cent white to one that is made up of an ethnic minority.

A fifth of Bradford's population of 500,000 is made up of ethnic minorities. The largest number are the 80,000 Muslims from Pakistan, almost all hailing from the same rural region. There are also 17,000 Indian Hindus and 6,000 Afro-Caribbeans as well as scattered groups of East Europeans, such as Poles and Ukrainians, and asylum-seekers from the former Yugoslavia.

Kamlesh Patel, director of the health and ethnicity unit of Lancaster University, produced a report five years ago that warned of the danger of a heroin epidemic among Asians living in the smaller Northern towns. 'That explosion has now come true,' he said.

It certainly has on the streets of Lidget Green, and no one knows that better than Amraiz Khan, who owns a newsagent's a few hundred yards from where the rioting began. At a phone box within view of his cash till, dealers wait to take orders and make deliveries. 'Hardly half an hour goes by without someone coming to that phone box to start selling,' he said.

In slang terms, most of the dealers on the streets are called 'little fishes'. They work in pairs or threes and take orders on their mobile phones. They hang around phone boxes, taxi ranks, street corners and snooker clubs. They will collect money, make deliveries and have designated patches to sell their wares. In a tight-knit community like Lidget Green everyone knows who to contact to score a hit. It is virtually impossible for an outsider to break in.

Behind the little fish are the drugs bosses - the big fish. Everyone knows who they are but nobody is talking. The silence of some residents is sometimes bought, occasionally with free phone calls to relatives in Pakistan to the tune of several thousand pounds.

In Oldham's Glodwick area the same problem has arisen. Last week young men, decked in gold chains, cruised the streets slowly in fast sports cars, staring at passers-by. The message to outsiders is stay away, the message to addicts: we're open for business.

Taking their fashion cue and slang from the US drug scene, dealers have become a fact of life in some Asian areas. Naveed, 22, has lived all his life in Lidget Green and says: 'Every day I leave my house the dealers are outside. Selling cocaine and heroin has become a trend. It is the "in thing" to do, like wearing stylish clothes.'

Khan, the newsagent, drove round the network of terraced streets and pointed out a pair of 'little fish' on a street corner. A few streets later and two more emerged. None looked older than 18. 'They have little fish every two streets,' Khan said.

For Abdul Mhaeed, 24, the problem goes back 10 years when his local park closed and never reopened. Bored youths took to roaming the streets, the gangs started to form. When the police station closed, it was the final straw. 'No one cares about what is happening around here. It is an Asian area and so they don't see it as their problem,' he said.

Mhaeed faced the same choices as Doc. He, however, chose Islam. It was a difficult decision and one that many of his schoolmates mocked. But though Mhaeed's religion has kept him out of drugs and gangs, it has not freed him or his friends from the racism and poverty of Bradford.

Bradford Council's race panel has commissioned a report into racial attitudes in the city, headed by Sir Herman Ouseley, a former head of the Commission for Racial Equality. The Observer has learnt it will warn of the growing threat of self-segregation, especially among the young. It will paint a picture of a city where there is little social mixing between races. It is a dangerous situation.

'To some extent I was not surprised to see what has happened at Lidget Green. I hope it might be a one-off, but you can never say never when there is this sort of tension,' Ouseley said.

The development of no-go areas could be the next step. A few militant youths in Oldham have already stated that their aim is to keep whites out of their estates. Despite police protests that they will not allow it to occur in Bradford, it could happen. 'It is already starting,' said one source at the race review panel.

Bradford has now suffered three riots since 1999. The slightest spark could set off more disturbances.

At times the divide can look intractable. The race review panel set up an Internet bulletin board for Bradford residents' comments about race relations in the city. There are few messages that don't make unpleasant reading. 'I say let the Asians have Bradford and us whites can move out. I speak to many white people and when I ask them what they think about Bradford they all say "I want to move out to get away from the Pakkies",' stated one.

webTitle: Labour failing to meet pledges on race

fields.headline: Labour failing to meet pledges on race
fields.standfirst:
Fewer black candidates than in 80s, while speeches fuel attacks on refugees

Race in Britain: Observer special
fields.trailText: The Labour Party was last night accused of being 'institutionally racist' after an investigation revealed it will fail to hit its own target on electing black and Asian MPs at the next general election.
fields.body:
The Labour Party was last night accused of being 'institutionally racist' after an investigation revealed it will fail to hit its own target on electing black and Asian MPs at the next general election.

As the row over race intensified yesterday, it emerged that 10 of the 12 new black and Asian candidates who will fight the election in June are in what the party admits are 'hopeless seats'.

Labour is now fielding fewer black and Asian candidates than it did during the 1980s, despite a pledge by Tony Blair in 1997 that the party had to be a 'beacon to the world' and the number of black and Asian MPs should reflect the make-up of Britain.

The embarrassing statistics will intensify the debate over race as Scotland Yard revealed that racist attacks soar each time a politician makes a speech on race or immigration.

Officers in the Race and Violent Crime Task Force, set up after the Stephen Lawrence inquiry, said they were shocked to discover a direct relationship between political rhetoric, such as Tory leader William Hague's 'foreign land' speech, and an increase on attacks on asylum-seekers.

Yesterday the Tories attempted to distance themselves from the compact on racist language put together by the Campaign for Racial Equality. The CRE report says 'racially hostile lan guage' must not be used during the election campaign.

The row over race exploded when Tory MPs claimed the document prevented free speech, and Labour claimed refusal to sign the compact showed the true feeling within the Conservative Party about race.

Hague tried to defuse the row yesterday, saying: 'I did not expect or require all candidates to sign the compact individually, as Michael Portillo made clear on Friday.

'I have instead placed Michael Ancram [the party chairman] in charge of investigating any alleged misconduct [on race].'

On a day when race again dominated the political agenda, critics described the new Labour candidates as 'electoral cannon fodder' to keep up the appearance that progress was being made. They said if Blair's pledge was to be met, the number of black and Asian MPs should be 22, rather than the 12 likely to be elected, two more than at the last election.

The vast majority of Labour's black and Asian candidates are facing huge Tory majorities and are often in third place behind the Liberal Democrats.

'It is sad, but the Labour Party suffers from the same degree of institutional racism that affects so many organisations in Britain,' said Sharon Grant, widow of the black Labour MP, Bernie.

Takki Sulaiman has been given the task of fighting Huntingdon for the Labour Party, John Major's seat, one of the safest Tory seats in the country with a majority of more than 18,000. Mushtaq Hussain will fight Stratford-on-Avon which has a Conservative majority of more than 14,000 and Keir Dhillon will fight Tewkesbury where the Tory majority is nearly 10,000.

'The issue of race for New Labour is like a bunch of red roses on a table, it's purely decorative,' said black Labour MP Diane Abbott. 'Millbank [Labour's headquarters] is run by groups of young, white men, Tony Blair has surrounded himself with groups of young white men.'

Gurbux Singh, the chairman of the CRE, said that the record of all the political parties in promoting black and Asian people was 'very disappointing'.

A Labour spokesman said that, although Labour had done a lot to promote black and Asian candidates, 'much more needed to be done'.

Senior police officers have also confirmed that racist attacks increase when politicians make speeches about asylum and immigration.

One Scotland Yard source said: 'The most serious trend we have seen is a rise in reports of incidents when the issue of asylum seekers and refugees is brought into the public domain by reputable politicians making inflammatory statements.'

Around 1,300 racially motivated incidents are reported to the Metropolitan police each month. The Monitoring Group, which provides advice and support to victims of racial harassment, confirmed there had been a threefold increase in reports of racial harassment and violence in March after the race issue was reignited by Hague's speech to the Conservative Party's spring conference.

Asylum will dominate this week's Metropolitan Police conference on diversity. Metropolitan Police Commissioner Sir John Stephens will say lessons learnt about racially motivated hate crime need to be applied to other areas, including abuse of the elderly, crime against the disabled and homophobic attacks.

Home Secretary Jack Straw is under attack after pulling out of Tuesday's conference, planned to mark the anniversary of the death of Stephen Lawrence.

webTitle: Go see

fields.headline: Go see
fields.standfirst: The Pirates of Penzance
fields.trailText: The Pirates of Penzance.
fields.body:
You have to feel for Messrs Gilbert & Sullivan. As Mike Leigh's lauded biopic Topsy-Turvy showed us, penning 13 wildly successful comic operettas certainly didn't do much for the duo in terms of critical acclaim. Indeed, poor Sullivan was considered something of a musical also-ran in comparison to Elgar, the then golden boy of British music.

In more recent years, posthumous praise has also been thin on the ground. The deeply unfashionable flag of the comic-opera genre, the Savoy Operas seem to have been surrendered to die-hard fans and any amateur dramatics society with the requisite number of pirate costumes. Small wonder then that many viewed Gilbert & Sullivan with the same enthusiasm Bridget Jones reserves for Una Alconbury's turkey curry buffets.

Of course, that was all before Topsy-Turvy gave us a historical glimpse behind the scenes and Gilbert & Sullivan some much needed kudos. The reformed D'Oyly Carte opera company has recently netted two Olivier Awards for The Mikado and HMS Pinafore . Now the same company is back at its original home, the Savoy Theatre, with a special staging of one of Gilbert & Sullivan's best loved works, The Pirates of Penzance .

Produced by Raymond Gubbay, who has long been on a mission to bring opera to the people, this version aims to strike a balance between the authentic Gilbert & Sullivan tradition and the spectacle of a West End show. Director, Stuart Maunder has promised a good deal of contemporary references alongside the classics, such as 'I am the very model of a modern Major-General' and 'Poor Wandering One' which will hopefully please new and old fans alike.

Whatever happens, there will be much ta-ran-ta-ra-ing as the full complement of pirates, policemen and Major- General Stanley's daughters bound round the Savoy's stage.

 The Pirates of Penzance opens on Friday 20 April for eight weeks at the Savoy Theatre. Tickets from £12.50. Call the Savoy Theatre box office on 020 7836 8888

webTitle: Can I enforce boss's pay pledge?

fields.headline: Can I enforce boss's pay pledge?
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Work
fields.trailText: I took on a job four years ago at a salary of half the market rate because I was desperate for work. I was told the pay level would be reviewed in a year, but there has been no response to my repeated requests for a rise.
fields.body:
I took on a job four years ago at a salary of half the market rate because I was desperate for work. I was told the pay level would be reviewed in a year, but there has been no response to my repeated requests for a rise.

My second concern is that I am now being asked to do work which is at a higher degree of responsibility than that specified in my contract and job description. I am being asked to take overall responsibility for producing spreadsheets, for instance, not just helping to compile them. If I decided to leave, would I have grounds for constructive dismissal?

The agreement with your employer to review your pay does not sound as if it is a contractual term. There is no legal right to get a pay rise each year. This means that you need to negotiate to get higher pay. You can do things such as getting comparable examples of earnings for people in similar jobs, finding out if colleagues are in the same position and negotiating together.

On your second concern, you probably do not have a very strong legal case either. Constructive dismissal is notoriously difficult to prove. You would have to show that there was a breach of contract which was so substantial it went to the heart of your employment contract.

webTitle: Titanic greed of the telecom giants

fields.headline: Titanic greed of the telecom giants
fields.standfirst: The current worldwide mobile phone crisis serves as a stark warning of the evils of unregulated capitalism and corporate cynicism
fields.trailText: The current worldwide mobile phone crisis serves as a stark warning of the evils of unregulated capitalism and corporate cynicism. By Will Hutton.
fields.body:
Imagine the chorus of criticism if a collection of state-owned companies had wasted tens of billions of pounds in duplicating their efforts amid juicy stories of fraud, cheating and epic miscalculations and whose excesses now threatened the world with a recession. The attack-dog columnists of the right- wing press would be outdoing themselves in their excoriation of all things to do with the public sector and pleading for more privatisation and deregulation. But when the same happens in the world of private enterprise, silence descends.

What has happened to the global telecoms industry and, not least, to British Telecom, is a salutary lesson to all those who buy the simple proposition that public is bad and private is good. Over the last five years, American, European and Asian telecom companies have run up more than $700 billion of debt in outdoing themselves to bid for a stake in the communications action. Now the industry lies crippled in debt as the dotcom bubble has burst. Conservatively, at least $100bn will never be repaid, posing a mounting threat to the integrity of the world banking system. There have been 100,000 telecom job losses worldwide in the last 10 weeks and with Ericsson's announcement of another 12,000 on Friday the pace is accelerating.

In the same way that we don't need a multiplicity of gas, electricity or water distribution networks, we never needed the multiplicity of mobile phone and broadband networks on which the boom was predicated. There will now be a round of mergers and takeovers and we will be left with powerful, private-sector monopoly networks instead of ones accountable to the public through public ownership. But the transitional devastation will contribute to recession as companies slash their telecom and IT spending while banks nurse their bad debts. Capitalism in this style does not get much more stupid.

The irrationality of greed of the companies is a majestic condemnation of the way unmanaged and deregulated markets work. They paid too much for the licences for third-generation, mobile-phone radio spectrums in Britain and elsewhere because nobody dared risk being the odd man out without a licence. It was ridiculous that the American giants tried to build competing domestic and international networks as if telephone networks were like any other consumer durable, so more than halving their rates of return and quadrupling their debt. It was absurd that the partially privatised German and French telecom companies tried simultaneously to do everything in the information and communication revolution, along with our own BT. The three now have, respectively, £35bn, £40bn and £30bn of debt.

But as they and their equally indebted American and Asian counterparts cut back their spending, manufacturers of telecom equipment feel the knock-on effect. In the US, Cisco, Nortel and Lucent are reeling from the impact; there is speculation, which is denied, that Lucent is on the point of bankruptcy. As the companies desperately try to maintain the pace of technological innovation in order to provoke consumers to keep up their spending on the next wave of products to bail them out of their debts, so mistakes are made. The toe-curling BT press conference last week, when the new net-connected handsets failed in their public demonstration, is only the most raw example of how too hastily designed equipment is not working as it should.On top of it all, sales are slowing down.

All this interacts with the unwinding of the dotcom bubble, the companies which were projected to deliver so much increased traffic through the new networks and whose failures make the economics of network building so much more hazardous. If the CEOs of telecom companies were chasing their generous share options in their absurd expansion plans, they look like Snow Whites beside the avarice of the US and UK investment banking community which duped the investing public into what was close to theft. In the last two years, 1,262 hi-tech companies went public in New York; the shares of 152 can now be bought for less than a dollar and most of the others have fallen by two-thirds or more. Not that the investment banks like Merrill Lynch or Goldman Sachs care; they earned more than $600 million of fees. It was a wealth transfer from ordinary savers' pension funds into the pockets of overpaid bankers on an unparalleled scale.

That is not all. More and more troubling stories of fraud are surfacing as 'entrepreneurs' proved increasingly innovative with the truth as they tried to cash in on the boom and disguise the frailty of their companies. Lemout & Hauspie, a voice-recognition company, is under investigation in the US for fiddling its accounts. Lucent is involved with a now-dead fraudster. Even the mighty Deutsche Telekom is being investigated for overstating the value of its property assets by half. And in Britain, we are discovering the industry has exaggerated the scale of mobile-phone sales by around a quarter.

The defenders of all this will argue that the greater prize is technological innovation and that capitalism has always involved some jiggery-pokery at the margins; better this than any socialist alternative. But to object to waste, duplication, fraud and avarice on such an epic scale is not to argue for the Soviet Union or British nationalised industries.

Instead it is, to insist on straight thinking by governments about the limits of markets. Telephone networks are natural monopolies and public goods; the objective must be to offer cheap access to all. Duplicating networks is an economic nonsense. Better one mobile-phone network, with universal coverage and one network of masts, than four incomplete networks and many more masts with their potential radiation risk.

Equally, privatising a monopoly network simply offers the privatised monopoly owner the cash flow on which to build a debt mountain to make stupid acquisitions, as the experience across the globe proves. The trouble is that free-market ideology, sponsored by the all-powerful Americans, taught otherwise and nobody stood up for a different concept in which the public ownership and public construction of networks was seen as rational and economically efficient. We followed like lemmings andhave a telecoms débcle to match the disaster in the US. And still nobody dares say the emperor has no clothes.

The attack-dog columnists of the right- wing press would be outdoing themselves in their excoriation of all things to do with the public sector and pleading for more privatisation and deregulation. But when the same happens in the world of private enterprise, silence descends. What has happened to the global telecoms industry and, not least, to British Telecom, is a salutary lesson to all those who buy the simple proposition that public is bad and private is good. Over the last five years, American, European and Asian telecom companies have run up more than $700 billion of debt in outdoing themselves to bid for a stake in the communications action. Now the industry lies crippled in debt as the dotcom bubble has burst. Conservatively, at least $100bn will never be repaid, posing a mounting threat to the integrity of the world banking system. There have been 100,000 telecom job losses worldwide in the last 10 weeks and with Ericsson's announcement of another 12,000 on Friday the pace is accelerating. In the same way that we don't need a multiplicity of gas, electricity or water distribution networks, we never needed the multiplicity of mobile phone and broadband networks on which the boom was predicated. There will now be a round of mergers and takeovers and we will be left with powerful, private-sector monopoly networks instead of ones accountable to the public through public ownership. But the transitional devastation will contribute to recession as companies slash their telecom and IT spending while banks nurse their bad debts. Capitalism in this style does not get much more stupid. The irrationality of greed of the companies is a majestic condemnation of the way unmanaged and deregulated markets work. They paid too much for the licences for third-generation, mobile-phone radio spectrums in Britain and elsewhere because nobody dared risk being the odd man out without a licence. It was ridiculous that the American giants tried to build competing domestic and international networks as if telephone networks were like any other consumer durable, so more than halving their rates of return and quadrupling their debt. It was absurd that the partially privatised German and French telecom companies tried simultaneously to do everything in the information and communication revolution, along with our own BT. The three now have, respectively, £35bn, £40bn and £30bn of debt. But as they and their equally indebted American and Asian counterparts cut back their spending, manufacturers of telecom equipment feel the knock-on effect. In the US, Cisco, Nortel and Lucent are reeling from the impact; there is speculation, which is denied, that Lucent is on the point of bankruptcy. As the companies desperately try to maintain the pace of technological innovation in order to provoke consumers to keep up their spending on the next wave of products to bail them out of their debts, so mistakes are made. The toe-curling BT press conference last week, when the new net-connected handsets failed in their public demonstration, is only the most raw example of how too hastily designed equipment is not working as it should.On top of it all, sales are slowing down. All this interacts with the unwinding of the dotcom bubble, the companies which were projected to deliver so much increased traffic through the new networks and whose failures make the economics of network building so much more hazardous. If the CEOs of telecom companies were chasing their generous share options in their absurd expansion plans, they look like Snow Whites beside the avarice of the US and UK investment banking community which duped the investing public into what was close to theft. In the last two years, 1,262 hi-tech companies went public in New York; the shares of 152 can now be bought for less than a dollar and most of the others have fallen by two-thirds or more. Not that the investment banks like Merrill Lynch or Goldman Sachs care; they earned more than $600 million of fees. It was a wealth transfer from ordinary savers' pension funds into the pockets of overpaid bankers on an unparalleled scale. That is not all. More and more troubling stories of fraud are surfacing as 'entrepreneurs' proved increasingly innovative with the truth as they tried to cash in on the boom and disguise the frailty of their companies. Lemout & Hauspie, a voice-recognition company, is under investigation in the US for fiddling its accounts. Lucent is involved with a now-dead fraudster. Even the mighty Deutsche Telekom is being investigated for overstating the value of its property assets by half. And in Britain, we are discovering the industry has exaggerated the scale of mobile-phone sales by around a quarter. The defenders of all this will argue that the greater prize is technological innovation and that capitalism has always involved some jiggery-pokery at the margins; better this than any socialist alternative. But to object to waste, duplication, fraud and avarice on such an epic scale is not to argue for the Soviet Union or British nationalised industries. Instead it is, to insist on straight thinking by governments about the limits of markets. Telephone networks are natural monopolies and public goods; the objective must be to offer cheap access to all. Duplicating networks is an economic nonsense. Better one mobile-phone network, with universal coverage and one network of masts, than four incomplete networks and many more masts with their potential radiation risk. Equally, privatising a monopoly network simply offers the privatised monopoly owner the cash flow on which to build a debt mountain to make stupid acquisitions, as the experience across the globe proves. The trouble is that free-market ideology, sponsored by the all-powerful Americans, taught otherwise and nobody stood up for a different concept in which the public ownership and public construction of networks was seen as rational and economically efficient. We followed like lemmings andhave a telecoms débcle to match the disaster in the US. And still nobody dares say the emperor has no clothes.

webTitle: Fury over Gide's house

fields.headline: Restoration of Gide home proves to be bad manors
fields.trailText: The sleepy little French village of Cuverville-en-Caux would be unknown to the world if a Nobel Laureate for literature hadn't lived there.
fields.body:
It should be a sleepy little French village just like a thousand others. Cuverville-en-Caux (pop. 233) nestles in the Lezarde valley a few miles inland from the Normandy coast and would be unknown to the world if a Nobel Laureate for literature hadn't lived there.

But André Gide did live there, and as a result the village is now plunged into an extraordinary, and very French, row embroiling architects, literati, journalists and more government agencies than you can shake the author's collected works at.

It all began in 1996 when the current owner of Cuverville's manor house, in which Gide lived and wrote for more than 50 years, decided that the place needed renovating. He contacted respected architect Jean-Claude Rochette, formerly France's inspector general of historic monuments, for advice on what needed doing.

Rochette decided that the manor needed to be restored to the way it looked when it was built in 1735. As a result, off came the white shutters that Gide knew during the last century, builders chipped away at the pale yellow rendering to uncover wine-coloured bricks, six rectangular columns were revealed and the pediment above them was painted white. Work cost several hundred thousand francs.

The result? According to Emmanuel de Roux of Le Monde : 'The renovation works have given the place the profile of a British manor house, chic and elegant, but one that the writer who stayed there until his death would not recognise at all.'

It is this fact that drives Gidophiles crazy. 'It's a massacre,' says Michel Drouin of the renovation works, while adding they are 'happily reversible' and indeed must be reversed to restore the manor to its 'Gidean state'. Drouin is a nephew of Dominique Rouin, a distant relation of the writer. It was she who inherited the house from Gide's widow Madeleine, and who sold it to the current owner in 1963.

Drouin is leading a campaign to have the renovation work undone. He has already embarrassed local conservation watchdogs, who are themselves angry that the renovation was undertaken without their say-so. Now he is hoping to convince President Jacques Chirac to get involved and order the re-restoration.

Drouin says that in the year of the fiftieth anniversary of Gide's death, the manor house should be main tained as a shrine. At present the house is private and is not open to the public.

Drouin cites a 1946 report by Inspector General Dalloz for the Minister of Education, which says: 'Cuverville, in the history of French literature, will have its place like Montaigne's chateaux. It merits protection. It is Gide's presence that transformed this honest, banal Norman manor house into a place that's worth keeping.'

In one of Gide's best novels, La Porte Etroite ( Strait is the Gate , 1909), Cuverville features under the guise of the fictional village of Fougueusemare (a rather poor guise since there is a real-life village of Fougueusemare just up the road).

The manor house itself receives a less-than-glowing description: 'Standing in a garden which is neither very large nor very fine, and which has nothing special to distinguish it from a number of other Normandy gardens, the white two-storeyed building, resembles a great many country houses of the century before last. A score of large windows look east onto the front of the garden; as many more on to the back; there are none at the sides.'

The house also figures in Gide's novel The Immoralists and in his Journals. It was at Cuverville that Gide received some of the great European literary figures, including the poet Paul Valéry, for tennis parties and literary discussions. Here he also worked with the co-founders of the Nouvelle Revue Française, one of Europe's most important literary journals.

Former Culture Minister Catherine Trautman has said that everything should be done to 'restore the building in the state it was in when the writer knew it'. Some Fr300,000 of state money has been pledged, and Drouin reckons that Gide devotees will contribute enough to make up the shortfall.

It remains only to convince the owner, who has heroically guarded his anonymity throughout the affair, that his home must be changed once more for the sake of French heritage. But should he be compelled to restore the property which he restored recently from his own pocket?

On Friday, no one was at home at the Cuverville manor house to answer this. 'Looking for André Gide?' yelled a passing motorist. 'You won't find anything of him there. Try the church.' And, a few hundred yards away in a grave under a simple slab in the churchyard lies the writer. It proved impossible to confirm if Gide was turning in it, but it wouldn't be a surprise if he were.

webTitle: Risque fiction of young Philip Larkin

fields.headline: How the young Philip Larkin courted Trouble at Willow Gables
fields.standfirst: Academic uncovers poet's lost stories of lesbian sex, thrashings and blackmail in the school dorm
fields.trailText: Academic uncovers poet's lost stories of lesbian sex, thrashings and blackmail in the school dorm.
fields.body:
The late Philip Larkin is famed as the poet of modern misanthropy: a dark and sardonic voice pronouncing on the world from Hull. But the next collection of his work to reach bookshelves will paint a lurid and very different picture of the writer.

Details of Larkin's two previously unseen erotic novellas, Trouble at Willow Gables and Michaelmas Term at St Bride's, have emerged as the manuscripts are being prepared for publication next spring. They show him to have been obsessively interested in the lesbian activities of young boarding school girls - so much so, in fact, that the sex of the narrator of the stories is often in some doubt.

'The gender of the writer isn't as clear cut as it should be,' says James Booth, the Hull University English academic who uncovered the novellas inside the library where Larkin used to work as chief librarian.

'It isn't a man writing pornography about girls, it's more like a woman writing closet lesbian stuff. He [Larkin] said it was his "lesbian phase",' explained Booth.

The stories are known collectively as the Brunette Coleman Material, after the ladylike nom de plume adopted by Larkin, and parody the jolly-hockey-sticks world created by the popular writer of schooldays tales, Angela Brazil. They are certain to prove an underground hit for Faber, but are also bound to undermine the standing of their author.

Typical lines from Trouble at Willow Gables run: 'Marie, her hair dishevelled over her pale little face, her underlip mutinously jutting out, her tunic off-shoulder and her sash also, fought like a wild thing as Ursula, out of all patience, gripped her by the neck and forced her backwards over the headmistress's desk, scattering ink and papers...

'As Pam finally pulled Marie's tunic down over her black stockinged legs, Miss Holden, pausing only to snatch a cane from the cupboard on the wall, gripped Marie by the hair and, with a strength lent by anger, forced her head down until she was bent nearly double. Then she began thrashing her unmercifully...'

As detail of the stories emerge, their literary merits are already in question. Those who have read them, including Andrew Motion, the Poet Laureate, have identified them as little more than mild pornography.

'While pretending its main pleasure is watching girls sex each other up, it can't conceal its male self-disgust,' said Motion, who is also the poet's biographer.

'Men are victims of their sexual attraction to women, the novels want us to believe - and to be powerless in the grip of desire is contemptible.'

Packed with hairbrush beatings, improbable sexual blackmail and girls with hockey-hardened muscles in poplin pyjamas, the stories were written by Larkin while he was an undergraduate at Oxford.

At worst they are examples of the kind of juvenilia the poet never wished to see published: at best they are saucy pastiches of the kind of breathless girls' fiction that was popular between the wars.

Booth, who is the secretary of the Larkin Society, stumbled across the material in the library. He has edited the Faber collection, knowing that it may well damage the reputation of his university's most renowned literary figure.

'There is a scene of sado-masochism where a lesbian blackmails another girl into going to bed with her,' he said. 'But Larkin is such a strange and unusual writer that unless you come to the work from a literary angle, you miss its significance.'

Larkin's life and views have been the centre of controversy since his death. His unconventional love affairs have been publicly picked over, and the recent publication of letters to his friends John Betjeman and Kingsley Amis have exposed his crude tongue as well as provoking allegations that he was racist. A virgin until he was 23, he had long overlapping relationships with three lovers: Monica Jones, Maeve Brennan and Betty Mackereth, his secretary. His many surviving letters to Amis have also shown how they swapped elaborate sexual fantasies about schoolgirls and lesbianism.

Booth explains that while Larkin had talked previously about a period of homosexuality in his youth, the later androgynous or transsexual phase displayed in the girls stories reveals a new side to this complicated man's identity. 'He went to an all-boys school and was quite alert to all that. But by the time he was writing these stories he was out of his homosexual phase,' he said.

In a paragraph towards the end of the second book the 'author' makes a postmodern appearance in the text - in drag. A girl called Pat blames events on, 'that woman who writes all these books. Haven't you ever met her, Miss Marie? I saw her once. She used to come in here and drink. Very tall she was, and beautifully dressed.'

Corporal punishment features extensively in the plot of Trouble at Willow Gables . One section reads: 'The younger girl twisted to escape but Philippa had learnt how to deal with Marie from experience. In a very short time she was lying face down on Philippa's silken knee, with her velvet skirt folded neatly round her waist. The belt had a curious metal buckle, which Philippa rightly adjudged would add an awful sting to the lashes. Oblivious to Marie's piteous tears, cries and struggles, she thrashed till her forearms ached. Towards the end she even started to enjoy it.'

Oliver James, the psychiatrist, is writing a book titled after the first line of one of Larkin's best-known poems ('They fuck you up, your mum and dad') and is a 'huge fan' of Larkin's work. 'But he had a very cruel streak, I think,' he said. 'The definition of a cynic, the way I understand it, is someone who takes pleasure in mocking other people's enjoyment. And it has always seemed to me that Larkin did that.

'I imagine he would have written these books partly for self-gratification but largely for the pleasure of mocking the genre.'

Motion is stricter with the poet. He detects a strong mood of violent frustration, rather than parody or lighthearted eroticism in the novels. 'Beneath the surface of both stories runs a strong current of angry sexuality,' he said. 'But the surfaces themselves are too bashful, too giggly... to exploit their potential. As a result neither novel is more than a fascinating curiosity.'

webTitle: The Bard slays St George as national symbol

fields.headline: The Bard slays St George as national symbol
fields.standfirst: Special report: what is Britain?
fields.trailText: As an emblem of Englishness, Shakespeare has overtaken St George, the country's own patron saint, according to two polls conducted to mark the dual significance of tomorrow's date.
fields.body:
As an emblem of Englishness, Shakespeare has overtaken St George, the country's own patron saint, according to two polls conducted to mark the dual significance of tomorrow's date.

Both St George's Day and the birthday of the Bard fall on 23 April and twin surveys conducted by Mori have revealed the playwright's public profile is much higher than the dragon slayer's.

Less than half the population knew the date of St George's Day. Three quarters of those aged between 16 and 24 had no idea when St George's Day fell.

A Mori Omnibus poll commissioned by The Royal Shakespeare Company found that 40 per cent of respondents not only knew Shakespeare's name and work, but also thought his plays were relevant to politics today.

EastEnders and Coronation Street were viewed as the dramas most likely to say something important about Britain in 2001, with 33 per cent mentioning the BBC soap and 29 per cent its ITV rival.

The poll also shows that half the British public have seen a stage production of Shakespeare. Of those who have, 32 per cent have seen one in the past six years. Attendance is highest among those with household incomes over £30,000 (70 per cent attendance). Equally, 85 per cent of those educated to degree level or higher have seen a Shakespearean theatre production, 42 per cent within the past five years.

'The poll proves what we already know from the box office - that these plays are as relevant and exciting today as they were 400 years ago,' said Adrian Noble, The RSC's artistic director.

Home Office Minister Paul Boateng, who will be speaking at an RSC debate this afternoon about Shakespeare and England, told The Observer that he sees Shakespeare as England's greatest ambassador.

'I came across the plays when I was growing up in Ghana and they seemed relevant there,' he said. 'English people should celebrate the fact that they have not needed to have the flag-waving patriotism of more historically repressed countries. We should be proud that England has always been outward-looking and proud of the fact that Shakespeare is a global figure.'

 This England: The Histories Debate takes place at 3pm today in The Pit Theatre at the Barbican, London.

webTitle: Greenspan at mercy of the markets

fields.headline: Greenspan at mercy of the markets
fields.standfirst: Cisco's Chilli Fest won't be so hot this year, reports  Jamie Doward, as the US giant's recipe goes wrong
fields.trailText: Cisco's Chilli Fest won't be so hot this year, reports Jamie Doward, as the US giant's recipe goes wrong
fields.body:
This year's Chilli Fest at Cisco System's headquarters in California is likely to be a muted affair. The mass cook- out for the thousands of employees who work at the company's San Jose campus is usually one of the highlights of their year, an annual morale-boosting jamboree giving them the chance to bond with the top execs. But after a disastrous downturn in company fortunes that rendered their share options worthless, Cisco's employees have little to cheer about.

In the past the Chilli Fest has given the event's master chef, Cisco's evangelical CEO John Chambers, a chance to whip his staff into a new economy fervour by preaching the all-encompassing doctrine that the internet is akin to the Moon landing 10 times over.

'This is truly the second Industrial Revolution, and it will change every aspect of people's lives,' Chambers has said many, many times. The inference he wants the world to draw is that Cisco, the maker of 70 per cent of the world's routers (gizmos that direct internet traffic around networks), is in pole position to benefit as the information revolution takes off.

Chambers is a master salesman, a man who will probably have 'Always Be Closing' written on his gravestone. His dedication to the sales cause is the stuff of new economy legend. He's the man who hands out his home phone number and begs clients to ring him whenever they want - a throwback to his days as a salesman for IBM, when he was encouraged to 'sell the dream'.

He's the man who regularly walks around the Cisco HQ - known as Pleasantville - handing out ice creams to staff. He's the man who, on a company fishing trip, refused to return to shore when a storm blew up because he was hell bent on catching more fish than his colleagues.

He's a Wall Street darling, a dyslexic who studied hard for his MBA from Indiana University then ended up steering Cisco from a company with revenues of $1.3 billion in 1994 to more than $18bn last year. The influential Fortune magazine rates Cisco the second most admired company in the world and the third best to work for.

Inevitably, the world's politicians have descended on Cisco's HQ to have their photo taken with the net prophet who, unusually in the dotcom world, runs a company that makes profits.

On the walls of Cisco's offices there are pictures of the luminaries who have come to pay homage to San Jose's favourite firm: UN Secretary-General Kofi Annan, former US Secretary of State Madeleine Albright, and former Russian Prime Minister Viktor Chernomyrdin. There are pictures of Chambers swapping gags with Bill Clinton and chatting with China's President, Jiang Zemin. He's also close to President Bush.

But people on pedestals have the furthest to fall, and last week the wheels well and truly came off Cisco's tram. Chambers suffered the ignominy of having to confess that the company's third-quarter earnings will be dramatically short of Wall Street's expectations.

Whereas US analysts had been predicting earnings of around eight cents a share, Chambers said they would now be in the 'very low, single-digit range'. This time last year Cisco's sales were growing 60 per cent quarter-on-quarter. The share price plunged 3 per cent to $16.66 after the news. Once, the share price had come close to the $80 mark.

As befits his messiah status, Chambers resorted to biblical allegory to describe how bad things had become. 'A dramatic decline in quarter-on-quarter revenues would be 10 per cent. This shows that a once-in-100-years flood can happen in your lifetime.'

It was the latest in a long line of body blows that Cisco, the bellwether stock of the new economy, has delivered to the market. In January, Chambers said the current second-quarter market was a 'little bit more challenging' than anticipated. A few weeks later, at second-quarter results, he said: 'The next several quarters will be challenging.' Then in March Cisco announced 7,500 jobs were to go. By last week this had risen to 8,500 worldwide. Cisco employs about 2,000 in the UK, 35,000 in total.

Chambers, 51, argued that such a drastic cull was essential. 'This may be the fastest any industry our size has ever decelerated, which has required us to make difficult business decisions at an unprecedented speed.'

The disciples of the new economy, who accept the argument that businesses these days have to turn on a dime if they are to stay competitive, would understand.

Indeed, Chambers, who described having to sack 3,000 employees when he was helping to run computer manufacturer Wang Laboratories in the early 1990s as the 'worst experience of his life', argues: 'Companies that are successful will have cultures that thrive on change, even though change makes most people very uncomfortable.'

Despite ominous signs towards the end of last year that telecom firms were paring back on capital expenditure, Cisco failed to cut its order book down to size. It is now faced with taking a $2.5bn hit for excess inventory on top of the $1.2bn it is writing off in restructuring costs.

The company, which for years has been asking customers: 'Are you ready?', was itself found wanting. This is not just a major embarrassment, it's a serious business problem for a company that has used itself as a marketing tool for its products.

It has made great claims for its sophisticated web-based ordering system, holding it up as a model for how its clients should transform their procurement operations. Cisco has boasted that by harnessing the power of the net it has saved more than $800m a year. Now it has undermined such claims and the whole US technology sector, which saw Cisco as its model, has taken a battering. If the prophet can't deliver on his promises, what chance is there for his disciples?

In a bid to start a fresh new economy cheerleading campaign, Chambers has already started talking of 30 to 50 per cent sales growth in the long term, a claim that is raising analysts' eyebrows.

'Fifty per cent growth rates are totally unsustainable. Sure, there will be growth, but it will be in the mid teens. After the events of last week I would have expected him to be a bit more chastened,' said Adrian Murray, electronics analyst with broker Teather & Greenwood.

What happens next depends on whether Cisco's attempts to spread its tentacles across the web will pay off. In order to diversify from old 'mature areas', notably routers, and into new sectors, chiefly optical networking (the infrastructure capable of carrying truly massive amounts of data), Cisco has been on a huge acquisition spree, gobbling up more than 70 companies in seven years.

Inevitably, given its sky-high share price, Cisco has used its paper to finance the deals, most famously the $6.9bn acquisition of Cerant, a company that, at the time of the acquisition two years ago, had revenues of only $10m. 'It's promising technology, but the price it paid was very high,' said Dr Peter Kjeldsen, industry analyst with the Gartner Group.

To add to fears it overpaid on some deals, more focused upstarts, such as Juniper Networks, are now nibbling at its heels. If the Cisco HQ is to receive more visits from the great and the good, it has to prove it can see them off.

As Chambers is fond of saying: 'You've got to walk the talk.'

webTitle: Observer review: The Blair Effect, Tony Blair, Prime Minister and Reforming Britain

fields.headline: Tony Blair, thoughts and all
fields.standfirst: While you're waiting for the election campaign to start, brush up on New Labour's achievements thus far with The Blair Effect, Tony Blair, Prime Minister and Reforming Britain
fields.trailText: While you're waiting for the election campaign to start, brush up on New Labour's achievements thus far with The Blair Effect, Tony Blair, Prime Minister and Reforming Britain
fields.body:
The Blair Effect
Anthony seldon
Little Brown £14.99, pp672
Buy it at a discount at BOL1001002000477522

Tony Blair, Prime Minister
John Rentoul
Little Brown £20, pp640

Buy it at a discount at BOL

Reforming Britain
John Morrison
Reuters/Pearson Educational £19.99, pp320

Buy it at a discount at BOL

Four years gone, probably four more years to go. Here come the half-time summaries. They are heavyweight (these three alone run to 1,800 pages and 8lb on my bathroom scales) but they are also inevitably conditional accounts of work in progress. Their relevance, for all their bulk and diligence, will fade with June's election results. But for the moment, as superior offerings at the crossroads where academia and journalism meet, they serve a vital purpose.

What, emerging from the disinfectant trough of desuetude, do we imagine this election will be about? On the face of it, dispiritingly little. The first cheapjack posters sneering about 'Economic Disaster II' mingle with selective statistics and ritual insults; another grubby, cynical exercise in democratic catharsis. Pause, though, over The Blair Effect, for it is a treat.

Anthony Seldon has gathered together 28 of the experts you most want to read and set them assessing the way their patches have changed since 1997. And the first fascinating thing, in so many territories, is to see not how little has altered, but how much. The second fascinating - and damning - thing is to see how scantily those upheavals have been evaluated or absorbed.

Is the Westminster Parliament as boring and irrelevant as our pundits proclaim? Or is it subtly transformed into a 'a parliament for England, a parliament for primary legislation for Wales and a federal parliament for Northern Ireland and Scotland', as Vernon Bogdanor asserts? 'Whether or not devolution means the end of the United Kingdom, it... marks the end of one strand at least of socialism or social democracy, namely the belief that a benign government at Westminster can secure the distribution of benefits and burdens on the basis not of geography, but of need.'

Can Prime Ministers deliver sudden physical change any longer or have they, as Christopher Foster argues over transport, become hapless victims of the switch they themselves engineered from hierarchical command structures to policy networks? 'With all their faults, hierarchies generally at their roots were sufficiently close to earth to make things happen. Policy networks mean long and sometimes endless chains of consultation... which frequently get in the way of the action.'

Is social policy still natural Labour territory? Or is it, as Howard Glennester wonders, now much harder for a party of the Left to manage than a party of the Right? 'Populist attacks on welfare win votes, but crafting a solid future for welfare institutions within a severe tax constraint, against attacks from traditionalists on the left and critics on the right, is much more difficult.'

These, and many more like them, aren't the headline questions of the coming campaign - they are nuanced broods about the body politic. They are also at least part of the answer to the question posed relentlessly through the three books. Who is the 'real' Tony Blair? Is he an actor or an extraordinary ordinary bloke? A manic control freak or a dedicated devolver? A frustrated man of inaction or a driving reformer? The tendency, of course, is to puzzle over those contradictions: the true answer, however, may be that he is the unleasher of forces - within society and the apparatus of governance - which he, and we, barely understand as yet.

We think of him as 'presidential', but he is the precise opposite, a determined disburser of presidential power - to Scotland and Wales, to city mayors and regional development authorities, to Brussels and Belfast, to the Bank of England. Where an election system, as in Edinburgh or Cardiff, favours his party, he changes it and loses influence as a result. He has done the same, pretty remarkably, for his Strasbourg MEPs. The old House of Lords has gone. Our law is no longer sovereign because it incorporates and embraces the European Convention on Human Rights. Our information may not be exactly free yet, but the tide of restriction has turned. Our election spending is about to be honestly regulated.

This is a formidable agenda of constitutional change (one very cogently laid out in John Morrison's admirable primer to the revolution) and it cannot be abandoned or rolled back. It is the way we are now, but not yet, perhaps, how we see ourselves or how the lobby correspondents of Westminster see their readers. In that sense, John Rentoul's revised biography of Blair, admirable as he first stepped into Downing Street, is less compelling for its added accounts of the routine ups and downs of office, the Mandelsons and the Robinsons, because it's not able to stand back far enough to see the big picture.

Morrison has seen it; Bogdanor and many chroniclers of The Blair Effect have seen it, too. We'll know in a few weeks time if the voting public has even realised it exists. Constitutional change may, in Millbank terms, be porridge for policy wonks. Who wants to drone on about voting systems when you can cuddle babies for photographers in front of some sheeny new hospital?

Yet, as Seldon concludes in his book of analysis by writers of all parties, and none: 'This government outshines in achievement that of all other Labour administrations except 1945-50.' It has done a hell of a lot. It has relaid the foundations of the country we live in. Will it get credit for that? Probably not, because it seeks to claim no credit for such achievements, preferring to let them pass in silence. Will it pound on through a second parliament? Possibly not. 'Very few governments,' Denis Kavanagh writes, 'have become more successful or radical over a second term. For Blair, the future may not be better; the best may be in the past.' Can Labour even bank on a decent majority? The thing that strikes Ivor Crewe is not how well Blair has done in the polls through these four years, but how 'remarkably badly' he's done at the polls. 'Polls offer one verdict on his electoral strategy; actual elections quite another.'

And so to that actual election with its dreary din. But take heart - you can always turn the TV off and retreat next door with a few good books.

webTitle: Don't spring into the market

fields.headline: Don't spring into the market
fields.standfirst: David Hunt kicks off four pages on homes by asking if now is the time to move
fields.trailText: David Hunt kicks off four pages on homes by asking if now is the time to move.
fields.body:
Spring, apparently, is when the nesting instinct takes over. The weather is supposed to improve and, historically, the housing market takes off.

This year, however, it is not only the weather which could dampen enthusiasm. On the plus side, interest rates are low and headed even lower - mortgage rates are now at, or near, their lowest levels for more than 30 years. On the downside, the 'R' word - recession - is being heard more often.

Hardly a day goes by without a press report of some company, somewhere in the UK, laying off staff. Cuts are widespread, from the 20,000 high paid jobs estimated to disappear in the City of London area, to places such as Merseyside and the North East, the homes of Cammel Laird; Luton, home of Vauxhall; and areas hit by the foot and mouth crisis.

In addition, the affordability of buying your own home, as measured by the Cheltenham & Gloucester Affordability Index, has slipped to its worst level for eight years. Yet the market remains relatively optimistic about the spring house-hunting season. 'The market is actually pretty strong this year,' says Ray Boulger, senior technical manager at mortgage advisers John Charcol. 'There is no sign of a slowdown.'

This message is confirmed by Hugh Dunsmore-Hardy, chief executive of the National Association of Estate Agents (NAEA). 'The mood among my members is fairly buoyant. Talk of recession is premature. Interest rates are low and spring is as good a time as any to think about buying or moving home.'

Conditions, of course, are far removed from the last big recession to hit the household property sector. Back in the late 1980s the market had gone mad in the run up to the ending of double Miras tax relief. It was then hit by escalating mortgage rates, which climbed to over 15 per cent in 1990. Negative equity and widespread repossessions resulted and memories of that period are only just beginning to fade.

'This time around it is completely different,' argues Bernard Clark, communications manager at the Council of Mortgage Lenders (CML). 'The house price increase pattern is very different to last time; relatively stable at around 5-6 per cent per year. We are also predicting a stable level of transactions of between 1.4 and 1.5 million per year compared with last time when the level shot up to 2.2 million and then fell back drastically.'

Clark believes people are better prepared and more realistic these days. As an indication, he points to a higher take-up of Mortgage Payment Protection Insurance (MPPI) which, he says, is providing a safety net for more people.

MPPI is a relatively cheap form of insurance that provides cover to home owners who experience a loss of income, either through unemployment, sickness or injury. Policies usually pay the mortgage for a limited period - say 12 months - with the CML quoting a figure of around £5.50 per £100 of the monthly mortgage repayment as a rough indication of the cost.

For prospective home buyers concerned about their job prospects, insurance is probably sensible, but MPPI may not always be the answer.

'MPPI is being pushed by the CML and the Association of British Insurers in association with the Government,' argues Charcol's Ray Boulger. 'Clearly, the Government has a vested interest in that the more people have their own insurance, the less it is going to cost them. But only certain people will find that MPPI is sensible for them: it's a complete waste of money for the self-employed.

'A self-employed person can lose 90 per cent of their work and will still not be regarded as unemployed, so won't be able to claim.'

Boulger says borrowers should consider other options, such as permanent health insurance, (PHI) which pays out around 65 per cent of total income, or a combination of short-term MPPI and long-term PHI.

Reducing the risks

For borrowers concerned about what might happen if things go wrong, the Council of Mortgage Lenders offers several suggestions about how to reduce the risks of repossession.These include:

 Having a large amount of equity in your home.

 Borrowing only modestly in relation to your income.

 Setting aside savings for emergencies.

 Insuring against the loss of income caused by unemployment or illness.

For many people the first two suggestions are impracticable: most find they have to borrow up to the hilt simply to afford the property they want.

Flexible mortgages now make the third suggestion more possible. Borrowers can overpay in the good times and take payment holidays in times of trouble. Lenders regard insurance as the most realistic way for their customers to protect against the possibility of having their homes repossessed.
