'This time around it is completely different,' argues Bernard Clark, communications manager at the Council of Mortgage Lenders (CML). 'The house price increase pattern is very different to last time; relatively stable at around 5-6 per cent per year. We are also predicting a stable level of transactions of between 1.4 and 1.5 million per year compared with last time when the level shot up to 2.2 million and then fell back drastically.' Clark believes people are better prepared and more realistic these days. As an indication, he points to a higher take-up of Mortgage Payment Protection Insurance (MPPI) which, he says, is providing a safety net for more people. MPPI is a relatively cheap form of insurance that provides cover to home owners who experience a loss of income, either through unemployment, sickness or injury. Policies usually pay the mortgage for a limited period - say 12 months - with the CML quoting a figure of around £5.50 per £100 of the monthly mortgage repayment as a rough indication of the cost. For prospective home buyers concerned about their job prospects, insurance is probably sensible, but MPPI may not always be the answer. 'MPPI is being pushed by the CML and the Association of British Insurers in association with the Government,' argues Charcol's Ray Boulger. 'Clearly, the Government has a vested interest in that the more people have their own insurance, the less it is going to cost them. But only certain people will find that MPPI is sensible for them: it's a complete waste of money for the self-employed. 'A self-employed person can lose 90 per cent of their work and will still not be regarded as unemployed, so won't be able to claim.' Boulger says borrowers should consider other options, such as permanent health insurance, (PHI) which pays out around 65 per cent of total income, or a combination of short-term MPPI and long-term PHI. Reducing the risks For borrowers concerned about what might happen if things go wrong, the Council of Mortgage Lenders offers several suggestions about how to reduce the risks of repossession.These include:  Having a large amount of equity in your home.  Borrowing only modestly in relation to your income.  Setting aside savings for emergencies.  Insuring against the loss of income caused by unemployment or illness. For many people the first two suggestions are impracticable: most find they have to borrow up to the hilt simply to afford the property they want. Flexible mortgages now make the third suggestion more possible. Borrowers can overpay in the good times and take payment holidays in times of trouble. Lenders regard insurance as the most realistic way for their customers to protect against the possibility of having their homes repossessed.

webTitle: Don't move. Hire a space invader

fields.headline: Don't move. Hire a space invader
fields.standfirst: Creating extra room can pay, says Joanna Moorhead
fields.trailText: Creating extra room can pay, says Joanna Moorhead.
fields.body:
You may think you need a new home, but with a bit of imagination your current property could be adapted so that you don't need to think about moving for a few more years.

Liberating the extra space you want from your current home will probably be a far better investment in the short to medium term.

Staying put can cost money if you employ builders and architects to extend or change your home. Generally, however, the bill will be less and what you spend is what you see. Much of the money spent on a new home goes to removal firms and in solicitors' and estate agents' fees.

So you think there is nothing you could do to make your home roomier? Think again. Architect Simon Miller, whose north London firm Home Economics specialises in finding added space, says he comes up with ideas for nine out of 10 of the houses he visits.

'The obvious one is a loft extension,' Miller says. 'If you've a back extension you can add a sloping room to give more height; if you've a cellar you can think about digging it out and adding a basement room.

'It can make good economic sense. In many parts of London a family home can easily be worth £500,000, and if you're going to spend £80,000 on a basement and it adds £100,000 to the property, that makes sense.'

Many areas of London, says Miller, have a dearth of homes with four or and more bedrooms but with the arrival of children many couples aspire to this size of home.

'Adding a new bedroom and bathroom in the loft usually makes sense, but you don't have to stop there. You can look at extending the kitchen, or making a playroom. A rear extension is good for a breakfast room. It can be a really attractive area and a real selling point when you do decide to move.'

A good starting-point is to look at what neighbours have done in your road, and to ask around - go to the bottom of your garden and look up and down to see whether anyone else has added a loft room, or a kitchen extension. Asking to look round can be good idea - many people are rightly proud of the work they've done on their homes and quite enjoy the chance to show it off.

Buying an adjoining property and knocking through is another possibility, although this can be prohibitively expensive in urban areas. It's sometimes possible to buy an adjoining garage, or - if you live in a flat - to buy the one above or below your own. If you work at home, building a single-storey office at the bottom of the garden can make sense.

Hiring a home organiser can be worthwhile. Annya Ladakh of Clear Space says: 'I look at whether the rooms being used in the best ways? Would more shelves or better storage give a lot more space? Are there rooms that could be dual purpose, or would space-saving devices such as wall beds make a difference?'

We've more room, with less upheaval

Margaret and Martin Galea, who live in Balham, south London, with their four young sons, were on the brink of moving 18 months ago - but when the deal fell through, they decided to think again.

'House prices had gone up and we realised that adding a loft room to our own house was going to be a much cheaper way of getting a five-bedroom, two-bathroom house than moving,' says Margaret. 'We really like the area and our children are very happy at their school, which is round the corner. We've got a reasonable-sized garden and basically everything is good about being here - but we did need more space.

'I wasn't looking forward to the work actually being done but in fact it wasn't too bad . The results have far exceeded our expectations. We've got a lovely big room at the top of the house - my only regret is that we didn't have it done sooner.

'It's probably cost us around £40,000, but that's an investment we'd recoup if we sold. Moving to a five-bedroom house round here would have cost a great deal more, on top of which we'd have had the moving costs and the upheaval of having to move.'

webTitle: Maria Scott: Get onside to support Nationwide

fields.headline: Get onside to support Nationwide
fields.trailText: 'Nationwide building society is in for another summer of turmoil. The society still faces an attempt by would-be converter Andrew Muir to win a place on the board.'
fields.body:
Nationwide building society faces another summer of turmoil. Despite having thrown out as invalid a proposed resolution for conversion, the society still faces an attempt by would-be converter Andrew Muir to win a place on the board.

In a move interpreted as a pre-emptive strike to get members on side for another conversion battle, Nationwide cut its mortgage rate for existing borrowers earlier this year.

But, this is threatening to backfire because it also ditched discounted products. Other lenders are still discounting fiercely, and brokers have been putting their business elsewhere.

Nationwide wanted to simplify the market and please existing borrowers, who subsidise newcomers drawn in by discounts. For now, the market is not moving with the big building society although its management says it budgeted for a period of lower mortgage sales.

Nationwide is vulnerable on another front. A separate group of campaigners has been trying to gain a voice on the board; they don't want conversion but do want a greater say in the running of the society. Directors' pay has come under attack: chief executive Brian Davis's package last year was worth more than £700,000.

By ruling the resolution invalid Nationwide may just have got itself off the hook for another year. But it still faces a battle with rebel boardroom contenders, and the constant assaults on its status must be a distraction for management.

Nationwide is an important source of competition on the high street and while it does not always offer the keenest rates it does aim for consistency. It is fighting a lonely battle, and time could be running out. If members value what the society represents they need to vote resoundingly in favour of existing board members at this year's elections.

The new board at Equitable Life was right to appoint top City solicitor Herbert Smith to investigate whether cases for negligence can be made against its former directors and advisers.

Policyholders, who will pay for Smith's advice, shouldn't get too optimistic about compensation. Nevertheless it is in their interests to explore every avenue for redress. There are many unanswered questions about the origins of Equitable's crisis. Any answers found may help to prevent other disasters.

webTitle: How to buy a freehold

fields.headline: Feudalism's last stand
fields.standfirst: You can buy the freehold, but it's not easy Graham Norwood writes
fields.trailText: You can buy the freehold, but it's not easy Graham Norwood writes.
fields.body:
Housing minister Nick Raynsford calls it feudal - something only Britain and Hawaii allow. It is the bizarre system whereby owners of leasehold properties are subject to annual charges and sometimes stiff repair bills by landlords who own the freehold to the block.

It is possible for flat owners to buy the freehold, but the process is so complicated that few have - only around 1,400 groups of residents have bought the freehold from their landlords so far.

To buy the freehold you must:

· Check that less than 10 per cent of the building is used for commercial purposes

· Establish whether the residents qualify - have two-thirds lived there for more than a year and do they own at least half of the flats?

· Organise the participating residents into a legal entity to prevent disputes over voting rights, negotiations with the landlord, and the size of each resident's contribution to the purchase

· Instruct solicitors to open negotiations with the landlord. Valuers should be hired to put a notional price on the freehold. This is then put forward in an initial notice from the residents to the landlord, which triggers the legal purchase process

The landlord is entitled to query the price and the residents' qualifications to buy the freehold, and can serve a counter notice with 21 days. If there is no immediate agreement over a price for the freehold, there is a six-month negotiation period. Most freehold purchases are agreed amicably during this time but if there is still no settlement the process goes to a Leasehold Valuation Tribunal, which may add another 12 months to the process.

Gerry Fox, who chairs the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors' committee on leasehold says the procedure is 'too cumbersome. People come to valuers saying they'll pull together the other residents if the exercise doesn't cost too much, but different valuers will come up with very different estimates, and the Valuation Tribunal may come up with something different again if it gets that far'.

The valuation element is the biggest complication. The freehold itself is deemed to have no value other than its future potential income for the landlord, so speculative investment values are attached to it based on factors such as how the future housing market will perform.

It is also assumed that the value of the individual properties will rise if the freehold is bought. This is because the residents could increase the duration of their own leases if they bought the freehold, making the properties more attractive on resale. So an additional sum is added to the cost to cover this.

The Leasehold Advisory Service provides an illustration based on a block of 24 flats, each with 68 years of their leases left, and valued at £60,000.

Using different variables based on different market predictions, the cost of buying a flat's freehold ranged from £3,323 to £35,036 - without legal and valuation fees.

To rub salt into the residents' wounds, the landlord's legal fees are paid by them if they buy the freehold at the end of the process, effectively encouraging the landlord to use the most expensive representatives for as long as necessary.

Change depends on poll

There is widespread recognition that the law allowing landlords to hold the freeholds of flats complicates the housing market and is simply unfair.

Likely changes in legislation have been announced by the Government and are being discussed by the House of Lords. Most parties support the proposals, but their passing into law depends on the timing and result of the forthcoming general election. The plans include:

1 Cutting the 'residency test' for flat dwellers to qualify to buy a freehold from the present 12 months, or three years in the last 10, to six months. Buy-to-let landlords would have to prove ownership for at least two years.

2 You will no longer need two-thirds of flat owners to agree before beginning to buy a lease. This will fall to 50 per cent - a recognition that in the buy-to- let era, many owners cannot be identified or contacted.

3 The right to buy a freehold will be extended to flats in blocks which are 25 per cent shops or offices - up from the current 10 per cent.

4 A new system called commonhold will allow flats to be bought outright, with communal parts of the building - such as service areas and the roof - owned jointly by residents. This will apply to new developments, but not to existing flats.

Contacts

www.lease-advice.org
Willowacre property management: 020 7309 9900
Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors: 020 7222 7000.

webTitle: Tim Atkin: Dinner party drinks

fields.headline: Making a meal of it
fields.standfirst: Having a dinner party? Best start by planning what you're going to be drinking
fields.trailText: Having a dinner party? Best start by planning what you're going to be drinking.
fields.body:
How do you tell a winemaker who's standing a few feet away from you that his wine sucks? That something to which he dedicated a year of his life would be better poured down the nearest sink? The answer is that you don't, assuming you want to hang on to your front teeth. You tell him a white lie instead. 'This will develop in bottle, but it's a little understated at the moment,' you murmur, turning your face to the nearest spittoon. Better still, you tell him: 'This is a food wine.'

The term is a handy escape hatch for wine writers in a tight and potentially dangerous corner, but does it mean anything? The implication is that a wine's character will be embellished, enhanced or miraculously improved by serving it with a particular dish. But, nine times out of 10, this is cobblers. Bad wines aren't made any better by food, and good wines have a habit of tasting good, married or unmarried. Our perceptions of each may differ - there are people out there who persist in drinking Piat d'Or - but you get the point.

The only exception to this particular rule is tannic red wines, especially young ones. Chunky reds, be they Barolo, Cornas, claret or California Cabernet are softened by the right dish. That's why red Bordeaux and English beef are, or rather were, such a great match. The fat in creamy cheeses performs the same function, relubricating the palate and mellowing red-wine tannins. Try the two reds I've recommended this week with and without a piece of cheese and you'll see what I mean.

Big butch reds are legitimate food wines, at least in the sense that I understand the term, but that's about it. Despite what you might think, most food and wine combinations are what specialists call 'non-reactive'. Combinations from heaven are rare, but so are combinations from the other side of the Styx. This means you can drink pretty much what you like as long as you're sensible. If you serve a dry red with a pudding or a dessert wine with boeuf bourguignon, then you're courting disappointment, although a chef friend of mine loves the combination of Sauternes and lamb chops.

Does this mean that food and wine matching is silly? It's certainly true that people are far too precious about what they serve at dinner parties. Most modern wines are pretty adaptable and, should you find that a particular wine doesn't go with a particular dish, it's not exactly a catastrophe. You can always open a bottle of something else. Or you can in my house, anyway. I pay a little bit of attention to what I drink with food, but only a little. The best advice I was ever given came from an American Master of Wine called Tim Hanni, who specialises in classes that 'enhance your dining experience'. Hanni's theory is very simple: acidity in wine lowers our perception of acidity in food, while sweetness or softness in wine increases our perception of acidity. The same thing applies the other way round. Lick a slice of lemon before you drink a Chardonnay and the wine will seem much, much mellower.

Hanni argues any wine can be a food wine, providing the food is right. And by food, he means the sauces, seasoning and garnishes as much as 'the lump of protein in the middle of the plate'. So drink what you want, whenever you want, and change what you eat to match it. Sounds like good advice to me.

Best cellars

Two whites that are fine without food and two reds improved by it.

2000 Corazon Pinot Gris, Jacques Lurton
(£3.99, Thresher, Wine Rack, Bottoms Up).
One of the best Argentine whites I've tasted in a long time, especially at this price. A perfumed, peach-scented white with a crisp, stylish finish.

2000 Tesco Finest Marlborough Sauvignon Blanc

(£6.49, Tesco).
Marlborough Sauvignon is expensive stuff these days, but this is brilliant value for money from Highfield Estate, with classic Kiwi characters of gooseberry and tropical fruit.

2000 Fairview Zinfandel/Cinsault, Paarl
(£6.99, Oddbins).
A big, turbo-charged Cape red from the inimitable Charles Back. This is rich and alcoholic with notes of liquorice, tobacco and mint overlaying a core of sweet fruit and powerful, muscular tannins.

1998 Bragnolo, Marche Rosso
(£7.99, Unwins).
A blend of Sangiovese and Ciliegiolo from central Italy, this is a dense red with flavours of plum and cherry, and a firm tannic finish. Call the butcher or the cheese shop.

webTitle: Nigel Slater: Nanny knows best

fields.headline: Nanny knows best
fields.standfirst: Puddings to take you back to the days when the cure for all ills came smothered in cream
fields.trailText: Puddings to take you back to the days when the cure for all ills came smothered in cream.
fields.body:
I am sitting at Le Caprice with five incredibly thin women from a fashion magazine - all Prada peeptoes and Fendi bags, pushing their salads round their plates, drinking mineral water and chain smoking. These women don't swallow, they simply rearrange the food on their plates. I am the only one to order pudding. Before you can say stick insect, a perfectly co-ordinated air attack of spoons and fingers entirely demolishes my hot treacle sponge and custard. I am left with three large crumbs, a smudge of sauce and someone else's licked spoon.

You should not mess with anyone else's pudding. Pudding is important for our wellbeing, our soul. You see, pudding is not a treat but a necessity. It is there to heal and comfort, to cosset and hug. Pudding is not food, it is medicine.

There is an unshakeable link between stress and pudding. At least there is in my house. It is not silver that lines my black clouds but butter, sugar, jam and cream. Warm, milky rice pudding and a blob of red jam is as effective an ointment for a bad time as tea-tree cream is for a cut finger.

The puds we turn to for comfort are inevitably those that remind us of our childhood, or more likely, an imaginary one - those dream-like sugar-and-spice-filled early years that never really existed. A mother in an apron brandishing a rolling pin; a cupboard lined with home-made plum jam; a kitchen filled with the smell of baking and warm spice.

The rules are simple: for dessert that heals rather than simply pleases, it must be stunningly sweet or blissfully milky. Like treacle sponge or, better still, treacle tart where you get pastry, too, or perhaps the rice pudding - the ultimate panacea for every ill in the book.

Any sensible person knows that rice pudding was invented for humans either too young or too old to feed themselves. I am willing to bet more rice pud has slithered down chins than has ever been swallowed. It has never been out of fashion, nor, mercifully, 'in' either.

Obviously in serious need of being bounced on someone's knee, I recently tucked into a restaurant dessert of rice pudding in a pastry shell. Come to think of it, I must have needed a hug as well, as it also came with a caramel coat. (I didn't order it, you understand, but was helping out a friend whose eyes had been bigger than her belly.) In theory, pastry, creamy rice and caramel sauce should have been the ultimate in comfort eating. It wasn't. It was as if a much-loved nanny was holding a pillow over your head till you stopped breathing.

Throw in cream, eggs or sultanas, and you have lost the spare, delicate purity that is the essence of this pudding. Rosewater, vanilla, cardamom and bay will add a whiff of luxury, but more dairy produce is literally over-egging the pudding.

Cold rice is another matter. Then it's a case of the colder and the creamier the better. It is not true that comfort food must be warm, only that it contain sugar or dairy products, or preferably both. Plump, almost fluffy grains of cold rice will take cream, and sultanas, and cinnamon, and lemon. It will take toasted, flaked almonds, too. In fact, you can throw the whole sweet section of the larder at it and it will come up trumps. Just don't tinker with the warm stuff.

If dairy doesn't do it, then teeth-shuddering sweetness might. They don't come sweeter than treacle tart or sponge. Either will rock us into a better frame of mind. You will come across recipes that contain eggs, cream and both syrup and black treacle, those with a few nuts and even a handful of oats, but for my money you cannot the beat the simple purity of syrup, crumbs and a shot of lemon. This is also one of those mysterious puddings that is better the day after you make it, when the pastry has gone ever-so-slightly soft.

With sugar in mind, you could turn to any one of our school-meal puddings and eat yourself into a good mood. Most of our baked puddings are based on the comforting chemistry of butter, flour, eggs and sugar. If you are lucky, the cook might have thrown in the odd apple, too. Best of these apple puddings is the sponge-topped Eves's pudding. Less of a farce than apple hat, this still has the requisite ingredients and would be the perfect way of using the last of the apple crop that has been in store for so long now and best used for cooking.

All this sounds immeasurably unhealthy. Who cares - it is only once in a while. And what is healthier than ensuring our wellbeing? That is, if you can get to your pudding before the non-pudding eaters scoff it all.

Vanilla rice pudding

This is a reminder of how simple it can be to have a pudding on the table when you need one. Serves 4.

50g round-grain 'pudding' rice
1 walnut-sized knob of butter
2 tbsp sugar
500ml full-cream milk
1 vanilla pod

Pour the milk into a pan and bring it to the boil. Put the rice into a small baking dish with the butter and sugar, tuck in the vanilla pod, and pour over the hot milk. Bake at 180 C/gas mark 4 for 45 minutes to 1 hour.

Some good things to add to your rice pudding before cooking

2 tsp rosewater
1 bay leaf
4 cracked cardamom pods
a little grated nutmeg

after cooking

apricot, plum or blackcurrant jam
orange marmalade
poached rhubarb

For a richer pudding or for serving cold substitute 125ml of the milk for double cream.

Old-fashioned treacle tart

If you fancy more pastry, then make half as much again and cut it into finger-thick strips, laying it in a trellis over the top of the tart before baking. I include white fat in the pastry recipe because it seems more appropriate here than an all-butter version, and is lighter and flakier, too. Serves 6.

125g plain flour
35g butter
35g lard or Trex
2 tbsp - maybe a little more - water

for the filling

120g coarse, fresh breadcrumbs
1 small tin (454g) golden syrup
lemon

Make the pastry in the usual way. I used a food processor, blitzing the flour with a tiny pinch of salt and the cold fats till they resembled coarse crumbs, then adding ice-cold water 1 tbsp at a time until the mixture could easily be brought together as a ball.

Roll the pastry out on a floured board (it is much more manageable than sweet paste) and lift it into a 30cm tart tin. Push the pastry well into the corners and up the sides of the tin then prick it with a fork, and, lining it with greaseproof paper and baking beans if you wish, bake it at 200 C/gas mark 6 for 15-17 minutes (less if it's unlined) until it is dry and pale-biscuit coloured.

Meanwhile, mix the breadcrumbs (which should be fairly coarse) with the golden syrup and the lemon juice. Pile them into the tart case and smooth them a little. Turn the oven down and return the tart, baking it for a further 25 minutes. Remove and leave to calm down for 10 minutes or so.

Eve's pudding

Pudding fanciers need to arm themselves with a collection of recipes before the pudding police ban them all. Best of the lot is Mary Norwak's glorious little book English Puddings (£13.99, Grub Street). This is Mary's apple pudding, which is light and fruit-laden but also deeply healing. Make the most of the majestic Bramleys that I notice are still in good nick right now. Serves 4-6.

450g cooking apples
75g light, soft, brown sugar
100g butter
100g caster sugar
100g self raising flour
grated rind of 1 lemon
tsp vanilla extract
extra caster sugar for sprinkling

Peel and core the apples and chop coarsely. Put into a greased ovenware dish and sprinkle on the brown sugar. Mix the fruit and sugar lightly together. Cream the butter and caster sugar. Work in the eggs, sifted flour, lemon rid and vanilla and mix to a soft batter. Spread over the apples. Bake at 180 C/gas mark 4 for 40 minutes. Sprinkle the surface with caster sugar and serve at once with cream or custard.

webTitle: Monty Don on the good side of weeds

fields.headline: Invasion of the soil snatchers
fields.standfirst: Weeds are the unwanted visitors which spoil our garden parties. But before you chuck them out, they can teach us a thing or two
fields.trailText: Weeds are the unwanted visitors which spoil our garden parties. But before you chuck them out, they can teach us a thing or two.
fields.body:
The weeds are coming! Take the children indoors and close the shutters, hide the seed corn and let the livestock fend for itself. OK, it is not exactly barbarian hordes raping and pillaging, but the inexorable invasion of the garden by weeds can feel like enemy action. In my own garden, almost nothing else has grown over the past few weeks except the weeds, which, unlike every other form of vegetation, seems to be enjoying this dismal spring with unhealthy relish.

I have creeping buttercup, burdock, greater and lesser celandine, couch grass, bindweed, docks and nettles all doing very nicely, thank you, and those are just the perennials. All the annual weeds, such as the great rafts of goosegrass, caper spurge, wavy bittercress, shepherd's-purse, dead nettle, shepherd's needle, groundsel and sow thistle are showing up nicely - God's crop, joker that he undoubtedly is.

There is a school of thought that gets all touchy-feely about weeds, saying that, hey, they are just plants in the wrong place, right? Well, no. A weed is a plant you don't want, it is acne on a beautiful face or hairs in the soup. Not the end of the world, but we don't want them. But there are some positive things to learn from weeds before you get rid of them. For a start, the greater fecundity of your weed population, the healthier and better conditioned is your soil. Secondly, the greater the diversity of weed types, the healthier your garden environment and the greater the range of plants that you will eventually be able to grow. A wide range of weeds will also attract a wide selection of insects and do much to contribute to the holistic balance of your garden - which is the very essence of successful organic gardening. (And chemical gardening is a bore. Stop it at once.)

The type and limitations of the weeds growing are a useful indicator of the nature and condition of your soil. Very acidic soil will produce lots of sorrel and plantain, but no charlock or poppy which thrive on lime. Chickweed is a good indicator of a neutral pH. Nettles, ground elder, fat hen and chickweed point to a soil high in nitrogen. Silverweed and greater plantain will grow on very compacted soil. Creeping buttercup, horsetail and silverweed (again) point to a wet soil with poor drainage. Lastly, some weeds are very good to eat. Now is the best time to make nettle soup, using just the freshest new growth. Dandelion leaves are good in salad, ground elder was originally grown as a vegetable crop, wild sorrel makes a good sauce and horseradish, which can be one of the most intrusive of all weeds, is essential to a rib of beef.

In practical terms, there are two types of weed for the gardener, perennial and annual. Both are bad because they compete with your chosen plants for water and nutrition, and the nature of all prolific weeds is that they are extremely good at grabbing all available goodness. Obviously, there are places where this competition is less harmful - around mature trees and shrubs or along the bottom of a fully grown hedge. But hedges can be the last resort of perennial weeds in an otherwise weed-free garden. We have bindweed, greater celandine, creeping buttercup and couchgrass all firmly entrenched in our hornbeam hedges. Sometimes you can use weeds to improve the quality of a crop. I am thinking particularly of onions, which must be kept weed-free until they are fully grown, but which ripen better if they are then starved by weeds so that no more growing energy goes into top growth. But, in general, aim at a weed-free garden.

Any regular reader of this page will know that in my book this does not include any kind of chemical control. Chemicals are very good at destroying weeds, but they also destroy plants you want to keep and - I believe - your health, let alone the micro-diversity of your soil and the insect life of your garden. I am convinced that there is never any need to use chemical weedkillers and that conviction is based upon experience. Weedkillers are pushed hard by chemical companies because they are enormously profitable. That's all.

There are other ways to deal with weeds:

1 Hoe. There are lots of hoes available, but there are only two basic principles: you either push or you pull. I find I use a Dutch hoe most of the time, which, if kept sharp, slices through the roots of any weeds just below the surface of the soil. The secret of hoeing - like all weeding - is to do it little and often. If you have a very weed-infested bit of ground you want to cultivate (and remember, weed-infestation implies good healthy soil) and they have not yet gone to seed, then hoe the weeds off with a mattock or large draw or field hoe, let the weeds wilt for a day in the sun and then dig the whole thing over, weeds and all. This will not get rid of the perennial weeds but will increase the fertility and allow you to grow a crop of fast-growing, weed-suppressing vegetables such as potatoes, beans or squashes.

2 Mulch. Cover every piece of bare soil with a light-excluding but moisture-permeable layer. I use mushroom and garden compost and cocoa shells. Well-rotted horse or cattle manure is good, but cattle manure can include a lot of weed seeds if it is not very well-rotted. But anything will do, including straw, hay, shredded bark, permeable plastic, old carpet, or rolls of white paper mulch. If you are using an organic mulch (ie, one that will rot down into the soil), place it at least 2in thick - 4in is better. This will not stop existing perennial weeds growing through but will make them much easier to pull up.

3 Hand-weed. First the bad news: hand-weeding means getting down on your knees and removing every scrap of weed. Now the good news: it is one of the most enjoyable aspects of gardening. You get to know your soil, your plants, the seedlings and herbaceous perennials coming through.

4 Timing. You must remove weeds before they seed. The old adage 'one year's seeding means seven years' weeding' is pretty much accurate.

My weeds: Monty's list of garden horrors

Annuals

Never let these seed:shepherd's-purse (Capsella bursa-pastoris); bittercress (Cardamine); fat hen (Chenopodium album); caper spurge (Euphorbia lathyrus); petty spurge (Euphorbia peplus); goosegrass (Galium aparine); herb Robert (Geranium robertianum); Himalaya balsam (Impatiens glandifulifera); knotgrass (Polygonum aviculare); shepherd's needle (Scandix pectenveneris); groundsel (Senecio vulgaris); charlock (Sinapsis arvensis) ; prickly sow thistle (Sonchus asper); chickweed (Stellaria media)

Perennials

Very difficult (will take long-term strategy or inspired acceptance): Japanese knotweed (Polygonum cuspidatum); horsetail (Equisetum)

Take very seriously (dig up every scrap of root and burn): ground elder (Aegopodium podagraria); bindweed (Convolvulus arvensis, Calystegia sepium); creeping buttercup (Ranunculus repens); couch grass (Agropyron repens); lesser celandine (Ranunculus ficaria)

Work at (dig up as and when you can): broad- leaved dock (Rumex obtusifolius); nettles (Urtica dioica); spear thistle (Cirsium vulgare); creeping thistle (Cirsium arvense); burdock (Arctium lappa)

Handsome (but intrusive): daisy (Bellis perennis); greater celandine (Chelidonium majus); teasel (Dipsacus fullonum); rosebay willowherb (Epilobium angustifolium); hogweed (Heracleum spondylium); dead-nettle (Lamium); alkanet (Pentaglottis sempervirens); mallow (Malva sylvestris); plantain (Plantago major); silverweed (Potentilla anserina); selfheal (Prunella vulgaris); comfrey (Symphytum); feverfew (Tanacetum); dandelion (Taraxacum).

My roots: A week in Monty's garden

Harry is out on the JCB. I'm anxious, mainly because he is petrified. Harry dug our septic tank 10 years ago, when the garden was no more than a gleam in my eye. It was the first and last time he had ever operated a digger. It will take a couple of days Harry, I say. And more than a couple of Valium, he mutters. I haven't slept all weekend. It's a bit tricky_

You may remember that we flooded last autumn and our septic tank was out of use for three weeks. So we have arranged for another one to be put in, which means digging up a large piece of the garden. To be honest, I had almost forgotten about it, but they turned up yesterday with JCB, dumper and a lorryload of stone. It was like knowing that you had a nagging tooth and coming down to breakfast to find the dentist hovering over your chair, drill ready whirring.

Did I say that it has rained all week? That the garden is like a slurry. That even a wheelbarrow is almost impossible to manoeuvre on the grass? So a JCB_ never mind. It must be done.

The new bench for the greenhouse has been delivered. It is all aluminium and stainless steel. No soul but we are now seriously smart in the greenhouse department. We don't need this, of course. It is a way of pretending to be more professional and grown-up than we ever are, and the trick works every time I walk in there. Every inch is now laden with seedlings. I made some soil blocks the other day, sowed them with Little Gem lettuce and Mizuna, went off to Birmingham next morning to spend a day filming, came back, and I swear that all had germinated and were sprigged with leaf. Magic.

Rather grudgingly I tackled the lesser celandine in the spring garden. There is no joy in this kind of weeding because it has infiltrated nooks and crannies so thoroughly that inevitably precious hellebore seedlings are taken up as you fork, however carefully you do it. It is a real object lesson in weed control, as it should have been tackled properly last year, but as it wasn't too bad I let it go. Fatal.

It is the wetness in the spring garden from global warming that has ruined the drainage system, which has meant digging new drains that has upset Harry so much. It's all that George Dubya Bush's fault. I'd get him to come over and remove the celandines and send him penitent back to Kyoto, but Harry says he'd have to do the JCB stuff first. That would sort him.

My weeds: Monty's list of garden horrors Annuals Never let these seed:shepherd's-purse (Capsella bursa-pastoris); bittercress (Cardamine); fat hen (Chenopodium album); caper spurge (Euphorbia lathyrus); petty spurge (Euphorbia peplus); goosegrass (Galium aparine); herb Robert (Geranium robertianum); Himalaya balsam (Impatiens glandifulifera); knotgrass (Polygonum aviculare); shepherd's needle (Scandix pectenveneris); groundsel (Senecio vulgaris); charlock (Sinapsis arvensis) ; prickly sow thistle (Sonchus asper); chickweed (Stellaria media) Perennials Very difficult (will take long-term strategy or inspired acceptance): Japanese knotweed (Polygonum cuspidatum); horsetail (Equisetum) Take very seriously (dig up every scrap of root and burn): ground elder (Aegopodium podagraria); bindweed (Convolvulus arvensis, Calystegia sepium); creeping buttercup (Ranunculus repens); couch grass (Agropyron repens); lesser celandine (Ranunculus ficaria) Work at (dig up as and when you can): broad- leaved dock (Rumex obtusifolius); nettles (Urtica dioica); spear thistle (Cirsium vulgare); creeping thistle (Cirsium arvense); burdock (Arctium lappa) Handsome (but intrusive): daisy (Bellis perennis); greater celandine (Chelidonium majus); teasel (Dipsacus fullonum); rosebay willowherb (Epilobium angustifolium); hogweed (Heracleum spondylium); dead-nettle (Lamium); alkanet (Pentaglottis sempervirens); mallow (Malva sylvestris); plantain (Plantago major); silverweed (Potentilla anserina); selfheal (Prunella vulgaris); comfrey (Symphytum); feverfew (Tanacetum); dandelion (Taraxacum). My roots: A week in Monty's garden Harry is out on the JCB. I'm anxious, mainly because he is petrified. Harry dug our septic tank 10 years ago, when the garden was no more than a gleam in my eye. It was the first and last time he had ever operated a digger. It will take a couple of days Harry, I say. And more than a couple of Valium, he mutters. I haven't slept all weekend. It's a bit tricky_ You may remember that we flooded last autumn and our septic tank was out of use for three weeks. So we have arranged for another one to be put in, which means digging up a large piece of the garden. To be honest, I had almost forgotten about it, but they turned up yesterday with JCB, dumper and a lorryload of stone. It was like knowing that you had a nagging tooth and coming down to breakfast to find the dentist hovering over your chair, drill ready whirring. Did I say that it has rained all week? That the garden is like a slurry. That even a wheelbarrow is almost impossible to manoeuvre on the grass? So a JCB_ never mind. It must be done. The new bench for the greenhouse has been delivered. It is all aluminium and stainless steel. No soul but we are now seriously smart in the greenhouse department. We don't need this, of course. It is a way of pretending to be more professional and grown-up than we ever are, and the trick works every time I walk in there. Every inch is now laden with seedlings. I made some soil blocks the other day, sowed them with Little Gem lettuce and Mizuna, went off to Birmingham next morning to spend a day filming, came back, and I swear that all had germinated and were sprigged with leaf. Magic. Rather grudgingly I tackled the lesser celandine in the spring garden. There is no joy in this kind of weeding because it has infiltrated nooks and crannies so thoroughly that inevitably precious hellebore seedlings are taken up as you fork, however carefully you do it. It is a real object lesson in weed control, as it should have been tackled properly last year, but as it wasn't too bad I let it go. Fatal. It is the wetness in the spring garden from global warming that has ruined the drainage system, which has meant digging new drains that has upset Harry so much. It's all that George Dubya Bush's fault. I'd get him to come over and remove the celandines and send him penitent back to Kyoto, but Harry says he'd have to do the JCB stuff first. That would sort him.

webTitle: Drop case against me, says Shayler

fields.headline: Drop case against me, says Shayler
fields.trailText: Former MI5 officer David Shayler yesterday challenged the Government to investigate 'incompetence, malpractice and crime' in the intelligence services and drop all charges against him.
fields.body:
Former MI5 officer David Shayler yesterday challenged the Government to investigate 'incompetence, malpractice and crime' in the intelligence services and drop all charges against him.

Shayler will appear in the High Court in London on Wednesday, charged with breaching the Official Secrets Act.

Sources close to the intelligence community this weekend said MI5 was 'desperate to draw a line under the case' but that the trial would almost certainly be pushed back until after the general election.

Shayler last night called for a full parliamentary inquiry into his four key revelations that:

 Two foreign intelligence officers, known at PT16 and PT16/B, conspired to assassinate Colonel Muammar Gaddafi of Libya. In the failed plot, innocent civilians were killed, he claims.

 The Bishopsgate bombing of April 1993 could have been averted, but MI5 bungling meant that intelligence about the IRA active service unit that carried out the attack was ignored.

 The intelligence services systematically bugged confidential interviews between suspected terrorists and their lawyers at Belmarsh high-security prison.

 Warnings about the bombing of the Israeli embassy in July 1994 were ignored by MI5, leading to the false imprisonment of two Palestinians.

'I'm absolutely convinced that if my disclosures had been investigated and the results made public, it would be untenable to prosecute me now,' Shayler said.

He added that the Government would like to see the trial postponed until after the election to minimise embarrassment.

Shayler's lawyers will argue that the Official Secrets Act is incompatible with new human rights legislation and the trial could be postponed until spring 2002 if either side takes the judge's decision on the human rights issue to judicial review.

The Attorney-General, Lord Williams, has instructed prosecution lawyers to appeal if the decsion goes against them. Home Secretary Jack Straw and Foreign Secretary Robin Cook would both be subpoenaed as witnesses by the defence.

Ministers and civil servants agree that the Official Secrets Act needs substantial reform. The battle lines are drawn between the 'doves' who are pushing for a more open American-style system and 'hawks' who want a crackdown, to prevent confidential leaks over the internet.

The Intelligence and Security Committee, which oversees the work of the intelligence agencies, has warned Straw that he should strengthen the Official Secrets Act immediately after the election.

Its annual report concluded: 'Disclosures are now increasingly being made, sometimes anonymously, on media such as the internet, with no obvious redress by the authorities in the UK.'

martin.bright@observer.co.uk

webTitle: Peter Preston

fields.headline: Economics gurus are back, feeling the pinch
fields.trailText: See how the contagion spreads. There is, the experts say, no rhyme or reason to it. We shouldn't automatically be dragged into America's gathering gloom. Yet funeral pyres for diseased enterprises grow, City job culls begin. Hold the front page. The economics correspondents are back in business.
fields.body:
See how the contagion spreads. There is, the experts say, no rhyme or reason to it. We shouldn't automatically be dragged into America's gathering gloom. Yet funeral pyres for diseased enterprises grow, City job culls begin. Hold the front page. The economics correspondents are back in business.

Ten years ago, as Britain creaked towards its ERM debacle, economics gurus were Fleet Street's elite: the best paid, the best displayed, the most relentlessly wooed. Then the good times rolled again. Will Hutton turned editor and think tank commander; Chris Huhne turned Euro MP; Anatole Kaletsky became a fine multi-purpose columnist. Who needed to keep taking the markets' pulse when the beat was steady? Who cared about boom without bust? Football reporters and showbiz snoopers became the transfer fee masters.

But tides have a way of turning. Last week, when the Federal Reserve slashed interest rates, the Times splashed on it (and all broadsheets gave Greenspan prominence). Central bankers possess headline power again. The collapse of the hi-tech bubble matters. Readers have recession on their minds. And it is time, perhaps, to grow a little more thoughtful.

Economics journalists are human beings: they watch trends and statistics, but they also live in the world around them. Lead stories filled with doubt and sorrow set the adrenalin pumping. In that sense, gloom is good. A market force. Beyond it, though, a new reality bites.

We're used to thinking of our biggest international media groups as the strongest in town, the massed battalions of Pearson, Murdoch, O'Reilly, Black, and Gannett. These are giant players. Yet their size and spread in a global economy also makes them vulnerable. While Gordon Brown talks of preserving the fundamentals of prosperity here, their fundamentals are rooted elsewhere.

Consider the first-quarter results from Gannett last week. Newsquest (its British operation) continues to do well, with recruitment advertising 25 per cent up; but the flagship USA Today is 20 per cent down, and local dailies across the States are suffering. That must inevitably exert strains here.

Consider Pearson. The FT is doing wonderfully, more than 500,000 in circulation last month, turning in an £81 million profit last year; but factor in £113m of internet investment, caught short by American dotcom desuetude, and the squeeze is on. Ten per cent of website staff get the axe for starters; budgets come under pressure.

Consider Rupert Murdoch after his failure to do the deal with DirecTV, which looked like reviving his share price. He was trapped in the 1991 US recession and teetered for a while, almost going under. Once bitten, twice shy. Murdoch saw the dip in American advertising coming at the end of 2000 and ordered a hiring freeze throughout the empire. But now US ad decline is fact, not prediction, will freezes be enough? Are we in for a year of slashed budgets, too?

Conrad Black and Tony O'Reilly, in their separate geographical ways, have the same problems. Black may, with typical shrewdness, have sold the bulk of his Canadian enterprise at premium prices just in time, but he is commit ted to bruising fights in Toronto and Chicago. O'Reilly won't relish the immediate outlook in Australia and New Zealand; and South Africa remains promise unfulfilled.

In all these cases, at least for the moment, the weakest links are overseas. Gordon Brown's Britain may be a redoubt of profitability, but there's a chill from the outposts of empire and it makes any faltering here doubly dangerous.

Small advertising revenue declines (of the kind already being whispered) have a serious impact when they're tacked on to American enter prises down 10 or 20 per cent and being hammered by an unforgiving stock market.

Worse, a fresh development, the dotcom debacle, flows seamlessly across borders. A weakening in Washington for the FT is a weakening in London. A slash-back by Murdoch in the States translates almost automatically to other countries. The journalists and the managers who lose their jobs don't live in lonely islands: they are part of a wider community and need no jungle telegraph to feel its distress.

What does this mean in human terms? It means, if you're an economics correspondent for an international group, that you're already feeling the pinch. Redundancies, hiring freezes, talk of budget cuts - these are the realities that surround you: your corporate environment. Europe isn't so much of an influence because Europe is a minor player on your media stage. The bad news bears are raised in America.

'What's it like to manage your way through recession?' one young press executive asked me the other day. She had known only eight years of rosy growth. She had no idea of what downturns were like. Let's hope she doesn't need to find out now. Perhaps Greenspan has done the trick and turned a bust into a blip.

But if confidence is part of the equation, remember that confidence is a malleable feast and that most of its chroniclers find themselves sitting in exceptionally wobbly and untypical stall seats. As these commentators start to make it back on to the front pages, they come from their own front lines. Good news, bad news? Reach for the pills labelled Perspective.

webTitle: FT's Marj is still in charge

fields.headline: FT's Marj is still in charge
fields.standfirst:
But the City is now starting to ask hard questions about the first lady's Midas touch, writes Heather Connon

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: But the City is now starting to ask hard questions about the first lady's Midas touch, writes Heather Connon
fields.body:
When Marjorie Scardino addresses the annual meeting of Pearson in London's Queen Elizabeth Conference Centre on Friday she may find herself facing something rather unfamiliar: an audience of shareholders increasingly sceptical about her stewardship of the media group.

Any doubts early in her tenure that someone whose previous experience included a spell of shrimp fishing and the ownership of a community paper in Georgia would be able to sort out the messy Pearson conglomerate were quickly dispelled. As it turned out, Scardino did everything the City hoped, and more.

Her success earned her the nickname of 'Marj in Charge' from respectful Pearson employees.

Peripheral assets such as Madame Tussauds and Lazards were dispatched and proceeds were reinvested into the core publishing empire through acquisitions such as Simon & Schuster and NCS, the educational testing business. Circulation of the Financial Times has topped half a million worldwide - trebling to 135,000 in the US - and she is now promising to increase circulation to 750,000 by 2004.

The American set herself what looked like unrealistic targets - doubling market value within five years, growing earnings per share by at least 10 per cent a year - and managed to beat them. Her reward was a soaring share price. At their peak 13 months ago the shares had all but quadrupled since the start of her tenure, and she was. crowned First Lady of the FTSE. Recently, however, there have been a few rumbles of dissent. The $2.5 billion paid for NCS looks expensive now that euphoria about e-learning is starting to wane, and that has focused attention on slow growth at the rest of the US educational business. The City is waiting for the first sign that advertising revenue at the Financial Times, Economist and the group's other newspapers and magazines is being hit by the global slowdown.

The share price has fallen sharply, but some think it is still overvalued. 'There are considerable risks to forecasts,' one institutional investor said. 'And we are concerned that they have overpaid for acquisitions.'

Above all, there is ft.com. Scathing articles under headlines like 'FTDot Bomb' have appeared in publications from the Spectator to London's Evening Standard questioning whether it can ever make the electronic version of the FT pay. There is much speculation about job cuts and closure of some parts of the site, which continues even after the recent cut backs.

Then there has been the speculation about Scardino herself. There have been persistent and, the company insists, unfounded rumours that she is about to head back to her native America. One even suggested that she was about to join the Bush administration - apparently ignorant of the fact that she is a fully paid-up Democrat.

Pearson's riposte to concerns about ft.com is detailed right. In essence the case for ft.com rests on its ability to grow income from areas that hardly exist, let alone have any measurable historic trends, such as supplying data to wap telephones and selling specialist company searches. Pearson's justification for the price it paid for NCS rests on similarly unquantifiable claims.

NCS is the leading supplier of software services to schools, which do everything from count the number of absentees to showing children's grades.It has products in almost half of all US schools. Finance director John Makinson believes the big opportunity is to use these links to 'personalise learning' for individual pupils by integrating the teaching programmes with monitoring and assessment.

Pearson believes the business will also benefit from the educational reforms proposed by President Bush, including a commitment to introducing regular testing of all students. At the moment, only eight US states comply with Bush's plans and, as the leading supplier of testing systems, NCS could be a big beneficiary.

That is a lot of 'ifs'. Makinson is convinced the acquisition will prove itself and he points out that NCS had a strong growth record before Pearson bought it.

But the $2.5 billion price represented three times NCS' revenues. To justify that, it has to do far more than just maintain growth. It has to demonstrate that it can establish NCS as the internet platform for schools, and that it can build on that to sell other products and services.

For the moment, the City seems prepared to trust Scardino to do that. 'I still regard the management team very highly,' said one large shareholder.

Both Pearson and Scardino have been anxious to avoid a cult of personality - so much so that she rarely does interviews. But there is little doubt that she is heavily identified with the contentious issues. The performance of NCS and ft.com over the coming 12 months will do much to determine the atmosphere at next year's annual meeting.

'We weren't carried away by euphoria, and there's no doom and gloom now'

webTitle: I have a stream - or I did till they pulled the plug

fields.headline: I have a stream - or I did till they pulled the plug
fields.standfirst:
More internet news
MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: One of the great pleasures in life is to listen to Radio 4's PM programme while shaving in a Seattle hotel. How come?
fields.body:
One of the great pleasures in life is to listen to Radio 4's PM programme while shaving in a Seattle hotel. How come?

Simple: Radio 4 now streams its programmes over the Net.This is incredibly useful, and not just for those who are homesick in Seattle. Most of us, for example, listen to the Today programme with only half an ear while trying to locate missing socks. By the time we've twigged that an item is interesting, it's usually ended.

For example, that clip on Thursday morning in which John Prescott seemed to maintain that the US had not abandoned efforts to combat global warming. Surely I imagined that?

In the old days, it would have vanished into the ether. But all I had to do was log on to www.bbc.co.uk/radio4/today/ and there was Prescott - large as life and still inflicting grievous bodily harm on the English language. There is also a searchable archive of sound clips. A search for 'Richard Branson', for example, turned up innumerable interviews with the great man about trains and planes and national lotteries.

Radio 4's website is not only a good example of what public service broadcasting is for, but also a reminder of how revolutionary the technology of streaming audio has been. Like all great ideas, it was stupendously simple. It's always been possible to transfer audio files across the Net, but you had to wait until the entire file had downloaded before you could play it.

But suppose, mused Rob Glaser one day in 1994, you could compress the file, download the first bit of it and then start to play that while the rest was downloading. He reckoned that this would transform the listener's experience of internet audio. And he was right.

With some notable exceptions (for example Ireland's RTE) conventional radio broadcasters were initially sniffy about this disruptive technology. The audio quality was dire, they pointed out; more like old-fashioned short-wave radio than proper FM signals. Who would want to listen to that stuff?

It turned out that countless thousands of people wanted to listen to it - especially those scattered in diasporas across the globe. RTE, for example, found that its servers were swamped on big days like the All-Ireland Hurling Final, when my countrymen in Seattle and Tokyo and Cape Town tried to hear the game live.

RealAudio (as Mr Glaser's product was called) became a lifeline for those who emigrate but want to keep in touch with home.

As time passed, the speed of internet connections increased and streaming software improved, to the point where the technology could deliver good audio quality over broadband links and quite tolerable reception even over dial-up connections.

At this point the objections of traditional broadcasters mysteriously evaporated and many of them began 'simulcasting' - streaming - their programmes over the web as they were going out on air.

Like everything else related to the internet, the practice has mushroomed and there are now some 10,000 stations doing it worldwide. Or rather, were, until last week when some big US domestic broadcasters abruptly pulled the plug on their simulcasts.

The reason? Some legal eagle had spotted that the settlement terms of the 1999 strike by the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists included a 300% bonus fee payable to voiceover artists whose commercials are run on the web. Advertising agencies, which are liable for the fees, demanded that broadcasters pull the affected commercials off the Web.

The broadcasters opted to shut down their streaming operations entirely. Which only goes to show that while technology is wonderful, it still pays to read the fine print.

But all I had to do was log on to www.bbc.co.uk/radio4/today/ and there was Prescott - large as life and still inflicting grievous bodily harm on the English language. There is also a searchable archive of sound clips. A search for 'Richard Branson', for example, turned up innumerable interviews with the great man about trains and planes and national lotteries. Radio 4's website is not only a good example of what public service broadcasting is for, but also a reminder of how revolutionary the technology of streaming audio has been. Like all great ideas, it was stupendously simple. It's always been possible to transfer audio files across the Net, but you had to wait until the entire file had downloaded before you could play it. But suppose, mused Rob Glaser one day in 1994, you could compress the file, download the first bit of it and then start to play that while the rest was downloading. He reckoned that this would transform the listener's experience of internet audio. And he was right. With some notable exceptions (for example Ireland's RTE) conventional radio broadcasters were initially sniffy about this disruptive technology. The audio quality was dire, they pointed out; more like old-fashioned short-wave radio than proper FM signals. Who would want to listen to that stuff? It turned out that countless thousands of people wanted to listen to it - especially those scattered in diasporas across the globe. RTE, for example, found that its servers were swamped on big days like the All-Ireland Hurling Final, when my countrymen in Seattle and Tokyo and Cape Town tried to hear the game live. RealAudio (as Mr Glaser's product was called) became a lifeline for those who emigrate but want to keep in touch with home. As time passed, the speed of internet connections increased and streaming software improved, to the point where the technology could deliver good audio quality over broadband links and quite tolerable reception even over dial-up connections. At this point the objections of traditional broadcasters mysteriously evaporated and many of them began 'simulcasting' - streaming - their programmes over the web as they were going out on air. Like everything else related to the internet, the practice has mushroomed and there are now some 10,000 stations doing it worldwide. Or rather, were, until last week when some big US domestic broadcasters abruptly pulled the plug on their simulcasts. The reason? Some legal eagle had spotted that the settlement terms of the 1999 strike by the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists included a 300% bonus fee payable to voiceover artists whose commercials are run on the web. Advertising agencies, which are liable for the fees, demanded that broadcasters pull the affected commercials off the Web. The broadcasters opted to shut down their streaming operations entirely. Which only goes to show that while technology is wonderful, it still pays to read the fine print. john.naughton@observer.co.uk

webTitle: 'We weren't carried away by euphoria, and there's no doom and gloom now'

fields.headline: 'We weren't carried away by euphoria, and there's no doom and gloom now'
fields.standfirst:
ft.com is right at the heart of the troubles, says Heather Connon

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: ft.com is right at the heart of the troubles, says Heather Connon
fields.body:
Unravel the speculation about management and the rumours of investor unrest and, at the heart, you will find ft.com, the internet site of the Financial Times. It is not hard to see why.

On the revenue side, the figures look impressive enough: income from the site rose threefold to reach £18 million in 2000. But at what cost? Pearson does not split out spending on ft.com from the rest of the Financial Times Group's internet activities, but analysts believe ft.com accounted for the lion's share of the £155m cost last year. The result was a £113m loss, wiping out more than half the profits of the Group.

Marjorie Scardino was unfazed: 'We weren't carried away by the internet euphoria and we aren't carried away by the doom and gloom now either.' To prove it, she is promising that internet activities will break even by the end of next year, a full two years earlier than had originally been expected.

To some, that seems a heroic promise. Internet advertising is falling sharply as dotcoms collapse and conventional companies are getting too few clicks. Even the mighty Dow Jones warned that advertising revenue on WSJ.com 'fell off significantly'.Pearson has set itself firmly against charging subscriptions for its basic services, as the Wall Street Journal does. Other free sites have closed or are struggling.

John Makinson, Pearson's finance director, has a clear idea of how he gets to break-even. Advertising is less buoyant than it was but revenues are still rising. But the main focus will be on building other revenues: syndicating its services and offering premium services, such as the search service askft and FT Mobile, the service being sold through Carphone Warehouse which launches next month. These, he predicts, will supply 45 per cent of revenue this year, up from just 21 per cent in 2000.Spending on technology peaked last year and should fall in 2001. There have also been other cost cuts. Earlier this month, ft.com shed 40 of the 350 people dedicated to its internet business and it is also making savings by integrating advertising and editorial services with the newspaper.

In editorial, there are about 80 people who work mainly on ft.com, but they will also be expected to contribute to the paper, while newspaper writers also produce work for the website.These three elements - lower costs, higher revenues and reduced technology spending - are expected to contribute equally to the pledge to break even.

That suggests total internet revenues across the FT group would have to more than double from last year's £42m. That was not too ambitious when e-phoria was at its peak; now, it looks demanding, particularly when a large part of last year's revenue came from e-signal, which will not grow very much.Having made such a public commitment, however, it would be disastrous to fail. It is not too extreme to say that Scardino's reputation depends on it.

FT's Marj is still in charge

webTitle: Media Diary

fields.headline: Media Diary
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: BBC Jeff is in the sky-high club
fields.body:
BBC Jeff is in the sky-high club

Jeff Randall, the fun-loving business editor of the BBC, has learned to take the knocks over the years, but a recent dig in Private Eye really had him fuming.

The piece revealed how the 'cigar-chomping, £250,000-a-year Essex boy' had blown no less than £3,350 of Auntie's cash (that's more than 30 TV licences, dear reader) by flying club-class on a business trip to the US, apparently risking the wrath of the belt-tightening director general, Greg Dyke. In the spirit of objective reporting, which has become our hallmark, Diary rings Jeff to grill him on where the Beeb's licence fee is going. A peeved Randall is perplexed by Lord Gnome's news agenda. 'If they'd caught me out travelling economy, that would have been a story.'

FACT - Randall had the right to business-class air travel written into his BBC contract.

Ann, the romantic?

Working Title, the film company behind Bridget Jones's Diary, will be delighted by Diary 's exclusive news that its fans can be found in the most unlikely quarters. Standing behind our 37th favourite female politician, Ann Widdecombe, in a taxi rank the other night, Diary noticed Widders was carrying an HMV bag containing a Notting Hill video.

Worryingly, there was also a copy of Thomas Harris's Hannibal.

Damien's bad omen

Diary learns in something of a less-than-astonished fashion that Damien McCrystal, restaurant reviewer and diarist extraordinaire, has had what our top source calls 'a falling out' with the Savoy hotel chain's owners, the US money men Blackstone.

Given his vast patronage of the hotels' eating facilities - especially the Savoy Grill - this is a serious thing.

The Yanks apparently took umbrage at something McCrystal wrote, and revived a dispute about a bill, eventually cancelling his credit facilities in all their restaurants. 'They've lost a very big customer,' says McCrystal, 'but I don't mind. Marco Pierre White has given me account facilities in all his restaurants.'

Grill manager Angelo Maresca is said to be heartbroken. Diary reckons a Savoy profits warning is imminent.

webTitle: Neil insists Barclays keeping Scotsman

fields.headline: Neil insists Barclays keeping Scotsman
fields.standfirst: Publisher dismisses as 'lies' claims that media empire will be sold off after huge investment fails to improve newspapers' performance
fields.trailText: Publisher dismisses as 'lies' claims that media empire will be sold off after huge investment fails to improve newspapers' performance.
fields.body:
Andrew Neil, the embattled publisher of the Scotsman, is this weekend fending off fresh reports that the secretive Barclay brothers, who own the Scotsman, Scotland on Sunday and Sunday Business, are planning to sell the papers.

Just days after Neil dismissed as 'lies' claims that the Barclays were hiving off their media empire, informed sources say the Barclays are losing patience with Neil and the millions of pounds of the family's money he has spent trying to revive Scotland's national newspaper.

Sources close to the Barclays say Aidan Barclay, son of David Barclay who with his twin brother Frederick bought the Scotsman, does not share his father's emotional attachment to newspapers and is considering a sell-off.

One source told The Observer: 'Aidan is not happy at the way Andrew Neil has spent so much money and hasn't yet got the improved performance to justify the investment. Neil burned a lot of money last year at the Scotsman with cover price cuts and promotions and the jury is still out as to whether it's been a success.

'Andrew Neil may tell his public detractors that the papers are not for sale but they are not his to sell. Aidan Barclay took seriously an approach from the Trinity Mirror group last spring to buy the papers for £250 million and is thought to have carried on negotiations behind Neil's back.'

Neil admitted last week that the Scotsman, which has already lost dozens of key staff following the Barclay twins' takeover, was making fresh cutbacks. Scotsman insiders say budgets are being slashed by up to 20 per cent. The picture desk budget has been particularly badly hit - despite its staff photographers winning a clutch of national awards - and there is a clampdown on expenses.

Not even the paper's editor, Rebecca Hardy, has survived unscathed. The fresh jugs of coffee that used to sit outside her office have been removed. When Neil told her about the cuts, she reportedly stormed out of a meeting.

Neil said last week that 'after five years of continuous increased investment in editorial excellence' spending was being cut. 'We are tightening our belts a little because of the current downturn in advertising revenues, which all papers are experiencing because of the slowdown in the economy.'

A split is also developing between the Scotsman and Scotland on Sunday, its widely acclaimed and vastly different sister paper which has been rejuvenated under new editor Margot Wilson. Scotland on Sunday has recently been successfully redesigned and its magazine, Spectrum, won the Scottish supplement of the year award.

Staff on the paper, which has seen off the challenge of the Sunday Herald in Glasgow by maintaining its 100,000-plus sales, say the well-publicised problems at the Scotsman are damaging their image. One staffer said: 'There's a buzz here with a solid young team in place and a confidence that has been hard won. I just hope it isn't all lost.'

Neil, a former Sunday Times editor, continues to deny that the group's titles are being pared down as a prelude to a sell-off. Last week he bitterly criticised Scotland's biggest selling daily, the Daily Record, for questioning his future as the head of the Barclay's media empire.

He accused the Record of 'making up' a story that the Scotsman was for sale and that he could be forced to quit. 'There seem to be no depths to which Scotland's biggest-selling downmarket tabloid is prepared to plummet as it peddles invention and untruths?' Neil said.

'The Scotsman is not for sale. I can be categorical about that because it is the truth.'

Informed sources who say the Barclays are planning a sell-off say the Scotsman has been losing money at an unprecedented rate. Insiders say the number of copies sold at full price is as low as 70,000.

Morale at the Scotsman is at rock bottom with staff complaining they cannot bring out a newspaper on a shoestring. 'The cuts of 20 per cent are a killer,' one said. 'We have stopped working like a national newspaper. It feels more like a local paper now, run on local paper budgets, with local paper rules. Senior journalists have quit or been fired. The young hacks appointed in their place are not good enough.'

To make matters worse, the main rival, the daily Herald, under new editor, Mark Douglas-Home has been setting the news agenda with a series of scoops that have left the Scotsman looking off the pace. 'We are being scalped on a daily basis,' one staffer said.

A spokesman for the Barclays dismissed claims that the Scotsman would be sold as 'madness, tittle tattle'.

webTitle: The painting is genuine but this artworld bad boy is fake

fields.headline: The painting is genuine but this artworld bad boy is fake
fields.standfirst:
He has an art O-level and knows a lot about emulsion. But could he hack it in London's galleries? Vanessa Thorpe meets the decorator who fooled the critics

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: He has an art O-level and knows a lot about emulsion. But could he hack it in London's galleries? Vanessa Thorpe meets the decorator who fooled the critics.
fields.body:
It is a familiar refrain among people at art galleries: they could have painted some of the pricey abstract paintings on show themselves and basked in critical acclaim.

Now, for the first time, the truth can be revealed: it would take a complete newcomer as little as a month to learn how to fool the critics and win a place among the elite earning thousands of pounds for contemporary abstract work.

A former painter and decorator from Liverpool has proved the point by passing himself off as a rising star of the conceptual art scene. Each step of his astonishing transformation is laid out on television screens next Monday in the third episode of Channel Four's Faking It.

Paul O'Hare ran a successful decorating firm before he was persuaded by programme-makers to live and work in fashionable East London for four weeks - and to learn, at high speed, the ways of the art world.

Armed with an O-level in art and a knowledge of non-drip emulsions, O'Hare agreed to become the subject of a daring experiment. While not exactly 'faking it', because he would create his own works of art, he would attempt to convince three experts that he was a genuine professional at the end of a month of training.

O'Hare confessed he did not understand what abstract art 'was for'. 'I know what it is. I just don't agree with it,' he told the Slade-trained artist Laura Godfrey Isaacs, who was charged with the task of turning O'Hare into a credible fake.

She took him to see the work of other young artists at an annual contemporary art show held in North London, but he remained nonplussed. Damien Hirst's wheel of butterflies stuck in paint was the only piece O'Hare connected with. 'I have had insects get caught up in my paint like that before, and I always feel sorry for them,' he said.

But things changed when he got his hands dirty in the studio. Starting with self-portraits, O'Hare quickly moved on to monotype prints, made by tracing a simple image on to glass. Almost instantly the student found himself drawn to making images that referred to a long period of illness in his childhood. He focused on one outline shape of a child with a crutch.

O'Hare also swotted up on the language of bohemia by studying the crib book Bluff Your Way in Modern Art. Much to the horror of his wife, his appearance was radically altered for the deception. A trendy hairdresser in East London shaved away the longhaired style that had been criticised by his new friends as an outmoded 'Eighties mullet'.

O'Hare was also kitted out with a series of bright charity shop suits and a pair of regulation-issue black-framed glasses.

Then, like Eliza Doolittle in Pygmalion, O'Hare was given a dry run before his big test in front of the critics. At an art world party his work was praised by a guest from the Victoria and Albert Museum. His images, she said, reminded her of Rembrandt's work 'with just a hint of ancientness'.

O'Hare approached his final judgment day with the same nerves he felt on his wedding day. His work was to appear along side four other professional abstract artists; Nigel Love, who has a commission for a £3,500 work from a Labour MP, the award-winning Ollie Beck, Shane Bradford, a former Chelsea Art School student whose work sells for £5,000, and Richard Bartle, whose works were recently bought for the chic London hotel, One Aldwych.

When the critics asked Paul to explain his inspiration, he simply said 'I had a bit of a rough trot when I was a child,' but they seemed happy. He told them he admired Jackson Pollock and they moved on.

Finally the critics Tim Marlow, editor of Tate Magazine, and Rose Aidin, a critic for the Independent on Sunday, picked out Richard Bartle as the fake. He was rather hurt.

'I was a bit shocked,' Bartle told The Observer . 'I laughed at it and then afterwards I got a bit paranoid. I thought, I have been picked as a fake. I looked at my work and I had spent six weeks on one or two of them. I torture myself over my work.'

Only one judge, Giles Baker Smith, a director of The Blue Gallery, chose the right man as a fake.

'I picked Paul because he was still doing work that was very involved with his childhood,' said Baker Smith. 'And by the time people have been to art school that kind of cathartic stuff is often behind them.'

O'Hare says he has been changed by the experience. 'I know how to look at art now. I am not as cynical as I was.'

 An exhibition of Paul O'Hare's work runs at E1 Gallery at Studio A, Florida Studios, 63 Squirries Street, London E2 from next week.
