webTitle: Comment: Anne Robinson has exposed America's irony deficiency

fields.headline: The bleakest link
fields.standfirst: Anne Robinson has exposed America's severe irony deficiency
fields.trailText: Anne Robinson has exposed America's severe irony deficiency.
fields.body:
Americans take everything seriously - even fun. Which explains why no one was surprised at the news that Anne Robinson, acid-tongued presenter of The Weakest Link, is under 24-hour protection in the United States. It may be a wicked publicity stunt concocted by NBC, which imported the infamous quiz show, but it sounds all too plausible in the land of the irony-free. Anne's special brew of the public put-down and the humiliating hectoring drew 15 million viewers to the show's debut last Monday. But it's also already turned her into a hate figure whom trigger-happy sickos could target as fair game.

Ms Robinson taunts her quiz show contestants for being ignorant, lazy or simply hopelessly stupid. This bullying may be as British as steak-and-kidney pie, but it is not the American Way. You humiliate an American - even the meekest mildest of nerds - at your peril: the cowed nail biter who stammers all the wrong answers could boast a little arsenal at home and his revenge explodes in a machine gun massacre: 'You're the weakest link, Anne. Goodbye.' Even among 'healthy' Americans, who will not fantasise about giving Ms Robinson a knuckle-sandwich, her breed of contempt provokes anger ('snippy British snob' according to the Washington Post ) rather than amusement.

In Britain, The Weakest Link could bank on our cultural acceptance of humiliation. Like a fierce nanny, the quiz mistress preyed on the snivelling creatures before her: nothing they said was good enough, nothing they did was right, and nothing was ever private (not even bowel movements: 'Show me your potty' was one English friend's red-faced memory of his nanny). This bludgeoning of the self-esteem is expected as a matter of course: from public schools to Parliament, from sitcoms to stand-up-comics, the national character is molded by reciprocal scorn. Policies are made, laws drawn up, campaigns waged through an exchange of abuse. On these shores, 'taking yourself too seriously' is the worst insult; being branded as earnest, the social kiss of death.

It's only natural. With the loss of empire and the shrinking of cultural exports to the World Service and a handful of novelists, British self-importance would invite international ridicule. Like a bit of fluff caught reading a book upside down, Britain wants to pose as one half of a special relationship, but is forever being caught on all fours, in servile prostration before Uncle Sam.

Servility, instead, is alien to the Yank (though black slavery of course was a way of life only a few generations ago). Bossy boots translates as ball-breaking bitch there; public knuckle-rapping is tantamount to Saudi stone-casting. From the first day at school, when he mouths his pledge of allegiance to the flag, every American child is reared in the knowledge that everyone's equal under that Star-Spangled Banner. 'I won't take shit from no one' is the macho message in nearly every Hollywood movie; and the point is driven home in every school shooting, where the bullied settle the score.

Americans don't like humble pie: they regard themselves - collectively and individually - as Number One; and they approach their selves, their countrymen, and every institution with a corresponding degree of seriousness. History, economics and geopolitics have schooled them in self-importance: every little thing they say, every little thing they do, has worldwide implications. When Americans slip on a banana skin, the rest of the world breaks its legs. Conscious of their global role, Yanks uphold this earnest ethos.

Compare a debate in the House of Representatives with one in the House of Commons. In an atmosphere of yawn-making gravitas, Congressmen deliberate with sonorous pomposity and confront one another with serious accusations based on past records. MPs, on the other hand, jeer and poke fun, trade insults with the puerile enthusiasm of schoolboys. I still remember the outrage an American friend of mine expressed when Have I Got News For You turned a tub of lard into a stand-in for Roy Hattersley. 'Don't you guys take anything seriously?' he shouted in disgust at what he considered the demeaning of democracy.

His reaction explains why 'You laughing at me?' is a De Niroesque threat, not a harmless question, across the Atlantic. Humour at someone's expense (especially your own) is subversive, sinister stuff. Those who dare practise it - Woody Allen and Steve Martin - win plaudits from fans on the fringe (and in Allen's case outside the country) but never win over the people's hearts. The lesson was clear: you can't laugh at Uncle Sam without incurring his wrath.

Their Cold War role as Superpower entrenched Americans in their humourless ways. Laugh at someone, and you expose their weakness: in inconsequential Britain, this may pass as a character-building rite of passage; but in the nation that protected us from the Evil Empire, it could lead to World War III. A safe world needed a self-confident US of A: so no lip from you, smart-ass.

Today, the Cold War has only partially thawed - the Chinese dragon may ultimately prove as dangerous as the Russian Bear. And so there is really no reason for Americans to lighten up. Beware, Ms Robinson: your new audience is dead serious about just about everything. Especially themselves.

webTitle: Children left with no school to attend

fields.headline: Children left with no school to attend
fields.standfirst: Britain's schools - Observer speciall
fields.trailText: Twenty children in one Northamptonshire town have no school to go to because all their local secondary schools insist they are full up.
fields.body:
Twenty children in one Northamptonshire town have no school to go to because all their local secondary schools insist they are full up.

In a situation which could soon affect the rest of the country in a climate of teacher shortages and tight admissions policies, the parents are being advised to take legal action after all three secondaries in Wellingborough told the local education authority that they have no places spare.

The former grant-maintained schools are now 'foundation schools' which gives the LEA limited power to intervene and force them to provide the excluded children with an education.

Even though local politicians have discovered that, between them, the schools have 25 spare desks in their classrooms, the headteachers are refusing to act.

A local Labour county councillor told The Observer the situation was 'crazy' and called on the Government to review the admissions procedures and the whole concept of parental preference.

'It is mainly traveller children and those recently moved into the town who are suffering. Of course we have a duty to provide them with home tuition but then we have a shortage of home tutors,' said Olwen Loud. 'The problem could be bigger because not all parents will approach the education authority to tell us their child did not have a place at school.'

One of the Wellingborough children, 15-year-old Sarah Robertson, has not been to school since her family moved to the town before the Christmas holidays and is having limited tuition at home. Her mother, Valerie Robertson, said: 'I phoned all three schools in Wellingborough and all three said they were full.

'The education officials said they couldn't do much about it because they can't get involved as it is up to the schools who they take in.'

Councillor Loud said: 'The ridiculous thing is, we are responsible but we have no schools in Wellingborough under our control.

'The schools have to be careful about actually doing their job and serving a community's needs because it may just push their school down in the league tables. So they will be punished in a way for taking in those extra children.

'Were I Secretary of State, I would be looking very closely at this whole admissions situation right now. It just cannot be accommodated, our appeals processes are already stretched beyond belief.'

The area's MEP, Liberal Democrat Nick Clegg, told BBC Radio: 'This shows the problem of a policy in which, as the Government has said, you let "bog standard" comprehensives go to the wall and you have a sink-or-swim approach in which some schools do well and others basically sink and you have some kids who don't go to school at all.'

Clegg added: 'This might be a portent for the future. The Government has announced this policy of specialist schools across the country. What about the kids who can't get into these specialist schools? I hope this case will be a wake-up call.

'It is completely preposterous. The LEA should have not only the responsibility - but the authority - to compel these schools to take in the kids that want to go to school.'

Clegg has told parents to consider legal action under the Human Rights Act, because the children were being denied their right to education.

The schools were unavailable for comment.

webTitle: Armed police on May Day riot alert

fields.headline: Armed police on May Day riot alert
fields.standfirst: Globalisation
fields.trailText: Specialist firearms teams are being drafted in to police this year's May Day demonstrations in the City of London over fears that rioters armed with samurai swords and machetes will infiltrate the protests.
fields.body:
Specialist firearms teams are being drafted in to police this year's May Day demonstrations in the City of London over fears that rioters armed with samurai swords and machetes will infiltrate the protests.

The teams will be ready to isolate anyone carrying these weapons from the thousands of other demonstrators expected. A senior officer involved in the operation said: 'If somebody used a samurai sword or a firearm we would want to put some space between them and the crowd.'

Armed response vehicles would not be appropriate in packed streets, he explained, so small groups of weapons specialists would operate across the City, available to commanders on the ground at a moment's notice.

The concern in London was heightened this weekend by reports from Quebec City in Canada, where police arrested six anti-capitalist demonstrators with a cache of smoke bombs and stolen military training equipment. Violence erupted at the Summit of the Americas in the Quebec capital, as anti-capitalists demonstrated against moves to spread free trade.

The seized arsenal included four smoke bombs and three devices known as 'thunderflashes', used to simulate grenade explosions in military exercises. The police also found chains, baseball bats, bags of steel balls, catapults and gas masks.

The London demonstration on Tuesday week has been dubbed May Day Monopoly after the property board game. The organisers have identified dozens of targets involving the game's famous streets. It is thought the activity will culminate with a 'sale of the century' protest in Oxford Street, seen as a centre of consumer capitalism with its stores and branches of multinational chains.

Although London's financial district is not included on the Monopoly board, City police sources said previous experience of anti-capitalist demonstrations showed that targets identified in advance by the organisers often turned out to be decoys. Dozens of businesses were identified for action before the 'J18' demonstration in June 1999, for example, but few were actually involved.

Perry Nove, the City of London Commissioner, said bogus lists of targets were designed to stretch police resources, and the Square Mile was, in the protesters' jargon, 'target-rich'.

'They are heavily into disinformation,' Nove added. 'Therefore it could be a smokescreen, with no single focus of attack.' Signs of a split on strategy between his force and the Metropolitan Police, which is leading the operation, have appeared just over a week before the event. Officers in the City force are known to be uncomfortable with comments by the Met's Assistant Commissioner Mike Todd, who said he would operate a 'zero tolerance' crime policy on May Day. Todd's City colleagues, however, believe this policy is 'conceptually flawed' as it constrains officers from using their own initiative.

Activists accused the police of demonising genuine protesters by concentrating on a violent core. Jim Carey of the direct action magazine Squall said: 'Attempts to reduce anti-capitalism to a menacing monoculture of violence are so wide of the mark as to suggest they are being strategically divisive.

'There is nothing the police or Home Office can say to change the fact that anti-capitalist activists hail from all walks of life, religions and social backgrounds.'

Divisions have emerged among the protesters, too. Peter Cadogan, who helped organise the 1968 anti-Vietnam war protest in London, criticised the 'Wombles' - the self-styled leaders of May Day Monopoly, who plan to wear padded boiler suits to protect them from police batons.

'The enemy is not the police,' he said. 'If we misidentify the enemy we shall be the agents of our own defeat.'

He broke with the organisers when they refused to identify any aims beyond anti-capitalism, and they in turn have called him a 'splitter'.

Cadogan said this weekend: 'The leadership want sheep-like solidarity, and they are condemning anyone who doesn't fall into line.'

webTitle: How the East won the West

fields.headline: How the East won the West
fields.standfirst: To be Asian in Hollywood used to mean parts as villains or dainty flowers. Now, after Crouching Tiger, movie bosses think eastern stars are the next big thing
fields.trailText: To be Asian in Hollywood used to mean parts as villains or dainty flowers. Now, after Crouching Tiger, movie bosses think eastern stars are the next big thing
fields.body:
Is Hollywood actually capable of saying sorry? It seems unlikely, but saying sorry to the Chinese for the sorry treatment of Oriental actors over the years would seem to be a good idea right now.

Following the unprecedented success of Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon, American producers have signed up a host of Asian stars aiming to introduce them to multiplexes around the world. There's Rush Hour 2, a couple of big-budget Jet Li movies and a number of intriguing Chow Yun-Fat projects. Meanwhile, Columbia Pictures Film Production Asia, the people who made Crouching Tiger, are working on four Chinese-set US-backed movies, with Donald Sutherland in Beijing shooting the comedy, Big Shot's Funeral, directed by Feng Xiaogang, with Hong Kong star Tony Leung (In the Mood for Love) playing a Taiwanese detective in the thriller, Double Vision. The Chinese (whether Hong Kong, Taiwanese, mainland or homegrown) presence in the US movie industry has never been more substantial.

Which is why it might be wise for Hollywood to repent about how Charlie Chan was played by men with names like Sidney Toler and Warner Oland, apologise for the old yellow-peril movies and most of all, the day David Carradine was chosen over Bruce Lee to star in the TV series Kung Fu. The time has come to say sorry that Nancy Kwan, who became a star in the 1960's The World Of Suzie Wong, ran out of decent parts so quickly.

And Hollywood could find a word or two of regret about the attitudes that made silent star Anna May Wong leave town in 1928, announcing: 'I was tired of the parts I had to play. Why is it that on the screen the Chinese are nearly always the villain of the piece, and so cruel a villain - murderous, treacher ous, a snake in the grass? We are not like that. How could we be, with a civilisation so many times older than that of the West? We have our rigid code of behaviour, of honour. Why do they never show those on the screen?'

The movie industry is not going to apologise for the sake of its conscience, of course. It is just that, as with the Latin American craze in recent years, it is clear there is money to be made from the domestic Asian-American market, and much more from the huge south-east Asian market.

Making movies that play on both sides of the Pacific is the purpose behind Columbia Pictures Film Production Asia. But Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon was the climax to a long, slow struggle, mainly by veterans of the Hong Kong movie industry. Thirty years ago, San Francisco-born, University of Washington-educated Bruce Lee had to leave LA and go to Hong Kong to become a film star. Only now is the reverse trip becoming more frequent. The youngest member of the Crouching Tiger cast, Zhang Ziyi, has been snapped up to play a villain in Rush Hour 2. And because her English isn't up to much, her part will be subtitled. Times have changed.

The advance, though, has been glacier-like at times. It is only since 1998's Rush Hour that Jackie Chan, who, for two decades, had been a megastar not only across south-east Asia, but in India, and much of the rest of the world, finally cracked the big time in the US. Li, the other leading martial-arts star, has moved faster, having gone from villain in his first US movie (Lethal Weapon 4) to romantic lead in his second (Romeo Must Die).

'Jet Li got a deal with Warner Bros because women in test audiences loved him in Lethal Weapon 4,' according to producer Chris Lee. 'You'll definitely be seeing more of the Asian male as romantic hero, instead of just gun-wielding villain or sexless geek.'

One reason it hasn't been easy is that since the Second World War, all foreign stars have struggled in Hollywood. Think of the brief US careers of non-American stars like Gérard Depardieu or even Sophia Loren. The few who have made it - Antonio Banderas or Chan - have done so with huge determination and over time. Most, faced with indifferent reactions to indifferent movies, have gone home.

Some Chinese stars are convinced it is that much harder for them, with attitudes in the United States little changed Anna May Wong's day. 'At the parties, people are nice, but below the surface you feel the tension,' says Leslie Cheung, leading man in dozens of Hong Kong hits.

When Hong Kong's most famous director, John Woo, arrived in Hollywood, he didn't bring his stars with him, choosing instead to establish himself by working with John Travolta and Tom Cruise. Those who have made it to the US have found that working habits are different too. Until recently, many Hong Kong films were shot silently, so that both Mandarin and Cantonese dialogue could be dubbed on afterwards. The films are made quickly there; stars can make up to 12 a year. And despite the century and a half of British colonial rule, many Hong Kong stars, including Chan, when he first arrived in the US, don't speak much English. Add up those factors and you can see why some suggest the chief beneficiaries of the Asian awakening will be US-born actors like Lucy Liu.

Still, the economic imperative works on both sides of the Pacific. The Hong Kong film industry, so strong in the late Eighties and early Nineties, had a bad end of the century. 'You can see the Hong Kong market right now is dying,' said Chow Yun-Fat in 1998. 'That's why I have to move, to look for a new way to support my career in the future.'

Fortunately, as Chow has established himself in Hollywood, the power balance has finally shifted. Michelle Yeoh and Li felt comfortable enough to both turn down roles in The Matrix sequels, Yeoh having been passed over in favour of Carrie-Anne Moss in the original movie. And Chow, who before Crouching Tiger had already gained the true Hollywood seal of approval - starring opposite Jodie Foster in Anna and the King - is trying to rewrite a bit of that bitter history by developing a new Charlie Chan film.

Although Jackie Chan is the biggest Chinese star right now, and the younger and more handsome Li is closing in fast, Chow might be the biggest star in the long run: as he's not a martial-arts' artist, he doesn't have to worry about his battered body giving up on him. He has also stretched himself far beyond the two-gunned John Woo thrillers which made him famous in the West.

It might not last, but right now, the Crouching Tiger effect is very strong. 'For me, it was a long time coming and it was just so thrilling every time they announced a Chinese name and pronounced it right,' said ER 's Ming-Na on Oscar night.

Even when the frenzy subsides, there will will be no going back to the days of the Warner Bros memo re Kung Fu, which read: 'The American public won't sit for a Chinaman appearing in their living-rooms every week.'

It is just that, as with the Latin American craze in recent years, it is clear there is money to be made from the domestic Asian-American market, and much more from the huge south-east Asian market. Making movies that play on both sides of the Pacific is the purpose behind Columbia Pictures Film Production Asia. But Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon was the climax to a long, slow struggle, mainly by veterans of the Hong Kong movie industry. Thirty years ago, San Francisco-born, University of Washington-educated Bruce Lee had to leave LA and go to Hong Kong to become a film star. Only now is the reverse trip becoming more frequent. The youngest member of the Crouching Tiger cast, Zhang Ziyi, has been snapped up to play a villain in Rush Hour 2. And because her English isn't up to much, her part will be subtitled. Times have changed. The advance, though, has been glacier-like at times. It is only since 1998's Rush Hour that Jackie Chan, who, for two decades, had been a megastar not only across south-east Asia, but in India, and much of the rest of the world, finally cracked the big time in the US. Li, the other leading martial-arts star, has moved faster, having gone from villain in his first US movie (Lethal Weapon 4) to romantic lead in his second (Romeo Must Die). 'Jet Li got a deal with Warner Bros because women in test audiences loved him in Lethal Weapon 4,' according to producer Chris Lee. 'You'll definitely be seeing more of the Asian male as romantic hero, instead of just gun-wielding villain or sexless geek.' One reason it hasn't been easy is that since the Second World War, all foreign stars have struggled in Hollywood. Think of the brief US careers of non-American stars like Gérard Depardieu or even Sophia Loren. The few who have made it - Antonio Banderas or Chan - have done so with huge determination and over time. Most, faced with indifferent reactions to indifferent movies, have gone home. Some Chinese stars are convinced it is that much harder for them, with attitudes in the United States little changed Anna May Wong's day. 'At the parties, people are nice, but below the surface you feel the tension,' says Leslie Cheung, leading man in dozens of Hong Kong hits. When Hong Kong's most famous director, John Woo, arrived in Hollywood, he didn't bring his stars with him, choosing instead to establish himself by working with John Travolta and Tom Cruise. Those who have made it to the US have found that working habits are different too. Until recently, many Hong Kong films were shot silently, so that both Mandarin and Cantonese dialogue could be dubbed on afterwards. The films are made quickly there; stars can make up to 12 a year. And despite the century and a half of British colonial rule, many Hong Kong stars, including Chan, when he first arrived in the US, don't speak much English. Add up those factors and you can see why some suggest the chief beneficiaries of the Asian awakening will be US-born actors like Lucy Liu. Still, the economic imperative works on both sides of the Pacific. The Hong Kong film industry, so strong in the late Eighties and early Nineties, had a bad end of the century. 'You can see the Hong Kong market right now is dying,' said Chow Yun-Fat in 1998. 'That's why I have to move, to look for a new way to support my career in the future.' Fortunately, as Chow has established himself in Hollywood, the power balance has finally shifted. Michelle Yeoh and Li felt comfortable enough to both turn down roles in The Matrix sequels, Yeoh having been passed over in favour of Carrie-Anne Moss in the original movie. And Chow, who before Crouching Tiger had already gained the true Hollywood seal of approval - starring opposite Jodie Foster in Anna and the King - is trying to rewrite a bit of that bitter history by developing a new Charlie Chan film. Although Jackie Chan is the biggest Chinese star right now, and the younger and more handsome Li is closing in fast, Chow might be the biggest star in the long run: as he's not a martial-arts' artist, he doesn't have to worry about his battered body giving up on him. He has also stretched himself far beyond the two-gunned John Woo thrillers which made him famous in the West. It might not last, but right now, the Crouching Tiger effect is very strong. 'For me, it was a long time coming and it was just so thrilling every time they announced a Chinese name and pronounced it right,' said ER 's Ming-Na on Oscar night. Even when the frenzy subsides, there will will be no going back to the days of the Warner Bros memo re Kung Fu, which read: 'The American public won't sit for a Chinaman appearing in their living-rooms every week.'

webTitle: Our man in Panama

fields.headline: Our man in Panama
fields.standfirst: John le Carré's world of seedy spies is brought to vivid life by John Boorman, with a knowing nod to Graham Greene
fields.trailText: Philip French: The cleverest trick, which adds to the humour and excitement, as well as underlining the film's meaning, is the casting of Pierce Brosnan, who's never been so good
fields.body:
After the critical and commercial failure of his single excursion outside of genre fiction, The Naive and Sentimental Lover, John le Carré returned by popular demand to espionage in 1974 with one of his finest works, Tinker, Tailor, Soldier, Spy. The title gave a deadly twist to a children's playground game and when, more than two decades later, he chose to make his hero a genuine clothier, he gave the novel a deceptively innocent title reminiscent of childhood and Beatrix Potter, The Tailor of Panama.

One doubts if he was consciously thinking of Graham Greene's celebrated, semi-satirical essay on Potter's fiction in which he dismissed the eponymous hero of The Tailor of Gloucester as 'ineffective and too virtuous'. Without doubt, however, le Carré had Our Man in Havana in mind, as he says in his acknowledgements.

Like Greene's novel, The Tailor of Panama is about a British expatriate in an unstable Latin American country put under pressure by British intelligence and inventing, with lethal consequences, a non-existent spy ring and a fictitious political conspiracy. Le Carré's fine book is nearly twice the length of Greene's, denser and less funny, but the movie, of which he is co-scriptwriter with Andrew Davies and director John Boorman, is far superior to, and much tougher than, the film Greene made of Our Man in Havana with Carol Reed in 1960.

Le Carré's equivalents of Jim Wormold, the vacuum-cleaner salesman, and Hawthorne, the very establishment MI6 agent (the characters played by Alec Guinness and Noël Coward in Our Man in Havana) are Harry Pendel (so well played by Geoffrey Rush), the Panama City bespoke tailor, and Andy Osnard (Pierce Brosnan), the maverick MI6 operative who's been posted to the backwater of the Panama embassy as punishment for troublemaking.

Although the comic intrigue in Greene's novel anticipated both the success of Castro's revolution (which followed the book's publication by a few months) and, quite uncannily, the 1962 Cuban missile crisis, Wormold and Hawthorne are figures from farce. Pendel and Osnard have a much greater weight and are altogether, on first acquaintance, less genial.

Both men are frauds and self-deceivers, but their fraudulence and self-deception have a larger political dimension, as we appreciate during the witty courtship between tailor and spy with which the film opens. Pendel, the working-class Londoner who learnt his tailoring in jail, poses as an established Savile Row master and dispenses old- world class to the unscrupulous rich and nouveaux riches of Panama. The spirit of Benny, his late Jewish uncle (an amusing turn by Harold Pinter), hovers over his shoulder giving dubious advice, but Pendel really believes in the snobbish standards and outmoded Englishness that he has espoused.

Osnard, who has seen through Pendel's façade, works for an organisation that, in the post-imperial, post-Cold War world, has become largely redundant. He pretends that Britain has a major role in the world, if one dependent for intelligence operations on US subventions, but his growing cynicism has turned him into an opportunist. When he seduces Pendel - with money and blackmail - into becoming an agent, he wants to believe in 'the silent opposition' of local liberals that the tailor invents, and in a non-existent clandestine scheme to sell the Panama Canal to a Chinese, French and Japanese consortium.

The difference between the two is that Pendel is essentially a decent man, real concern underlying his subservience, while Osnard exists in a moral vacuum. The truly good person, however, is Pendel's American wife, Louisa (Jamie Lee Curtis), a representative of the reality principle. She respects the recently appointed Panamanian executives of the canal company for which she works, and stands in sharp contrast to her half-demented fellow-countrymen plotting against them in the Pentagon.

The film is given a firm sense of reality through the confident handling of authentic locations by Boorman, who has worked in Latin America before in The Emerald Forest and, more recently, in a politically volatile state in Beyond Rangoon. There is no excessive use of local colour and the background is integrated into the dramatic action. Boorman directs with a light touch of a sort that was only to be seen intermittently in his work before his last movie, The General, about the Irish gangster, Martin Cahill. Brendan Gleeson, so superb as Cahill, here immerses himself in the role of a burnt-out ex-revolutionary who becomes Pendel's chief fall guy.

The cleverest trick, which adds to the humour and excitement, as well as underlining the film's meaning, is the casting of Pierce Brosnan, who's never been so good. When he is briefed at MI6's Thamesside HQ by a bland superior, his eyes twinkle evilly at the prospect of easy pickings in corrupt Panama, and we realise that this is a different organisation from that last bastion of patriotism served by James Bond. There have been supposed anti-Bonds on the screen before, but here we have the most confident embodiment of Bond since Connery's day serving himself rather than Her Majesty.

Osnard is suave in the manner of a student of Playboy ;his only piece of advanced technology is a Zippo containing a miniature camera; as a lover, he's violent, sweaty and not irresistible, and his word is not his bond. Just before Osnard arrives at the tailoring shop, Pendel is assuring a corpulent client that the suit he's fitting is the sort Mr Connery wears and that he has the same 'golfer's shoulders'.

webTitle: Paperback of the week: Ravelstein

fields.headline: Paperback of the week
fields.trailText: More than a mellow but exuberant after-supper reminiscence, a century's worth of observation and knowledge
fields.body:
Ravelstein
Saul Bellow
Penguin £6.99, pp240
Buy it at a discount at BOL

The fatally ill protagonist of Saul Bellow's first novel in 13 years has a favour to ask his old friend Chick: 'You could do a really fine memoir. Do it in your after-supper reminiscence manner - I love listening when you are freewheeling.'

Ravelstein is just this: a mellow but exuberant after-supper reminiscence. Bellow's informal prose, delivered in the voice of his alter ego and narrator Chick, meanders from Lanvin suit-shopping to the Holocaust via pizza parties and John Maynard Keynes, as Abe Ravelstein, international intellectual, ekes out his final months in Paris and Chicago. Chick's memoir opens with a haute-cuisine meal in Paris before opening out like the postprandial stroll into the past requested by the great man before he dies.

Controversy surrounding the novel has been fierce across the Atlantic, where conservative former fans of the real Ravelstein - Bellow's late mentor Allan Bloom - are unhappy about the book's disclosure that Bloom, aka Ravelstein, was a gay man who apparently died of Aids. Having openly admired and quoted from his bestseller, The Closing of the American Mind, they feel betrayed and presumably also rather foolish. Bloom, having never addressed the subject of his sexuality in print, is said to have asked Bellow for a completely honest memoir; after all, who wants a censored after-dinner speech?

It is the honesty of Bellow's characterisation that makes Ravelstein spring - virtually high-jump - from the page at the centre of a universe of misfits. His extravagant tastes ($20,000 watches) are as appalling as his generosity is unbounded. The force of this extraordinary personality drives Chick's rambling memoirs forwards - and sideways and backwards - as layer upon layer of a lifetime's experience is unravelled.

But Ravelstein is more than a series of brilliant character sketches. A century's worth of observation and knowledge is expertly distilled into Bellow's luxurious prose.

webTitle: Things Can Only Get Better written and read by John O'Farrell

fields.headline: Things Can Only Get Better written and read by John O'Farrell
fields.trailText: Throughout this witty and entertaining audiobook, O'Farrell portrays himself as the Labour Party personified.
fields.body:
Things Can Only Get Better
John O'Farrell
Read by the author
Listening time 2 1/2 hours
Random House £8.99

'My name is John O'Farrell and I was embarrassingly left-wing in the Eighties.' Now, this Labour candidate for Maidenhead gives money to Murdoch for the privilege of watching Sky Sports, seriously considers sending his kids to prep school, and bribes the au pair to deliver pro-Labour fliers on his behalf. But you can't help respecting O'Farrell's undying devotion to a party that squatted for 6,532 days in the shadows of a Conservative government.

Throughout this witty and entertaining audiobook, O'Farrell portrays himself as the Labour Party personified, from his militant rantings as a campaigner witnessing the first flush of electoral apathy - 'They could abolish the right to vote, trial by jury, the right to free speech, as long as they didn't change the theme tune to The Archers' - to the realisation that, although Tony Blair isn't strictly the leftie that die-hard Labour supporters had been looking for, he was nearer to what O'Farrell had become himself by the time Tony ended 18 years of Tory rule. 'Do what you have to do, Tony,' says the voice of New O'Farrell.

The irony of these observations is doubly effective in being spoken by the author himself, and although not all writers do their own work justice, no one could do a better job of driving home the reasons for never voting Conservative again: 'Think David Mellor, Neil Hamilton, Tim Smith, Steven Norris.' Need he say more?

webTitle: Paperbacks: 22 Apr

fields.headline: Paperbacks
fields.trailText: Jonathan Bate's inquiry into ecopoetics - the symbiosis between poetry and nature - reads even more urgently than when first published, plus The Question of Bruno, Blonde, Slab Rat and The Twins
fields.body:
The Song of the Earth
Jonathan Bate
Picador £7.99, pp335

Already Jonathan Bate's inquiry into ecopoetics - the symbiosis between poetry and nature - reads even more urgently than when first published. As rural dwellers strive to redress an archaic post-industrial sense of the picturesque, Bate, author of The Genius of Love, investigates the restorative properties of nature when viewed through a poetic prism.

While the interpretations are at times radical, the texts on which he centres his impassioned thesis are more conservative. The Romantic poets and the Enlightenment that preceded them are when his song resonates most thrillingly, yet he also reads John Clare, Elizabeth Bishop and Les Murray with inspirational acumen. Though overstrident and dogmatic at times, it is an ambitious and stimulating manifesto, and at its best is the undergraduate lecture you never attended as it strives, by administering the elixir of poetry, to restore rhyme and reason to a world losing its roots.

The Question of Bruno
Aleksandar Hemon
Picador, £6.99. pp232
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Aleksandar Hemon arrived in Chicago in 1992, and stayed after war broke out in his native Bosnia. Apparently, he learnt English by reading Lolita: there could be worse prescriptions for British illiteracy. This impressive debut features eight stories that mix linguistic tap-dancing with occasional clodhopping.

A tragicomic novella, 'Blind Jozef Pronek and Dead Souls', explores a Bosnian's experience in an infantilised America, where the Balkan people are seen as 'squabbling'. Pronek's girlfriend's parents like Kundera, and so does Hemon, who weaves personal threads into the public tapestry of twentieth-century history.

Most remarkable is 'A Coin', a subtly poignant, indirect dialogue between a male émigré alone in America and a young woman on the Sarajevo frontline. Hemon is at his best when he is most himself: the self-conscious tricksiness and verbal sleights of hand, pace Nabokov, cannot disguise a singular talent that need not dress itself in others' fine rags.

Blonde
Joyce Carol Oates
Fourth Estate £7.99, pp939
Buy it at a discount at BOL

You couldn't make up the legend of Marilyn Monroe, but somehow Joyce Carol Oates has. Blonde is a terse title for a panoramic life; this isn't a novel, this is hand luggage. Yet despite its 939 pages, it moves with surprising agility to trace Norma Jeane's [sic] well-documented disintegration from fostered orphan to movie star. Her absent father and flaky mother ('unpredictable as a candle flame flickering in agitated air') set the tone for her Cinderella life, futilely awaiting her Dark Prince.

Oates directs her fictionalised biography like a feature, changing angle and perspective constantly. What she is unafraid to do, in all her prolific output, is to reap the corn of the American Dream, unabashedly sorting the rotten ears from the golden. Written in a furious, passionate flow, Oates's heavily stylised vision will either infuriate or captivate to its magnificently improbable close, when a malodorous, sour waft replaces the Chanel No 5.

Slab Rat
Ted Heller
Abacus £7.99, pp388
Buy it at a discount at BOL

The ghastly cover does little for Ted Heller's lip-bitingly arch debut novel of office politics, in which he ploughs up the rich dirt on the American magazine-publishing world. Zachary Post, slab rat (skyscraper worker) and associate editor at It, craves power; syntactical power, as in 'Editor: Creative'. He also chases It-girls, in the shape of a nymphomaniac, flame-haired ex, an icy, alabaster English beauty, and a funny, bright intern. However, to do this, he must overcome Mark Larkin, the newcomer with 'editor' written through him like seaside rock, for whom Zachary is constantly mistaken.

Crammed with dastardly behaviour, such as stealing from a leaving collection, brown-nosing, and funny-tawking English, Heller steals more than a leaf from his father's books in this wittily neurotic take on corporate back-stabbing, the perils of book reviewing and the battle of the mighty against the trivial. And all for a corner office.

The Twins
Tessa de Loo
Arcadia £6.99. pp392
Buy it at a discount at BOL

A bestseller in both her native Holland and Germany, Tessa de Loo's saga explores the troubled relationship between the two countries through the personal histories of two elderly women. Both in the Belgian town of Spa for rheumatism treatment, it turns out they are estranged sisters, separated in 1921 as six-year-olds after their parents' death, when Anna went to German peasant relatives, and Lotte to cultural Dutch ones.

Through a mist of time, heavy as the baths' vapour, the physical cure engenders a therapeutic one as they describe, in detailed passages of flashback, contrasting war experiences and their lives afterwards. For two weeks they relive their polarised lives, with memories bitter like the coffee that sustains them, while the dichotomy of the post-war German soul is laid bare. De Loo's considerable achievement is to not shirk awkward issues of guilt while treating her delicate subject matter with extraordinary compassion.

The Twins Tessa de Loo Arcadia £6.99. pp392 Buy it at a discount at BOL A bestseller in both her native Holland and Germany, Tessa de Loo's saga explores the troubled relationship between the two countries through the personal histories of two elderly women. Both in the Belgian town of Spa for rheumatism treatment, it turns out they are estranged sisters, separated in 1921 as six-year-olds after their parents' death, when Anna went to German peasant relatives, and Lotte to cultural Dutch ones. Through a mist of time, heavy as the baths' vapour, the physical cure engenders a therapeutic one as they describe, in detailed passages of flashback, contrasting war experiences and their lives afterwards. For two weeks they relive their polarised lives, with memories bitter like the coffee that sustains them, while the dichotomy of the post-war German soul is laid bare. De Loo's considerable achievement is to not shirk awkward issues of guilt while treating her delicate subject matter with extraordinary compassion.

webTitle: Interview: Jake Arnott

fields.headline: Jake's progress
fields.standfirst: He beat Guy Ritchie to the punch by inventing geezer chic. Now his second book proves there's more to Jake Arnott than publisher's hype. For a start, there's his interest in Baden-Powell's sexuality...
fields.trailText: He beat Guy Ritchie to the punch by inventing geezer chic. Now his second book proves there's more to Jake Arnott than publisher's hype. For a start, there's his interest in Baden-Powell's sexuality...
fields.body:
It's almost tempting to think of Jake Arnott as a photofit novelist, a figure Shaw Taylor might have pieced together - 'Have you seen this man?' - from a publisher's sketchy brief. His second book, a stylish crime narrative concerned with the moral legacy of Flying Squad corruption in Sixties London, comes complete with a charge sheet of its author's 'previous', for which any self-respecting editor would probably have offered several holdalls of used tenners, regardless of the manuscript.

The writer, we are told, has worked as a 'mortuary technician, a theatrical agent, an artist's life model, an actor and a sign-language interpreter... during the Eighties, he lived in various squats, one of which burned down, leaving him possessionless and under arrest on suspicion of arson... his last acting job was as the Mummy in Universal Pictures blockbuster The Mummy - though you won't recognise him through the bandages...' All that before he ever picked up a pen.

Uncharitably, there have been those who have suggested that it is largely because of this hard-sold outlaw mythology, allied to what one reviewer was moved to describe as 'brute-boy' good looks, that Arnott has jumped to the front of the queue of bankable, youngish literary novelists. This perception was fuelled by a BBC documentary on fiction debutants that gave Arnott's entry into the world of letters something of the breathless trajectory of the Craig David song: sent off his manuscript on Friday, called by his agent on Monday, lined up a 'substantial six-figure deal' on Tuesday, booked a photo-shoot on Wednesday, invented a genre - 'geezer chic' - on Thursday, been chilling ever since.

In fact, of course, there is no such thing as an overnight literary success. Arnott had been writing for seven years pretty much full time, living on nothing in Leeds, before he got any kind of break. He'd completed an earlier manuscript ('My great squat novel,' he says, smiling. 'It had the word "crepuscular" in the second paragraph') which collected a neat stack of rejection slips, and he was pushing 40 when his book came out.

He is reluctant to suggest that the subsequent hype did much to propel The Long Firm on to the bestseller lists, either: 'Perhaps the saving grace of publishing,' he says, bright eyed and hesitantly spoken, 'is that even with the greatest amount of publicity possible, it's not really going to impinge on the general population in any way at all. It's not like being in a boy band. People aren't that interested in authors really. Any book has to sell itself.'

The Long Firm did just that. An inspired reaction to the heritage industry of East End organised crime, it trained the sawn-off conventions of a gangster novel on received notions of masculinity. The book tells the story of one Harry Starks, a gay Soho racketeer with a taste for cultural studies and stage-managed menaces. Starks was loosely based on Ronnie Kray, with a dash of Macheath, the aspirational villain of Brecht's Threepenny Opera, thrown in.

As soon as he started writing it, Arnott knew he was on to something: a way of getting at the particular male anxieties that begin to tell the story of Englishness in the latter part of the twentieth century. 'I did the whole book,' he says. 'with a kind of pressing fear that someone would beat me to it and write about Ronnie Kray and his boyfriends, because it was such a wonderful, obvious story.'

He suggests that, in a way, Quentin Tarantino had started the trend 'with this very homosocial lads kind of movie, in which everyone is scared of being "bottom", everyone literally watching their arse', but suggests, too, that he wanted to come at 'that kind of fetishised masculinity from a different angle. Obviously, some people might read my books for exactly that masculinity: fast moving, lots of violence, and so on, but I think there is a little more going on, too.'

As it turned out, Arnott also pre-empted the latest bout of gangland nostalgia that attended Guy Ritchie's film Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels. He finds it vaguely amusing that he and Ritchie have sometimes been lumped together at the vanguard of a revivalist British trend.

'In, say, Lock, Stock, you come away thinking essentially this is a feel-good gangster movie,' he says, distancing himself from the idea. 'I mean, my idea of film noir is that there should be at least a little bit of noir about it. The great examples of the genre show how the individual is brought down by society, the great American tragedy if you like. You shouldn't come away just thinking: that was fun. Gangsters can't simply succeed.'

In some ways, Jake Arnott is well placed to comment on the particular merits of 'failure' in a man's life. Having done wilfully little to live up to his management consultant father's aspirations for him at the boys' grammar school in Aylesbury, he left at 16 and tried a variety of ill-fitting worlds for size. Looking back, he says, giggling a little at the idea, 'National Service might have done me some good, anything tangible really.'

Instead, he found himself living in a series of London squats and working in the mortuary at University College Hospital. 'My main duty was to clean the vast dissection-room floor first thing in the morning,' he recalls, 'with about 150 bodies on these glass-topped trolleys. If you'd filmed it from the top with stop action, it would have been this strange Busby Berkeley scene. I'd often sing show tunes with the embalmer Kay, from Walthamstow, and I did learn how to embalm a body, so that was useful, in a way.'

This Damien Hirst fantasy came at a time in his life when, he says - chirpily - he was 'disturbed and depressed and I think still trying to sort out lots of things in myself. I came out as bisexual in my twenties, still had girlfriends and it was all, you know, mad flux. Looking back, I'm glad there was all that to work through, because there's nothing left to worry about now, nothing at all'.

Some of those happily resolved conflicts resurface in different guises in his novels, he admits, but he rejects the notion of himself as a 'gay writer'.

'I suppose I've always felt that an identity solely based on sexuality is a bit depressing anyway,' he says. 'In the Eighties, it was a slightly too political thing; now, even worse, it's become a marketing niche.'

The person who did most to help Arnott through his period of doubt was his paternal grandmother who lived in Clapham and who had worked in the West End as a dancer for most of her life (Arnott's father had done his own rebelling by moving to Buckinghamshire). She was the first person Arnott talked with about his sexuality: 'As a dancer, she knew so many. But also because I knew she would have an honest reaction to it. It's difficult for the parents anyway. That pressure to say the right thing. But she had no qualms.'

In return, his grandmother always told him vivid stories about her time on the Soho stage and these tales became the root of his fascination with the role in that world of the mob, a fascination which led to the preoccupations of The Long Firm.

'I was interested in the kind of theatricality that attends violence,' he says. 'If part of your job is to have this profile of menace, you need that front of artifice. Gangsters often talk about "shaping up" before they get into a fight. I remember John McVicar suggesting how good he had been in going through that kind of performance. And, of course, there is a long history of villains sending their children to stage school.'

Arnott's career on the stage, also partly inspired by his grandmother's example, was less dramatic than it might have been. Throughout the Eighties, he picked up bits of work, 'improvisational stuff, all very obscure and underpaid', and subsequently became involved with Red Ladder, a theatre company in Leeds. 'I think it was socialist-feminist, though it might have been the other way round,' he says.

His acting was one aspect of an unfocused political involvement - 'endless marches, demos, meetings' - that came with life in the squatted houses and warehouses of south London.

It was that period of Arnott's life which provided the genesis for his second novel. On one march in the early Eighties, he heard a chant, borrowed from the football terraces, used by Class War to goad the police: 'Harry Roberts is our friend/ is our friend/ is our friend/ he kills coppers'. The chant - 'something eerie about it, like a malevolent nursery rhyme' - referred to the infamous murder of three Met officers in 1966.

Over the years, the words haunted Arnott as 'emblematic of all that working-class-hero nonsense, typical of the anarchists, who wanted to seem butch and bold' and when he came to research the real story of Harry Roberts, a man with a grudge, a veteran of the colonial conflict in Malaya, 'a kind of Travis Bickle', it led him into a tale of three decades of corruption on both sides of the law.

Roberts is reinvented in He Kills Coppers as Billy Porter, and through a series of smart connections, Arnott also succeeds in recreating the world into which he emerged. Some of these links were chance encounters: 1966 obviously led him to football - his book addresses the implications of the 'great national bonding moment' that was the World Cup victory - and while he was researching that he came across a London Evening Standard clipping that tied in a CID operation to the beautiful game: Nipper Read leading a clean-up iniative on Soho clip-joints for the duration of the tournament.

'It was like the opening scene of Measure for Measure,' he says. 'You know where the Duke charges Angelo to clean up the city and, of course, those supposed to be sorting things out get corrupted themselves.'

Arnott is slightly concerned that his book goes over some of this contentious ground at a time when Harry Roberts, who has been in prison for 34 years, is coming up for release. 'He's awaiting a parole board, I believe,' he says, guardedly. 'He's in open conditions. I have to be careful because I don't want to get caught up in any of that debate. Although, of course, as soon as soon as I mentioned in passing to my publisher that Roberts might be paroled this year, their eyes were going round in their heads.'

The case also provided Arnott with a way of exploring some of his own past, in that he uses the folkloric 'Harry Roberts, he's our friend' idea to satirise the 'easy radicalism' of the Eighties. 'I'm very cruel about the kind of person I was then, I suppose,' he says now. 'The chant itself sort of encapsulated everything I hated about the anarchist movement. I just got sick of the fact that in every squat there would be this inevitable all-inclusive debate about everything - racism, class war, sexuality - brought into discussions about whether you were going to have a washing-up rota. People would always label you a fascist if you argued that there should be one,' he laughs. 'You know, that kind of thing.'

The point at which Arnott realised that the revolution probably wasn't going to happen was when he helped to organise support for the miners in 1985. 'A women's group came down from South Yorkshire to thank us,' he remembers, 'and, of course, they had dressed up for the occasion. And they walked into this place, this squatters' café, and you could see the look on their faces, like, "Fucking hell, they're sending us food". And I suddenly just thought this was just so ridiculous, like pretending we were in nineteenth-century Poland or something.'

How Arnott got from there to here is the stuff of publisher's blurbs. He now owns a flat on Islington's Upper Street in north London and is amused by the fact that the lifestyle he once enjoyed for nothing - playing Changing Rooms in empty warehouses - is now the expensive aspiration of City bankers and way beyond his vaunted 'substantial six figure' means. Still, he's not complaining. He has just signed another two-book deal with his publisher and is waiting for a script of The Long Firm to be worked up into a TV series by Joe Penhall, the author of the National Theatre hit Blue/Orange.

He lives in the novelist's philosophical hope, too, of somebody picking up the film rights for He Kills Coppers. 'Of course it would be great if the Americans bought it,' he smiles. 'Set the early stuff in Vietnam, not Malaya, and gave me lots of money...'

In the meantime, not holding his breath, he is working on the third part of what will turn into a loose trilogy about the myths of Sixties London.

And after that?

'Oh, I'll do something completely different,' he says. 'I seem to have developed this obsession with empire, and I'd like to go back to like The Riddle of the Sands era, I think. The Krays loved it all. Apparently, Ronnie went to see Gordon of Khartoum and he came out with tears in his eyes, and said, you know, "Gordon was a real man, and he was bent, like me..." I love all that stuff.

'I sometimes play a parlour game - name the straight empire hero. They were all gay, had to be, really: Gordon of Khartoum, Lawrence of Arabia, Baden-Powell. I don't know about Clive of India, but, I mean, probably...' Arnott laughs, drains his wine, looks up and says: 'I suppose I've always been interested in the extraordinary modes of expression brought about by all that repression.'

webTitle: Observer review: John Dory by John Murray

fields.headline: It all began when I was smiled at by a turbot
fields.standfirst: John Murray, the lyric poet of the Cumbrian inferiority complex, returns with the story of a mid-life crisis in John Dory
fields.trailText: John Murray, the lyric poet of the Cumbrian inferiority complex, returns with the story of a mid-life crisis in John Dory
fields.body:
John Dory
John Murray
Flambard Press £7.99, 221
Buy it at a discount at BOL

John Murray's Radio Activity was one of the most striking novels of recent years, a satire on Sellafield and the nuclear power industry, steeped in Cumbrian dialect though anything but narrow culturally, using something like magic realism to come at its subject from the least expected quarter.

His follow-up was Reiver Blues, a less energetic performance but one that showed some of the same hallmarks, seeing the historically debated lands between Scotland and England as our own version of the conflict in former Yugoslavia. The book also boasted the first appearance in serious fiction of the aubergine.

John Dory, Murray's new novel, has a more embattled attitude towards the author's home region, a more exasperated devotion: 'Progressive Whitehaven, which got there first with the wine bars and the Middle East carry-outs and the Georgian renovations, puts its hands to its mouth and titters at its dingy competitor Workington... Workington likewise titters at Maryport... everyone laughs at someone else and to make matters worse the rest of the county laughs at the whole of the primitive west coast. And then most infuriatingly the rest of the country laughs at the whole of our bloody county. At bloody comical Cumbria, God's apparent gratuitous joke when he was resting between the creation of England and the creation of Scotland.'

Murray is the lyric poet of this sliding-scale inferiority complex. Nevertheless, John Dory is a relatively conventional work, being the loosely ordered reminiscences of 56-year-old George Singer, overeducated proprietor of a sweet kiosk in Maryport. Singer is having some sort of midlife crisis, brought on by the strange behaviour of a turbot in the town's aquarium, which smiled at him one lunchtime.

On subsequent visits, the fish does nothing irregular, but the one revelation has been enough to stir up silted memories of long ago. Some of these are tender (Christmas decorations when he was three) others boisterous (a schoolfriend colliding with a bicycle and smashing his tatie pot, used to transport the totemic local dish of string beef, blood pudding and root vegetables).

The relationship between dialect and standard English is not as mutually enriching as it has been elsewhere in Murray's work. At times, the narrator's language becomes archly hearty ('Instantly, Willy experienced a 50 per cent increase in thwarted concupiscence'), as if to distance itself from the caricatural antics being described. Latinate vocabulary has a clogging effect ('Jinnie being the supererogatory blessing, the bounteous dowry for the recalcitrant bride').

Halfway through the book, the fish start to act up again. Singer seems to receive instructions from a John Dory to turn up the next night at the far end of North Quay. The fish is one of the oldest Christian symbols and the John Dory bears a mark that has been variously supposed to be the thumbprint of St Peter or Jesus himself, so it isn't altogether startling that the rendezvous should turn out to be with a visiting preacher, Kenneth Wright, testifying in 'a tin mish chapel' ('mish' as in missionary) about his own fall and redemption.

Quite how old-time religion fits in is hard to say. Although Wright's arrival in the story has been insistently foreshadowed, there is no confrontation of the two world-views (Singer's mother was strongly anti-religious and his father a socialist). The sermon sets off more memories in the narrator, this time of how he threw away the happiness of his married life with a self-destructive affair, but there's hardly so much as a conversation between him and the mysteriously announced stranger, let along a dramatised debate.

The disparate elements of the book co-exist rather than combine. It may be that Murray needs a general disaster to have a particular impact on Cumbria, as the destructive plume from Chernobyl so fertilised Radio Activity, before his talent fully rouses itself. In which case, he doesn't need to look further than the trenches currently being filled with thousands of slaughtered animals.

Workington likewise titters at Maryport... everyone laughs at someone else and to make matters worse the rest of the county laughs at the whole of the primitive west coast. And then most infuriatingly the rest of the country laughs at the whole of our bloody county. At bloody comical Cumbria, God's apparent gratuitous joke when he was resting between the creation of England and the creation of Scotland.' Murray is the lyric poet of this sliding-scale inferiority complex. Nevertheless, John Dory is a relatively conventional work, being the loosely ordered reminiscences of 56-year-old George Singer, overeducated proprietor of a sweet kiosk in Maryport. Singer is having some sort of midlife crisis, brought on by the strange behaviour of a turbot in the town's aquarium, which smiled at him one lunchtime. On subsequent visits, the fish does nothing irregular, but the one revelation has been enough to stir up silted memories of long ago. Some of these are tender (Christmas decorations when he was three) others boisterous (a schoolfriend colliding with a bicycle and smashing his tatie pot, used to transport the totemic local dish of string beef, blood pudding and root vegetables). The relationship between dialect and standard English is not as mutually enriching as it has been elsewhere in Murray's work. At times, the narrator's language becomes archly hearty ('Instantly, Willy experienced a 50 per cent increase in thwarted concupiscence'), as if to distance itself from the caricatural antics being described. Latinate vocabulary has a clogging effect ('Jinnie being the supererogatory blessing, the bounteous dowry for the recalcitrant bride'). Halfway through the book, the fish start to act up again. Singer seems to receive instructions from a John Dory to turn up the next night at the far end of North Quay. The fish is one of the oldest Christian symbols and the John Dory bears a mark that has been variously supposed to be the thumbprint of St Peter or Jesus himself, so it isn't altogether startling that the rendezvous should turn out to be with a visiting preacher, Kenneth Wright, testifying in 'a tin mish chapel' ('mish' as in missionary) about his own fall and redemption. Quite how old-time religion fits in is hard to say. Although Wright's arrival in the story has been insistently foreshadowed, there is no confrontation of the two world-views (Singer's mother was strongly anti-religious and his father a socialist). The sermon sets off more memories in the narrator, this time of how he threw away the happiness of his married life with a self-destructive affair, but there's hardly so much as a conversation between him and the mysteriously announced stranger, let along a dramatised debate. The disparate elements of the book co-exist rather than combine. It may be that Murray needs a general disaster to have a particular impact on Cumbria, as the destructive plume from Chernobyl so fertilised Radio Activity, before his talent fully rouses itself. In which case, he doesn't need to look further than the trenches currently being filled with thousands of slaughtered animals.

webTitle: Observer review: The Cold Six Thousand by James Ellroy

fields.headline: Powders, treason and plots
fields.standfirst: James stops. James thinks. James writes a sequel. Tom Cox is increasingly irritated by James Ellroy's stylistic tics in The Cold Six Thousand
fields.trailText: James stops. James thinks. James writes a sequel. Tom Cox is increasingly irritated by James Ellroy's stylistic tics in The Cold Six Thousand
fields.body:
The Cold Six Thousand
James Ellroy
Century £16.99, pp692
Buy it at a discount at BOL

For a man often heard deploring the vacuous clichés of modern cinema, James Ellroy writes a worryingly inevitable sequel. In his previous novel, 1995's American Tabloid, Ellroy part-abandoned the criminal underworld of his earlier novels and began a mission to 'recreate twentieth-century American history through fiction', chronicling the thousand days leading up to the assassination of JFK from the point of view of the men behind the big names - the men who really wield the power. The Cold Six Thousand picks up where Tabloid left off, speedily, assumptively and, from a writer obsessed with excitement, transformation and scale, rather predictably.

It's hard to say how this book is inferior, but it certainly lacks Tabloid's urgency, perhaps because its climactic event (Robert Kennedy's assassination) doesn't cast quite such a huge shadow over the modern world, perhaps because Ellroy's ever more jazzy and minimal delivery is beginning to have the opposite effect to the intended one.

Ellroy was fast and clipped enough as it was, earlier novels like LA Confidential, American Tabloid and White Jazz creating something immense and symphonic (always Ellroy's aim) via something ultra-economical. But there's barely a paragraph longer than two lines here, the endless repetition of names ('Wayne yawned. Wayne stretched. Wayne scratched his balls. Wayne dumped his piss cup') quickly becomes irritating, and it seems unrealistic that everyone connected with the American political underworld in the mid-Sixties would do their thinking in jive. The reader clicks into Ellroy's pithy groove, but even then there's an emptiness behind the thrust and swagger of his prose.

The plot is faultless, but there's never been a question mark hanging over Ellroy's maths. Punched and counterpunched along with Ellroy's traditional three-tough-guy set-up (the speccy nerd, the gorilla who actually - shock! - is nice to women and the slimeball charmer), we follow the intricacies of the relationships between the CIA, the FBI, Jimmy Hoffa's Teamsters, Martin Luther King's civil-rights campaigners, heroin producers in Vietnam and the Cuban exiles. Or, rather, those of us who enjoy listening in to police-band radio conversations follow it, while the rest of us might wonder why exactly we need to care about all this.

There's a subtle shift in the three man arrangement here: American Tabloid's towering French-Canadian Pete Bondurant still thugs it up, but the smooth operator, Kemper Boyd, is dead and his lawyer friend Ward Littell has mutated from nerd to slick 'fixer'. His old role is taken by a new character, Wayne Tedrow Jr. What exactly do these men do? Tangible 'work' seems secondary to camaraderie. They make backhanded compliments about one another's honour, they kill people, they talk in soundbites, they act macho and inscrutable. The difference between before and now is it used to be fun watching Ellroy try to help these men get over the fact that they are emotional cripples.

There's no doubt that Ellroy has a talent for pace, punch and moral pollution, but you can't help feeling that this is less taxing than the work of the genuine heavyweight novelist. Often during The Cold Six Thousand, there's a depressingly empty sense that the interwoven relationships of the American underworld are no more colourful than an FBI report. But Ellroy probably thinks FBI reports are colourful.

webTitle: Observer review: Spike Island by Philip Hoare

fields.headline: A hospital with sick building syndrome
fields.standfirst: The Royal Victoria Military Hospital got off to a bad start. Then things got worse as Philip Hoare tells in Spike Island
fields.trailText: The Royal Victoria Military Hospital got off to a bad start. Then things got worse as Philip Hoare tells in Spike Island
fields.body:
Spike Island: The Memory of a Military Hospital
Philip Hoare
Fourth Estate £17.99, pp417
Buy it at a discount at BOL

The dustjacket of Philip Hoare's history of a hospital shows an ancient, silvery photograph revealing an interior: a long, narrow ward - a corridor more than a room - flanked by iron beds. At the end of the ward is an arched, open doorway; through this doorway is another ward of identical length and layout with, at its end, a second archway; beyond this can be seen another smaller arch, and beyond this another, as if the wards continue endlessly.

The building is Netley's Royal Victoria Military Hospital, a structure so immense, so grandiose, it was 'as though designed by a team of architects whom no one had told to stop'. The hospital was completed in 1863; seven years before, Queen Victoria had laid the foundation stone at a ceremony during which a gunboat assembled on nearby Southampton Water had prematurely fired, killing two sailors. Any Victorian interested in symbolism may have taken this as a warning.

The beautiful, lumbering show-off of a construction, measuring a quarter of a mile in length, able to accommodate 1,000 patients and along whose corridors postmen would ride their bikes to deliver the mail, was in trouble even before it began. Florence Nightingale, having first stressed the necessity of a new hospital after suffering a lack of places to treat soldiers wounded in the Crimean War, rapidly became one of its most vociferous critics. Describing it as 'gross and cavernous', she pointed out that its unwieldy design went against modern medical practice and referred to the building as 'the patient' due to its own urgent need of treatment.

She was right. Within three years, its medical quarters were so covered in fungi their damp made the doctors ill. (When the Americans arrived during the Second World War, they were horrified at the plumbing.) As Hoare asserts: 'Imperial hubris had taken precedence over humane function.'

Spike Island (the name its inhabitants gave the area centuries before), is as singular as Hoare's previous work: simply, his chosen subject is so interesting it is astonishing to consider that no one has written of it before. However, few could combine such rigorous scholarly accuracy with Hoare's narrative flair. His literary tones - ghostly, haunting, reminiscent of du Maurier - find their echo in Netley's grim history.

This history is even greater, more labyrinthine, than the hospital itself, with stories spawning still more stories, each as fascinating as the one before. Victims of the Boer War and both world wars found themselves here; Wilfred Owen was a patient. An 'eerie, depressing place', doctors would experiment on themselves in the laboratories and, it was rumoured, use German PoWs as human guinea pigs. In the psychiatric wing, shell-shock victims were treated as harshly as the decades dictated and Hoare's descriptions of these psychological casualties are deeply affecting.

Hoare develops a gothic theme that marries glamour with morbidity and runs throughout the work, in which lies its only flaw. In order to establish the gothic theme, Hoare recounts the history of the area: a Cistercian abbey built near the hospital grounds is necessarily deserving of explanation, but is written of in such exhaustive detail it seems like a lecture. But it is Spike Island's only failing, and a small one.

More daring, and far more successful, is the personal history that the author weaves into the fabric of the book. Hoare writes of his own family, who live near the hospital (Hoare himself attended a school whose class huts were once part of the building), and recounts childhood memories, strange coincidences and the death of his brother and his father.

Spike Island - elaborate, riveting, touching, strangely romantic - is itself a gothic tale and, one imagines, a catharsis for the author. In closing the circle on his own youth, Hoare lays to rest many ghosts - his own and those of the soldiers who took what he describes as 'the inexorable journey that began with a train to the Front and ended [at the Royal Victoria Military Hospital] deep in a Hampshire wood'.

webTitle: Crime roundup

fields.headline: He's fat and crude but, by golly, he's clever
fields.standfirst: Detective novels need more than sleuthing to make the grade.  Peter Guttridge investigates the latest crop
fields.trailText: Detective novels need more than sleuthing to make the grade. Peter Guttridge investigates the latest crop
fields.body:
Reginald Hill is clearly having a very good time in Dialogues of the Dead (HarperCollins £16.99, pp453), the eighteenth of his highly acclaimed, award-winning police-procedural series featuring Andy Dalziel and Peter Pascoe. There are murders aplenty as a serial killer dubbed the Wordman cuts a swathe through a range of literary luminaries on Dalziel's patch, then writes up his exploits in multiple entries for a short-story competition. But there's also pretty much a laugh a line and a playful enjoyment of language in all its forms, from the 'Fat Man' Dalziel's colourful Yorkshire dialect to arcane polysyllables and bizarre neologisms.

For as well as being a hugely enjoyable mystery, Dialogues of the Dead is a novel about language, about its power and the power of naming (half the characters are using assumed or altered names for a variety of reasons). Much of the humour comes from the clash between Dalziel's exaggerated crudity and more intellectual matters in which Hill is clearly interested, as when Dalziel is described 'scratching his crotch like a man refuting Bishop Berkeley'.

Dalziel and Pascoe, while looming large in the novel, share centre stage with 'Hat' Bowler the ambitious young DC who reminds Pascoe of his young self. Bowler is in pursuit both of the Wordman and Rye Pomona, the lovely but distant librarian who helps him with the case.

Almost everybody is other than they seem and Hill keeps you guessing just about to the end - you might figure out the final twist but it remains a satisfying conclusion nevertheless. Dialogues of the Dead is a highly engaging read, but I recommend you keep a dictionary handy.

For Riptide (Weidenfeld and Nicolson £16.99, pp322), the fourth novel featuring Frederick Troy, the policeman son of a distinguished Russian émigré, John Lawton has turned the clock back to 1941, three years before the setting of his striking debut novel, Blackout. It's spring, America is neutral (just), Russia is about to be invaded by Germany and Troy is still a young, ambitious sergeant in the Metropolitan Police.

After 10 years spying for the Americans, Wolfgang Stahl, deputy to Obergruppenführer Heydrich, disappears during an air raid on Berlin. He's supposed to be dead but nobody believes it: not MI6, which assumes he's headed for London; not US intelligence, which sends a young German-speaking captain to the English capital to find Stahl; and certainly not Heydrich, who dispatches Nazi assassins to England to kill his deputy before the Allies can get their hands on him.

The sense of London during the Blitz is strong and the story, with its mix of real history and believable invention, is fast-paced, twisting and tense. There's also an intriguing ménage à trois of the US captain, Troy, who is working with Stahl, and a precocious, independent policewoman, who, in her own way, loves them both. These elements combine to produce a novel that is sheer entertainment.

Julie Parsons got high praise for her first two psychological thrillers and her publishers are giving her third novel, Eager to Please (Macmillan £10, pp370), a big promotional push. It charts the life of Rachel Beckett, how she is imprisoned for 12 years for the murder of her husband (a murder she swears she didn't commit) and how, when she is finally released, she plots her revenge on the person she holds responsible for framing her for his death.

The publishers describe the novel as 'literary crime', which I guess means that Parsons takes her time establishing Beckett's character. This makes for a slow but absorbing start as the horrors of going to jail and then of adjusting back to civilian life are carefully described. The problem is that Beckett is established so strongly I would have liked it more if Parsons had stayed with her story throughout the novel.

But, perhaps to inject mystery - because there is no mystery about who really did kill Rachel Beckett's husband - the author abruptly takes the focus off Beckett and introduces, about a third of the way into the book, a new main character, Inspector Jack Donnelly, and a new murder investigation. The two stories do eventually merge, but not seamlessly, and the careful, realistic writing of much of the novel gives way to a rather melodramatic ending that seems to belong in another book. Eager to Please is compelling but flawed.

The same can be said of Caroline Carver's Blood Junction (Orion £9.99, pp280) but for a first novel that's pretty good going. It's a fast-paced tale centred round journalist India Kane, who travels from Sydney to the outback town of Cooinda for a reunion with her friend Lauren. Forty years before, the town witnessed the massacre of an entire Aboriginal family and locals renamed it Blood Junction. When Kane arrives, she is almost immediately arrested for murder.

Carver is particularly good at making you feel Kane's isolation and fear and the threatening atmosphere around her. There are also enough startling incidents to keep you turning those pages, but I wasn't entirely sold on the plot. Nevertheless, Blood Junction is a most promising debut.

Donna Leon, meanwhile, goes from strength to strength. Her latest Guido Brunetti novel, A Sea of Troubles (Heinemann £15.99, pp247) is clever, vivid and wholly absorbing. In it, Commissario Brunetti tries to investigate the murders of two clam fisherman from the close-knit community of the island of Pellestrina on the Venetian lagoon. This is her tenth Brunetti novel but it's a fresh and entertaining as the first, Death at La Fenice. Dare I say that these days Brunetti is edging out Michael Dibdin's Aurelio Zen as the most interesting Italian policeman in fiction?

Cutter and Bone (Serpents Tail £7.99 pp320), Newton Thornburg's landmark crime novel is a minor masterpiece of 1970s American literature. It's a taut thriller but like, say, Robert Stone's Dog Soldiers, it's also much more. Reissued by Serpents Tail, with an introduction by George P. Pelecanos, it still carries a big wallop.

Bone is the ageing gigolo who witnesses the dumping of a murdered woman's body and Cutter is the embittered, viciously articulate, maimed Vietnam veteran who insists on nailing the tycoon they suspect of the murder in a scheme that is part vengeance, part blackmail, part self-destructive lunacy. Truly wonderful.
