webTitle: Observer review: A Clouded Peace by John Cole

fields.headline: Two pints of Guinness and a ceasefire, please
fields.standfirst: Anne McHardy remembers a different Belfast to the one that John Cole uses as a backdrop to A Clouded Peace
fields.trailText: Anne McHardy remembers a different Belfast to the one that John Cole uses as a backdrop to A Clouded Peace
fields.body:
A Clouded Peace
John Cole
Weidenfeld & Nicholson £12.99, pp265
Buy it at a discount at BOL

There are improbabilities in John Cole's novel, A Clouded Peace. There are improbabilities in any novel. My problem with this novel is that the plot is set in John Cole's native city, Belfast, in 1977, when I was working there as correspondent for the Guardian, of which John had been assistant editor.

John was then reporting on British politics, first as the deputy editor of The Observer and then as the political editor of the BBC. In both roles, he assiduously avoided commenting on Northern Ireland, recognising how difficult his instinctive bias was to suppress. He had worked in Northern Ireland as a reporter for the first 11 years of his career. My most frequent contact with him was in the House of Commons, when I travelled from Belfast to cover Northern Ireland debates and he twitted me about being too gulled by the Nationalists, as he knew himself to be too gut-reactingly Unionist.

The novel's plot turns on the traumas brought to the family of a Northern Irish Protestant journalist, who accepts an invitation from a pre-Thatcherite Labour government to serve as policy adviser to the Northern Ireland Secretary. It was a time when John himself, who joined the Guardian to report on trade union affairs, was used as a sounding-board by members of the Wilson and the Callaghan governments about what he calls, his accent not completely softened by his 40 years in England, 'Ulster'.

However, it is hard to believe a Belfast-born 'Prod', who was so publicly recognisable that people in the street knew him, as Cole makes his hero, could walk into the Falls, still only patrolled by the Army because it was too dangerous for the police, to meet a senior member of the IRA army council over a couple of pints of Guinness to initiate peace negotiations.

The scenario is the more unlikely since Cole's IRA man chooses a Provo drinking club so that he will be seen by his Provo circle to have the ear of the 'Brits'.

Some of the physical descriptions of the city sound an odd note, too. They seem to date from later. The Europa was nowhere near as cosy in 1977 as the novel makes it. However, Belfast is a strange city and seemingly utterly improbable meetings in improbable settings have occurred to achieve the current peace process. What the novel certainly does catch is the wreckage the Troubles have brought to ordinary families and the mismatch between the needs of Northern Ireland and the priorities of Westminster. It tellingly reflects the destructive lunacies that government 'spooks' have perpetrated by listening to the wilder voices on all political sides.

There are other improbabilities in the story, not least that the hero's wife contemplates leaving the domestic hearth of 20 years to live with another man on the strength of a couple of pecks on the cheek. Accused of adultery, she reacts in blank horror: 'That has not happened.'

With all these provisos, most of them reflecting my too great intimacy with the era the novel is set in, this is a story that rolls along grippingly with telling insights into the politics of the British and the Northern Ireland administrations, and into the mind of the sort of liberal, Labour-supporting Protestant that Cole is. Its most serious flaw is probably that it is too hard on the media. We may be easily led by spin doctors, but most of us are surely less wickedly vacuous than John makes the TV programme-makers whose follies drive the plot.

The story is, of course, well and tightly written, as one should expect from a journalist so professional, well worth the brief hours that it demands for its readers to reach the pathos of its conclusion.

webTitle: What's the point of writer's clubs?

fields.headline: What's the point of writer's clubs?
fields.standfirst: ...well saving lives is clearly a bonus
fields.trailText: ...well saving lives is clearly a bonus
fields.body:
A group of eminent British writers and journalists, among them A.S. Byatt, Tom Stoppard, P.D. James, Beryl Bainbridge, Craig Raine, Howard Jacobson and Kieran Prendiville, gathered in London's Italian Cultural Institute last week to pay tribute to Primo Levi with an evening of readings entitled In Praise of Freedom.

The pieces were largely chosen from In Search of Roots, an anthology of pieces Levi collected for their autobiographical significance, and the last of his books to be published in Italy during his lifetime (the English translation is to be published for the first time in June by Allen Lane). While the book is fascinating as a picture of Levi's cultural landscape, the tribute took on a broader significance, since the event was organised by Pen, the international writers' association, in aid of their Writers in Prison foundation.

Writers' groups are often denigrated for their clubbiness, the sense that they exist only for writers 'who need to be on committees', as one author put it. Indeed, Pen began life as a writers' dining club, with John Galsworthy as its president, but its charter rapidly evolved to take on a more ethical hue, with aims of promoting the universality of literature and the opposition of suppression of free expression. Among its early members were Conrad, Chesterton, Shaw, Yeats and Rebecca West.

Today, Pen's involvement with imprisoned writers around the world is a practical gesture of solidarity of undeniable significance. Pen's work in this country includes educational projects to promote literature, as well as public debates and literary prizes, but the Writers in Prison programme is especially valuable, because it offers a bridge to writers around the world who have been persecuted, punished or imprisoned for their work. Members write to them in prison and send literature and although letters and books are often seized and censored, the prisoners are sometimes able to write back.

Often, they are only able to express their gratitude after their release, if they are lucky enough to secure it. Pen also campaigns for the release of these writers and offers support to their families.

Why specifically writers, though? Is this another example of the literary world looking after its own; surely all prisoners of conscience deserve the same support? This was a question addressed to one of the guest readers at the Levi tribute and it provoked considerable discussion about the common ideals and potential self-importance of literature. Though Pen works closely with groups such as Amnesty (which it predates), its charter limits members to working on behalf of those who have been imprisoned purely because of what they have written, be it overtly polemical journalism or fiction, poetry or plays whose interpretation has been twisted and misappropriated by the authorities.

The answer, I think, is that it's sometimes easy to forget the power of the written word when you live in a community where censorship exists only in the very subtlest ways. If you were to judge the state of literature in this country by the stories that make their way on to the news pages, you could be forgiven for thinking that the writing business, like the music industry, is more about being famous than being creative - the six-figure advance, the Hollywood film deal, the black-tie award dinners, the best-seller market dominated by a handful of monolithic corporations.

Pen's work, and the equally valuable work of the journal Index on Censorship, enables those who make their living by writing to pause and recognise that their counterparts in countries such as China, Turkey, Nigeria, Iran or Cuba worry not about how much review space their latest book will garner, but whether it will bring the feared midnight knock.

Yet these writers bravely continue to produce their tracts, novels, plays and poems in the face of possible torture or imprisonment. The Galician novelist, Juan Goytisolo, exiled under Franco, said in a recent talk that the best works of art are those that are not obviously political in content, but writers don't operate in a vacuum, and they often can't help but engage with the issues of the society that surrounds them; under many regimes, even the most oblique reference makes them immediately vulnerable.

'The life of a prisoner is hard and desperate, even more so when the victim is innocent,' wrote the Peruvian writer Yehude Simon Munaro, in a letter to Pen after his release last December, having served eight years of a 20-year sentence on false charges of espionage. 'I do not know what I would have done without your oceanic solidarity.'

Like the writings of Primo Levi, the testimonies of these writers are a powerful and necessary reminder that there is a world of literature beyond Harry Potter and Bridget Jones.

webTitle: Observer review: On Green Dolphin Street by Sebastian Faulks

fields.headline: Out of the blue
fields.standfirst: Sebastian Faulks's love story, On Green Dolphin Street, owes more than its title to Miles Davis
fields.trailText: Sebastian Faulks's love story, On Green Dolphin Street, owes more than its title to Miles Davis
fields.body:
On Green Dolphin Street
Sebastian Faulks
Hutchinson £16.99, pp356
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Reflecting on his conviction that he has 'exhausted the world's literary output', Charlie van der Linden, an English diplomat posted in Washington, remembers how his father used to warn, 'Ars longa, vita brevis'. But with time he discovered that even 'ars was not as longa as people made out'.

His dismay at the insufficiency of literature is revealing: in different ways, the three main characters in this novel are all struggling against the limits of their lives. And any confessions of contentment are either self-deluding or straightforwardly phoney.

Some years before this story began, Charlie had an affair with a girl in Tokyo, and was involved in illegal share-dealing - sufficient leverage for an attempt to blackmail him into being a spy. He refused, preferring to enter the diplomatic service 'by the front door'. Now, Charlie and Mary live a diplomatic life, in every sense of the word: Charlie is an alcoholic, on the brink of a mental and physical collapse; tactfully, they avoid confronting his imminent breakdown, especially in front of their two children.

But the focus of the novel is less on their marriage than on the relationship which threatens its fragile equilibrium. Enter Frank Renzo, Chicago-born journalist, who becomes Mary's lover.

Yet things do not fall apart. There is no anarchy set loose upon Mary and Charlie's marriage. Nor is the result a triangular relationship so much as dualism's Archimedean point, found and tested. Their world is knocked out of joint, not tipped off its axis.

Faulks holds this relationship up as a mirror to the age. Exhausted by the sullen black-white oppositions of the Cold War, McCarthyism, and the South, America is described as being in a state of 'free-floating anxiety'. As Eisenhower's term comes to an end, the war in Indochina - with its numberless, invisible enemy - symbolises precisely this neurosis; and Kennedy's victory over Nixon is conceded by the slenderest of grey margins.

There are obvious similarities between On Green Dolphin Street and Faulks's superbly popular trilogy (The Girl at the Lion d'Or, Birdsong and Charlotte Gray). The story centres around a heroine. Love is the engine that drives and directs the narrative; desire gives it shape and dimension. Topographical detail is closely rendered and lit with a gathering fever of emotion. There's a faultless depiction of place and time, served up on a bed of generous reservation: even flawed characters are worthy of pity.

But this is also a new departure for Faulks. The title is taken from a Miles Davis track, and the novel's structure owes much to the complex layering of rhythm and theme that is the currency of jazz: the story is delivered in a non-linear sequence, buoyant with swing and syncopation. And the plot performs like an elegant melody, sliding above and below a dense articulation of sound, so that any sense of a character's autonomy - a sudden, heartfelt solo - is soon tempered by the limits of tradition, family, or a diplomatic world become stupid with Cold War paranoia.

The setting, too, is a new one. The story is played out in Washington, New York and London - with a brief stint in Moscow. The Second World War is the subject of remembrance, merely offering the background boom of noise to more subtle, personal themes of desire and despair: this is, above all, a love story. But it is a love story with scant hope of resolution.

Mary's family depends on her: her mother is dying, her children are lonely, her husband can't live without her. And at 40, she feels that 'the slipped responsibilities of the old and young were hers alone to bear'. But it's impossible to resolve the love story for another reason: she admits to 'a hunger for his [her lover's] presence that his presence could not sate'. To my mind, Faulks's writing is at its best when he allows metaphor to convey this sense of emotion's pressure against possibility's limit. And the island of Manhattan is as useful a metaphor as any.

The lovers' dream of insularity is entirely subject to the waking reality of the world's physical and political landscape. Manhattan is far from being a blessed isle, after all. There are traffic jams and delayed flights to contend with. And notwithstanding Frank's declaration to Mary, 'I love you with all my heart', waiters wield an awesome power with, 'Can I get you folks the check now?'

My main reservation is that Faulks takes no risks. He never falls into what V.S. Pritchett called 'the determined stupor out of which great novelists work'. But then it's nice to be able to criticise a novel essentially on the grounds that you wish there were more flaws, signs of authorial sweat and struggle - what William Faulkner called 'the human heart in conflict with itself which alone can make good writing'. (I imagine Faulks has a mind like an expensive car: his readers travel in certainty and comfort, even through dangerous neighbourhoods.) Having said this, he successfully renders the trope of passion as a circular descent into the underworld. Mary crosses the Delaware, thinking more of the Styx than the first state of the Union. Later, she gets lost on Moscow's ring roads. She also takes a train through 'an underworld of rusted sidings and wrecked tracks'.

But it is Faulks's insistence on the inability of an individual human life ever to contain the spirit that galvanises it, that underpins his story. The jazz metaphor is as apt as Charlie's confessed fondness for Melville: however tricksy or vast the vessel of expression, humility forces one to admit that the greater part of life is uncontainable, endlessly various, ultimately elusive.

Just as Charlie despaired of the limits of literature, Mary almost despairs of love, wondering if it means only that 'at some point you give up the idea of yourself as a person capable of infinite expansion'. But her love for Frank tells her otherwise, and I suspect that, as an author, Faulks is rather in awe of his heroine's yearning to step beyond the limits of her life.

webTitle: 10 ways to get it right the first time

fields.headline: 10 ways to get it right the first time
fields.standfirst: Avoid the snags with a guide from Graham Norwood
fields.trailText: Avoid the snags with a guide from Graham Norwood.
fields.body:
Around 1.6m people will buy a house for the first time in 2001, says the Council of Mortgage Lenders. But without a lot of preparation, the process can become a nightmare long before you get your hands on the keys.

There are 10 vital stages, and the first four should be completed before you even visit an estate agent.

1. Saving for a deposit. Most first-time buyers need to save as much as they can to minimise their borrowing. Many lenders demand 10%, though Virgin One asks half that and some, such as the Halifax, take as little as 3%.

The average cost of a home in Britain is £87,038, according to the Halifax, but first- time buyers outside London usually pay an average of£58,198, says the Nationwide building society Assuming you need a 5% deposit for a £65,000 flat, your first cost will be the £3,250 deposit.

2. What sort of mortgage? Some 125 lenders offer more than 4,000 between them. Many first-timers ask a broker, some of whom charge a fee, to find the best deal. The alternative is to try the high street or the internet and choose from the following sorts of loan:

· Standard variable mortgages (SVR), where the interest rates are set at between 1.5 and 2% above the Bank of England base rate.

· Discounted: interest is charged below SVR, but reverts to it after a set time.

· Fixed, where you agree to pay a set rate regardless of changes to base rate or a lender's SVR.

· Capped mortgages, which cannot rise above an agreed ceiling but can fall at the lender's discretion.

· Flexible loans, which rarely offer the most competitive rates but allow borrowers to repay extra when they have spare cash.

3. Find out how much you can borrow. Loans are based on income. The Norwich and Peterborough Building Society is typical in offering sole buyers 3.5 times their income, so if you earn £20,000 a year, your mortgage could be £70,000.

For a couple there are two ratios. One is 3.5 times the highest income plus one time the lowest. If each of you earn £20,000, the loan would be £70,000 plus £20,000 - a total of £90,000. The second is 2.6 times the joint income. In our example that would total £104,000.

But self-employed borrowers beware. Some lenders insist on audited books going back up to three years.

4. Finding a property. Visit agents in the area you are moving to, give them precise details of what you want and your price range. Remember, house-selling is not tightly regulated, and agents act in vendors' best interests, not the buyers'. The internet can help buyers to shortlist properties, but is no substitute for a visit.

5. Making an offer. First, check that the seller can move out when you want to move in. If all looks good, make an offer, subject to contract. House-buying experts Hometrack say the size of offer depends on the market. If demand is strong, buyers are likely to offer close to the asking price.

6. Get a survey. Your lender will require a valuation survey to ensure the home is worth more than the mortgage. This costs between £150 and £200. But buyers should get a more detailed survey, outlining the condition of the house and listing what needs doing. These are called homebuyers' surveys and usually cost between£300 and £400. If the property is very old or run-down, opt for a full structural survey costing £800 or more.

7. Appoint a solicitor or a conveyancer - a legal expert who specialises only in house transactions. The seller's solicitor/conveyancer will prepare a draft contract between you and the seller. Your solicitor will contact the local council, paying £100 for "searches", or investigations into the legal history of the house, and details of any rights of way or planning permissions for roads, buildings or extensions nearby.

Land Registry fees are between £40 and £800,and your solicitor will arrange to pay stamp duty on the deal, which is 1% of the house price between £60,000 and £250,000 and more for dearer homes. Sundry costs usual total about £50. On our £65,000 home, the total of the legal fees including stamp duty would be about £1,100.

8. Exchanging contracts between the two parties. After this, you and the seller are locked into a binding deal. The contracts should include all search details, surveyor's findings, mortgage and deposit information and a date for completion of the deal - the day you move in.

9. Choose a removal company. Some first-time buyers have few belongings and may be able to get away with hiring a van and persuading friends to help. If you have more, it may be worth hiring a removal firm. Ask three for quotes. Most first-time moves cost about £600.

10. Completion. On the day you and the seller agree to complete the deal, your lender will send the mortgage money to your solicitor who forwards it to the seller's solicitor. As soon as it is received, the keys can be handed to you.

Even in our modest £65,000 flat the new owner has already spent £5,600 before the first mortgage payment is due. The news is much worse in London, where first-timers borrow an average of £98,091.

The alternative is to try the high street or the internet and choose from the following sorts of loan: · Standard variable mortgages (SVR), where the interest rates are set at between 1.5 and 2% above the Bank of England base rate. · Discounted: interest is charged below SVR, but reverts to it after a set time. · Fixed, where you agree to pay a set rate regardless of changes to base rate or a lender's SVR. · Capped mortgages, which cannot rise above an agreed ceiling but can fall at the lender's discretion. · Flexible loans, which rarely offer the most competitive rates but allow borrowers to repay extra when they have spare cash. 3. Find out how much you can borrow. Loans are based on income. The Norwich and Peterborough Building Society is typical in offering sole buyers 3.5 times their income, so if you earn £20,000 a year, your mortgage could be £70,000. For a couple there are two ratios. One is 3.5 times the highest income plus one time the lowest. If each of you earn £20,000, the loan would be £70,000 plus £20,000 - a total of £90,000. The second is 2.6 times the joint income. In our example that would total £104,000. But self-employed borrowers beware. Some lenders insist on audited books going back up to three years. 4. Finding a property. Visit agents in the area you are moving to, give them precise details of what you want and your price range. Remember, house-selling is not tightly regulated, and agents act in vendors' best interests, not the buyers'. The internet can help buyers to shortlist properties, but is no substitute for a visit. 5. Making an offer. First, check that the seller can move out when you want to move in. If all looks good, make an offer, subject to contract. House-buying experts Hometrack say the size of offer depends on the market. If demand is strong, buyers are likely to offer close to the asking price. 6. Get a survey. Your lender will require a valuation survey to ensure the home is worth more than the mortgage. This costs between £150 and £200. But buyers should get a more detailed survey, outlining the condition of the house and listing what needs doing. These are called homebuyers' surveys and usually cost between£300 and £400. If the property is very old or run-down, opt for a full structural survey costing £800 or more. 7. Appoint a solicitor or a conveyancer - a legal expert who specialises only in house transactions. The seller's solicitor/conveyancer will prepare a draft contract between you and the seller. Your solicitor will contact the local council, paying £100 for "searches", or investigations into the legal history of the house, and details of any rights of way or planning permissions for roads, buildings or extensions nearby. Land Registry fees are between £40 and £800,and your solicitor will arrange to pay stamp duty on the deal, which is 1% of the house price between £60,000 and £250,000 and more for dearer homes. Sundry costs usual total about £50. On our £65,000 home, the total of the legal fees including stamp duty would be about £1,100. 8. Exchanging contracts between the two parties. After this, you and the seller are locked into a binding deal. The contracts should include all search details, surveyor's findings, mortgage and deposit information and a date for completion of the deal - the day you move in. 9. Choose a removal company. Some first-time buyers have few belongings and may be able to get away with hiring a van and persuading friends to help. If you have more, it may be worth hiring a removal firm. Ask three for quotes. Most first-time moves cost about £600. 10. Completion. On the day you and the seller agree to complete the deal, your lender will send the mortgage money to your solicitor who forwards it to the seller's solicitor. As soon as it is received, the keys can be handed to you. Even in our modest £65,000 flat the new owner has already spent £5,600 before the first mortgage payment is due. The news is much worse in London, where first-timers borrow an average of £98,091.

webTitle: Comment: Shayler case proves that spirit of secrecy is dead

fields.headline: Breaking the code
fields.standfirst: The Shayler case proves that spirit that kept Enigma under wraps is long gone - thank goodness
fields.trailText: The Shayler case proves that spirit that kept Enigma under wraps is long gone - thank goodness.
fields.body:
Almost thirty years after it was made, The World at War, now being shown again on BBC2, is remembered by television producers as a summit of public-service broadcasting which can never be climbed again. The scope of the programme, the resources spent on finding the best witnesses and footage for 26 one-hour episodes can't be matched today. Competition in a medium stuffed with channels has downsized budgets. The need to catch and hold attention with any trick, however meretricious, has undermined respect for the viewers' intelligence.

The difference between The World at War 's efforts to tell it like it really was and Jeremy Bowen's asinine hunt for the 'real' Jesus - 'The film crew are going to leave me, up here, all alone, in a cave, high up on the Mount of Temptation in the middle of the Judaean desert!' - is a cultural chasm. We are stranded on the wrong side looking back at a lost world.

Veterans of the series retain a justifiable pride in their achievement, but are struck by what they didn't find out. They worked from 1970 to 1973. Pretty much everyone on the British side in the Second World War was more than happy to talk to them. No one mentioned the breaking of the supposedly unbreakable Enigma code with the first working prototype of a computer. The World at War 's account of the Battle of the Atlantic has the Allies deploying superior naval tactics to defeat the U-boats. The writers didn't know that the Allies were able to blast the U-boats out of the ocean because they had the slight advantage of being able to read German signals.

My colleague, Neal Ascherson, who worked on the programme, remains astonished. Twelve thousand people, including his very own sister, deciphered Enigma codes at Bletchley Park. At the end of the war they were sworn to utter and permanent secrecy. There were no sticks or carrots. The codebreakers trusted authority and kept quiet about their part in one of the great intellectual achievements of the twentieth century.

Imagine how difficult it was for men in particular to stay silent or to mutter that they had 'desk jobs', while others boasted of their experience of combat; to take the condescension and questioning of their courage and not to be able to shout that they had saved lives and turned battles. But they did - for decades. Their enormous stoicism represents the best side of the national character. Very British, as we used to say.

On Wednesday David Shayler goes on trial for refusing put his trust in authority. The former MI5 officer faces three charges of breaking the Official Secrets Act and a maximum prison sentence of six years if convicted. He will not deny that he refused to restrain himself. He told the Mail on Sunday about MI5's files on politicians and its poisonous office politics; how it wasted hundreds of thousands of pounds on tapping the phones of a journalist and fluffed chances to catch an IRA active service unit and prevent the bombing of the Israeli embassy. The legal argument will, in its own way, turn on the national character; on what it means to be British.

The British are not meant to be the victims of political trials. We're a democracy, not some sweltering banana republic. The British have equality before the law - a politician cannot order the arrest of ideological enemy while allowing criminal officials and bent suppliers of party funds to go free. We're innocent until found guilty beyond reasonable doubt by a jury of our peers. We're free to speak our minds.

Protected by these ancient liberties the free-born Briton can pity the luckless inhabitants of Abroad as lesser breeds without the law. Until, that is, he's charged under the Official Secrets Act and discovers that everything he thought he knew about Britain was tosh.

The Shayler trial is a political trial. The prosecution was authorised by Lord Williams, the Attorney General and a politician who wants to restrict the rights of juries to reach true verdicts in the courts. A separate civil action against Shayler was cleared by Jack Straw, the Home Secretary. When Shayler fled to exile in Paris because a vengeful Government decided to persecute the whistle-blower rather than investigate his allegations, Britain persuaded the French to arrest him. The French courts said he was a political prisoner who couldn't be extradited for political crimes and released him.

The trial won't be much of a vindication of equality before the law either. If the Government believes Shayler broke the Official Secrets Act by talking to the Mail on Sunday, then it must also believe that the paper broke the law when it published his tales of a bungling and unaccountable secret state. The Mail on Sunday is not being prosecuted. I've no wish to see journalists sent to prison - apart from news editors, obviously - but the only explanation for selective justice I can find lies in a balance of power. Shayler has been widely slandered and is all but broke. The Mail on Sunday is a wealthy institution which can afford the best lawyers in London. There is also an election coming up. Someone may well have calculated that its editor would not have taken the kindest view of New Labour if it had compelled him to organise his political coverage from the dock of the Old Bailey.

The charges against Shayler, meanwhile, are selective. His most sensational accusation was that MI6 spent £100,000 on a failed attempt to assassinate Colonel Gadaffi. Robin Cook dismissed it as 'pure fantasy'. Documents supporting Shayler's allegations were posted on the internet. Shayler's account of MI6 officers organising a coup by Islamic fundamentalists suddenly looked credible. Egypt, Morocco, Algeria and Tunisia prefer Gadaffi to the alternative. They are fighting religious opponents and would have been furious with Britain if the assasination had succeeded. Someone has taken the politic decision not to charge Shayler with leaking details of the plot. No one will discuss Libya at the trial or how MI6 can play games in North Africa without the approval of elected politicians.

As for freedom of speech, the Official Secrets Act prohibits it. You can be prosecuted even if you have found evidence of corruption in MI5 or 6. It's a crime to reveal a crime. All information from the security services is a state secret, unless it is in the forthcoming memoirs of Stella Rimmington, the former head of MI5, who appears to be above the law. The Government doesn't have to prove that Shayler helped an enemy, merely that he spoke out. This is probably just as well from the Government's point of view. All an enemy could learn from Shayler's revelation that MI5 classed Jack Straw, Harriet Harman and Peter Mandelson - three of the more right-wing politicians in Labour history - as dangerous subversives is that the British secret service is run by reactionary simpletons.

Liberty, the human rights group which represents Shayler, will argue that blanket official secrecy contradicts the European Convention of Human Rights. The case should be stopped, it says, and the 1989 Official Secrets Act reformed. The prosecution will say that Parliament wanted a blanket ban when it passed the Act and the Commons can override human rights law. (They'll have to forget that Straw and Tony Blair opposed the Tory measure in 1989 precisely because it didn't give defendants the chance to argue that their revelations were in the public interest.) The legal dispute could last for months - each side has said it will appeal if it loses. Shayler may never have to face a jury.

If he escapes, he can relish the irony that the Europe which the codebreakers of Bletchley Park worked to save is now a better defender of British liberty than Parliament. Even if he loses, the ideas he represents will win.

The Enigma codebreakers kept quiet because they believed in authority. Their trust was abused. They were forced to stay silent until the mid-1970s, not for reasons of genuine security but to uphold secrecy for secrecy's sake and prevent reports of Britain's part in the atrocities of the Cold War being made public.

Their deference has vanished and glasnost is a spirit of the age. You may not like the consequences. I back away from journalists who write about the awfulness of their boyfriends and difficulties with bowel movements. I would love to see Robert Kilroy-Silk and Esther Rantzen bankrupted because no one would expose themselves on their manipulative shows. I travel great distances to avoid the work of Tracey Emin.

But egotism and babbling have their consolations. Governments and businesses can no longer be sure that their subordinates will obey orders to shut their mouths without good reason. Civil servants slip out documents. Patients demand inquiries into medical malpractice. The over-mighty directors of vast corporations can never quite escape the voice in the head which asks: 'What if this gets out?' The repressive laws of the 10-year regime of Michael Howard and Jack Straw can be seen as a vicious but, I hope, futile attempt to limit the growth in individual freedom.

The chasm which separates us from Bletchley Park is uncrossable. For all their virtues and all our faults, we're lucky to be on the right side looking back at a secret world which has gone for good.

webTitle: No style, no substance

fields.headline: No style, no substance
fields.standfirst: Special report: Scottish parliament
fields.trailText: Every week politics seems more and more like pantomime or a kind of slide show where images in rapid succession distort the underlying substance and dazzle the audience.
fields.body:
Every week politics seems more and more like pantomime or a kind of slide show where images in rapid succession distort the underlying substance and dazzle the audience.

Thus Hague poses for pictures with Portillo and the images expressing their undying mutual loyalty duly hit the front pages. Next day Portillo refuses to sign the statement on race already endorsed by the leader, suggesting that the reality is precisely the opposite of what the picture seemed to show.

Wendy Alexander proudly parades her new tourism boss, former aviation executive Rod Lynch, even though advisers warn that the Scottish press will ask him where he plans to take his holidays.

The answer, quite reasonably, is the United States. But it prolongs the outburst of ersatz moral outrage that has forced the hapless Tourism Minister, Alasdair Morrison, to cut short a family holiday in Tuscany which he had booked long before the foot and mouth outbreak. Alexander, the serious-minded Minister who blundered into the Section 28 fiasco, has now been blamed by sources close to First Minister Henry McLeish for maladroitness.

Yet the excessive respect that politicians show to newspapers is one of the more pathetic features of modern life. Mr Morrison should have faced down the media but, I imagine, received insufficient support from his superiors in the coalition. Everybody is entitled to spend their holidays where they choose: that is the whole point of a holiday in the first place.

This brutish press power is a kind of mob rule. And it is mildly depressing that the reporting of Scotland's new politics should remain where it began, in the shallower reaches of a lake called Trivia where highly-paid feuilletonists skim the froth and sell it to their gullible readers in the daily prints. This diet is as suspect as the water that private companies used to sell in the streets of Glasgow before the great Victorian scheme purified the city's supply.

Thus the style rather than the substance of what goes on in the Parliament obsesses our pundits. It comes as no surprise to learn that Sir Anthony Jay had difficulty in finding memorable modern examples for his Oxford Dictionary of Political Quotations , published this month. If political correctness has made the insult a shadow of its former self - who today, apart perhaps from Anne Robinson, could get way with Ben Jonson's 'thou Scottish fat-kidneyed dogfish!' - then our political discourse too has lost much of its elegance, pungency and vigour in the age of the sound bite and spin.

Yet the plodding world of professional politics goes on and, if the press and public seem to prefer the comedy to the substance, there are always the assiduous academics to follow every motion and amendment. A study of voting patterns in the first year of the Scottish Parliament, by Philip Cowley and Stephen Lochore, appears in the current volume of the journal Representation.

The findings are not particularly surprising. The infant Parliament has so far failed to develop the new consensual politics for which many hoped. The formal coalition hangs together reasonably well but the opposition of SNP and Conservatives go their own separate ways.

Yet the coalition is not completely secure. It has been shaken by dissent, usually when Lib Dem members have come under intense constituency pressure, and the commitment to implement the proposals for the care of the elderly in full is still opaque. After the election, it may cause renewed storms.

The authors concede that it is possible that the committee system, which distinguishes Edinburgh from Westminster, may yet prove more consensual, less tied to party lines. Of one thing we may be sure. You won't find many of the easily outraged commentators who pursue Ministers to their holiday villas spending much time in the real world of our legislators. That would be too much like hard work.

webTitle: Oh good, the Tories have caught mad cow disease again

fields.headline: Oh good, the Tories have caught mad cow disease again
fields.trailText: MONDAY: Perhaps not the loveliest Easter break I've ever had, but I always wondered whether the very best way for us to get away from the foot-and-mouth crisis was to go off to Chequers
fields.body:
MONDAY: Perhaps not the loveliest Easter break I've ever had, but I always wondered whether the very best way for us to get away from the foot-and-mouth crisis was to go off to Chequers, which is after all sort of in the (ugh) country. Tony talks to sobbing locals and our aghast children in ways wise, stern and reluctant-statesmanlike, like Roosevelt if Roosevelt had ever worn Timberland laced wellies and a stupidly thin Markies cardy from the exultantly wrongly-named spring collection (rather than, more pertinently, four carpeting layers of clotting tweed and narwhal-fat from the Inuits' emergency Christ But Bugger Me It's Cold When You Fall Through The Ice collection) and - where was I, sorry, delightful British spring hypothermia, found myself drifting a bit there - anyway, he told them all bravely that it just 'had' to be done, absolutely no alternative, months of ugly monstrous slaughter and filthy weepy memories of 2001 tragic but unavoidable, they'll hate him but they'll thank him. Masterful, and impressive - there's nothing like a man with the courage to be unpopular when he knows he's right.

Except he's not unpopular. New poll results show a frankly ludicrous increases in poll points, seeming to coincide suspiciously with the precise number of sheep killed, all of which makes me think history's most epic battles might have been a little more_ pleasant_ if we'd realised this somewhat earlier. Vlad the Knitter. Ghengis Purl. VietLamb. Baa'l.

TUESDAY: And, er, except he's not right either. Tony arrives back from emer gency Maff briefing in same head-in-hands what-horror-have-I-done? posture as when he heard the news, like Pilate or Othello or Thatcher if she'd actually had any morals, having learnt from quiet unassuming bespectacled genocidal chemist that we didn't really have to destroy any of them in the first place. I suspect Alastair's 'oops' was a little inadequate, unless ironic.

Still, proud of Tony. There's nothing like a man with the courage to be popular when he knows he's wrong.

Oops.

WEDNESDAY: The Tories are talking about drafting in Thatcher to 'reunite' the party.

Maff is talking about drafting in an expert to 'reunite' 15,000 slaughtered animals with their exploded intestines.

And the papers proudly tell me that American researchers have built a 'living robot', a computer connected to the brain of 'an eel-like fish' which somehow knows to always move towards the light, which would at least explain Hague, in Chinese.

THURSDAY: Too early, of course, to talk about any kind of reshuffle if we win, but speculation still seems rather rife. Tony, of course, exemplary in his diplomacy: much talk of 'God, no Keith; hope you're feeling better' and 'Superb job, Robin, superb', and 'Lose you? More chance of Man Utd losing in Europe, hahaha!'

Oops.

FRIDAY: Euan in the doghouse again, but not for the usual reason this time. No, Tony ticked him off over breakfast as Tony was singing our new theme song, which is uplifting in an 'aren't people and life wonderful?' type of pop music way which young people apparently like, and which will accompany the push for our triumphal second term. Euan's comment that he shouldn't give up the day job was unnecessarily cruel and Tony has been sulky, pouty, trembly bottom lippy ever since. Oops. Again.

Tony talks to sobbing locals and our aghast children in ways wise, stern and reluctant-statesmanlike, like Roosevelt if Roosevelt had ever worn Timberland laced wellies and a stupidly thin Markies cardy from the exultantly wrongly-named spring collection (rather than, more pertinently, four carpeting layers of clotting tweed and narwhal-fat from the Inuits' emergency Christ But Bugger Me It's Cold When You Fall Through The Ice collection) and - where was I, sorry, delightful British spring hypothermia, found myself drifting a bit there - anyway, he told them all bravely that it just 'had' to be done, absolutely no alternative, months of ugly monstrous slaughter and filthy weepy memories of 2001 tragic but unavoidable, they'll hate him but they'll thank him. Masterful, and impressive - there's nothing like a man with the courage to be unpopular when he knows he's right. Except he's not unpopular. New poll results show a frankly ludicrous increases in poll points, seeming to coincide suspiciously with the precise number of sheep killed, all of which makes me think history's most epic battles might have been a little more_ pleasant_ if we'd realised this somewhat earlier. Vlad the Knitter. Ghengis Purl. VietLamb. Baa'l. TUESDAY: And, er, except he's not right either. Tony arrives back from emer gency Maff briefing in same head-in-hands what-horror-have-I-done? posture as when he heard the news, like Pilate or Othello or Thatcher if she'd actually had any morals, having learnt from quiet unassuming bespectacled genocidal chemist that we didn't really have to destroy any of them in the first place. I suspect Alastair's 'oops' was a little inadequate, unless ironic. Still, proud of Tony. There's nothing like a man with the courage to be popular when he knows he's wrong. Oops. WEDNESDAY: The Tories are talking about drafting in Thatcher to 'reunite' the party. Maff is talking about drafting in an expert to 'reunite' 15,000 slaughtered animals with their exploded intestines. And the papers proudly tell me that American researchers have built a 'living robot', a computer connected to the brain of 'an eel-like fish' which somehow knows to always move towards the light, which would at least explain Hague, in Chinese. THURSDAY: Too early, of course, to talk about any kind of reshuffle if we win, but speculation still seems rather rife. Tony, of course, exemplary in his diplomacy: much talk of 'God, no Keith; hope you're feeling better' and 'Superb job, Robin, superb', and 'Lose you? More chance of Man Utd losing in Europe, hahaha!' Oops. FRIDAY: Euan in the doghouse again, but not for the usual reason this time. No, Tony ticked him off over breakfast as Tony was singing our new theme song, which is uplifting in an 'aren't people and life wonderful?' type of pop music way which young people apparently like, and which will accompany the push for our triumphal second term. Euan's comment that he shouldn't give up the day job was unnecessarily cruel and Tony has been sulky, pouty, trembly bottom lippy ever since. Oops. Again.

webTitle: Let's have more passion in politics

fields.headline: Let's have more passion in politics
fields.standfirst: Tactical voting will again keep the Conservatives in their place, but what this country is crying out for is a fairer electoral system
fields.trailText: Tactical voting will again keep the Conservatives in their place, but what this country is crying out for is a fairer electoral system.
fields.body:
During the October 1974 election campaign, I asked Harold Wilson how he would advise people to vote in Tory-held seats where a Liberal was a close second, and Labour a distant third. This was a matter of some importance at the time since a previous election, held only seven months earlier, had resulted in a hung parliament. A single seat could well have made the difference between a Labour and a Tory government. Wilson removed his pipe from his mouth, expelled a cloud of tobacco smoke in my direction, replied: 'Vote Labour' and then clenched his teeth firmly and decisively once more on his pipe.

Tactical voting was not then much talked about. It was the age of conviction politics, or so we thought. You voted for what you believed in. Certainly, I have never been able to vote anything other than Labour - not even for friends standing for the residents' association in local council elections - since I announced to my shocked parents at 18 that I had joined the party. Nor, I imagine, could my parents ever have voted tactically. I was the first of my family in three generations, I was sternly informed, to desert the Conservative Party, though my grandmother was thought once to have voted for Lloyd George on the grounds that he cut a dashing figure.

Now, people are seemingly more sophisticated. I have before me lists of constituencies where tactical voting, or the lack of it compared to 1997, could make a difference; these are to be plotted on a giant map for this week's New Statesman. Billy Bragg, the musician and long-standing Labour supporter, has already informed our readers of his plans to expel the Tories from Dorset. He will cast his vote for the Lib Dems (who are within 2,000 votes of overthrowing the Tory Eurosceptic, Oliver Letwin, in West Dorset) in exchange for a promise from a Lib Dem supporter to vote Labour elsewhere in the county. This swap is to be arranged through Bragg's own internet website, though another site (www.tacticalvoter.com) allows similar deals on a national scale.

All this arouses great excitement among the commentating classes. But does it also represent a great leap in voter sophistication? In one sense, many people have voted tactically for more than half a century. Public approval of Liberal policies and Liberal leaders has usually far exceeded the party's performance in general elections. But, it was said, a vote for the Liberals was a wasted vote. They had no chance of forming a government. So people didn't vote for them. National newspapers have taken a similar view. To recommend a Liberal vote, it was always felt, was to brand the paper as marginal and frivolous. And yet the leader writers very often expressed the view that a large Liberal vote - to come from who knows where - would be a jolly good thing.

Here we get to the nub of the matter, and a point that is not easily understood by political activists. As a rule, people do not vote out of enthusiasm or hope or idealism. Fear, hate and cynicism are greater motivators. They fear governments that will muck things up; they hate those that will interfere with their lives too much; they cynically believe that all politicians are much the same. They do not vote for politicians they admire, but against those they fear or despise most. Whatever their leaders may have said, the masses never believed that democracy offered the chance of Utopia. The vote was simply a means of controlling the worst excesses of the ruling class. That is why the most ambitiously idealistic regimes found it necessary to abolish voting.

Tactical voting, therefore, is neither more nor less sophisticated than abstention. Indeed, the two go hand in hand. They are merely alternative ways of putting arrogant politicians in their place. In 1997, many people voted tactically, not because they were enthused by New Labour, but because they wanted to humiliate the Tories. This time, I suspect, many of the same people will abstain. Note that, despite all the excitement created by Ken Livingstone in London last year (a clear protest against the established parties), his vote was far exceeded by the numbers who didn't vote at all.

All this strengthens the argument for some form of proportional representation. The objection to PR is that it turns politics into a matter of backroom deals, horse trading and cold calculation. That may be true for the politicians who, faced with permanently hung parliaments, have to negotiate with each other in order to form stable governments with agreed programmes. But PR allows the voters to follow their passions and beliefs, in the knowledge that their vote will still count in some way. It can pro vide a far more accurate snapshot of public opinion than any number of focus groups or polls.

No system is perfect. In Australia, minority parties (of which there may be as many as 20 or 30 on the ballot papers) routinely advise their supporters on how to use their second and third preferences. Smart operators in the big parties invent 'dummy parties' to scoop up support from people who might otherwise vote for the opposition or not at all. Suppose Labour wants to get votes from the dopeheads and the pensioners. It finds somebody willing to stand under the banner of a Legalise Marijuana Party and somebody else willing to stand as a Senior Citizens Party candidate. These 'parties', which are likely to be eliminated fairly quickly, then advise their supporters to cast their second preference votes for Labour.

It is all utterly cynical, but at least the cynicism is reserved to the political class, where it belongs. Ordinary voters rarely feel passionately about the ragbag programmes of the established parties, with all their fudges and compromises. They feel passionately about single issues: animal rights, the pound, nuclear power, the countryside and so on, as well as drugs and pensioners. Our system gives them no vehicle to express such passions without 'wasting' their votes. A good PR system would allow people to vote for what they really believe while still, through second or third preferences, casting a 'serious' vote for a future government. There is then no need for tactical voting; we leave the tactics to the politicians, who are the experts.

That still leave us with the problem of what to do in the forthcoming election under an unreformed, first-past-the-post system. As it happens, I live in a Tory seat where Labour comes a not very close second, so I have no dilemma. But would I vote tactically? Isn't the Tory party weak enough as it is, without us trying to expel it even from strongholds like West Dorset or Michael Howard's Folkestone and Hythe? If all Labour and Lib Dem supporters followed Billy Bragg's example, there would hardly be a Tory MP left in the House of Commons.

I have two answers to that. One is that it is worth voting tactically to persuade the Tories that they have no future under William Hague, and they need to change radically if they are to form an effective opposition. The other is that the Lib Dems, in any case, would make a better opposition than the Tories.

So for now, tactical voting it is. But I'd still rather express my passions for, oh, I don't know, the Ban All Motorcars From Anywhere Near Me Party or the No Music in Restaurants Party, under a better electoral system.

Peter Wilby is editor of the New Statesman

webTitle: Pendennis

fields.headline: Pendennis
fields.trailText: Keeping it in the family
fields.body:
Keeping it in the family

Hillary Clinton is diligently serving as a US senator. And Bill, with new offices in Harlem, is planning his presidential library. But what of Chelsea, their patient daughter who recently returned to Stanford University after a year on the campaign trail? 'Chelsea will finish her history studies,' reveals an old family acquaintance visiting Britain for a spring break. 'But people shouldn't assume she'll disappear. She has very, very strong principles. She could be on her own campaign trail sooner than you expect.' Chelsea is just 21. But that's exactly the same age, of course, at which Patrick Kennedy, son of Edward, was first elected to the Rhode Island House of Representatives in 1988.

At last, a ray of good news for the Tories. Labour apparatchik Amanda Delew, known to friends as 'Miss Cashpoint' and to detractors as 'Deloot', is to quit her job just after polling day. As head of major donors for Labour, she has helped secure million-pound donations from a string of benefactors like Lord Ondaatje and Chris Evans. She also organised the most expensive cheese and wine party in British history, when guests were asked by Peter Mandelson not to leave without giving £25,000. 'Amanda's tired of having her efforts to schmooze revealed publicly,' confides a devastated party admirer. 'And she hates finding her every thought leaked to the press.'

For years, countryside campaigners have insisted that hunting with hounds was an 'essential' method of culling foxes. Thanks to foot and mouth, hunting has now been suspended for exactly two months. So presumably picturesque rural areas up and down Britain are already infested with bushy-tailed predators. Do let us know if you see one.

How touching to hear Mr Andrew Lansley, the shadow Cabinet Office Minister, complain last week that Robin Cook was playing the race card. It must be a different Mr Andrew Lansley altogether who composed a valedictory report upon resigning as Tory research director in September 1995. That Mr Lansley wrote: 'Immigration, an issue we raised successfully in 1992 and again in the 1994 Euro-elections, played particularly well in the tabloids and has more potential to hurt.'

Renee Zellweger teases that she won't star again in a sequel to Bridget Jones's Diary , the vvg new British film. It's not the only challenge facing producers. Haven't they noticed that in the already-published sequel, The Edge of Reason, Bridget goes to interview film star Colin Firth? But Mr Firth, who made his name so memorably in wet breeches as a Jane Austen heroine, is already playing Bridget's boyfriend in the newly-released film.

 Ambasadoral chic once involved the serving of Ferrero Rocher chocolates. But the Diplomatic Corps is much more hip now. My man who passed through the bedroom of 56-year-old Gavin Hewitt, Britain's ambassador to Brussels, the other day - don't ask, just don't - reports that nestling on the ambassadorial bedside table was a copy of The Edge of Reason .

Squeaky-voiced Tory John Selwyn Gummer has bravely entered the race row too. Is it time for a re-issue of his unforgettable 1966 pamphlet When The Coloured People Come ?

Fifteen years ago, 'refuseniks' at the Times resisted plans to move to Wapping in east London. Now News International, owner of the Times and its sister papers the Sun and the News of the World, has secret plans to de-camp again, crossing the Thames to Deptford. Over the years, legions of News International journalists have been happy to help crush the print unions, entrap the Countess of Wessex - among others - and make up, or trim, stories to order. But this may be the last straw. Why? 'Deptford,' quivers a horrified Times scribbler after we break the news, 'is south of the river.'

webTitle: Blair's big error, by Bush's guru

fields.headline: Blair's big error, by Bush's guru
fields.standfirst:
Britain is ditching traditional culture for meaningless multi-racial policy, claims presidential adviser

Telling the poor to shape up
fields.trailText: President Bush's leading social policy guru has launched a swingeing attack on Blair's Britain, warning that the Government is dismantling British culture in the name of fuzzy multiculturalism.
fields.body:
President Bush's leading social policy guru has launched a swingeing attack on Blair's Britain, warning that the Government is dismantling British culture in the name of fuzzy multiculturalism.

Myron Magnet, a political theorist whose book The Dream and the Nightmare Bush calls the most influential he's read other than the Bible, told The Observer that Britain is making the same errors in the name of social progress that have proved so damaging in America.

'You are making all the mistakes we made for the same reasons with the same disastrous effects,' he said. 'It's terrible to watch the whole old culture being dismantled in the name of some fuzzy multicultural ideal that doesn't mean anything.'

Magnet, 56, provided what Bush's political strategist, Karl Rove, calls a 'road map' to the president's attitudes on the role of government.

His views on family, welfare, racial equality and minority policing have become a mantra for conservatives on both sides of the Atlantic, particularly as they now guide the hands that steer the world's largest social experiment - the United States - and as debate over the shape and contours of a multi-cultural Britain become an election issue.

The mistakes made in America and now in Britain, he says, stem from wishing to see social policy through the prism of politically correct racial equality rather than tradition. 'We have assumed that because we seek racial justice we have to junk all of the traditional values of our culture.

'But as soon as you say all things that amount to British culture are oppressive, racist and old-fashioned, and are standing in the way of progress, you end up with a culture that doesn't know what it believes in.'

The guiding light of compassionate conservatism, Magnet edits the City Jour nal , the provocative urban policy magazine of the neoconservative Manhattan Institute. He says the wholesale destruction of tradition, from the House of Lords to hunting with hounds, in the name of Modern Britain is a dangerous act of cultural vandalism with potentially disastrous consequences.

'This is a huge mistake. You're losing your identity but not by some natural progression. People are doing this with a whole agenda in mind - to make England amenable to foreigners and to not impose national values on them. But they came to England because it had created a successful culture and economy and the principles that made this success should be preserved.'

Magnet predicts that hyper-race consciousness in England will prove a disaster and calls the recommendations of the Macpherson Report a recipe for soaring crime. Making police vulnerable to accusations of racism distracts them from concentrating effort where crime is.

'It drives a New Yorker crazy to see you decriminalising crime in the name of social justice. In America, we decided we would avoid racial incidents by not policing the ghettos. The result was that the ghettos turned into anarchies. So to make racial sensitivity a priority will mean, as it meant here, that crime will explode and will be catastrophic to poor, inner city communities.'

Magnet warns that treating one-parent families the same as two-parent families has caused a generation of children to fail. 'It's an enormous mistake to believe that all happy families are the same.'

He says that creeping multi-culturalism is a dangerous road to take. 'We live in a secular age, so how do we know what's the right kind of life? We know from Jane Austen what it is to have good manners, we know from Sophocles what it is to have free will, we know from Plato what justice is.

'But one of the great projects of multi-culturalism is to say that the whole accumulation of western culture, the repository of our values over a thousand years, is illegitimate because it is oppressive and patriarchal.

'People do not want to be challenged on their behaviour and told they are wrong. But the authority to do that is enshrined in the great works of literature.'

webTitle: Protesters march to halt mass slaughter

fields.headline: Protesters march to halt mass slaughter
fields.standfirst:
Special report: foot and mouth disease

Foot and mouth virus spreads to wild deer
fields.trailText: Protests against the mass slaughter policy for foot and mouth disease erupted in London, Gloucester and the Netherlands yesterday.
fields.body:
Protests against the mass slaughter policy for foot and mouth disease erupted in London, Gloucester and the Netherlands yesterday.

Actress Joanna Lumley told a crowd of several hundred animal rights protesters outside Downing Street that the public had been misled over the possibilities for halting the outbreak. The Absolutely Fabulous star demanded an immediate end of the mass slaughter policy, which has led to the culling of almost a million and a half animals, and a start to vaccination. The Government last week agreed that vaccination was the best option but refrained from introducing it because of opposition from the National Farmers' Union.

webTitle: When politics and race collide

fields.headline: When politics and race collide
fields.standfirst: Chicken tikka time bomb
fields.trailText: 1964: Labour's defeat at Smethwick
fields.body:
1964: Labour's defeat at Smethwick

Shadow Foreign Secretary Patrick Gordon Walker lost his seat to Tory candidate Peter Griffiths, in a campaign that allegedly featured the slogan 'If you want a nigger neighbour, vote Liberal or Labour'. Harold Wilson described the victor as a 'parliamentary leper' because of the ugliness of the campaign.

20 April 1968: Enoch Powell's 'rivers of blood' speech

Powell, then Opposition defence spokesman, urged a virtual end to black and Commonwealth immigration and voluntary assisted repatriation, adding that 'like the Roman, I seem to see "the river Tiber flowing with much blood".' He was sacked by Tory leader Edward Heath: but the Daily Telegraph complained that he had merely been 'expressing anxieties felt by millions of people', and dockers marched in his defence.

December 1990: John Taylor stands in Cheltenham

Black barrister John Taylor, selected as Tory candidate for a safe seat, was promptly described as a 'bloody nigger' by local party member Bill Galbraith and faced a vote of no confidence. Taylor lost the seat: the ugly row prompted Tory reforms to encourage ethnic minority members. Taylor has since been made a life peer.

April 1990: Norman Tebbit's 'cricket test'

The Tory MP told the Los Angeles Times it would be 'an interesting test' to see how many British Asian immigrants cheered on the teams of their country of origin rather than England at cricket. The inference of disloyalty enraged the Asian community.

September 1993: British National Party wins London council seat

Labour blamed allegedly racist Liberal Democrat leaflets for the narrow by-election victory by Derek Beackon of the BNP, which appalled politicians and was condemned by the Archbishop of Canterbury. The BNP lost the Tower Hamlets seat five months later.

webTitle: Foot and mouth virus spreads to wild deer

fields.headline: Foot and mouth virus spreads to wild deer
fields.standfirst:
Protesters march to halt mass slaughter

Special report: foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: The foot and mouth virus has passed into Britain's wild deer population, making the Government's policy of mass slaughter of farmyard livestock futile.
fields.body:
The foot and mouth virus has passed into Britain's wild deer population, making the Government's policy of mass slaughter of farmyard livestock futile.

There have been several cases of vets clinically identifying the disease in wild deer, some of which have died from it. There have also been many reports from Devon, Cumbria and Northumberland of deer limping and exhibiting other unusual behaviour linked to the disease.

Veterinary experts say it is impossible to vaccinate or cull wild deer and once infected they will act as a reservoir for the virus, repeatedly re-infecting livestock. It will make it almost imposs-ible for Britain to rid itself of the virus, until it dies out naturally in wild deer, which could take years.

Last week a roe deer was found dead at Kirk House Farm near Penrith, which had already been confirmed as having foot and mouth in livestock. Local vet Matt Coulston, of Frame Swift and Partners, identified lesions on all four feet and in its mouth. 'It had signs consistent with foot and mouth disease,' he told The Observer. 'There have been loads of people round here reporting dead deer and sick deer. People suspect that Maff [the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food] are ignoring it because it is difficult to deal with.'

The British Deer Society has been flooded with reports from deer experts reporting the animals limping and being covered with lumps. Mike Squire, secretary of the society, said: 'We find it difficult to believe that deer exposed to the same pastures as infected cattle and sheep have not been exposed to foot and mouth disease.'

A Maff spokesman said yesterday that government vets had tested nine deer for foot and mouth and none had been found positive: 'So far there have been no confirmed cases of foot and mouth in deer.'

However, the Maff vets use the Elisa test, which was developed on cattle and sheep and is not thought to be so effective on deer. Research from Russia also suggests it is very difficult to test whether deer have been infected with foot and mouth from blood samples.

In 1974 the government Animal Health Institute in Pirbright kept a number of deer in proximity to sheep with foot and mouth for two hours in a controlled experiment. The scientists found all six native species of deer contracted the disease, and several died.

In an outbreak of foot and mouth in California in 1924, the outbreak spread rapidly to deer. Slaughtermen culled 22,000 deer in the Stanislav National Park and found that, of those, 2,279 were infected.

Dr John Fletcher, past president of the Veterinary Deer Society, said: 'It's highly likely the virus has entered the wild deer population - the deer are in abundance and graze in close contact with sheep and cattle. Nothing has been confirmed, but there is an abundance of anecdotal evidence, and it would be quite surprising if it hasn't entered the population.'

Simon Booth, director of the Deer Inititiative, the government advisory body on deer in England, said: 'There have been unconfirmed cases of it appearing in deer.'

Deer experts have been calling on Maff for weeks to conduct a selective deer cull to ascertain the extent of the disease and to draw up contingency plans. However, Maff ignored their warnings until it called an emergency meeting on Friday. It is now considering lifting the ban on deer-stalking to provide the carcasses for tests.

The existence of the disease in Britain's 1.5 million wild deer population means the policy of mass slaughter of more than a million farm animals and the closure of most of the British countryside has been pointless. Wild deer are so evasive and diffi cult to track down that it is impossible to vaccinate or cull them. Shooting at herds of deer will simply cause them to run, spreading the disease further.

The deer population will harbour the disease before building up resistance and it eventually dies out. This could take years. Until then the deer will repeatedly re-infect livestock and, with the disease endemic in Britain, meat exports will continue to be banned.

Squire said: 'We're looking at a huge slaughter and cost to the taxpayer for no purpose. How do you think the public will react when they know that?'

Booth said: 'If it's in the deer population, it will mean the mass slaughter policy will not work.' Confirm-ation of foot and mouth among deer will force the Government to abandon the mass slaughter programme, a move that has been steadfastly resisted by the National Union of Farmers. 'It will force their hand into vaccination,' said Fletcher.

webTitle: Young to face impact of their crimes

fields.headline: Young to face impact of their crimes
fields.trailText: Young offenders will be forced to carry out hard work for their communities in a shake-up of the youth justice system to be unveiled by Tony Blair this week.
fields.body:
Young offenders will be forced to carry out hard work for their communities in a shake-up of the youth justice system to be unveiled by Tony Blair this week.

Teenagers will be forced to clean up graffiti, clear streets of litter or repair vandalised buildings under the 'community payback' scheme to make them realise the social consequences of what many consider victimless crimes.

Ministers have been privately worried by the failure of some of the so-called Youth Offending Teams, set up two years ago to devise methods of so-called 'restorative justice', to make much impact.

The first inspection into two of the teams is understood to have uncovered poor performance. Downing Street admitted yesterday there was 'patchiness' in the results.

'Young offenders take something out of society through their offending and we will make sure they put something back,' Blair will tell an audience of local government leaders in London.

'Central government's role is to give local people and local government the freedoms and support it needs to tackle these issues.'

Many of the Youth Offending Team schemes, rolled out nationwide last year, have concentrated on making offenders write letters or personally apologise to victims.

But Blair wants to extend the idea to crimes where there is no obvious victim but the community is affected, such as vandalism. Although the teams already have such powers, many are not using them.

Under so-called referral orders, young offenders are sent by the courts to one of 154 local panels, which can include police, teachers, social and health workers as well as members of the local community. Victims can also attend to explain the impact on their feelings.

The panels discuss the reasons for offending and recommend how reparation should be made. Reparation orders are backed by the threat of a return to court if the offender refuses to co-operate.

A report on the pilot schemes from the University of Sheffield last year found relations between courts and the referral panels were sometimes strained. Some teams reported victims had 'very little interest' in offers of reparation. It also raised doubts about the appropriateness of reparation for some offences, such as possession of soft drugs or driving offences.

Downing Street was last night unable to say how many referral or reparation orders had been issued since pilots for the scheme began in 1999.

The announcement will be part of a speech on how Labour would tackle issues such as safety on the streets and inner city regeneration if it won a second term.

webTitle: Big Apple's taste of Big John

fields.headline: Big Apple's taste of Big John
fields.standfirst:
Ed Vulliamy joins Prescott on the subway to hear his views on Kyoto, the Tube - and Miles Davis

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Ed Vulliamy joins Prescott on the subway to hear his views on Kyoto, the Tube - and Miles Davis.
fields.body:
First he took Manhattan, then he took the subway. John Prescott descended into the nether world of the 'R' line at 60th and Third Avenue, beneath a huge Union Jack hanging from the back of Bloomingdales.

It was a short ride, but enough to convince him that 'if this is what we're upgrading to, God help us. They've improved it enormously from what it was 20 years ago when every train was covered with graffiti. But ours is faster, cleaner, quieter and the seats are more comfortable'.

Prescott shouted above the rattle and hum, and banged a hard plastic seat to prove his point. His view of the superiority of London's underground may be heresy against the received wisdom and that of Messrs Kiley and Livingstone, but Prescott had the good fortune to encounter passenger Mihai Martin, who had been to London and thinks 'it's better over there; I like it when they say "Mind the Gap"'.

This was the big man's big day in the Big Apple. Apart from defending the Tube, he was in town to defend the science behind the Kyoto accord on global warming. At a meeting on the environment he told his American counterpart that it was 'reasonable to negotiate Kyoto, but to reject it outright would throw away ten years of negotiation,' following President Bush's decision to renege on the treaty.

The indefatigable Prescott was still going at one o'clock yesterday morning, listening intently, eyes closed and tapping his fingers on a tabletop at the Sweet Basil jazz club in Greenwich Village as The Frank Lacy Experience - starring Art Blakey's trombonist - added an extra composition to their late-night set.

Resurfacing from the subway into the bustle of Third Avenue, Prescott threw down his gauntlet at Mayor Ken Livingstone and Bob Kiley, his transport commissioner. 'I say our system is better. The safety record is better, the trains are better, we have information boards on every platform so you know how long your train is going to be - here you're left hoping it'll come.

'Yes, Kiley lifted this system and we want him to lift ours. But it's incomparable.' He said New Yorkers paid for improvements with community tax and car tax. 'Do Londoners want those increases? Or do they want an injection of cash from the national treasury in partnership with the private sector?'

In front of Prescott's car is a white stretch limousine. 'I presume that's ours,' he cracks, 'saw one yesterday had a Jacuzzi in the back.' Sitting up front in a more modest town car, weaving through the Midtown gridlock, the 'DPM' (as they call him) returns to the reason he is here: a UN summit on sustainable development and with it, inevitably, Kyoto.

In Washington earlier in the week Prescott had been under pressure to browbeat Bush over his decision to effectively kill the treaty.

Instead, Prescott chose the UN forum to insist that whatever the fate of the agreement, 'the scientific message is clear and accepted'.

He insisted in his speech that 'sustainable development is about economic growth and social justice, as well as about the environment', and now, in the car, Prescott adds: 'Kyoto is just a place in Japan. The Americans do not dispute the science, we have the summit in Bonn in July and we will keep talking. We don't expect the Americans to dictate to us.'

Prescott is convinced that 'even President Bush was surprised by the strength of reaction. Business is changing its mind about things; the public associates climate change with the real world around them - Mississippi flooding on TV this week - there's a general feeling this is serious'.

Britain's 'special relationship' with Washington is now a highwire the Government must walk between Bush's conservatism and ideological kinship with the likes of Gerhardt Schroeder and Lionel Jospin. Prescott thinks the tightrope-walk is manageable.

'The relationship with America is there for historical reasons - it's in the psyche of our country, this alliance Westward. As for the Europeans, well, we fought most of them!

'When I went to lead the European group, I thought hey, we can all be socialists together. But you find all kinds of surprises when it comes to the national interest - they always put that first, only rarely the European interest.'Our appointment with America was long and close during the Clinton administration but that doesn't mean we can't have a close relationship between Tony Blair and President Bush.'

On the other hand: 'I'm a strong European and Tony is a strong European. We are not America's negotiator in Europe.'

Prescott clearly dislikes his caricature as some Britannic incarnation of Jimmy Hoffa. 'I was always put down as the old union thug. But actually I don't think a political meeting can be a glass of water and three people.'

Also: 'I was arguing for one-member-one-vote in the unions before they'd even heard of it, or when they were still lecturers at university. And I'd also like to point out that I was talking about private-public partnership when we were still in opposition.'

Prescott is clear that whatever the rumours, he would stay on in his job as 'DPM' if offered after 7 June.

No zimmer frame yet. It's approaching one o'clock and 63-year-old Prescott has changed from his suit into an open rose-coloured shirt and jeans, hanging loose at Sweet Basil with a small entourage and a mountainous plate of fries.

No booze, no cigarettes. On stage is Frank Lacy, with haunted eyes, dreadlocks and a rather Prescottian style, actually: loud, passionate and, not infrequently, funny.

Prescott laughs and closes his eyes to listen, a transported half-smile on his face. When the band finally finishes and everyone else is ready to hit the sack, Prescott can't resist the chance to linger and talk about something other than global warming and subways.

Like seeing Louis Armstrong as a young man - 'and Miles Davis at the Apollo in Harlem, playing with his back to the audience, arrogant bastard!'. And that favourite song: 'I never got it at first, by Billie Holliday, "Strange Fruit". Know what? It's about black people hanging from trees. Amazing.'
