webTitle: Volatile chef hits out at 'smarmy' PM

fields.headline: Volatile chef hits out at 'smarmy' PM
fields.standfirst:
Marco Pierre White interview:
observer.co.uk/foodmonthly
fields.trailText: Marco Pierre White, who is as famous for his raging tantrums, womanising and celebrity bust-ups as for his cooking, has dismissed Tony Blair as 'a smarmy bastard'.
fields.body:
Marco Pierre White, who is as famous for his raging tantrums, womanising and celebrity bust-ups as for his cooking, has dismissed Tony Blair as 'a smarmy bastard'.

In an exclusive interview with Observer Food Monthly, The Observer's new magazine devoted to what we eat and drink, which is published for the first time today, Britain's best-known chef, declares he is a socialist who loathes New Labour. 'I just can't stand Tony Blair,' he says, adding that the Prime Minister is a 'smarmy bastard'.

However, White says he admires Blair's rival, the Chancellor, and says that he is welcome to eat at any of the chef's Michelin-starred restaurants. 'Gordon Brown can come and have a meal. He's a proper man, and at least he seems to believe in something.'

In the interview, White who turns 40 this year and was married recently, talks frankly about his rows with rival chefs, his staff, his customers - and the women in his life - which have made him Britain's most notorious restaurateur. He blames his tantrums on his obsessive desire for perfection.

'Of course I was a shit in those days. I was terrible. I didn't like myself. No one could but there were reasons for it. Firstly, I wanted that Michelin star so much. The Michelin star was all I could think of.

'So I became totally driven, totally critical of myself, wanting every dish to be three-star and that changes you, and changes the way you behave to people. Working that hard, in that heat, those hours. I was going for perfection... So I shouted. And I got my stars.'

Asked why he threw diners out of his restaurants, he said: 'There was always a reason. I was trying to create something special, and they were trying to spoil it.'

White dismisses much of Britain's recent 'food revolution' as nonsense. 'Cuisine Nouvelle was just a concept, and one which, crucially, the English managed to get wrong. I mean, if you run a restaurant you've got to feed people, not make pretty little pictures on plates to make up for your lack of ability.'

He bitterly criticises the spread of restaurant chains across the high streets. 'I massively object to your Café Rouge, and Café Flo, and Chez Gerard. I mean, they're appalling. They're an insult to all of us - because they're run by accountants, not restaurateurs.'

webTitle: Minister heads off new exam disaster

fields.headline: Minister heads off new exam disaster
fields.standfirst: Special report: Scottish parliament
fields.trailText: Jack McConnell, the Scottish Education Minister, has named the man chosen to help the Scottish Qualifications Authority avoid a repeat of last year's exams fiasco.
fields.body:
Jack McConnell, the Scottish Education Minister, has named the man chosen to help the Scottish Qualifications Authority avoid a repeat of last year's exams fiasco.

Leading civil servant Colin McLean, a former chief statistician in the Scottish Office Education Department, has been seconded to take up the position of national exams co-ordinator. A source close to the Scottish Executive said: 'Mr McLean will effectively be the Education Minister's eyes and ears at the SQA.'

The main objective for the 'exams tsar' will be to help SQA, schools and colleges, education authorities and other organisations work together to ensure successful delivery of this year's Highers and Standard Grades, which begin in just two weeks.

The move is an attempt to make sure that the system's various parts work in concert and avoid the failure of last year, when 17,000 candidates were left with inaccurate, late or incomplete results. The then Education Minister, Sam Galbraith, was accused of being too far removed from the process and McConnell is clearly moving to avoid such accusations.

McLean was himself a maths teacher in Edinburgh from 1973-79 and has had two spells at the education inspectorate. Since July 2000 he has been closely involved in working with the SQA to ensure the completion of last year's exams and successful delivery of the 2001 diet. It has been stressed that effective lines of communication must be kept open with candidates.

Joining McLean will be Brian Naylor, currently director of properties in care at Historic Scotland. In 1993 he set up the Scottish Office Private Finance Unit before taking up his present post.

webTitle: Leader: Prejudice has no place in politics

fields.headline: Prejudice has no place in politics
fields.standfirst: The Tories are a disgrace on race
fields.trailText: The Conservatives may have betrayed their prejudice last week, but we await convincing evidence that life can be better in Labour's multicultural Britain.
fields.body:
The last week has provided the sharpest of retorts to voters who claim thoughtlessly that there is no difference between the Labour and Conservative parties. The sight of some Tories celebrating their refusal to endorse racial harmony during an election campaign serves as a tart reminder that the argument over Britain's role as a multicultural nation is still not won.

Some Conservatives claim that the disputed Commission for Racial Equality declaration on political campaigning inhibits them from discussing asylum or immigration at all. Untrue. It merely asks them not to use 'words or actions' which might 'stir up racial or religious hatred'. And our report today - revealing that police now recognise that inflammatory political rhetoric appears to encourage race attacks - undermines the notion that this initiative is of no substantive importance, even if the totemic act of signing a declaration is not a substitute for action.

No one should be condemned just for declining to sign a piece of paper. But the prevarications of Conservative MPs, and their party's refusal to remove the whip from John Townend for his recent repulsive comments on immigration, confirm a residual willingness to allow race to be exploited for electoral purposes. Above all, this furnishes evidence that the Conservative Party remains unfit for government. A preparedness to alienate swathes of our nation's population for electoral gain betokens a party unwilling to govern for all. And also, in an irrevocably global economy, a willingness to alienate powerful business communities both here and overseas - particularly when you already wish to turn your back on Europe - betrays the naïve introspection of politicians who should not be entrusted with our national economic wellbeing. Thankfully, we believe that in 2001 far more voters will recoil from such opportunism than will ever be attracted by it.

However, the offensiveness of the Tory approach to race should not provide too much succour to New Labour. A political curiosity of the last four years has been Ministers' preparedness to take admirable electoral risks by endorsing racial equality, while delivering pitifully little - a failing mirrored almost exactly in their approach to gay equality. Government, and the Labour Party itself, still employ far too few staff from minority ethnic groups in senior positions. The Labour Party, as we also report today, has failed to secure parliamentary nominations in safe seats for black and Asian candidates. Two years after the Lawrence Inquiry, the Home Office is pitifully failing to reach its own police recruitment targets. And tougher sentences for racially motivated crimes remain academic while tens of thousands of victims are still fearful of reporting that crime to police in the first place.

The Conservatives may have betrayed their prejudice last week, but we await convincing evidence that life can be better in Labour's multicultural Britain.

webTitle: Another fine massala

fields.headline: Another fine massala
fields.standfirst: Labour is right to condemn the Tories over race. However, its own track record doesn't bear close scrutiny
fields.trailText: Labour is right to condemn the Tories over race. However, its own track record doesn't bear close scrutiny.
fields.body:
Robin cook likes a curry. I remember sitting opposite him in the Foreign Office canteen one lunchtime, watching him demolish a pile of tweed-coloured slurry draped over a gaudy heap of pilau rice. Personal preference may have informed his decision to spurn the Chinese takeaway (its image dented by foot and mouth) or the doner kebab (never a winner with the River Cafe set) and single out, during his speech to the Social Market Foundation, chicken tikka massala as a 'true British national dish'. How right Mr Cook is. There is something quintessentially British about the diner who piles out of the pub, 10 pints of lager to the wind, in search of an Indian meal to fortify him against a night of aggro.

Nothing conjures up some aspects of our national culture more effectively than tanked-up, Union Jack-flapping soccer fans belting out the 1998 World Cup anthem of 'Vindaloo'. Even at the genteel end of the market, the flock wallpaper and acid lighting of the average high-street Indian takeaway evoke exhausting hours and low pay for its staff rather than get-ahead vibrancy. Cook might have been on safer ground if he had stipulated stuffed crust pizza or pot noodles as our culinary emblem of multiculturalism.

Alternatively, he could have recalled that politicians seeking to unfurl a vision of a certain type of Britain rarely sound convincing, whether their theme is cricket on the village green and spinsters cycling to Communion or an ode to an onion bhaji. Still, in some ways, the Baldwin of Brick Lane was successful. Given the febrile mood of the Opposition, all antidotes to racism are welcome. As a bonus, Cook's catchy way into the race debate provoked predictable and gravy-curdling wrath from beef Wellington fans incensed by his statement that there was no such thing as an 'ethnically pure' British race.

Smoking out racism, in the Tory party and its supporters, would be more rewarding, but for the fact that the cheerleaders for Anglo-Saxon purity are so pathetic. John Townend was unknown before his recent anti-immigrant speech. Sir Richard Body, author of the xenophobically titled book, England For the English , exudes as much Powellite menace as Peter Rabbit. James Cran and Eric Forth, opponents of the Commission for Racial Equality's code of electoral conduct, hardly add up to Jorg Haider and Jean-Marie Le Pen. Michael Portillo, the most senior non-signatory, is not a racist but a tactically- brilliant Judas whose gesture will endear him to all those Tories who cannot decide whether William Hague or the bossy CRE appals them more.

Hague is not a racist either. He is something almost worse, an opportunist who decided that it would be useful to mimic one. Hence his 'foreign land' speech, his authorisation of a leaflet on 'bogus asylum-seekers' and his swipe against the Macpherson Report. Some time ago, Andrew Lansley, the former Tory election strategist, told this newspaper that 'immigration played particularly well in the tabloids in the 1992 general election' and 'has more potential to hurt'. Now the pain is all Hague's. His attempt to be both asylum-seekers' scourge and immigrants' champion looks as fake as Lansley's assertion that his leader never played the race card.

Of course he did, but so has Cook; not through his message but by his omissions. In particular, his cosy, curry-house scenario seemed oddly pitched in the week when white and Asian communities in the north of England went to war. Whatever racial unrest exists in Britain today is less a product of Tory rants than of the reality of life in Britain under a Labour administration which, as the Foreign Secretary did not say, has too often been a poor deliverer on issues involving race. Foot-dragging over the promised review of the iniquitous voucher scheme for asylum-seekers continues. The wider policy shambles has prompted the Council of Europe to castigate Britain for its treatment of migrants. While Hague might have been even harsher, the measure must be outcome, not intent.

Cook, like all his senior colleagues, is a committed anti-racist. Personal credo does not, however, entitle him or any of them to paint a vista of a wish-list Utopia and pass it off as the real thing. Modern Britain, however tolerant and well-integrated, is far from a frictionless haven. As Ofsted discovered last year, the failure gap between Afro-Caribbean and Pakistani pupils and their white counterparts is nearly double that of a decade ago. Students from ethnic minorities have a much lower chance of getting a job than white graduates. In one recent week on BBC2, the only non-white faces in the channel's top 10 programmes (combined viewing figures of 33 million) were those of cartoon characters in The Simpsons. While government cannot be held responsible for who joins Charlie Dimmock on Ground Force , there is, in areas it can influence, too great a mismatch between rhetoric and results.

Despite the eagerness by Jack Straw and the Metropolitan police commissioner to apply the findings of Sir William Macpherson, old tensions reappear as the second anniversary of the report approaches. In Bradford last week, a fight at a Hindu wedding erupted into a car-burning, window-smashing, battle between white and Asian youths which echoed the devastating 1995 riot. In Oldham, the tribal battles between young Bangladeshi and Pakistani men have mutated into a new delineation of aggression. According to police, more than half of the 572 racist attacks recorded in the town during the last year have been against whites. However the battle lines are drawn, the causes remain a constant dirge of unemployment, overcrowding and bleak futures.

An exponential rise in the nationwide reporting of racist crime, up by 107 per cent over 12 months, no longer looks like Macpherson-inspired openness. It looks like more racist crime. That is not to criticise Sir William or those who seek to implement his recommendations. It is to say that there is a vast, unbridged gulf between semantics and solutions.

Presentationally the Government (asylum-seekers apart) has been a model of correctness, but signatures on CRE declarations and benedictions to Macpherson are the easy bits. They are also camouflage on the uncomfortable reality that, at a time when racial harmony is lauded and the economy is strong, too little has been achieved.

The conditions that create inner-city brawlers and school failures are also the complex issues of economic and social polarisation that fail to interest the Tories. The measure of their cynicism is that both Hague and Portillo have now, in different ways, mortgaged race issues to personal ambition.

As for the Government, Robin Cook's vision of a multicultural nation sitting down to break poppadoms together does not quite reflect a landscape in which teachers, police officers, politicians and the judiciary remain disproportionately white.

A Conservative Party that shows no sign of being in a position to ensure that such unfairness prevails looks less worrying than the prospect of a second-term government failing to alchemise its wishes on racial equality into results. Squandered influence is always more dangerous than none.

webTitle: Euan Ferguson meets Tony Booth

fields.headline: One Tony who can't be phoney
fields.trailText: Gone are the simple days of 1992 when Tony Booth, father-in-law to the next but one leader of the Labour Party, had little reason to hold back and fought with righteous anger.
fields.body:
He'll campaign again this year, of course, if we stop shooting things long enough to meander in for the least surprising election result since the days of Enver Hoxha, but he'll be doing so with a new diffidence. Gone are the simple days of 1992 when Tony Booth, father-in-law to the next but one leader of the Labour Party, had little reason to hold back and fought with righteous anger. Days when he told the party leadership, as he recalls now, with a wheezily infectious laugh, that Thatcher should be first against the wall.

'Well, no, not quite,' he guffaws again, eyes vanishing into the folds of a life roundly lived, 'but I did tell them that what we must do, if we won, was take back all the privatised utilities at the same knock-down prices they were sold off by the Tories. It was a bloody crime. And then, I said, we should take Thatcher to court for what she'd done.'

Fine, I say, gazing levelly back through the chopsticks of Manchester's Chinatown; and what was the precise problem with that? No punishment quite meet enough, I supposed; but no, his raised eyebrows and his silence tell me, I'm missing the point. Which is simple: this was 10 years ago.

1992. Before Tony Blair, married to Booth's daughter Cherie, swooned into power, declared that the battle between Right and Left was dead, and within that very first week invited the same Margaret Thatcher for tea, a fact of which I now remind the other Tony in order to make him choke on his dim sum. He copes admirably. A nervous swallow, and then, 'Yes, yes, he did, didn't he? Hmmm. I suppose he was trying to be conciliatory. It, um, it didn't quite come off, did it?'

1992. Before Booth had met Stephenie, his fourth wife, a mid-40s charmer who obviously adores the old roué and is now sitting at the same table and nudging him, openly elbowing, chopsticking him, to stop him saying something he shouldn't. 1992. Before Booth, with his hell-raising past of 'crumpeteering' and booze and bolting from women became a semi-legitimate target for the Daily Mail and its familiars, keen to pounce on any indiscretions likely to embarrass New Labour.

So most mention of belief, principle, radicalism and the like is out of the question. It's not that he doesn't feel these things; it's just that he can't say them for fear of the press; I'm not sure whether this is a sadder indictment of the press or his party. But conscious of it all he undoubtedly is; a few days before he had written a diary for the New Statesman in which he ventured the opinion that some of our royals are thick and greedy. This 'crass behaviour' (© Simon Heffer) had, the Mail went on to shriek, 'plunged into embarrassment' Tony Blair. Booth shakes his head. 'I know, I know. I don't get it either. Ageing socialist.' He turns to Stephenie in mock dismay: 'Oops, I've said the S-word!

'Ageing socialist says he's not completely in love with the British monarchy shock! Of course they should be abolished. And the logical next step is the abolition of the House of Lords. But you even think about saying these things now, because of how everything is played.' Stephenie shushes him, wondering if he's said too much.

That he buttons his lip these days is not because he's leant on by the party, he insists; and I tend to believe him, for this is a man for whom anti-authoritarianism is as natural as dreaming and twinkling and flirting. He spoke at one stage of his joy as his postwar generation erupted on to the stage and television, the untrained working-class oiks who loved acting so much they were willing to put up with any amount of death-rattle sneers from the middle-class establishment. 'After the war, we just thought, we've made it! We're alive, and we're not just going to do what you tell us any more!' I suspect any genuine party attempt to silence him would have the opposite effect. No, he says, Alastair hasn't had a word. 'Saw him recently; told him he was doing a bloody good acting job on that Rory Bremner thing.' The reaction? 'He laughed. Well, he laughed for Alastair, which means he told me to fuck off.'

Rather, the strong impression is that his reticence is based on respect for Cherie, about whom he will say absolutely nothing, and, by extension, her husband.

Already, over the years, his anger at disability benefits and the treatment of unions has been recorded, but he won't even rehash those thanks to fear of the constantly lurking chopsticks, other than saying: 'I think everything will change in the second term. He's a good man. At heart, Blair's a good man.'

If he feels he owes Cherie, he's probably right. Stephenie, whom he met at a party, is his fourth wife (and he her fifth husband). He left Cherie's mother, sometime actress Gale Smith, for producer Julie Allan, by whom he had two more daughters. Then came Sixties model Pamela 'Suzie' Smith, mother of Lauren and Emma, and, incidentally, the end of his drinking, when he almost died after she locked him out one night; the attempt to climb in via unsteady paraffin drums meant months in hospital with vicious burns. He lived, and hit the wagon. Then there was the affair with Coronation Street 's Pat Phoenix, whom he married a week before her death.

He doesn't talk easily about those times, for he sees himself, or likes to portray himself, as a changed man, mellowed and careful. There are flashes of old: the asides, the stories about nights with Sean Connery that leave him creased with laughter. And the drive behind it all wasn't just to be naughty: he was, he says, genuinely part of a time when the British working class grew to learn they had brains and talent and dreams, and the world seemed their oyster.

'My father had had a bad accident at Cunard's. He broke his back, leg, arm, pelvis and skull. He should have died; my mother wouldn't let him. So I went to work, dull work, but I was also involved in am dram. And I remember learning from one guy that he was earning £8 a week in rep. £8! Beautiful! For doing something you enjoyed! That was me started.'

He wished he'd done more, of course, and accepts that, for all the fun he had as the Scouse git in Till Death Us Do Part and various cheeky-Lothario parts, he was, in the end, typecast. Gone are the simple days of 1992 when Tony Booth, father-in-law to the next but one leader of the Labour Party, had little reason to hold back and fought with righteous anger. Days when he told the party leadership, as he recalls now, with a wheezily infectious laugh, that Thatcher should be first against the wall. 'Well, no, not quite,' he guffaws again, eyes vanishing into the folds of a life roundly lived, 'but I did tell them that what we must do, if we won, was take back all the privatised utilities at the same knock-down prices they were sold off by the Tories. It was a bloody crime. And then, I said, we should take Thatcher to court for what she'd done.' Fine, I say, gazing levelly back through the chopsticks of Manchester's Chinatown; and what was the precise problem with that? No punishment quite meet enough, I supposed; but no, his raised eyebrows and his silence tell me, I'm missing the point. Which is simple: this was 10 years ago. 1992. Before Tony Blair, married to Booth's daughter Cherie, swooned into power, declared that the battle between Right and Left was dead, and within that very first week invited the same Margaret Thatcher for tea, a fact of which I now remind the other Tony in order to make him choke on his dim sum. He copes admirably. A nervous swallow, and then, 'Yes, yes, he did, didn't he? Hmmm. I suppose he was trying to be conciliatory. It, um, it didn't quite come off, did it?' 1992. Rather, the strong impression is that his reticence is based on respect for Cherie, about whom he will say absolutely nothing, and, by extension, her husband. Already, over the years, his anger at disability benefits and the treatment of unions has been recorded, but he won't even rehash those thanks to fear of the constantly lurking chopsticks, other than saying: 'I think everything will change in the second term. He's a good man. At heart, Blair's a good man.' If he feels he owes Cherie, he's probably right. Stephenie, whom he met at a party, is his fourth wife (and he her fifth husband). webTitle: It's my party and I'll cry if I want to... (part two)

fields.headline: It's my party and I'll cry if I want to... (part two)
fields.standfirst: Politics is all about popularity. So what does an MP do when the public no longer wants them? Here, some of the last election's losers relive the tears and the tantrums
fields.trailText: Lord Lamont, Gyles Brandreth,  Liz Lynne and Derek Conway.
fields.body:
Lord Lamont
Then MP for Harrogate and Knaresborough. Elected 1972
Now Company director

Over tea in the Lords, where egg sandwiches are subsidised down to 90p, Norman Lamont admitted that he knew defeat was inevitable at least a year before the election. When the polls were predicting a 100-seat Labour majority, he ran into a pollster who doubted his own findings. 'I bet him £100 he was right.' Lord Lamont took a sip of his milkless Indian tea and smiled - a more engaging sight than you might imagine.

But when did he know he was going to lose Harrogate, turning a 9,000 majority into a Lib-Dem one of 6,000? 'Fortunately, only three days before.' He arranged for a friend to make 'secret calls'. This deception revealed, he explained, the extent of the local alliance between the Liberals and Labour - whose vote actually went down. 'I'm a fairly fatalistic individual. I knew defeat was a possibility. And that confirmed it. I didn't have much time to reflect. I'd been through difficult times in the years before. It just seemed one more thing.'

Things like the Miss Whiplash scandal. Things like being the chancellor who presided over Britain's departure from the ERM. Things like being dumped by Major. Things like watching Ken Clarke's chancellorship reap the plaudits that could have been his.

'I never took defeat personally, even though I had a bigger than average swing against me. For Portillo, though, I think it was a personal thing.' There was no letter of condolence at all from Major. There were, though, phone calls from both Thatcher and Hague.

'I didn't feel tremendous emotion at the moment of defeat. I felt sad, but not in a crushed way. Apart from anything else, I knew I'd come back here.' A slight gesture of the hand, almost but not quite a wave, indicating the Lords. 'If I'm not abroad on business I come here most days. It provides an element of continuity.' He does believe, though, that there should be a 'part-elected element' to the red-carpeted House.

He is now a director of five companies and consultant to two others, with an office in Park Lane. He lectures, he writes, he runs a think-tank, he travels: Poland the week before we spoke, the US the following day. He's learned to use a computer - well, he can surf the web for research; he still can't type or do spreadsheets. He's struck up an unlikely friendship with Agriculture Minister Nick Brown - they would have been paired in this parliament.

He's bought loads of CDs. 'I might become a Wagner fan. I want to go to Bayreuth.' He's thinking of learning Spanish, perhaps inspired by his campaign for few people's favourite Chilean, General Pinochet. 'It was unpopular but it provided a lot of interest for me.'

What does he miss? 'The bustle, the excitement, the rudeness. This place is very quiet. I also rather wish I had constituents. Mail from them directs you. Not having it is like being without a compass.'

A pause, a sip of his milkless tea. 'The fact that I make that remark shows I'm still interested in politics. I'm what you call a junkie.' Another sip, another smile.

Gyles Brandreth
Then MP for City of Chester. Elected 1992
Now Journalist

Gyles Brandreth saw it coming the way you see a truck coming. 'My defeat was no shock. I was in a marginal seat. I knew for a year before the election that I'd lose. I was resigned to it. You shouldn't take defeat personally, but you do. You know that the same tide that has swept out complete drunks and utter incompetents has also done for you, a good constituency MP.'

So certain was the loss of his Chester seat that, well before the election, Conservative central office offered to find him another, safer one. Loyalty, he says, is what kept him from switching. That and a feeling that he'd be thought chicken. Not an anxiety you would have thought to trouble a man who has appeared on our television screens in some of history's most idiosyncratic fully fashioned knitwear.

His wife was 'delighted' by the prospect of his defeat. As you would be when your husband has spent several years working 7.15am to midnight. 'That's a whip's life. Not much of a life, but a complete life.'

He lived with the knowledge of impending disaster for month after month - while not being able to do anything about it. 'You can't be seen to be looking for a job.' He spent election day living 'a charade', still talking up his chances to anyone who'd listen, knowing he didn't stand a prayer.

'English people are very pleasant. They say they'll vote for you even if they have no intention of doing so.'

His wife was more realistic. She booked them a holiday in Sicily. 'It turned out to be one of the best of my life.' She also wanted to put their constituency house on the market before election day. He managed to dissuade her, briefly. 'But still, the result came at 2am, and by 10am she was at the estate agent's.'

By the time he got back to his London base, there was already a letter on the mat, asking him to return his pass. 'That was harsh.' He was, however, allowed to keep his ministerial box. 'That's now in my Teddy Bear Museum in Stratford.' Tony Blair's old teddy, Lynton, sits on top of it. He returns to the House of Commons, occasionally, but doesn't feel completely comfortable. The first trip, in particular, was 'unnerving'.

Life has changed in the obvious ways, bringing more time with the family and more money, probably. It also brought a possibly unexpected sense of freedom.

'I don't miss having to be on my best behaviour at all times, having to watch what I say. If I'm asked to open a fete, I can turn it down. As an MP I only seemed to meet two kinds of people: those who had problems, and those who thought they knew the answer to everything.'

What does he miss? Power: 'In the whips' office, you're not close to the centre. You are the centre.' The Palace of Westminster: 'The camaraderie of the club.' And, more than anything, the library: 'The far end, the European history section. It's the most beautiful spot overlooking the Thames. I shared a table with Mandelson.' His point was subtly clear: as they rise, so they fall.

Derek Conway
Then MP for Shrewsbury. Elected 1983
Now Chief executive of the Cats Protection League and Conservative candidate

Derek Conway grew up on a council estate, left school at 15, worked as a whip under Major, fell out with John Major and was, for a while, Vice Chamberlain to Her Majesty's Household. Every day, in formal dress, with a 5ft wand in hand, he'd give the Queen a briefing on what her parliament was up to. Not the stuff she could read in the paper, but the real skinny. 'Who's sleeping with who, who's going bankrupt.'

We talked over a pint in the Swiss restaurant, right beneath the Department of the Environment. The first thing I noticed about him was his pink socks. Next I spotted his brown suede loafers and dark pink trousers. Then I remembered his nickname - Bulldog.

He lost Shrewsbury by 1,670 votes. 'Before the count, I told my wife Colette that I was going down the tubes. But the first time I really knew I was going to lose was 9pm.

I just thought: bugger that. It's important not to get bitter. Even if you've been beaten by a Labour nerd with no idea where London is, let alone the House of Commons. If Labour had thought they were going to win my seat, they would have put someone better in. That unreasonableness did hurt.

'The electorate was right to punish us, but it was a bit excessive. OK, you chastise a child, but you don't beat it senseless.

That was just plain cruelty. Still, we did work pretty hard at losing that election.'

The outer strength just about contains inner hurts. 'My wife found it harder. It was a test on our marriage, but Colette's a strong girl.' She is still angry that her husband didn't get the knighthood he was promised. 'I was on the first two lists, then taken off the third,' he shrugged.

'I hadn't had to do a CV for 23 years.

And unfortunately the Queen doesn't give references. A whips job offers the ideal experience for becoming a blackmailer, but there's not much call.' Initially, he was a 'public affairs consultant' - what you and I call a lobbyist. 'But I wasn't used to the freelance mentality. I wanted a proper job with a salary.' So when a headhunter came calling, in October 1997, he was interested in what was being offered - chief executive of the Cats Protection League.

But, like a heroin addict getting by on methadone, he still hankered after the real thing. 'I wasn't sure about going back into politics. My wife certainly wasn't sure. But it's in my blood.' When asked to apply for Alan Clark's Chelsea seat, he declined at first. 'I'm not natural Chelsea stuff.' Then he changed his mind and 'thoroughly enjoyed' himself. 'Maybe it would have been stressful if I thought I could actually win.' Energised, he secured the nomination for Ted Heath's supersafe Bexley seat. 'It was the fit I was looking for.'

The Bulldog is on his way back.

Liz Lynne
Then MP for Rochdale. Elected 1992
Now MEP

Liz Lynne, everyone will tell you, is the LibDem woman who cried when she lost her Rochdale seat. 'I didn't,' says the former actress and voice coach to Paddy Ashdown. 'It was a member of my local association who burst into tears. I was comforting her.'

It could well have been Liz who was crying, though. She'd had just an hour and a half's warning of her defeat. She was eating fish and chips with Liberal giant Cyril Smith when a phone call from her agent brought the bad news. 'You're joking,' she said. 'I'm not,' he replied. 'I think you've lost by 4,000.' In a 'state of shock', she called her mother, who started sobbing. 'I was devastated. At the count, I told my agent not to touch me because I would cry.' Her emotional waters did finally break, though. What set her off was her neighbours' daughter who handed her a posy and said, 'Sorry.' It took a long time for the tears to stop.

She admits she was angry. She found herself asking: are the voters crazy? 'I was shocked they got rid of me.' Her former electors came up to her in Tesco and told her it was nothing personal. 'I'd lost something I loved. I went through all the different stages of mourning: non-comprehension, anger, worthlessness, the lot.'

This lasted at least eight months. 'Even by Christmas I wasn't sure what I wanted to do with my life.' She tried to get a job as a TV presenter, but it didn't work out. She thought of working for charities. Money was tight. She was unemployed for two years. 'I lived on my savings. Cyril encouraged me to sign on.' At the DHSS, that is. 'But I wouldn't do it.'

Eventually, she cast her mind back to when she was 11, 'setting out to change the world. How can I do that now, I thought.' Her answer was to stand as an MEP. Life is now split by a half-hour flight: Monday to Thursday in Brussels or Strasbourg, Friday to Sunday at her home base just north of Evesham.

What does she miss? 'Constituency case work.' What doesn't she miss? 'I can't think of anything. I've moved on.'

What doesn't she miss? 'I can't think of anything. I've moved on.'

webTitle: It's my party and I'll cry if I want to...

fields.headline: It's my party and I'll cry if I want to...
fields.standfirst: Politics is all about popularity. So what does an MP do when the public no longer wants them? Here, some of the last election's losers relive the tears and the tantrums
fields.trailText: Politics is all about popularity. So what does an MP do when the public no longer wants them? Here, Sir Malcolm Rifkind, Phillip Oppenheim, Gerry Malone and Michael Brown, some of the last election's losers, relive the tears and the tantrums.
fields.body:
I've been sacked and I've been dumped. But never in a town hall, in front of friends, family, supporters, enemies, journalists and television cameras. I'm not sure I could handle such public rejection. I'm not sure many of us could.

But that is how beaten MPs must face defeat. And 1997 wasn't just an ordinary defeat, it was a massacre. We dumped 132 MPs, of whom 126 were Conservatives and seven were cabinet ministers - a modern record. 'Gobsmacking is the word,' said Sir Graham Bright, then Tory vice-chairman, whose 28,000 personalised letters to his constituents didn't stop him losing Luton South. John Major rang Bright at 7am on the day of the election and asked him to tell him the truth. Bright told him that they'd lose by 60 to 70 seats. 'If only we had. What hit everybody was the scale of the defeat.'

As a US politician said: 'The people have spoken. The bastards.'

So what happens next? What do you do with an ex-MP? Some of those who lost in 1997 have remained public figures. One has died, one has had a major stroke. A few have become Lords. Some are standing again. Many have retired - or taken early, face-saving retirement.

Surprisingly, of all those approached about their defeat, only one declined to talk. Stand up, former Scottish Secretary Michael Forsyth, doing very well in the City but probably under some pressure since JP Morgan swallowed the merchant bank at which he is vice chairman, Investment Banking, Europe.

No one seems to have trodden in the steps of Labour MP Alf Dubbs, who signed on the dole the first Monday after his 1987 defeat. Some have taken the opportunity to smell the roses - as former Derby North MP Greg Knight put it. Many more, though, have had to wake up and smell the coffee.

Sir Malcolm Rifkind
Then MP for Edinburgh Pentlands. Elected 1974
Now Business consultant and Conservative candidate

Sir Malcolm Rifkind had been there since the start. He was a minister when the great Tory adventure began in 1979, and he was still a minister when it finished. 'I and three of my colleagues were the longest-serving ministers since Palmerston,' he said in that lawyerly way of his. There have always been two Rifkinds. The Rifkind who left a message on my answerphone one Sunday morning - sonorous, pompous even, the man you know from his Newsnight appearances. And the one I talked to - witty, intelligent, cosmopolitan. This is the Rifkind who managed to outlast a leader who hated him. 'We were never soul mates,' he said urbanely of Baroness Thatcher.

This is also the Rifkind who is again being talked about, within the Tory party, as a potential future leader. The suggestion is that he would take over in the aftermath of the title fight between Hague and Portillo from which both will - inevitably - emerge mortally wounded.

First, though, he has to get back into parliament. He's standing again for Edinburgh Pentlands, which he lost in 1997. 'My seat was never safe. Some of my colleagues in the Home Counties had bigger majorities than my total vote. The gap didn't narrow as the campaign went on. I was a potential victim, to put it mildly.' The wry, Scottish-Jewish Rifkind then gave way to the lawyerly one, with a delicately balanced double negative. 'I was not not upset, though.' The urbane, subtle one returned. 'Being a Scots Tory requires certain personality traits. And if you don't have them when you start, you certainly acquire them over the years.'

He works as a consultant, mostly with oil companies with links to the Middle East. 'Even when working hard, it's different to being a minister. Last week I was in Romania. As a minister, it would have been wall-to-wall meetings. Instead, it was two meetings, a leisurely lunch and a free evening. The downside is that I believe we all work better under pressure.'

The other reason he opted for the freelance life, of course, was because it left him free to re-enter the game. Why go back? 'There's no known cure,' he laughed.

Phillip Oppenheim
Then MP for Amber Valley. Elected 1983
Now Bar owner

'Sheer capitalism,' explained Phillip Oppenheim when I asked the ex-Tory MP about the two AK-47s on his walls and the picture of Che Guevara in his toilet.

Such is the decor of Cubana, the Cuban bar he owns and runs. It sits, very brightly, on a corner by the tradesman's entrance to Waterloo station, about a 10 minutes' walk from the House where Oppenheim sat till he lost his Amber Valley seat. He describes its style as 'post-Communist grunge' - laughingly but seriously.

As we sat drinking mojitos - the national rum, mint and sugar cocktail of Communism's only sun-kissed paradise - we were joined by another ex-Tory MP, Tony Coombs, a major investor in Cubana. His thoughts on the irony of a Thatcherite Tory running a Cuban-themed bar filled with Marxist revolutionary bric-a-bric? 'Business is business is business.'

Oppenheim said he knew his party was heading for defeat as early as 1992. 'We'd lost credibility.' But he only realised he'd lose his own seat in the last weekend of the campaign. 'I was a bit thick.'

For Oppenheim, the 1997 election was a light-hearted affair. 'We didn't think about defeat much. It was a fun campaign. You try to be gracious. The Labour lot made an effort not to be nasty. You don't bust a gut. We did lots of pub quizzes. We hoped against hope that something would happen, but it didn't. It was like saying goodbye to an old dog - a pleasant campaign.'

The moment of defeat? 'I was young when I won in 1983, and it was a burden of responsibility. Defeat in 1997 was like having a weight taken off my shoulders. From a career point of view, it would have been better to have lost in 1992. The upside was that I was Ken Clarke's PPS.' In a 'very depressing' government, he also spent time in Michael Portillo's department. 'I always hated him before, thought he was a smug git, but working with him was a pleasant surprise.' His time in Ann Widdecombe's department was less pleasant. 'She'd literally slap my wrists after meetings.'

In 1992, when he thought he'd lose his seat, he laid plans to go into the sushi business. By the time he really did lose, he still fancied the restaurant business but sushi was everywhere. So he needed a new trick. He found it on a trip to Cuba and opened the bar a year after the elect- ion, with 'freshly made juices, free-range chicken, old-style Cajun cooking and premium spirits'. A second opened last month. There are plans for a chain. 'We've just got to cruising altitude.'

Still, how does he square the circle between Conservatism in his heart and Cuban guerrilla chic in his bar? 'I have no sympathy for Castro. He's only interested in power for power's sake. But Che had ideals. He was a doctor who'd travelled around on his motorbike and worked with lepers. It's true that later he became a brutal zealot, but he was never a political hack.'

And he met more than a few of those in his own party. 'It was always the po-faced guys who rose to the top,' he said, still surprisingly hurt after all these years. For him, politics is almost certainly in the past. He was asked to stand again but declined the offer. 'If it gets more liberal, I might be interested. If Ann Widdecombe ever became leader, I'd vote New Labour.'

Gerry Malone
Then MP for Winchester. Elected 1992
Now Non-executive company director

Gerry Malone lost Winchester by just two votes after two recounts. Then he lost it again a few months later in a rerun election - by 21,556. Politics is a tough game, of course. But it's an even tougher game than you may think. Another Conservative politico claimed to me - almost proudly - that he knew, personally, the two voters who'd swung Gerry Malone's seat by switching to the Lib Dems. Nor did he blame them: he'd have done the same if Gerry Malone had been his MP.

People don't like Gerry Malone much. He's seen as arrogant, unclubbable. 'I had few friends in politics and it remains so.' He's a pal of Andrew Neil's. John Major's, too. He's a left-winger in a party now run by rightbacks. He's a Scotsman living in London. He speaks with Caledonian certainty, and rectitude, in a world debased - or blessed - by the art of compromise. Unlike other ex-MPs, he doesn't miss 'the House', but he does miss power. He genuinely adored being a minister in the Department of Health and still talks with great passion about it.

How did it feel being dumped by the electorate? 'A nightmare. I felt like the victim of a road traffic accident.' As he engagingly admits, losing was no little achievement. Over the two elections, he managed to convert a Tory marginal into the safest Lib Dem seat in the land. 'Probably in recorded history,' he added. 'I certainly didn't expect the scale of the defeat. And I couldn't claim a 21,000 majority was a result of the weather.'

At the count, he was calm to the world, but his private self was already doing the maths. 'What's my resettlement allowance?' he was asking himself. 'Divide that by my monthly mortgage. Works out at six months to put it right.' As he prides himself in doing, he was dealing with 'the practicalities'.

'Anyone who's not practical will founder. Survival is the first thing. Nor did I burst into tears in private. My wife Anne and I never had a discussion about it. There are some things you don't discuss.'

Was there self-doubt? 'Yes.' Disappointment? 'There must be a degree of disappointment when 20 years of work dissolves into dust.' Pain? 'My wife is a consultant anaesthetist and I felt like imbibing some of her products at points.'

To pay the mortgage, the school fees and music tuition bills, he returned to journalism for 12 months, working on the ill-fated European with his friend Andrew Neil. An 'odd interlude' is his polite turn of phrase for a period that involved a chilling dunk in controversy over an altercation with a female journalist. Then he turned to the health business, making understandable use of the knowledge and contacts he'd built up as minister - something the rules barred him from doing for two years. He now has a non-executive role in several companies, including Regent GM Laboratories, Ultrasis and Chiltern Invodex.

They don't employ him because they like his suits or his soft Edinburgh accent, of course. 'Practical crossover from my ministerial job,' is how he puts it. Also: 'One's income is considerably in excess of what it was. To replace the zing of politics is difficult, though.'

How involved is he now? 'I support my local party by going to the odd function.' No canvassing, though. 'Life has moved on.'

Michael Brown
Then MP for Cleethorpes. Elected 1979
Now Journalist

It was over lunch at the Reform Club that number 481 in The Pink Paper's Top 500 lesbian and gay heroes, former Tory whip Michael Brown, talked about being dumped by his Cleethorpes constituents.

He chose the venue. The Reform is a deeply political place. Michael Brown is a deeply political man.

When he spotted Labour Transport Minister Lord MacDonald in the club's grand central hall, his childish delight was infectious. Later, he had a chat with Sir Alan Peacock, his old economics professor. All that, a good lunch and a brace of G&Ts: Mr Michael Brown, a left-handed right-winger who was outed by the News of the World in 1994 some years after he'd outed himself - was having a very good day. For him, politics is what water is to fish: pretty much everything.

A secondary-school boy driven by his 11-plus failure, he wanted to be a Tory MP from the age of 16. His only civilian job was as a graduate trainee for Barclays. 'I hated it every day.' A job as a Conservative Party researcher led to a shot at the very marginal seat of Cleethorpes and an unexpected win in the 1983 landslide. He was 27. 'I was one of Thatcher's kids.' He turns 50 this July.

When did he know he was going to lose? 'My bank manager tells me it was 1992. He noticed that I became more financially responsible. Personally, I knew from 1993. We fell out of the ERM and I was notified of boundary changes in my seat.' He stopped buying 'new cars, etc', and by the election had paid his debts. The bright sunny day of the election was 'unreal', he recalled. 'It hit you that you were utterly down the toilet. People's glances never met yours. But I can say there was no shock. It was a release. I'd been in an awful government, waiting for the Sword of Damocles. You know you're going to die. You just want the bloody thing to happen. If there was an emptiness, it came two weeks later at the state opening of parliament. That was my wake-up moment.'

Then came the sympathy letters. Thatcher wrote the next day. 'A personal note.' There was also a hand-written one from Ann Widdecombe. 'Her views are loopy, but we have a friendship. Of all the letters, hers was the most genuine and decent.' Finally, two months later, came a note from Major. 'Pro forma, computer-generated.' Brown's eyebrows arched upwards in distaste at the lack of courtesy.

An endowment mortgage of £32,000 matured during the campaign. 'So, with my redundancy payment, I had a cushion of £50,000. It prevented me panicking. But I did fear that it would have to last me till I was selling the Big Issue.'

His constituency house was up for sale within 24 hours - though it didn't sell for nine months. 'I was bleeding £1,500 for the mortgage every four weeks. I was terrified. The really horrible bit came in late May.

I thought I didn't have a friend in the world.' He had no kids or family to support - or to support him. 'Just my boyfriend's shoulder.' Like other dumped Tories, he had to tell himself what he'd told 20,000 redundant steelworkers - you're on your own now, mate. 'It was not a pleasant place to be. I'd never done a proper job before. I had a stack of cash, but not a clue what I was going to do.'

For a while, like other dumped Tories, he worked for former MP David Evans' contract cleaning firm - not scrubbing, of course, but drumming up business. 'I wouldn't say I was a great success.' Eventually, at the time of the 1998 local elections, a piece of writing led him to political journalism. After 18 years in the House, he now taunts Hague from the pages of the Independent. He still worries that it will all go wrong, that he'll collapse into penury. But he clearly loves the life he lives. 'If you offered me a safe seat, I wouldn't go back. If I were a backbench MP, I'd have no influence at all. People read my opinions. Alastair Campbell's courteous to me now. I'll not work for the Conservative Party again.'

Defeat has also, indirectly, cost him a friendship. He was a good friend of Portillo's, a very good friend. They went on holiday together, more than once, both with and without Portillo's wife. Portillo led the openly gay Brown to believe he was as straight as a Roman road. When Portillo swanned out of the closet in an interview, Brown was profoundly hurt. 'I'd always bought the line he sold me about the rumours.' They are no longer friends. 'He's cut me off.' Brown takes his revenge at press conferences, barking out questions like: Portillo, don't you think your policies are crap? 'I love that.'

webTitle: Chicken tikka time bomb

fields.headline: Chicken tikka time bomb
fields.standfirst:
Rebel Tories, and a nicely timed speech about curry, have put the explosive issue of race on top of the election agenda

Race in Britain - Observer special
fields.trailText: When a smiling William Hague shook hands with Gurbux Singh in his wood-panelled parliamentary office on the eve of Valentine's Day, neither man could have imagined the trouble that would follow.
fields.byline: Gaby Hinsliff, Kamal Ahmed and Martin Bright
fields.body:
When a smiling William Hague shook hands with Gurbux Singh in his wood-panelled parliamentary office on the eve of Valentine's Day, neither man could have imagined the trouble that would follow.

The purpose of the meeting was to arrange the signing of a Commission for Racial Equality pledge by all the party leaders not to play the race card during the election. Singh, the chairman of the CRE, arrived with Robin Bannerji, his press spokesman. Hague was accompanied by chief of staff Sebastian Coe and Tory vice-chairman Tim Collins. Over coffee and biscuits they discussed the 'compact' on the table in front of them.

Hague said he agreed 'with the princi ples'. Singh said it would be important that other MPs should be invited to sign up. Hague agreed, was shown the document and requested no changes.

After less than an hour of polite discussion, Singh and Bannerji left the meeting. They were happy. And Hague was happy.

But unknown to the five who gathered in Hague's office, they had just lit a fuse. It was connected to the incendiary issue of race which is suddenly at the centre of the political debate in Britain. Both Labour and the Tories have been engulfed: Michael Portillo has said he will not sign the CRE document, Robin Cook has spoken of Britain's chicken tikka massala culture.

Long lists of prospective parliamentary candidates' thoughts on asylum and immigration have peppered the papers. Tory MPs have been queueing up to denounce the CRE as a jumped-up organisation which is engaged in a McCarthyite witch hunt to root out 'racists'. And suddenly race, the most delicate of issues, is being batted about in the foghorn language of party political war just over a month away from a general election.

In the cold sunshine of an early spring day, Harrogate waited for the hordes to arrive. It was March, and Hague was about to give his keynote speech to the conference, ostensibly about Europe.

'Let me take you on a journey to a foreign land - to Britain after a second term of Tony Blair,' Hague told delegates. The 'foreign land' line had been hastily concocted by speechwriter George Osborne and press secretary Nick Wood to feed journalists in advance, and wasn't even linked to a later passage on asylum seekers.

But it became the leitmotif. Critics said Hague was suggesting that Britain was in danger of becoming a foreign land because of immigration. Hague insisted he was only talking about Europe. Many didn't believe him.

Then, from the right-wing fringes of the Tory party, came John Townend and his views on preserving Anglo-Saxon culture. Townend had told a local party meeting: 'Our homogenous Anglo-Saxon society has been seriously undermined by the massive immigration - particularly Commonwealth immigration - that has taken place since the war. Illegal immigrants have got a new ploy. They call themselves asylum-seekers. In my view the only way to deal with the problem is to send them back quickly.'

That brought the row right to the door of Central Office, raising questions over how far its MPs were under its control. Hague is now locked in bitter recriminations, not just with the CRE - which his camp accuses of changing the goalposts on the deal, accusations emphatically denied - but with some of his own colleagues. His leadership is in question once again.

'I think the co-location of "foreign land" and stuff about asylum-seekers in the same speech is seen by most people as a mistake,' said one shadow cabinet Minister. 'And I think those responsible for the speech would agree with the benefit of hindsight.'

But the real fear now gripping thoughtful Tories is not that the party has foolishly let itself be portrayed as racist, but that the leader's inner circle may not care how it looks if the voters and the right-wing press are happy. 'The awful thing is that some of these people around Hague probably think this is playing well for us,' said one Tory veteran.

'And the sadness for me is that a lot of this is absolutely playing to what some people undoubtedly think. Why did he not withdraw the whip from Townend? Because he was worried that too many potential Tory voters would say "but I agreed with him".'

But if it was the Right that led Hague into trouble, ironically it is the liberal wing of the party that is working hardest to get him off the hook. The first decisive intervention was the pro-European backbencher John Gummer's attack on the 'unconstitutional' CRE pledge on Friday morning. The second was the tireless trawling of TV studios by two instinctive liberals on race issues, party chairman Michael Ancram and his deputy Steve Norris, arguing that because Hague had signed on behalf of the party, ordinary MPs didn't have to.

And the third was Michael Portillo, the Shadow Chancellor, declaring on a visit to Cardiff: 'I don't think we should be drawn into committing ourselves to sign up to every apparently well-intentioned declaration.' The headlines howled of another split: Hague had signed, but Portillo wouldn't. Surely a shameless bid to woo the Right? But what Portillo was actually doing was giving covering fire to his good friend Norris and to Ancram. Powerless to make the three CRE refuseniks - Townend, James Cran and Eric Forth - actually sign, the party was trying the Spartacus defence instead, insisting that almost everyone was a rebel, too. Even Ann Widdecombe, who has signed the pledge, issued a statement suggesting that she disapproved of the exercise.

But the farce at Central Office is only one part of the question. Another is whether the CRE could have erred tactically in organising its campaign. And a third is whether Labour's staunch response - from Robin Cook's 'chicken tikka massala' theory of the benefits of multiculturalism to the streetfighting Minister Ian McCartney - is entirely without risk.

When the nation's billboards were suddenly stripped of a Tory poster depicting a young black man and his son under the slogan 'You've paid the taxes so where are all the teachers?' - to be replaced by a poster starring a white-looking man - Millbank apparatchiks scented blood.

Surely, they thought, the poster was dumped because the Tories were afraid to use blacks. This was the line Labour spin doctors suggested to journalists. But there was only one problem: they were wrong.

The poster was actually pulped after complaints by the man's ex-wife about the use of their son: and the new model was actually of non-British origin. It seems that playing the anti-racist card can also backfire.

Robin Cook has genuinely strong per sonal feelings about racism. So in the political limbo caused by the delayed election, one idea dusted off to keep the restless Foreign Secretary busy was a speech on multiculturalism.

His aide David Clark had spotted before Christmas a survey saying that chicken tikka massala was now the nation's favourite dish, For Clark, the idea of the Indian tikka mixed with an inauthentic massala sauce to satisfy Britons' love of gravy was a useful metaphor.

But then, on the eve of the speech, newspapers began reporting Townend's refusal to sign the CRE compact. Clark was hastily summoned to add more lines recalling Ancram's warning to Tories not to overstep the mark.

'Coming to terms with multiculturalism as a positive force for our economy and society will have significant implications for our understanding of Britishness,' Cook concluded. It was misreading history to believe otherwise.

The Daily Mail howled its outrage at his suggestion that there was no such thing as a 'British' race, in a story that helped convince Conservative Central Office that its cause against the CRE might not be so unpopular. But as far as Labour was concerned, it had worked. The rest of the press gobbled up the curry metaphor, and when Cook arrived for a lunch at the Mirror newspaper's east London offices on Thursday, he was offered a plate of chicken tikka massala.

'The Tories have a real problem with race,' said one leading Labour campaign manager. 'They twist one way and the other, trying to satisfy the superficial need to appear non-racist while stoking up their core support. It is a good issue for us.'

Party officials, however, will bear in mind the Metropolitan Police's findings, revealed today by The Observer, that provocative speeches on immigration can trigger hate crime.

Critics will say that the Government's own record on asylum issues and race is far from impressive. Just two of the 12 new ethnic minority candidates standing in the forthcoming election will do so in a winnable seat. 'We might be paying lip service to the issue but in fact we are going backwards,' said Diane Abbott, the black Labour MP and veteran campaigner. 'If you look at the 1980s there were more black and Asian Labour candidates and more black and Asian Labour councillors.'

It is all a far cry from the autumn of 1997, when Tony Blair - still basking in the warmth of victory - told the Labour party conference in Brighton that he wanted to be a beacon of meritocracy to the world. 'Not one black High Court judge, not one black Chief Constable or Permanent Secretary, not one black army officer above the rank of Colonel. Not one Asian either,' he said. 'Not a record of pride for the British establishment. And not a record of pride for Parliament that there are so few black and Asian MPs.'

Little has changed since then, in Westminster at least, and there are calls on the ground for less fine talk and more action. The number of ethnic minority MPs will probably only rise by one in June. The Foreign Office still boasts no black ambassadors. Abbott points out that Labour's Millbank HQ itself boasts 'rows and rows of young white people and very few black and Asian faces'.

A letter dropped onto William Hague's desk a week after the signing of the CRE compact on 14 March. The CRE 'did not intend to police the signing of the compact by individual MPs or candidates', it said, but it wanted to know which ones supported the pledge. Could Hague encourage his MPs to sign?

Hague's response was noncommittal, enclosing a copy of party chairman Ancram's letter to all candidates reminding them to watch their language and warning that candidates 'may also be invited to sign the compact in their own constituencies'.

Hague's closest aides are adamant that they had an understanding from the CRE that individual MPs would not be singled out for refusing to sign the compact. Although it had been used in 1997, it was just the party leaders who had signed up then. Expecting all MPs to adhere to the document had been seen as too officious.

'We were taken aback to find the names of MPs who have refused to sign appearing in newspapers,' said one senior source last week. 'That was not the terms of the agreement.'

The CRE only gave a few hours' notice on Thursday that it was posting results on its website. But the organisation - backed by the Liberal Democrats - is adamant that it was obvious from the start that the signatures would be publicised. 'We had never said this was going to be a closed process,' said a spokesman. 'If people asked for the figures, were we really going to say, no, it's confidential? That would have been ridiculous.'

Either way, the row looks unlikely to go away. Labour is compiling a list of statements made by Tory candidates such as Michael White, fighting the safe Labour seat of Dagenham, who accused Labour of 'importing foreign nurses with HIV' to scare people off waiting lists. The prospect of more bad publicity depresses the silent but sizeable rump of the Tory party, desperate not to be tarred with the extremist brush.

One disgruntled liberal said: 'What I cannot deny is that there are two Tory parties, one of them including people like Michael Ancram and Steve Norris and me, who hate being accused of racism, and another party - smaller in numbers - but Nick Wood and others think this is the agenda we want to play. There is a decent Tory party and it is struggling to get out.'
